description:
Ever since I saw Chris Cosentino on Top Chef, fell in love with everything offal, and moved to SF, Cockscomb has been on my list of must-try places. I FINALLY got to go, and it did not disappoint!! 

The pig's head is THE REASON to go to Cockscomb. It's a half pig's head with everything still there --yes even eyes, pieces of brain, snout -- and super crispy skin on top. The meat underneath is just incredibly tender, juicy, and flavorful. Even the beans and cabbage on the side was super tasty.

The tombo crudo (fresh & light compared to the heaviness of everything else) and beef heart were some other faves. And that's probably the best gnocchi I've ever had. The smoked XO sauce with the clams was packed with umami, and the foie gras with trotters was rich and decadent. 

TBH, there were two things I would have skipped -- the crispy pig ears (that were served with the pig's head) and the trucker's corn. 

We WAY over ordered, so I had the bacon chop for dinner the next night. Still delicious and perfectly seared, even reheated in the oven. 

Recs for 2-3 people (well if you can eat a lot!): "hot mess," tombo crudo, beef heart tartare, pig's head, gnocchi. It's going to be rich, but delicious!! I can't wait to go back! 

A list of everything we tried:
The Hot Mess Special (foie gras + trotters)
Tombo Crudo
Gnocchi
Trucker's Corn
Clams & Smoked XO Sauce
Wood Oven Roasted Pig's Head
Beef Heart Tartare
CC Charcuterie
Bacon Chop
Chocolate Mousse
author: Rebecca S.

description:
Cockscomb has been on my bookmark radar for quite some time now, but I've just never made much of an attempt to go. Was I missing out big time? No, not really. Was it good food though? Yes, it was.

Attention to detail and quality sourcing is an undeniable fact at Cockscomb so you best be sure that you'll be paying a premium for many of these dishes. That being said, the level of service provided is second to none. Dishes were described with impeccable precision, glasses were regularly topped off, and waiters would even refold your napkin if you stepped away to use the restroom!

We began our meal with the Hot Mess which is grilled sourdough topped with braised trotters and seared foie gras. It is then drizzled with brown butter pork an jus and garnished with mission and kubota figs. This is easily one of the most decadent things I've had in my life, but it hit all the right notes. The sourdough crust, despite being soaked in an jus and fatty foie gras, still maintained a little bit of crispness. The braised pork trotters then added a little bit of meatiness. Buttery notes were met with the foie gras and also the soft braised pig skin. And the figs then provided some nice sweetness. I definitely could have used some actual bread to soak up the extra an jus/sauce though. This dish was also very popular - at least all 3 of our adjacent tables also tried this.

For our shared main, we went with the ribeye wagyu (14 oz) which comes accompanied by diver scallops (locally sourced), roasted baby onions, roasted butterball potatoes, and drizzled with a brown butter green pepper corn an jus. The wagyu was good, but not the best I've had. It was tender, but did not have the melt in your mouth feel that I've experienced with wagyu at Japanese restaurants. The scallops, on the other hand, were definitely one of the best I've had! They were perfectly seared and the peppercorn an jus was a delicious accompaniment for it. As for the sides, I liked the roasted baby onions - they were sweet and slightly carmelized, a perfect pairing with the steak. The potatoes were more hearty but I personally felt they were a hair bit undercooked, a little harder than I prefer.

We also added a side of brown butter gnocchi with fresh parm. They were delicious little pillows of potatoes served over browned butter....so what's not to love?

And to finish the meal off, we opted for the panna cotta. It was perfectly set and had the right consistency. It's pairing with fresh sliced strawberries and a reduced balsamic vinegar was also very good and not overwhelming, just acidic enough to cut an otherwise very creamy dessert. I've had a similar version before where the vinegar was not reduced nearly enough and it sucked so much, but Cockscomb version was on-point and one that I would opt for again and again!

Overall, Cockscomb is a great place to come if you want to try some unique plates and splurge a little.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
Came here one Saturday night and for some reasons all the food tasted salty. The pig's ear salad was not the right combination since the ears are fried and the others were some citrus, but they didn't mesh well with each other. Way too salty we had to send it back. Just stick with the pig's ear by itself is good. The cod over the giant beans was bland, need a little bit more flavors. 

We also ordered the pig's head to share. Though part of the pig's head was over roasted that one side was charred and we couldn't eat it. The Vietnamese salad that comes with the head was good. 

Overall the service was great!! That deserved a 5 stars! Everyone was nice and very attentive. I had a great time, but the food, not so much.
author: Lynnda T.

description:
This place is fantastic! On a Saturday night this place is hopping and has an energy that reminded us of NYC. 

We went here to celebrate and, with a reservation, were seated promptly. A cute celebration card was waiting for us when we sat down! After much deliberation (wagyu beef/scallops sounded so tempting!) we decided to get the classic pork chop, the "ham"burger (pork burger), and a side of brown butter gnocchi. I have to say that I thoroughly enjoyed my burger more than the pork chop, though both dishes were fantastic. 

For dessert, we got the berry cobbler, which came with delicious vanilla creme fraiche! Definitely recommmend!!!

Most of the parties around us were larger groups ordering the pin steak (4lbs if steak!) and pig face. Will definitely have to go in a larger group to try these dishes next time.
author: Michele L.

description:
Rating:3.5 stars

Came here for business dinner meeting and was seated immediately. Ordered the following:
Salmon belly special
Grilled cheese 
Crudo
Pin bone steak
Cauliflower
Fried potatoes 
Mushrooms
Escape from Alcatraz
48 sour
Dirty martini
Buttery Chardonnay
 
Everything was on point: food, quality, flavors, presentation, promptness and service. 
Taking out 1.5 stars for bathroom cleanliness and upkeep and maintenance of utilities. Toilet paper everywhere, rusty trash cans, cracked toilet seats. 
What a disappointment. If you're serving good quality food with a price tag of $$$, it is important that utilities are maintained and well kept. 
Checked off my bookmark! Will debate whether to come back here. No valet , only street parking. 
Trust!!!
author: Claudine V.

description:
Cockscomb has a good happy hour! The fishbowl (wine, gin, juice) is $30 during happy hour and meant for 4-5 people. We though 3 girls could take it on but nopeee. It's really worth the price! Get the potatoes! The seasoning was really good. We also got the pig ears which were overly crispy. 

The happy hour area is small and crowded so go early and don't expect to have your own private spot!
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
Pigs Head was delicious but heavy (definitely need to share)
Pin bone steak was still spot on

Overall Thoughts

Blissful overindulgence at its finest with no regrets!
author: Eddie W.

description:
Group dinners with co-workers can sometimes be tricky because you want to make sure everyone is happy with the cuisine, cocktails and ambiance. Anytime you go beyond the six person count for a meal, all hell breaks loose.

You don't want it to be too casual, or else it doesn't feel special. 
You don't want it to be too fancy, or else it breaks the bank.
You don't want it be too far away from the hotel, or else everyone complains about the long drive.
You don't want the restaurant to be too small, or else they can't handle a large party and you end up waiting three hours to eat.
You don't want the restaurant to be too large, or the quality of the food goes down and you may as well eat at a chain.
You don't want the food to be unimpressive, or else the group dinner is a total and complete failure.
You don't want it to be too much of "one thing," or else the vegans, the carnivores, the gluten-free and the pregnant women will revolt.
Boy, group dinners are hard. 

We selected Cockscomb for our team dinner and it was one of the most memorable of San Francisco meals ever! We ate upstairs in a room where the natural light streamed in and perfectly lit each dish. For libations we started with a little bubbly, a few chose to have cocktails, and the rest of us did a mix of white and red wines. We ordered a few starters to share family style, and each got our own entrees. The little gem salad was delightful and made me feel okay with drinking three cocktails, the roasted chicken entree was anything but ordinary and the grilled whole pineapple dessert with coconut ice cream almost made me die from happiness. 

From start to finish the staff was perfect in the welcome to the ordering to the execution. Everyone was happy, no one complained about what they were missing, everyone felt completely satiated and extra special. This never happens. Ever. 

Cockscomb is pure group dining magic.
author: Emi H.

description:
What kind of a name is Cockscomb? I just googled it: "the crest or comb of a domestic cock." ok.

I went here on a whim after a work event with 6 other people and this was the best spontaneous dinner I've ever experienced!

What we ordered:

- Medium oysters and shellfish - loved the oysters! didn't like the weird hot sauce it came with. Also didn't like the raw calms

- Grilled cheese - this was the best grilled cheese I've ever eaten! it was drizzled in honey with egg on a toasted bread. I dream about this grilled cheese

- Foie gras - this was a special, highly recommend!

- Pin bone steak with scallops - THE BEST STEAK AND SCALLOPS I'VE EVER EATEN 

- Gnocchi - this was fine

- Trucker's corn - good

- Crispy potatoes - really good

- Mushrooms - I was too full by the time this got to me

- Duck fat cauliflower - meh

- Tomatoes on vine - didn't even touch this, probably could have done without it

Dessert was a pineapple special and we also got their panna cotta which was amazing.
author: Andy H.

description:
We had a really nice group dinner here, and several people were charmed by Cockscomb and surprised they'd never heard of it. We had some amazing dishes, but some were total flops as well. 

RESERVATIONS: Easily made online a few days in advance for five people at 8pm. Plenty of openings. 

THE SERVICE: Really lively, friendly server. 

THE COST: $43.42 for my share of a light dinner split between five people (a few cocktails, 2 starters, 2 mains, 2 sides, 2 desserts). We were being cost-conscious and weren't super hungry (but I know from my last time here it's pretty easy to spend significantly more!). 

MUST-HAVES: Grilled Cheese, Gnocchi.

DO NOT GET: Duck Fat Cauliflower.

THE FOOD: 
* Daily Mocktail ($7) - 4.5 stars
Delicious! I can't remember the exact drink but it was fresh, tart, and lightly sweet.

STARTERS & SALADS
* Crispy Squid & Pig Ears ($19) - 3 stars
Too much chewy cartilage, just a pile of fried stuff - not for me, maybe for someone else!

* Grilled Cheese ($13) - 4.5 stars
Brilliant mix of flavors - a strong cheese with that surprising contrast of honey. Big hit at the table.

VARIETY MEATS
* Butcher's Choice: Hot Mess ($28) - 3.5 stars
Good, but not as great as I remember from last time. Components seemed hastily thrown together. Strawberries not quite ripe, flavor didn't really compliment the foie gras and meats.

SUPPER
* Zampini, Pork Fennel Sausage ($20) - 4 stars
Despite the sausage being quite spicy, we all couldn't help eating every last bite and really enjoying this!

DAILY REQUIREMENTS
* Duck Fat Cauliflower ($9) - 2 stars
This tasted like undercooked, steamed cauliflower. No flavor, texture way too hard. 

* Gnocchi ($9) - 4.5 stars
Fantastic. Each gnocchi melted in my mouth, surrounded by the most perfect light crisp. 

DESSERT
* Chocolate Mousse ($8) - 4 stars
Definitely the better of the 2 desserts by a long shot. We liked the warm toasted marshmallow on top!

* Fruit Pastry ($8) - 3 stars
The pastry was stale, the whipped cream a bit light for my taste.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
I can't wait to go back!

Sit at the cooks counter. 

Everything we ordered was phenomenal. 

Started with the grilled cheese sandwich with a perfectly cooked ducks egg. Holy crap!!! Unbelievable. I don't remember what cheese they used (maybe a sharp Brie) but it was they best grilled cheese I've ever had. Paired with honey. GENIUS! No question - insane. 

A seemingly standard Kale salad blew us away. Perfectly dressed with a ranch dressing and crunchy salty things that made Hidden Valley Ranch (which I like) taste bland. 

Sides of mushrooms and duck fat cauliflower wowed us. Still thinking of the cauliflower. 

The Hot Mess... if you get anything here get the Hot Mess. Wow. Meaty goodness topped perfectly with pickled strawberries to cut the richness. Wow wow wow!
author: Dave K.

description:
I've been here several times now for both happy hour and dinner. This may be one of my favorite places in the city. The food is top notch and delicious. The service is mostly awesome, with a few spotty experiences. 

Highlights:
Happy hour oysters
Happy hour pig's ears
Happy hour potatoes
Duck fat cauliflower - it's a vegetable so it's still good for you right? 
Pig's head - surprisingly lots of meat that ranges from tender cheek meat unctuously bathed in its own fat and gelatin to the crispy ear bits
Steak - just get it. so good.

Meh:
Impossible burger - but that's what I get for trying something that nature did not intend
author: Judy C.

description:
I recently had a wonderful meal here, upstairs, served by Dave. He took great care of our large, loud, boisterous crew. We only see each other a few times a year, so it's understandable that we're so excitable, but it's still a lot for someone to handle. We were seated in a really cool upstairs nook of this sprawling space. 

The most important thing about eating here is that it smells amazing. From the moment you walk in, you're enveloped in the wonderful smell of the burning wood and all the delicious meats roasting on the embers. You'll be instantly hungry the minute you walk in, even if you had previously believed you wouldn't be. 

I had the little gem salad and the roasted chicken. Is there anything better than a picture perfect little gem? Maybe, a perfectly roasted little bit of chicken, served up in all it's rich broth and juices, with artichoke. The meal was wonderful, I loved what I ordered, and I loved sampling a little bit from everyone else at our big table. 

Highly recommend for a dinner while traveling for work or fun - or in my case, very fun work.
author: Julie S.

description:
By far my favorite restaurant for steak in San Francisco! My family and I are huge fans of a great steak dinner, and Cockscomb definitely delivered an experience beyond our expectations. 

We decided to celebrate my dad's birthday on a Monday night, and the restaurant staff was very kind to have a birthday card at the table once we were seated. Once we were seated, the waiter was very friendly and eloquently told us the specials of the day. 

APPETIZERS
+ Fried squid and pig ears-- This might sound like a strange dish to try, but it was delicious! The pig ears tasted like crispy pig skin chips and the calamari was fried perfectly. I also enjoyed the addition of mint and citrus  to give the dish some brightness. 

+ Little Gems Salad--I ordered this salad without expecting anything too amazing (since salads are usually about the same to me), but this salad was so good! The romaine lettuce was crispy, fresh and sweet, and I loved the light vinegarette dressing. They also added fried anchovies and shredded cheese to give the entire dish some saltiness. 

ENTREES (Shared between 4 people) 
+ Pin Bone Steak--If you're looking to treat yourself and happen to have a party of four with you, get this steak! It was honestly one of the best steaks I have ever had at any restaurant. We ordered it medium rare, and the dry aged quality of the beef definitely proved itself in this dish. The steak was massive, and served with a delicious gravy and bone marrow dip. It also came with some fresh greens and crispy potatoes

+ Tuna Collar--I was skeptical about ordering this dish, since I've never been too impressed by fish collars, but I was blown away by this dish! The tuna collar was massive, and it came decked out with peppercorns, green onions, peppers, and other aromatics. It was cooked in the wood fire, and the meat was tender and fatty.  

Overall, this was an amazing experience and I cannot recommend this restaurant more! The staff was so kind and friendly, and the service was amazing. They were constantly checking up on us, and filling our waters. If you're looking to celebrate a birthday, anniversary, or any special occasion, this is the place to have it!
author: Sandra S.

description:
I ate Cockscomb twice in one week - that good. First time, some friends asked me to pick the spot. The handy Yelp app guided me there. The second time, it was a planned team dinner. Trust me when I say I wasn't disappointed that I was gonna eat there again. 

If you're a fan of oysters, wood-fired oven cooking, chop house meats and fish options - you will be a fan of Cockscomb. 

My first night, I ordered the roasted carrots with cashew ricotta "cheese" as my entree. But for starters, we shared the gnocchi with sage and brown butter, lemon garlic mushrooms, duck fat cauliflower. Others at the table ordered the steak, the burger, and local fish. Our entire dinner, my friend Tomas kept repeating, "I'm so glad you picked this place."

My second dining experience at Cockscomb REALLY won me over. I ordered the Spaghettini that has shaved tuna heart and an egg yolk. The shaved tuna heart gave the dish a slight salted and fishy taste that really enhanced the dish's flavor. I'm a huge fan of seafood and pasta, and this was the perfect marriage. 

Wine is great. Beer selection too. But if you like G&Ts, do order one at Cockscomb. I love how they serve it Spanish-style in the wine goblet. Presentation and flavor! 

Big fan of this resto and I've already told a few SF friends about it. But this is me, telling YOU about it. Enjoy. And LMK if you learn how to properly pronounce "Cockscomb." I'm still confused.
author: Farrah A.

description:
I came here with a group of colleagues while in SF on business and oh my goodness, we had the most amazing meal! Every single dish was exploding with flavor, their cocktails were unique, and service was friendly.

Since I am pregnant, they whipped up some mocktails for me that were very tasty and my favorite part was that they were served in pretty glassware with fun garnishes. That definitely makes it feel more like the real deal. ;) 

To start, I had their little gem salad and it was SO amazing. The lettuce was cold and crisp and the dressing was so flavorful. I would absolutely get this again! If you don't like anchovies, just have them leave them off. I am not a fan of them at all but this salad was not too fishy for me when left off.

For my entree, I ordered the roasted chicken with artichoke barigoule (A veggie medley with artichoke hearts, carrots, onions, fennel, and a light white wine/broth type sauce. It was so flavorful and the veggies were perfectly tender.) and garlic chive salsa. It was absolutely AMAZING and just what this momma wanted. Of course, I had to get a side and the fingerling potatoes were calling my name. They, too, were just what the doctor ordered.

For dessert, we all split their marinated and grilled *whole* pineapple with homemade coconut ice cream and it was absolutely heavenly. This is a MUST, regardless of how full you are. It is so light and the perfect palate cleanser. 

I would recommend this spot to ANYONE! You can literally smell the amazingness from a block away. You will not be disappointed!
author: Hailey P.

description:
I'm not sure what to say about Cockscomb that hasn't already been said, to be honest. 

But hey, I'll give it shot! 

So, was anyone blown the eff away at how this initially tiny place unfolds into an airy, bright space? Just me? Holy moly. This place has multiple vibes and I think that's pretty rad. 

Service--on point. For real. Our largish group was served flawlessly. Also, shout out to these professionals who not only know the menu items front to back, but seem passionate AF about what they do. 

Food? Well, unless you haven't read any of these other reviews, you already know this place somehow balances the beam between carnivorous rapture and vegetable bliss that even meat-eaters can't refuse. Seriously, you can eat cow udder here if you'd like. 

I opted for their Coulette steak entree, the duck fat cauliflower, and the browned butter gnocchi. First of all, THAT STEAK. SHUT UP. It was delicious. It was rich without being overly so. It was tender, savory. I... I... I just can't. Go try it. The gnocchi was simple, but just the little carby treat I needed. They were a little crispy on the outside and super-fluffy on the inside. The cauliflower, which I was hella pumped for, actually was not for me. The fresh mint ruined it for me. But if you love fresh mint, try this dish! 

Thanks for the amazing experience, Cockscomb!
author: Cara L.

description:
If you're on a Keto diet you'd love this place, if you're not on a Keto diet, you'd still love this place. Cockscomb is New American realness and I'm here for it. 

I have to start with the space. This place is larger than it looks and freaking gorgeous. Like if they go out of business, I'm buying it all. The industrial meets butcher shop look is to die for. They naturally have a vibe that a lot of restaurants pay to achieve. 

Now on to the service. Top notch. These folks are passionate and slightly weird. A pure reflection of San Francisco. I never had to wait for my water glass to be filled or my beer refreshed. Almost to a fault, too, because I had a sip of champagne during a toast and it magically kept refilling. 

The food is the star here, though. I had the coulotte steak dish, which was paired with king trumpets and a béarnaise sauce. The steak was tender and precisely medium rare. The sear on the steak was salted to perfection and gave the pure meat a kick. I loved everything about it. 

I also tried the gnocchi which was sinful. The brown butter added even more richness to the pasta. This one is to share, you may die if you eat the whole dish. 

I will definitely be back and that says a lot since I rarely visit the same place twice when exploring a city!
author: Luci H.

description:
Came here a while ago after we took our engagement photos. There were 4 of us and the establishment was clean and the people were very friendly. This was the first time
I've had foie gras and it was so delicious. I love the name of this place there were a lot of cocks present (roosters) and the chef is a top shelf contestant. The food was yummy and i would come back here again if i were in this area.
author: Chan T.

description:
Prior to heading in for dinner a quick look through the photos left me on the fence about what to expect from Cockscomb. The food looked like it was going to be extremely rich and heavy.  This place is for carnivores, after all. I was pleasantly surprised that there was some lighter fare on the menu. 

We were a group of seven, but we didn't order family style, which seems to be the best way to experience this restaurant. We did share some sides and appetizers.

- Crispy squid & pig ears: with a citrus, mint and chili sauce. It was good. 
- Little Gem Salad- the greens were super fresh and crispy, but the salad was very under dressed. 
Sides: 
-Dirty Crispy potatoes- not my favorite. 
-DuckFat Cauliflower- with chili, garlic and mint. 

For my entree I ordered the fish special, served over gigantic beans, marinated mussels & fennel. This dish was perfect. It was balanced and light enough that I had room for a bite of dessert. 

Dessert:
Sousvide Pineapple- this is an awesome dessert and absolutely meant to share with several people.  It's whole pineapple with coconut creme inside. The pineapple is marinated in star anis and served sliced on the side. This was one of my favorite desserts ever.

The service was excellent and the overall experience was really great. The starters and sides were slightly underwhelming, but I'd return to Cockscomb, for sure for a family style dinner experience.
author: Isabella J.

description:
Little 2 story fancy hole in the wall. Great atmosphere/ambience. Extremely helpful staff with letting us know all about the menu and most liked dishes.

Street parking only as it is in downtown (some what near/few blocks down AT&T park)

My friends and I went here for a Friendsgiving dinner, we did a family style. Had a few drinks and just really enjoyed each other's company. The area where we sat was upstairs near the window very secluded and almost felt private as there were only us and another party. Downstairs were more packed and busy. 

We ordered the Surf and Turf which is the Lobster and Pork belly. To die for! Super good, I want to share a secret; I didn't want to share. Haha just kidding. We also tried their Squid ink Pasta, it had a lot of squid pieces and arugula (arugula lover here!). We had a side of sauteed mushrooms too!

We had wine I forget now what I ordered it was white, but I always opt for something between a late harvest white to a reisling/moscato. 

We all enjoyed.
It was a nice visit to this restaurant and would definitely put it in my "to visit again" list :)
author: Madel R.

description: Came here for lunch. We got impossible burger and smoked salmon! It was my first time trying impossible burger and seriously the patty tasted just like meat! I don't know how they make this but it was delicious! Smoked salmon was great too. I think impossible burger is worth a try!
author: Clare L.

description:
My boyfriend took me here to celebrate our belated 6-monthaversary and that I passed the first test for my professional engineer license, so I was pretty excited to get dressed up and eat some yummy food. The location of this restaurant is definitely in a weird spot in the city. It's far away from the actual hustle and bustle of SF and in between the residential and empty commercial buildings. It's not a dress up type of place, more casual and for happy hour type of eating experiences.

SF made reservations for a Saturday night and we got seated upstairs. The restaurant was somewhat busy and we whizzed by the first floor, up the stairs to a corner seating arrangement overlooking the buildings. The tables were all crammed together upstairs and with people being seated, it was hard to maneuver between the chairs and the tables to get to the table and out.

Our server that night was very enthusiastic, but you can tell he was saying the same thing over and over to each table. He described their specials that night and it was kind of like a two meals in one plate. I wish we didn't order it because it was so little for two people and cost a bit more. SF ordered the sirloin and scallops special since I originally wanted the Coulette steak dish. We also ordered half a dozen oysters, the grilled cheese sandwich, and a Pisco Punch. The oysters were very fresh and I really liked their condiments - a Jalapeno vinegar sauce and homemade hot sauce. The grilled cheese sandwich was also very good with the sunnyside up egg on top, but it wasn't anything that was so over the top crazy. And there wasn't anything special about the drink, it wasn't too strong but tasty.

When it came to the actual main dish, it was SO DISAPPOINTING. The asparagus and the sirloin steak with scallops was okay. It was amazing and the portions were too small for two people. I though the sirloin was over seasoned with salt that I tried to eat the scallops to kind of off-taste the salt. Lastly, we ordered an angel cake dessert which ended up being really heavy and not light. Overall, I don't think I'll be coming back to try any more of their overpriced dishes.
author: Ada C.

description:
Gimme gimme gimme, I'm living for Cockscomb and can't stop raving about this place. The name may come across as raunchy but trust me you'll be screaming their name to everyone once you leave. We made a reservation through Yelp for a late dinner and were easily accommodated the day of. (We also dined on a Monday so it wasn't during peak hours).

Entrance is a little understated but that was a major appeal to me since the primary focus is the setting within.

The staff went out of their way to ensure everyone in the dining area had a great experience. The aroma and aura of this spot is divine, and you'll easily lose yourself in great conversations with delectable food and hoppy beers for a few hours.

As a table we started off with a few Daily Requirements which were the Gnocchi, Duck Fat Cauliflower, and Grilled Asparagus. Now I wasn't trying to be no Jennie Craig spokesperson or be aware of my caloric intake. HELL TO THE NO

Gimme the butter
Gimme the carbs
Gimme the calories
MOST IMPORANTLY
GIMME THE MEATS

The gnocchi will make you cry tears of happiness because it is so well executed. I don't know how to describe it, but literally every bite you take you'll be slopping the sage & brown butter. A simple dish ingredient wise, but damn Cockscomb knocked it out of the park.

You have to also grab an order of the cauliflower because it's a great savory app.

I was in complete desire for some proper meat sweats so I opted for the Bacon Chop. If there is one dish you need to try it has to be this one. My friend Farrah suggested this spot and I kept thanking her throughout the meal.

Definitely can't wait to come back!!
author: Tomas R.

description:
Cockscomb, the place for carnivores with a savage side... 

Made reservations here for 7:30 with my fellow meat loving friend. I requested counter seating and we were seated right in front of the giant fire roaring in the kitchen, which blasted my face with heat initially. Then I got accustomed to it and it became more like a light toasting. 

The first waiter who came didn't know any of the market prices on the menu, but our second waitress seemed much more knowledgeable. I'd done my research beforehand and cautioned my friend about ordering anything else if our plan was to have the pig's head. Our waitress was honest in saying that it was pretty big and we would most likely have leftovers, so we decided to just have the head in addition to our beer and wine. 

The pig's head is no joke. I watched it go into the oven and come out with blistered skin and a fork stuck through the eyeball. You even see its teeth (our pig had lots of cavities). It's kind of gross and the skin, once you cut through it, gives way to a dense layer of oily fat. I couldn't eat the skin without grease spilling out. Not the healthiest thing, but oh man it was so crunchy and had a slight sweetness from whatever sauce went on it. The meat underneath all that fat is tender and falls apart at the prod of a fork. There's also a salad with fried pig ears that comes with the head, which has a nice acidity that cuts through the fat. 

Amazingly, we finished the whole damn thing, including the eyeball (which was actually not bad). I think it would be a lot better with bread or something to soak up the juices and fat, and some vessel to eat the meat on. The meal sat heavily in my stomach until I walked up and down a couple hills. The other shareable dishes looked super good and there's a length specials menu. Would probably be a good place to go with a group so you can try everything!
author: Sophie W.

description:
We came in for happy hour.  $1 oysters?  Count me in!  You have to walk through the restaurant and up a flight of stairs to get to the bar but it's pretty cool because if you're lucky you can sit overlooking the restaurant (as the people who pushed us out of the way to get in before us even though we had been waiting longer did.)  I actually felt kind of lucky to be sitting right by the bartender.  He was fantastic.  Quick, friendly, knowledgeable and downright funny!

I'm usually skeptical of house wine because it's almost always a blend that I feel I could have bought at a gas station.  Not here.  The house white was a chardonnay and it was delightful with my oysters.  Light and crisp, citrusy.  

Speaking of those oysters... My experience has been that the older and smaller guys are usually the $1 ones served.  Again, not here.   Full plump, large oysters are what we received.  The celery mignonette was GREAT as well as the firefighter hot sauce.  Try this hot sauce.  Do it.  It wins awards for a reason.  

The rest of the food was spot on.  We had to order another order of the pigs ears because we were fighting over them.  Ask your bartender if there are any off menu items for happy hour as well.  We got some very good chicharrones this way.  

This place is absolutely on my list to come back and have a proper dinner.
author: Christina R.

description:
Okay, people. Cockscomb is so amazing. Don't hesitate to come here, just do it. It's sooo good and I feel like you'd have to be totally insane to NOT find something amazing on the menu that you're dying to order.

I'm kicking myself for not ordering oysters, first of all. It's the very first thing on their menu and they specialize in fresh beautiful seafood. Ah, well. Next time. I was still blissfully happy with what we did enjoy. We chose a bunch of sides ("daily requirements") to start with. Gnocchi with sage & brown butter, mushrooms "a la greque" with garlic, lemon, and parsley, "dirty" crispy potatoes, and duck fat cauliflower with chili, garlic, and mint. Being gluten free I avoided anything with gluten (duh) or anything fried, since they use one fryer for all things fried. But most of the menu was available to me! I loooooved the mushrooms which were so rich and just lemony enough, and the cauliflower was nuts. Why don't I use fresh mint more often in my daily life? It took the cauliflower to another level and I could not get enough.

For my entree I had the "Local Fish" dish, and I seriously ate every bite. That's a huge deal for me -- I tend to leave half of my meal for take-home leftovers. But this was just too good... The catch of the day was halibut, and it was incredibly fresh and salt-watery without being fishy at all. So flaky and soft and moist. It's served with "gigantic beans," which were hearty and rustic and gorgeous, plus marinated mussels. YUM. I got some shellfish in there! The best part was the skin of the fish... it was coated in fennel and pan-fried, so I had this perfect, crispy, aromatic skin that made every bite way better. I get a little weird about fennel sometimes because I'm not a huge fan of licorice-y flavors, but this application didn't make me think of candy... it was mild and bright and just right. 

For dessert we all shared the panna cotta. I'm not a big dessert person (I always choose savory over sweet), but you guys.... this panna cotta was INSANE. I feel like I'm being so over-dramatic in this review, but honestly... I can't get over how rad every single aspect of our entire meal was. Service included. Our waitress was wonderful and she helped me out with all the gluten-free stuff, plus she made my bff feel comfortable and safe with his nut allergy. 

Go go go here any chance you get.
author: Kendall S.

description:
Came here again for dinner, this time with a group of 7. It was a breez to make reservations a couple weeks in advance for a Wed dinner at 6:15. Our table was ready for us when we arrived. We were seated in the upstairs area which is my personal favorite, as there is a lot more natural lighting up there.

Based on my last experience, I knew to expect a couple of appetizers and entrees on their daily specials, and I wasn't disappointed. Our server reeled off a couple options for us, some of which sounded amazing. We ended up going with two appetizers and two entrees to share.

We started with an octopus and foie gras appetizers off their specials menu, which came in at $70 and $28 respectively. The octopus was pricey for the small portion size, but it was incredibly tender and probably the best octopus I've had in a couple years. The foie gras was served on a slice of sourdough bread and topped with a sweet strawberry sauce. I wasn't a huge fan of the sweet sauce, but it was an interesting way to eat foie gras so I appreciate the experience.

For our entrees, we went with the whole Liberty duck ($120) from the menu as well as a surf & turf ($195) from the daily specials. They brought out the whole duck before they cut it up so we could look at it and take a quick picture, which I thought was nice of them. However, when it actually came to eating the duck, it was a bit difficult as the pieces were cut up into awkward sizes and shapes. I quickly gave up trying to eat it with a fork and knife and picked it up with my hands. A lot of my friends did the same. The duck itself was also on the bland side. Probably my least favorite dish from this meal.

The surf and turf was interesting as it came with scallops, which I've never seen before. The steak was wagyu beef and came topped with some shiitake mushrooms and asparagus (gotta get your greens in!). The scallops were big and juicy and definitely my favorite part of this meal. I don't eat steak very often, but some of my friends thought the wagyu didn't taste as good as normal wagyu. Comparing this to the T-bone steak we tried last time, though, I think the T-bone steak was better if you're strictly comparing the steak itself.

Service was great, as always. We actually had the same server from last time who took great care of my friends and me.

Ended up spending close to $100 here with a drink.
author: Dianna H.

description:
Finally! I've passed by Cockscomb so many times and heard glowing recommendations from friends. One of them had a group dinner here and wanted to repeat the experience, so I made reservations for seven of us. We were promptly seated and served upon arrival.

Nina Y. and I were the first ones there, so we started with some appetizers while waiting. We went with the crispy potatoes and cauliflower off the menu, both of which were tasty. When the rest of our crew arrived, my friend didn't need to look at the menu... he just asked for all the specials.

I think there were five specials that day, and we ended up ordering four. Cockscomb really is best enjoyed family-style, which is what we did. I can't remember the names of the all the dishes we ordered, but they were all delicious! Everything from foie gras and pork belly to a whole catfish.

For dessert, there was a chocolatey one I wasn't too fond of, but the pineapple sorbet with grilled pineapple was one of the best things I've ever tasted. I would come back just for that, though I believe it was a limited-time special.

Anyways, pro tips would include making reservations in advance and ordering off the menu of specials. Each time eating here is a different experience. I agree with other Yelpers about the creativity and pizzazz that is Chris Cosentino. I recently saw him at the Taste of the Nation fundraiser, too! Good guy, good food, good vibes. Would recommend.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Oh man talk about amazing food and impeccable arrived!  Cockscomb delivers on every aspect!  We have a wonderful time here on my birthday. The food was on point!

We started the day with $1 happy hour oysters and here's the round up of food:

Happy hour 5-6:
- oysters,  their hot sauce and mignonette are soooo good
- grilled cheese with honey, on point 
- dirty crispy potatoes, so perfect with the right amount of mashed potato and crisp

Then we headed off to our reservation for the main course where they had their cute newly designed happy bday cards. What a surprise!

- crudo, very fresh
- beef heart tartar,  it is all heart. Try if you are adventurous
- steak, seasoned well 
- special scallop risotto with asparagus, perfection
- Tuna heart flake spaghettini,  highly recommend order this for sure! 

I'd come back for sure!
author: Michelle T.

description: Wow! Crazy good food and very unique food and ambiance. Exceptional service. Be ready to empty your wallet, but definitely a bucket lister if you're a foodie. 5 stars for sure!
author: Dustin O.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place for a long time and we finally got in for bday dinner. 
I go overboard when ordering all of the time and this time was no different. 

We got 8 oysters, 2 blood clams. Honestly I hated the blood clams so much. Tasted like a bloody soupy iodine mess. 

Kale and watermelon salad was great. If I knew how to make kale taste as good as this I'd eat it more. 

Culotte steak was cooked more towards rare than med rare but no complaints here it was wonderful. I could have done without the sauce on top as I felt it took away from the premium quality steak. 

Boyfriend ordered the sole dish, but the waitress stated they were serving it with cod for the night. He wasn't crazy about it and left more than half the portion. Peas it was served with were great. 

Duck fat cauliflower was ok, nothing special. 

Crispy potatoes were ok, also didn't like the heavy mayonnaise based sauce on this. 

Gin jams cocktail was very good. The house gin and tonic was basic. 

I loved the waitress we had she was so knowledgeable and helpful with pointing out dishes that were gluten free and also those that were celiac friendly. All waitresses should be as educated as she was in the allergy area! 

For the price compared to quality I would come back only for the steak and kale salad and not go overboard with sides.
author: Destinie Z.

description:
Finally got to eat here today for lunch! And glad we did. 

I was in charge of making reservations for lunch with out team at work. And since this was walking distance from the office, this was the perfect spot. I later then saw that Andrew Zimmerman had also dined here and loved it, which made me even more excited to try it.

We ordered the pig ears, mussels, and the guys ordered the burgers. Everything was delicious! And OMG their bread is so flipping good. It's soft, fresh and even toasted!!! 

The pig ears were like chicharrones and they were different because they paired it with herbs (parsley and mint), which didn't make it taste as heavy. 

The broth that came with the mussels was perfect for this overcast day. The mussels themselves were cooked well and not rubbery. I just didn't care for the potatoes as they were soggy since it sat in the broth.

The staff was so kind to us and they let us try some of their desserts. I don't remember what the name of it was, but all I remember was that it was drizzled with a balsamic reduction and it was SO good! It was luscious and creamy. 

I'd definitely come back.
author: Jerrica N.

description:
Made same day rezzies and had some good and not so good food, but the service here is great!!

Pros:
+ Service was great, servers were knowledgeable and polite
+ Majority of the food was great, excellent flavor
+ Spacious seating, calm atmosphere, great hip hop playlist
+ Reservations through Yelp, whoo!

Cons:
- Pin Bone Steak disappointed my friends so badly

Recommendations:
+ Octopus dish (so tender and not too crazy with the salt), 4/5
+ Crispy Squid and Pig Ears, 4/5

Skip:
- Pin Bone Steak, 2/5

Impartial:
- Gnocchi (nothing special, small portion), 3.5/5
- Arugula and Strawberries (its basic but I love arugula), 5/5

We were not pleased with the steak. At $125, this dry-aged steak should be spectacular. Firstly, it was not medium rare. Secondly, the meat was tough. I understand they're not a steakhouse, but at the same time, such a highly rated spot selling 28 DAY DRY-AGED STEAK for $125 needs to deliver. You may have given more in QUANTITY, but you fell short on QUALITY.

The starters were great! Unique, flavorful, and nicely executed. I was against the pig ears, but the dish came out and BOOM. YUM! I'd recommend going slightly lighter on the salt though.

Servers were great. Hostesses were great. They sent over a small plate of steak to make up for it. Our first round of drinks were complimented. Great attitude towards trying to resolve the issue.

I think we racked up a $300+ bill? The sweetest goober took care of the bill though. Would I return? Probably not anytime soon. I wanted to try them for years, glad I finally did, but it didn't blow my mind.
author: Fanny W.

description:
I had heard about Cockscomb for a long time, but hadn't been in a rush to come since I often heard it in the same breadth as pigs ear and pigs head.  Well, you can have a wonderful meal here without ordering items with exotic animal parts!

I was able to get an 8:15pm reservation for 2 on a Saturday night with a few hour's notice.  The hostess initially seated us at the bar, but kindly moved us to a table upon request as the bar seats were a bit toasty from being close to the oven. 

We had:
* crunchy pigs ear and calamari- which was served with tarragon and citrus. It was a generous portion for two. Probably perfect for 3 as it IS indeed crunchy and chewy so splitting between 2 was a good hefty portion. I loved how the tarragon and citrus made this dish feel fresh and refreshing!  Hubs wished the pigs ear was saltier (probably more a la drinking food) but I thought it was perfect!
* Octopus (daily special) - this dish was indeed special with the thick part of the tentacle being meaty yet tender, the tip of the tentacle being crispy. There was a hint of smokiness and a lovely spicy sauce to go with it. It was served on a bed of divinely crunchy on the outside, creamy on the inside potatoes. This was an appetizer (1 large tentacle + 1 medium sized tentacle). This is probably one of the best things we've eaten this year!  It also came in at $70 for the dish. It's cheaper than a ticket to Europe (which I feel like is the only other place you could get octopus this good, if then!), but not for the faint of heart. The waitress had told us this price, but I had thought she must have meant $17 since it's an appetizer. 
* Spicy fennel sausage- I thought this dish was very well balanced between the sausage and the large pile of corn, tomatoes, shishito pepper it was served with. For me, the sausage by itself was too intense, but perfect with the corn, tomato, pepper.  Hubs who enjoys spicy food LOVED this sausage 
* the gnocchi- was a bit soft for me, but paired well with the sausage dish
* we ended the meal with Chocolate Pot De Creme- this was a really nice way to end the meal!  It's chocolate pot de creme topped with toasted marshmallows, with a sprinkling of crunchy almonds between the pot de creme and toasted marshmallow.  The pot de creme is slightly bitter (they've added a touch of amaro to it) which pairs really well with the sweetness of the marshmallow.  This dessert had a lot of complexity both in flavors and texture. It was a wonderful combination of chocolate, slight nutty and crunchiness, along with the sweetness and different texture of the toasted marshmallow.  

Overall, slight sticker shock from the octopus appetizer, but a wonderful meal!  The waitress was great in explaining the food -- very passionate and with gusto!  Also, one of the best meals we've had in the city so worth it in our book!  

I will say the atmosphere is not a super smooth, refined atmosphere. It's hard to describe. It's got character and can be a bit loud, but we felt quite comfortable and pacing of service was good. 

For people who love good food and enjoys a comfortable atmosphere with warm service and doesn't mind a louder dining room, we would whole heartedly recommend Cockscomb!
author: Kathryn C.

description:
Great trendy place two blocks up from train station. You can sit at the bar and watch your steaks cooking on a open flame hickory wood pit. They aren't cheap but good food. And it's a very cool place to go on a date or to dinner before a Giants game. 
Upstairs bar with burger sliders is the way to go.
author: Mark B.

description:
Chef Chris Cosentino is a genius. And a badass.

Cockscomb is not for the faint of heart (or for vegetarians), but I'm completely convinced that anyone and everyone can enjoy their meal here (as long as they eat meat). Grossed out by the thought of pig ears or beef heart? If I could blindfold you and have you try the offal parts served here, you'd probably still enjoy yourself. For myself and a few of my adventurous eater friends, this restaurant was an absolute pleasure to dine at.

Some of the things we ordered:
- Crispy squid & pig ears: One of my favorite appetizers...possibly ever. The pig ear was so delightfully crispy and perfectly seasoned, and the squid wasn't tough in the slightest. The citrus, mint, and chili was a really beautiful compliment to everything.

- Beef heart tartare: Enjoyed the tartare, but wasn't a fan of the grilled bread, which is probably my only negative criticism of the meal. The slices of grilled bread were just too big and just overpowered the taste of the tartare.

- "Hot Mess" off-menu special: I wish I remembered the full details of this, but all I can recall is that it involved foie gras. Yum. It was delicious and rich as you'd expect. My only wish was that we ate it faster because it got cold fairly quickly.

- Carrots with lebne + duck fat cauliflower: Great little sides that provided some fiber to a very carnivorous meal.

- Roasted pigs head: A HUGE highlight of the dinner. It felt so primal seeing that entire half pigs head, eyeball and all, and then digging into it with our knives and forks. The skin was to die for - Amazingly crispy, crunchy, & savory. The meat was so tender that once you ate the skin, all the meat underneath just fell apart with a slight touch of the fork, and every part from the eye to the cheek tasted deliciously savory, rich, and all around just perfect. A bonus - A brain aioli dipping sauce for all of the skin and meat. Honestly this was one of the most decadent and most pleasurable eating experiences of my life. I took some of the leftover meat home and made fried rice with it the next day (highly recommend)

On top of all of this, service was fantastic, and our server was very attentive and friendly.

I absolutely plan to go back to try some of their other unique meat-centric dishes like the whole duck or meat pie.
author: Sara L.

description:
Took my gf here for a dinner date last Sunday, and I must say, it was an incredible experience. We ordered the squid with pig ears for starters. It was very delicious and meat was tender. It went well with the grape fruit, and had a tangy sweet taste to it. Oysters were delicious and creamy. We had the large dozens of Washington . Our main entree, I had the lobster and pork belly which we both shared together. Pork belly was amazingly crispy with the skin and juicy towards the meat. 

Mixed drinks was amazing! I had to get two of "Escape from Alcatraz". Had a good buzz afterwards. Wasn't drenched in alcohol to where you can taste it from the back of your tongue. 

Atmosphere is nice I love the music they play. House/R&B music. Our waiters were very nice and friendly and explained the menu very well to us with every detail from the ingredients to the temperature lol. I love this place and we will be back again soon!
author: Cheryl Ann B.

description:
From the genius that is Chris Cosentino. Such an amazing culinary experience that unfortunately I cannot properly describe because I never got to look at the menu nor had descriptions of all the off the menu dishes that graced our table.

If you ever get a chance, eat with chefs, especially ones that used to work at the restaurant you're eating at. Endless glasses of wine and shots of Fernet. And a sampling of all the best dishes the restaurant has to offer.

There were also plenty of special dishes that the kitchen prepared specifically for us. Our "amuse bouche" consisted of an entire Yellowfin collar. There was enough meat to feed 8 people. The foie gras was excellent. The oysters were excellent. The pig ear and squid was excellent. The pork loin flanked by Dungeness crabs stole the show. I've never experienced surf & turf like this.

They brought a good sampling of all their deserts including an entire frozen pineapple. You'll just have to see for yourself in the blurry pics I took. The chefs we were eating with wouldn't let me take pics of any of the dishes, but I snuck a few.
author: Joemm B.

description:
Yep! It's all that. Try it on for size!
Loud...Really loud!! 
The ingredients, preparation and presentation are exceptional.

The menu is mysterious and magical. 

This is one of those places I've wanted to enjoy for a long time. Often, when a place is on the radar for years it never lives up to the  expectations. This did.  

Cockscomb far surpassed an preconceived expatiation I had. Wow!! I will be back. 

+ Loud: This is a very loud restaurant upstairs. We sat by the Jeremy Fish so I think all the noise was bouncing off the walls into my ears. It's loud!! You will have to use your, "Saturday night bar voice." Usually this drives me crazy and it does bother me still but the food here is so good I can over look it and just have another three drinks.

+ Eat this: The Bacon Chop. I can't even start to describe the divinity this cut is. It's juicy; like no other piece of pork on earth. As I finish this review it's now two weeks after the meal and  my mouth is watering. Now that I think about it, why haven't I been back? It's amazing. If you come here and don't have at least one person at your table share a bite with you then you have truly missed out on a part of your life. It's almost like the first time you see David or the Eiffel Tower. Maybe I'm over reaching but it is good.

The drinks are good, too.
author: Justin S.

description:
Amazing from beginning to end! We came to celebrate a birthday, and I was surprised how accommodating the staff were to my reservation requests. We got a table in the corner of the balcony seating, and received a birthday card at the table upon sitting down. 

We ordered the duck fat fried cauliflower and crispy dirty potatoes (they come as sides but we got them as appetizers), and the coulette steak and fish of the day for the entrees. The potatoes were piping hot, crispy, and smothered with some kind of aioli. Really rich! The steak was juicy and flavorful; I don't even like steak very much, and I thought it was delicious.

Our waiter was so friendly and helpful. He surprised us with a sponge cake with a candle at the end of the meal. Even though we ordered rich and flavorful items, I left without feeling too heavy and stuffed.
author: Denise L.

description: A great interactive restaurant! Meat, meat, meat absolutely perfect.....atmosphere is fun even for the biggest ambiverts, introverts and extroverts. A must visit when in SOMA.
author: Andrea G.

description:
Came here for a birthday dinner.  The place is crowded with very little room and the air blasting cold air.

B: Foie on Pork Belly - pork belly was very mushy and foie did not come through as far as flavor goes

F: Kale Salad - was recommended by the server, was so terrible, nothing unique, hardly smell/taste the garlic

B: Spaghettini - pasta was al dente  

B: Cauliflower - tasted like my homemade cauliflower, was hoping for some unique texture

A: 28 day dry Bone Steak - I have been on a streak, eating these massive cuts.  The flavor was very good, great quality, however, there was a lot of fat on this piece

Not sure why they brought everything out first including the sides, and the steak last because we only had meat to eat with nothing to complement it.  Glad I tried it, a bit too crowded for me.
author: Lynda L.

description:
Last night, a group of 6 of us gathered here to celebrate 2 of our friend's birthdays. You will have to duck into the little alley to get to the front door. There is a brightly lit sign that reads "Food & Drinks" to help guide you. There is a bit of mystery when you get to the door because it is partly hidden and when you walk in, you are hit with a LOUD burst of energy!  The downstairs looks a little small, but we were led upstairs to a table nestled in the back.  It was still loud, so bring your bar voice with you.  

Our servers were attentive when getting us glasses of water (your choice of still or sparkling), but they gave us plenty of time to mull over the drink menu before coming to take our order.  I had the Social Network Spritz which was delicious (a bit fruity and sweet, but great for my liking!).  

Next, our server came by and introduced the specials to us.  It was quite a menu and he described each dish with a full description which at the end of the specials was a bit overwhelming.  We definitely had to clarify with one another about the different items that he mentioned, but after all was said and done, we ended up going with the 2 orders of the Wagyu Beef with Scallops and turnips special with the Peach Salad and a side of the Cauliflower.  The main dish was VERY tasty.  I thought the scallops were divine!  The turnips were not the hit of the dish, but when they are competing with beef and scallops, who would expect them to be?  The salad was great because it was light and the peaches were sweet.  I also really enjoyed the duck fat cauliflower (very tender and juicy!).  We also got a side of the crispy potatoes and although I am not a huge fan of potatoes, these were very good!  

We had a reservation for our friends' birthdays and were pleasantly surprised when we found a birthday card waiting for us at the table upon our arrival.  I thought that was a very sweet touch.  I will definitely be back...maybe next date night?  I thought the atmosphere was great and the staff was very friendly.  Probably wouldn't do this for a first date because it is a bit loud, but then again, takes the pressure off of eating a meal in silence haha
author: Lynne T.

description:
Pretty good place if you enjoy cocktails and meat. I saw a lot of dates which is surprisingly because you walk out of the place smelling like you just went to the Salt Lick in Texas. For dinner, we ordered the oysters for apps and Pin Bone Steak (feeds 3-5) and three veggies sides. Veggie sides were on the small side but good, Pin Bone was awesome.

Yelpers let me down though by recommending the pineapple frozen thing which frankly sucked (and I like any dessert). It was this frozen pineapple with coconut ice cream and a crap ton of whipped cream with a side of super sweet grilled pineapple. Skip it. Also the service gradually tapered down to ignoring us when we were on the dessert. A little pricey considering we didn't order that much ($100/pp).
author: Karen S.

description: Pig's head and potato was a great combo! Very rich and the veggies on the side tasted Vietnamese. It felt like a try once kind of meal but I do not regret it at all! The atmosphere was good and the service was exceptional!
author: Andrea T.

description: My absolute favorite restaurant in San Francisco! I've always been a Chef Chris fan and had to stop in. The open kitchen is so fun to watch and you can tell the chefs love what they do. The roasted tomatoes and street corn are amazing as appetizers and you HAVE to have the pasta with the tuna heart. Omgggggggosh. They even have an amazing wine list! Please, please check this restaurant out and make sure you sit at the chefs bar. You'll never forget it.
author: Chelsea L.

description:
After watching Chris Consentino on Top Chef Masters I was enthralled by his passion for food and cooking nose to tail dishes. 

The atmosphere and ambience of Cockscomb is what I like in a restaurant: non-pretentious and friendly.  I shared 5 dishes with my wife and left they meal quite full.  My favorite dishes of the night were the hot mess, duck egg grilled cheese, and the duck fat cauliflower. Would definitely come back here again.
author: Vincent Q.

description:
I went to Cockscomb recently for a lunch meeting with a vendor. I have been here before for dinner a couple of times before and the food has always been of great quality. The lunch menu is a shortened express menu and they have daily lunch specials which vary depending on which day of the week you attend. On Tuesdays they have a fried chicken special.

We were a party of four and we all decided to order the fried chicken sandwich. Note this is different to the chicken special and is actually a menu item. It was at this point however where our experience started to decline. The waitress asked us if we wanted our chicken sandwiches spicy and we said yes. When our food came out  we all got the chicken specials which was fried chicken with cornbread and coleslaw. Not the sandwiches we were quite expecting. 3 of us decided to keep our food as we were already quite hungry however one person requested it be made into a sandwich. 

Although there was nothing wrong with the special, we did not like how we were misled by the waitress when asked if we wanted our chicken spicy. We all assumed we would get spicy sandwiches.

In addition to this, we also ordered a few dozen oysters for the table. During the second dozen, our plates had been cleared quite quickly without being asked and we did not have any utensils left to finish our oysters. Not a big deal but during the busy lunch rush it was difficult to get the waitress to get more utensils. 

The food was of the same great standard it always was (some oysters were disappointingly small) however the service left a lot of room for improvement.
author: Kathy L.

description:
I've heard about Cockscomb for a while, but for some odd reason never put it on the top of my list of places to eat in SF. Now, I'm mad I waited so long. I will definitely say, that it is not a restaurant to go to if you're Vegan/Vegetarian or not hungry. You will be full, and you will eat so much you hate yourself for it, and then you will hate yourself for not eating more once you leave.

Me and a girlfriend celebrated our birthdays there, and ordered the crispy squid and pig ears, gnocchi, the special -hot mess, and the heirloom tomato salad because we needed something refreshing to make us feel  better about shaving a few months off our lifespan from the fatty foods. 

Crispy squid and pig ears: Delicious. Not heavy like it sounds, and a good amount of food.

Gnocchi: Quite possibly some of the best I've tasted. Nothing special about it, just yummy gnocchi with the perfect texture.

Heirloom tomato salad: Of course my favorite part of this was the croutons #becausecarbs

The Hot Mess: I forget exactly what was on it, but it consisted of bread with foie gras on top and then meat on top of that. It was so rich, we couldn't finish it. This is nowhere a reflection of how it tasted, because I would order it again in a heart-attack heart beat - we were just stuffed already and could feel the fat coagulating in our throats. 

I'd definitely come back again, service was good and food was even better. Just a sidenote however, you will leave smelling like food.
author: Abby B.

description:
Cockscomb is a restaurant for carnivores. You can't come here and want to eat healthy, unless your definition of healthy is paleo. Everything here is delicious (if you like meat). I recommend coming with a group so you can get the pin bone steak, which can feed 4-6 people easily. It is some of the best steak I've ever had.

You should also get the grilled cheese to share, because it is amazing and you won't regret it. Other good dishes are the fennel sausage and bacon chop.
author: Sherry L.

description:
I work in Soma and it's always a real treat when we get to eat here for our team lunches. It's quite pricey for lunch but the food options here are great! 

I've tried the Italian Dip & Grilled Cheese Sandwiches here and they're fantastic! The Italian Dip is a bit on the heavier and heartier side, but the red meat sauce is quite tasty! The Grilled Cheese is also my all time favorite here. It's topped with a runny duck egg and dipped in some honey. It might sound like an odd combo, but once you give it a try, you'll see how great it goes together! 

If you're ever going to eat for lunch, be prepared that you might hit some serious food coma after. Luckily there are a few coffee shops around the corner if you need to force yourself to stay away after a heavy lunch!
author: MyTien P.

description:
After years of wanting to try this place, I finally did last week! Came here for happy hour with the bestie on a Wednesday. Arrived at 5:30pm and the place was dead. Not even a single customer... but it's ok because the bar area where they hold happy hour was very small. It started filling up around 6:30pm.

Ordered:
x Happy hour oysters - medium sized oysters that were fresh. Came with yummy sauce and enough lemon to squeeze over twice. A steal for happy hour.
x TOMBO CRUDO Mexico City style, aqua Chile, corn nuts, cilantro & tortillas - Corn nuts were a total twist, but super good. Really enjoyed this.
x Tuna Collar - This was one of the specials of the night and it was HUGEEEEE. The flavors were amazing and the collar was cooked so perfectly. If you see this on the menu, ORDER IT!
x GNOCCHI sage & brown butter - decent gnocchi. Nothing to rave about, but still good.
x MUSHROOMS A LA GREQUE garlic, lemon & parsley - so much flavor. highly recommend.

Our bartender was super friendly and nice. Service was just great! Food on the other hand, was just good. I think this is a great happy hour spot with fun vibes. Not sure if I'd come here for dinner alone.

Ps. Happy hour is from 5-6pm.
author: Anna M.

description:
The crispy pig ear and squid was very tasty and it was a nice touch to add the citrus to the appetizer. Unfortunately, the spaghetti with the anchovies a bit salty and almost unbearable to eat. 

With the amount I paid for the dish and the other places to eat I'm not sure if I would go back here again since it wasn't that memorable. I know this might be nitpicky but it also made all my clothes smell like smoke which I wasn't expecting since I wasn't near any of the meat that was being cooked.
author: Kevin L.

description: Amazing food, we came for lunch and had the oyster Platter and I ended up having the fried chicken sandwich. And some pico sours. Definitely coming back .
author: Alex A.

description:
I'd love to be a fan, but they don't honor their hours.  Whether 11pm or 10:30, on several occasions I arrived well before the supposed closing time, but the restaurant was already closed.

If you're dining late, it's a gamble.
author: dark l.

description: This place lives up to the hype! Sooooo good. My colleagues and I discovered this place while in search for a late evening dinner option. The ambiance was a trendy, modern, rustic chic, and the service was just as warm and inviting.  American (New) is their thing and they do it oh so well. I kept it super basic and ordered the "ham" burger. It was anything but that. Decked out with caramelized onions, pickles, gruyere, tomato jam, an egg and foie gras, it was insanely indulgent and insanely memorable! Everyone else at our table was raving about their meal. From their signature oysters to their fish and salad selections, this place was a solid winner all around.
author: Helina G.

description:
We came here for a friend's birthday, and it was not that impressive.  Of course, you have the typical bay area friendly wait staff that elevated the experience a little...but that's about it.

The food was ok.  It was beautifully arranged, of course, but the taste was ok.  For the price, the portion was considerably small though.  And they charged per person for a cake cutting fee.  I felt like we were being punished for celebrating a birthday there.

The seating arrangement was quite terrible.  It's crowded.  I was constantly apologizing for bumping into people.  When I needed to get up to go to the restroom, it was some acrobatic challenge to maneuver around tables, chairs, and people.
author: Jenny H.

description: Great "ham"burger and kale salad. The burger is juicy and smoky. I was a little fearful it wouldn't deliver but it was delicious. The kale salad is beautifully adorned with persimmons and pomegranate seeds with a little crunch of walnut. Incredibly fresh and citrusy. Can't wait to go again and try some other things.
author: Briana T.

description: The entire experience was amazing the recommendations for salad dinner and drinks paired nicely the service was awesome I would definitely recommend this place for either a date night or a group outing either way you will enjoy the experience the food the drinks and dessert.
author: Tina O.

description:
9/24/17

It was the best of restaurants, it was the worst of restaurants, it was the age of creativity, it was the age of mediocrity, it was the epoch of....

Oh F it... anyway, let's set this straight: I love this place not because it is the best tasting (and really, some stuff I had here straight up SUCKED), but I cannot fathom giving a restaurant that puts forth their best effort to creating a meal like none other that you've ever had in America anything less than high marks.  Right?

Like NONE OTHER.

I challenge you to find another high-end restaurant that puts a frickin' PIG'S HEAD right in the middle of your table.  Yes, yes, I get that Chinese restaurants have had whole pigs hanging behind glass since the beginnings of China Towns, and yes my friend Dorothy had a hugeass whole pig in her dinning room after her wedding, and Filipino yada yada yada...... no........ we're not talking barbarian style hunt and slay a pig to feed the tribe...  I am talking a nice trendy restaurant, with prices to match their high-end-ness, serving to all races of people, even the most squeamish, a PIG'S HEAD body removed...

Yeah?  Where?  That's right... So let's see what else we got:

1. City of the Rose $13 "Bieler rose wine, Cynar & dry vermouth":  HORRIBLE.  Mostly tastes like cheap wine.  1/10

2. Grilled Cheese $12 "duck egg & honey":  Another extremely disappointing serving.  Looks absolutely amateur for one.  Two sad looking pieces of stale toasts with cheese in the middle, honey dripping out like baby dribble.  Fried duck egg on top looks fine for a standard diner restaurant, for here... come on.....!  Doesn't taste much different than a chicken egg either.  2/10

3. Whole Roasted Striped Bass $95 "green bean almondine":  So we learned the hard way that everything not served family style is probably crappy.  But they redeemed themselves with this fish!  Beautifully made, juicy, very crisp skin.  All X's crossed.  It's great.  Yes, I guess could be cooked a tad less to make the flesh even juicier, but it's still pretty good as it is.  Now get this--it's a whole fish but....... WHERE ARE THE BONES!?!?!?  Hell man, that's some kind of sick magic!  It's like a surgeon went in and removed all the bones in some mega operation, then sutured the whole thing back up!  Amazing.  Well done.  8/10

4. Wood Oven Roasted Pigs Head $69 "chicories, herbs & capers":  Yes.  YES.  You want this.  You don't think you want this, but YOU WANT THIS.

This is probably the richest meat I've EVER had without getting that impulse to vomit.  ...(...um, maybe that doesn't sound so great... but I meant it as a good thing, really.)  The only thing I've ever had that was richer would be some Samoan food I had down in Carson--it was so extremely oily and fatty that I had to fight to keep it down after a few bites.  Really thought there would be a Samoan-style mess on the floor... after my eyes stopped tearing into the trash it all went. ...... okay okay... just saying... I've only had richer once.

Imagine... foie gras but instead of liver, it's face.  ...(.... okay... that didn't sound good either...)...

Um, ...imagine beyond-ultra-marble Kobe beef, melting like butter just sitting on your plate, but with eyeballs on top........... oh... damn...

I GIVE UP.  Trust me, you want this.  10/10

5. Duck Fat Cauliflower $7 "red fresno & mint":  I think I was so struck with the fish and head that I totally forgot to eat this.  Seriously.  ?/10

6. Latte $5:  Smooth, creamy, light.  6/10

7. Fruit Bread Pudding $8:  The waiter called this a "bread pudding."  Really, maybe it could technically qualify as bread pudding?  Maybe?  Pretty big stretch though.  But just think of it as a fruit-drenched cake with lots of cream, oozing with flavor.  Tastes awesome.  They could work on plating though--looks pretty amateur.  Also... I dunno, it's not really what I'd expect to have at a nicer restaurant.  Marie Calledar's perhaps.  Anyway, tastes good, but doesn't really belong here.  7/10

If you haven't been here, I urge you to.

If you call yourself a foodie, this absolutely must be on your list.

And if you do not like this place, not that you have to enjoy everything they serve, but if you simply do not want to order every family-style dish they got...... YOU LOST YOUR FOODIE CARD.  Immediately shredded.  Go find yourself an Olive Garden or something...

4/5

#sanfrancisco #american #star
author: Dean C.

description:
Best cocktails in SF! 

This place is my go-to for a group dinner outing. Great service and having a group with you makes it easier to try more of their dishes. 

Don't miss out on the Bullitt (cocktail) or WOOD OVEN ROASTED PIGS HEAD!
author: Carlos A.

description: Very meaty. Def get their duck fat cauliflower, fresh burrata salad. I'll be honest, the food was a bit too rich for my liking but my party enjoyed it so giving them 4 stars.
author: Sandy M.

description: Great late night happy hour. $1 dollar oysters! I had the chicken, which was super crispy and my husband had the grilled cheese. He said it was the best grilled cheese he had ever had. Server was super nice. We are at the bar upstairs for their late night happy hour and had a blast.
author: Mrs. M R.

description:
Just go. Get the pig head. Get a salad. And drop them dough. I feel the experience was worth every penny. Loved the playfulness of the hot mess/ butcher's choice appetizer. 

The chef's vision is inspiring and the technique is to admire. I died just to be a part of it. But definitely when the waitress was listing the off menu items and it started getting into the 100's I was like wuuuuttt. She playin right? Naw. It was for real $$$$. You've been warned. At the end of the day a foodie would think it was worth the experience.
author: Grace K.

description:
We arrived early during happy hour but opted to sit at the downstairs counter and order off the dinner menu. I AM SO GLAD WE DID. 

I ordered a duck bruschetta special (omg- rich, rich heaven in every bite) and we split a starter salad and a side of potatoes. The best part (other than the amazing service) was that we got to see all our food being made. So cool!

Our total was under $100 but that's with only 1 drink on the tab. Either way, totally worth every penny!
author: Dana B.

description:
Meat, so much meat. I went here for a team dinner and we left incredibly stuffed and happy. Our group ordered the Wagyu beef and scallops (which fed a minimum of 4). Amazing. Cocktails were also delicious. 

Great dining experience as well. Ambience was perfect for conversation and providing a busy atmosphere. 

Go, eat lots of meat.
author: Steve R.

description:
I made a reservation via Yelp and received confirmation. Turns out the restaurant was closed that evening for a private event, which I only found out upon arrival (no one from the business had contacted me). 

Additionally, my party and I were completely ignored by the waiting staff after we repeatedly knocked on the door, hoping to speak to someone to clear up the situation. They just shook their heads and walked right past us. 

I am deeply disappointed by the misleading information and utter lack of consideration for customers. With services like this, they can count on my not returning.
author: Nancy L.

description: At one point, there was this place called Incanto. It was crazy good. It closed when the chef opened this place downtown. It's the sort of less cozy updated version.  Now, at the old place, there was this dish which, to my memory, was air cured tuna heart, yolk, parsley over spaghettini. It's an old world Italian dish which I got into arguments with my Italian friends over because they said it was not Italian only to do some web searching to find out that it is indeed a very old one. I was sad when the old place was gone because there was no place on earth I knew to find this amazing dish of umami Italian flavors. But, it's here still on his menu. Chef Chris, don't ever ever remove it...it's the thing that calls me. Oh ya, the other stuff here is also amazing. I've only ever taken bites from my friends plates because, you know, I play to my base.
author: David S.

description:
This is the worst place I've ever eaten at in San Francisco. Period. 
How is it possible they have a solid four stars? 
Well where do I begin for them to get only one star from me? 
Oh I know, the first let down was not having the Impossible burger for dinner, which was the ONLY reason we decided to check Cockscomb out. Why only serve it for lunch? The server said, "Well if that's the only thing you came here for, you're out of luck because we only have it for lunch, but there's other places you can try that do serve it." Gently responding without coming off as a bitch I said, "Well its 8:30pm and there's no way we would even be able to check out another place, on top of that you guys took a $20 reservation fee." Moving forward to an endless night it seemed like of kitchen mess ups and frustration; we proceeded to order. With not many vegetarian options directly visible, I decided to go with the grilled cheese and fried egg on top. I requested an over-hard egg. I'd say that that's the easiest way of making sure the eggs are not runny, yolky, or snotty; you get the picture. Well it took them THREE TIMES to get it right. I mean I am no chef by profession, but damn I would consider myself somewhat of a good cook at home and it does not take me three attempts to make a freaking over-hard egg. Every single time I cut into it, yolk spewed and oozed out all over the grilled cheese. Maybe some like it like that, but not me. It was unbelievable, the entire table was shocked at how many times they messed up. Ok so they finally got it right, the grilled cheese was good. I liked the honey on top, but because it took so long I already lost my appetite. It spiraled down fast from there and from there the dishes kept coming out. A kale and radish salad, cauliflower dish, artichoke (which made me choke), side mushrooms, side gnocchi with sage and butter, two $16 "Ham" burgers, oysters, the coulotte steak, bacon chop, and a $100 plate of crab. The only thing that everyone agreed they loved was the kale and radish salad. I mean all the veggie dishes were drenched in oil or butter not sure, but it was difficult to enjoy the vegetables! I'm so used to farm to table fresh veggies and this place is not that at all. I can't believe how awful the food was and not to mention I was only there for the Impossible burger, which I didn't get.
