A $600 bill that was not worth the oily veggies and an 'impossible' egg dilemma. Included was an 18% gratuity which was well deserved. The servers kept apologizing all night. All I got to say is the kitchen needs to get it together and think about making less artery-clogging dishes. Are they aware of the chemicals released from oils such as aldehyde that's linked directly to diseases and illness like cancer and heart problems in America? I couldn't put the fork to my mouth. Such a waste and certainly unimpressed with pure disappointment. My friend was right, we got ripped off!
author: Natasha K.

description:
First impression !  Can't accommodate a 5 top!  Wahaaaaa!!! That's ridiculous... more to come if we don't decide to leave or get kicked out! Add a star for the dining experience.  
Food was excellent and wine selections superb.

However, after making the fifth of our party leave for "policy" and the four of us sitting next to a larger open table occupied by 3 (& which could have held our 5) I'm not going back.  The PITA factor is too much to deal with.  Why not accommodate us 5 and put the 3 on our 4 top?

You can't make this stuff up.  You just lost a lot of future business from our party members. Especially the fifth guy you booted.
author: Kent D.

description:
1st time we ate here was 2 months ago after we rode the Leipheimer Gran Fondo in Santa Rosa.  So when we planned to spend the Thanksgiving weekend in SF, we had to eat here again!  

Its Saturday night, and of course, the place was packed.  As a result, our party of 10 was squeezed into to a table for 8.  So throughout the meal, we were asked to constantly lean in so the servers and patrons could pass through.  

For appetizers, we began with the beef tat tar which spread well on the toast.  However, that was not enough to hold us over for the next hour before receiving our main entrees of tuna collar, lobster, and pig head.  The pork was deliciously rich.  The accompanying crisp and fresh vinegarette salad helped reduce the heavy oil.  The skin was roasted to perfectly crispy crunch.

The tuna fin was moist and the meat fell off the bone.  Not much to review as I only got a small peice.

Lobster looked impressive.  However, there was very little meat.  The peice I did get was juicy, but this writer maybe slightly biased towards Chinese style of lobster and thus personally wouldn't recommend, particularly due to the $/oz of meat.

Last but not least, dessert.  We had both the persimmon short cake and apple tart with aged cheese.  Cheese on an apple tart sounds odd, but according to the server it's a traditional English style and very good.  She was absolutely right.  The shortcake was equally delicious with the paper thin slices of persimmon topped with a sweet cream.

In conclusion, I had to reduce what would otherwise be a 5 star review to a 4 due to the long wait, inconvenient and tight  seating arrangements, and mediocre lobster.  
That being said, I would only return on a weeknight, and save the seafood for the restaurants on the pier.
author: Ken W.

description: Wow this place did not disappoint. We had a large group dinner and the portions were MASSIVE. They had a great shock value and everything was delicious (except for the pork belly which was a little bland and the fat wasn't cooked down well). The steak and the salmon were amazing. The barrel aged negronis were great, and and don't pass on the mushrooms.
author: Lily C.

description:
Bacon chop is all hype, in my opinion.  The bone-in  presentation added flavor to a good, flavorful chop, but the "bacon" was really just a flavorless, thick fat cap. Served with "al pastor" braised cabbage and pickled onions and sliced radishes, it didnt work at all for me.  The pastor brown sauce was highly spiced and killed the pork flavor.  The cabbage was a slice from the whole head, core included, not at all tender.  Maybe this was supposed to be a take on a taco preparation, but it didn't work at all for me.

On the other hand, their gin and tonic version was quite good.  Nice enough, but busy bartender/server, as I was dining alone at the bar.
author: Thomas C.

description:
This is an addendum to my previous review that originally raved about Cockscomb.

I am sad to say that my dinner at Cockscomb was significantly less enjoyable than my lunch here. My wife and I ordered the Pork-Foie Gras appetizer, the Bacon Chop with Scallops, and the panna cotta and sadly we were disappointed by the pork aspects on both the appetizer and entree which to me really left me with feelings of regret upon leaving the restaurant. The pork lacked the same level of flair, presentation, and bold flavors that made my lunch visit so good here. I don't know if simplistic is the right word, but the pork just felt like something that I could have bought at a lower end restaurant for half the price. In addition, the shredded pork on the appetizer was dry and flavorless. The foie gras, scallops, and the panna cotta were spot on and saved the meal.

I also want to give credit to our incredible server who was knowledgeable, attentive, polite, and pleasant to my wife and I throughout the entire night. He really did an excellent job of describing all the dishes, being attentive without intrusive, and was very professional. Please see my prior review for the great lunch that deserved a 5-star review.
author: Andrew H.

description:
Carnivores rejoice! Eating at Cockscomb almost hearkens back to the caveman era where folks would catch, slaughter, and prepare whole animals over an open flame. Granted, Cockscomb isn't quite that crude, but it does offer lots of quality meats that are expertly prepared.

There's no denying the quality and portions of everything on offer here, whether it's juicy steaks, huge poultry portions (if not the whole bird in its entirety), or comparatively modest dishes like the meat pie I had. All seriously good stuff. Of course, with all this gluttony comes premium prices to match. It's an experience particularly well-suited to big groups so that you can get a bunch of plates (or whole animals) to share, although on that note I'd simply have to wonder whether going to a good churrascaria might be a better value.

Nevertheless, this is a quality venue that's worth a try with large groups, and particularly with healthy expense accounts.
author: Vincent L.

description:
Our first time here and it was fantastic!  

I'll admit I've been dying to try this place for a while now. Ever since chef Chris Cosentino was on top chef master to be exact. 

Food was fantastic and the service was impeccable! 

There was 5 of us and we ordered the following:

1. Grilled cheese: hands down the BEST GRILLED CHEESE we had! EVER!

2. Medium seafood tower: it was perfect amount for the 5 of us! The stand out was the mussels, oysters and ceviche. I realized that I'm not a huge fan of raw clams.  

3. Pin bone steak (shared supper): this was the perfect amount of food for the 5 of us -3 boys and 2 girls. 
The steak was nicely seasoned. The cook was a bit uneven. Some bits were rare while other parts were medium done. All delicious nonetheless.  
If I could order this again, I would see if I could sub out the potatoes. They were under seasoned but I think they may have tried to balance the saltiness of some cuts of steak with potatoes. 
The herb salad they served with the steak was fantastic, I asked for more of this. 


 4. Duck fat cauliflower: ORDER THIS. This was so good. Just listen to me. 

5. Sunchokes: it was good but nothing to write home about.
author: Danni C.

description:
Cool hip restaurant with an open cooking area! We got the huge sharing portion of the pin bone steak, tbh I thought it was just okay.. it was a 50 oz bone in steak and the meat was cooked unevenly, the main pieces were rare while all the other side pieces were overly cooked. I thought it was too rough and and the meat wasn't even tender. 
 The appetizers and side dishes were amazing tho! The peach and tomato is refreshing and light. My favorite side dishes are the corn and potato. The corn is super tasty and potato is cooked to a perfect crisp.
author: Majes W.

description:
Have ate here once before but wasn't memorable, probably to my own fault though since I was at happy hour prior to. Today, I returned for the sole purpose to try the impossible burger and it definitely hit the spot! It was delicious and I absolutely recommend this menu item.

A comment, however, is that my wanting to try the burger was because I was told and had read reviews that the burger was vegetarian but I have my suspicions that it isn't. Although the waiter did not ask me how I wanted my burger, the patty looked red and like it was bleeding so combined with the taste, I was very confused but also very satisfied. 

See photo and judge for yourself. What do you think??
author: Hello E.

description:
Cockscomb is one of my TOP 5 FAVORITE restaurants in San Francisco. And I eat out a lot, so that's a big thing to say. Chef Chris Cosentino is a very gifted chef. His menu is thoughtful and his restaurant impeccable in both service and food. Every detail in the joint has a purpose - it's artful, and I appreciate that. 

What to Order:  
Drinks: Any of the cocktails - but the Chef's Gin Jams is a rotating cocktail based on season. Fresh homemade jam is made per season and it's delicious with the gin. The drinks are also named after movies from the Bay Area (lovely detail, no!?) Great bar program! 

Food: The "ham"burger is one of THE BEST burger in SF. It's pork, not beef, and please add the egg. The crispy potatoes are also excellent
Also, be adventurous and if you see intestine or tripe, order it. Chef Chris is a "use the whole animal" type Chef so take advantage of his talents and try something new. 
The Duck Fat cauliflower is also a crowd pleaser. 

Dessert: 
 If you did it right, you wont have room. But I have had a wide varoety and it's all good. So get something that sounds good if you have a second stomach. 

Stats: 
Service: 9.5/10 
Food: 10/10
Drinks/Wine List: 10/10
Atmosphere: 10/10 - Modern, warm, and fun - plus I love an open kitchen!
author: Hannah S.

description:
Wow. Pigs Head order in advance when you make your reservation.  
The menu changes the specials are daily.  This is an must hit place without trying to break your bank. But they can break the bank with the wine menu. And the menu they bring you. The one you have to ask for. 

Service is great.  They know service.  Food wow. Wow.  I'm by no means a foodie.  I just like to eat. This place is Wow.  Great gem.
author: Michael G.

description:
Food is unique and presentation is extravagant. For example, we order one special dish that was lobster with pork belly and bok choy. Someone else at our table order a pigs head, that was so soft and savory. I was literally eating the pig's snout lol. 

Not as much of a fan of the prices. The lobster dish was $190. The pigs head was $155. Sure, these are dishes that can be shared by 4-5 people, but they also charge $9 for a small plate of cauliflower. I've always believed that significantly marking up prices solely because of your location is not a sustainable business strategy -- sooner or later people figure out that it's not worth the money.

However, gotta give props where props are due -- they were able to get us a reservation for 13 people the same night we called in. We salute you!
author: Vasiliy M.

description:
Jorge was our host/server, and one of the best we've come across. We had a splendid meal with his help and recommendations.

The bacon was the best quality that we have had in the city (my wife and I have eaten at a lot of high end places, and we love bacon). Must try!

The French onion soup was also spectacular. It's got some stiff competition with Absinthe, but I prefer Cockscomb's soup because it has less salt and the cheese is just right.

Finally, if you're looking for a place to try the Impossible Burger, this is where you need to go!

Everything on the menu looks delicious and I'll continue to come back for the great food and service.
author: Gaurav B.

description:
Full disclosure. My buddy and I were on a recon expedition. We always eat out together with our better halves. But this weekend, both of our S.O.s were up North. 

So we headed to a spot that had great reviews but we'd never tried before. Overall, we were pleased with the drinks, the food, the vibe and the service. 

The menu is extensive but not overwhelming, and I felt like I had plenty of great options even though I don't eat pork. 

We both had martinis. And they were excellent. I even pushed them a bit with an old school concoction: a Martinez. You can find these all over SF, but only a few places deliver really great ones. I count Cockscomb among the few. 

The ambiance was great. Bustling but not rowdy. I saw lots of couples on "dates", and while my friend and I vowed to bring our ladies with us the next time, this is not necessarily a "date night endorsement." It just feels like there's too much life happening around you at Cockscomb for intimate banter. I would say fours the magic number for date night (two couples). Of course, if it's just you and one of your besties, your gonna be all right. 

I look forward to coming back to Cockscomb in a few months. It will be fun to see what's the same on the menu and what's new. And to have another great Martinez.
author: Victor H.

description: The food is very tasty and they usually have good options as chief's specials. It is a little bit pricey but it totally worth to give it a try if it's a special occasion or you need a nice place to enjoy with a large group of friends .
author: Ilker D.

description: Loved it. Loved the vibe, the aromas, and especially the food. Starting with mixed oysters, we then tried the crispy squid and pig ears (the grapefruit was a touch of genius in here), and the beef heart tartare (wonderful). Then onto the roasted pig's head, which was as much of an experience as we'd hoped - spicier skin than expected, from the peppercorn crust, but that was a bonus. It crusted the meat perfectly - so juicy and tender. More than two of us could manage, but the box to take it home kept us happy (and the dog) for another couple of days
author: Mike R.

description:
This place is a seriously bad@$$, off the grid, foodie junkie hot spot. 

Came here on a Saturday night with the GF for an 8:15p reservation...thank goodness for having that reservation, be sure to call in or book it via Yelp app!

We ordered the Pin Steak, gnocchi, cauliflower, and naturally some wonderfully paired wine that our server chose for us. 

Simply put, do yourself a favor...order the pin steak...don't even question it...nope who cares that it is $125....that's the price ya pay for 80oz's of pure blissful beef. I mean MELT IN YOUR MOUTH steak...however total upfront disclosure, we ordered medium rare and it was probably more on the rare side which I'm eh i wish it was more pink. Anywhoooo, moving forward into the gnocchi, gah, for real...yeah...it's like a little potato starch bomb of yum, don't need to say anymore aside that it puts yo mammas and grandmas gnocchi to shame. As for the cauliflower, it was really good, but could've used some more sear to it (personal preference). 

Nonetheless...let's talk about presentation...if you don't like attention well you're screwed, if you love attention then the pin steak is the meal for you...you will literally break necks as couples sitting near you will be like "oh wow that's yuuuuge" or you'll simply get awkward eye contact from your table mates. 

.......ok I'm done writing any more....if that's a boring or crummy write up/depiction of the place well then I'm sorry and you don't have to go here...go get that Apple bees esq steak or a five piece McNugget meal...but if it shined any light on this place then go...go and achieve level 5,000 triumph and food game status.
author: Conrad A.

description: Came here on a Sat night. Yes- pretty pricey, but actually decent servings! A bit hidden in the alleyway so hard to find unless you are looking for it. Nice atmosphere, good service. I got the pork and fennel sausage which was a pretty decent size! The dirty crispy potatoes as a side was huge and tasty! Very crispy indeed. I tried some of the steak which was good as well. Panna cotta for dessert- pretty solid. Drinks were good. Overall a good experience, not mind blowing- or actually super memorable, but good to try. Not sure I would go out of my way to come back but still a good time.
author: Vivian D.

description:
Wow!

Delicious food, a full bar, and the owner Chris is a super friendly guy.   We sat at the chefs table and everything came out looking amazing.   We strongly recommend the Bacon Chop - a pork chop with a pork belly attached, the pigs head, and the hamachi collar!

All food is tied to the SF experience!
author: Mark K.

description:
Amazing. Truly remarkable attention to flavor and presentation. 
Yelp really wants me to say more. I would only ruin your experience by trying to describe the wonderful food.
author: Rennie S.

description: I took my girlfriend here for dinner we were escorted upstairs to have drinks at the bar before we were seated at the high top bar that's right next to the kitchen. The food and service was INCREDIBLE, it was such an enjoyable night filled with great drinks and exotic food options (for me atleast!). I had the pasta with shaved tuna heart on top of it and a over easy egg... IT WAS NEXT LEVEL. Definitely go here if you have the chance!
author: Jonathan H.

description:
Mark H is a vegetarian so we came to Cockscomb specifically for the Impossible Burger,  for a meatless patty, this was pretty mind blowing.

At the time, the restaurant didn't allow reservations for lunch so it was first come first served and with a only a limited amount of Impossible burgers per day, we knew we had to get here early and were first in line.  We chose to sit at the counter (which I always recommend) since you can chat with the chefs and watch the magic happen.  Seeing how the food is created and watching how efficient an establishment is is always so intriguing to me.

Getting to the burger, it really was unlike any other meatless burger I've had in the past.  It had the look and feel of actual ground beef, even the smell of the patty makes you think "beef".  There's a sear on the outside very similar to a beef patty and the pink interior is just like what a mid-rare burger would look like.  Being curious, i cut a piece of the patty and ate it separately and the texture is a bit different from a beef patty though; it's a bit more "mushy" but not off-putting at all.  Eaten as a whole with the bun, fixings, etc.,  it made me think I was eating a real beef burger.  Pretty amazing.

The burger came with a spring mix salad which was tasty.  We also ordered the house potatoes with aioli which was also tasty.  Nice, light crunch on the outside with a nice "creamy" potato interior.  It was a good sized bowl so we ended up not finishing it all.

I don't get to the city as much as I used to but will hopefully be back here for dinner.
author: Mark Y.

description: Amazing! The food, chefs, staff, and experience were all amazing!! Highly recommend the octopus and pineapple dessert.
author: Elisha V.

description:
Love!! 4.5/5 stars!!!

Went here around lunchtime to grab a bite with a coworker. Loved the ambiance: very cool/ hipster/SF. We were seated at the high-top tables, which I wasn't a huge fan of because we weren't facing each other.. but was pretty cool to see the chefs cook. 

Food was amazing! We of course had to try the "impossible burger". As a vegetarian/pescatarian of 7 years, this was definitely the closest thing I've had that tasted like meat. Legit looked like a bloody patty..to the point that I actually got squeamish looking at it. The taste was pretty good - would recommend everyone try this burger at least once! 

We also ordered the bruschetta, which was AMAZING. Honestly, everyone needs to order this. The order was HUGE, and luckily we were splitting it, because it is a meal in itself. 

It is on the pricier end, but honestly worth the quality of the food!

Service was super friendly, and surprisingly quick.. which we were thankful for as we were on our lunch break. Would love to come back at a time outside of working hours as the drinks looked GOOD.
author: Natalie F.

description:
Went on a Friday night and made a reservation through Yelp Reservations. Our table was ready right when we arrived.

Was a perfect place for a cozy Friday date night. The service was top notch, our server was excellent and recommended some amazing dishes. She was attentive the entire night, and always made sure we were good on drinks. 

I would have to say the food highlights were the grilled cheese (trust me!), the gnocchi and the steak. 

Awesome cocktail menu too!
author: Morgan W.

description:
Observations:

Cold atmosphere. The husband and I sat at the counter close to the wood burning oven and still felt chilly the entire time.

Wait staff was very attentive, no complaints there.

Overly salty. Every last thing we ordered -gnocchi, impossible burger, salmon tartine. Everything could have benefited from some acid and less butter. (and I LOVE BUTTER).

About the impossible burger itself: I've now had it in several places, and the ones that are best are the ones that are cooked rare and with condiments that cut through the richness of the fat meant to stand in for the "juice" of a beef burger. This was cooked well, so turned out rather dry, and didn't have the benefit of the right condiments to round out the mouthfeel and taste. 

Sitting at the bar/counter area meant watching the cooking happen. What was a bit awkward was that the part of the counterspace they used for laying out finished dishes was the same as the prep counter - which meant I ate my meal staring at a large platter of uncooked chicken. A bit unappetizing to say the least.

Won't be back.
author: Archana P.

description: Our favorite restaurant in San Francisco. If you want properly prepared meat and great pot pies and fatty pig parts, come here. If you want something horrible, go elsewhere suckers!
author: Nam N.

description: I like anything involving the word "cock", so I can unequivocally say I enjoyed being here and ramming offal into my mouth.
author: Suany W.

description: Food was on point! Loved the heirloom tomatoes.  Incredibly fresh. Bacon chop was amazing and the hot mess( foie gras) was on point. Only disappointing dish was the fish. They are clearly much more of a meat shop. Place also does get pretty loud with many big groups. We ended up having to shout to have conversations so just keep that in mind!
author: Carrie T.

description:
I don't think I have ever devoured as much steak as I did during this meal. My friends and I had reservations which got us seated very quickly. 

Service: 
Our waitress was amazing and was very helpful. I must say that they have A LOT of specials and she word vomitted all of them onto us. All I could remember were how much each one was but I do admit that they rehearsed the specials over and over again. There are some items on the menu that can be in half orders too! Just ask your server and they will tell you! Besides that, she was very attentive and helpful in our whole experience. 

Food: 
Pin Bone Steak (A Must Try) - Don't let the price of this steak deceive you because the size of it compensates for it. Coming in at almost 4 lbs of bone-in steak, it will cost. Think about it... this is shareable from 3-5 people so it would be worth it for some great quality meat. It comes with au jus sauce and bone marrow dip. The bone marrow dip is to DIE for and a bit salty so it adds a lot of flavor. OH! DO NOT FORGET THIS. The steak comes out REALLY rare so please let your server know to cook your meat more. I couldn't eat a lot of it because it was so raw. She did not ask how we wanted it cook. Also, it comes with potatoes so don't order it as a side. 
Cauliflower - We needed a vegetable and that was quite delicious. 
Gnocchi - I've never had gnocchi before but I thought these ones were amazing. 

I came with 2 friends and we were stuffed from this meal. We had a lot of steak leftover so I think this is most definitely shareable among 4 people along with some sides. I would most definitely come back to this restaurant and try the other things.  Oh, only reason I didn't do the 5 stars was because our server did not tell us the steak would come out so rare. I like my meats medium.
author: Leanne P.

description: Awesome good and fun atmosphere!!! This is the prefect place if you have a big party, wanna come for a great happy hour or if you coming just a couple friends. There are amazing shared suppers and other appetizers and entrees. The seafood is always fresh and the food is always tasty!! I come here pretty often and it never disappoints. The sides often get overlook and they are absolutely delicious! Cockscomb is a must visit if you are a food lover and adventurous. There are some fun things to try! The staff is also great and has a fun ambiance! The only thing is that it can get a bit loud. Highly recommend!
author: Andrea W.

description:
So my trek to the city was to try the infamous Impossible Burger for brunch. I came to Cockscomb expecting amazing food and was extremely underwhelmed. I had a few friends tell me that they had "meh" experiences but I wanted to give it a try for myself. Sure enough, the food and experience was "meh" at best. 

I had the Impossible Burger and the Fried Chicken sandwich which were both severely over salted. I sat at the counter and watched the chef take a handfull of salt and throw it on the patty and I thought to myself "this can't end well". The impossible patty itself still tasted like a veggie burger (a lot of soy in it) - with all the R&D dollars, I was expecting a lot better. However, the patty isn't the restaurant's fault and I think it's cool that they carry it. The seasoning and preparation of the burger, however made the burger a lot worse than it is (I also tried the Impossible Burger in NYC and it was a lot better). The chicken sandwich, which I thought was practically impossible to mess up was also extremely salty and the bun was stale and cold. The sandwich had no structural integrity and it was one of the worst fried chicken sandwiches or burgers I've ever had.

My experience at Cockscomb was terrible to say the least, the only redeeming factors of this place is their service and their decor is nice (but their restrooms were filthy). If you want to try the Impossible Burger I'd recommend going elsewhere since they ruin such a unique and revolutionary product.
author: Kimberlie L.

description: nice restaurant! We ordered a dozen of oysters, daily fish and steak here. All of them turned out to be flavorful. Moreover the waiter is very attentive. will definitely come back and try other dishes.
author: Roger Z.

description:
Man oh man, I love Cockscomb. Such incredibly creative meat dishes that focus on cuts and pieces that are often overlooked or not considered 'typical' in the restaurant world, and all prepared exquisitely. 

We came by for an early dinner on a Friday night, and were able to get in with last-minute reservations. This place does fill up quite fast, though, so I do advise booking ahead. Together, we feasted on (and packed in to-go bags once we were stuffed silly):

+ WATERMELON & MINT SALAD w/YOGURT, LIME & HARISSA 
A match made in heaven, and, by the way, PERFECT to help cut the fat/grease from all the meat you're about to consume. Beautifully presented, too.

+ BEEF HEART TARTARE w/GREENS & GRILLED BREAD
Another knock-out dish, shared perfectly between 3 people with more to spare

+ WOOD OVEN ROASTED PIGS HEAD w/GREENS, SHALLOTS & CAPERS
This was breath-taking. It's not meant for 3 people, but we sure did our best (and took a lot home with us afterwards). The bitter salad accompanying it was perfect to help cut all the fat again. This is really a showstopper of a dish, I absolutely loved it (even if I could only eat a few bites at this point!).

+++ BAY LEAF PANNA COTTA w/STRAWBERRIES, BALSAMIC & BLACK PEPPER. 
We were stuffed from dinner, but this just sounded so incredible, I had to order it for our table to share. Another perfect palate cleaner after the heavy but delicious dinner we had, and probably one of my favorite desserts I've had this year. Well worth the extra calories!

The only 'meh' moment of our evening was our server, who seemed to have a chip on his shoulder. When we asked if there were any specials for large groups, just wondering, he said it wasn't worth his time telling us since we wouldn't order it. He kind of ghosted our table the whole time we were there, and when we tried to find him to pay and asked another server for the bill, he popped up behind us and was incredibly exasperated that we deigned to not wait indefinitely for him to come back. 

It was such a lovely meal otherwise, and the rest of the staff was friendly, so I'm pretty sure that was a one-off. I definitely plan on returning here!
author: Claire S.

description: I would like to first point out that, this has been my first time actually "fine- dining" and going out in quite a few years. So if my review seems more up skewed, there's a slight reason why haha. Anyways! I've never heard of this place, my best friend chose this place and the location itself is hidden in an alley way. Very dark atmosphere as you enter, make reservations- we came on a Saturday evening around 8pm. The waitress was really nice and answered all of  our questions promptly. We went with the board as an appetizer/ starter and the presentation was so pretty! to be honest, i dont even know what was on that plate, i just ate it haha. It was good though. I do wish they had a different type of bread with it, but it wasn't bad! I liked the pickled vegetables and the prosciutto. The waitress constantly checked up on us and refilled our glasses with water. for our main course, we ordered the 28 day aged dry bone in steak- shared between 4 people. Let me tell you. It was HUGE and so good. I went for the pieces in the inside which were more rare. It comes with this really good XO sauce on the side to pour and vegetables cooked with it. Overall, the experience was great!
author: Audrey K.

description:
For the value Cockscomb is one of most disappointing I've experience. 
 Even more so because I was entertaining visitors that I had hoped to impress w SF's food scene - not a good representation.  The squid/pig ear was soggy & cold; the octopus was simply tasted salty & also luke warm; and the lobster/pork chop combo at $100 was uninspiring.  Panna Cotta was good though.  For the expense try Marlowe's just around the corner - you'll have a better meal.
author: Jasmine T.

description:
Great experience. I had been waiting to try this place and as not disappointed. We ended up there on a night when the restaurant was booked for a function,  it the staff kindly called us ahead of time and let us know we could come as long as we used the chef's counter. This was great as we could see the cooks work. Food was great, the staff was very nice.

I will make. A point of going back every time I am in The Bay Area. The proximity to the Caltrain station makes it easy to come even when staying in Silicon Valley
author: Christian v.

description: WOW this place flew under my radar for far to long. Came for my birthday and it was dish after dish of intrigue, excitement and unique takes on meat!
author: Morgan S.

description:
Excellent food in a very tony setting.

Waiting outside for a table, I felt like we were trying to get into an exclusive, trendy club. Fortunately, the food delivered on quality. My vegetarian buddy and I ordered a couple Impossible (aka "Ham") Burgers, beers, and home fries, all of which nailed it.

The bun for the burger almost managed to stay together towards the end, but what good burger doesn't eventually fall apart in your hands? I also liked the gruyere & mustard toppings; it's a flavor combo I sometimes employ at my own BBQs, unless somebody insists on ruining it with ketchup. One note on the Impossible Burger, which isn't really an indictment on the restaurant: my guts were pretty... active the following 24 hours. Stick to well ventilated areas after eating this thing ;)

The home fries, I dare say, were even better than the burger. Crispy on the outside and fluffy in the middle, just perfect. The bill was about 4x what I usually pay for lunch on a work day, but I regret nothing.
author: Carlin F.

description:
Came here for weekday lunch with a former coworker. Our main goal was to try the Impossible Burger, but we ended up ordering a lot more food. We ended up with the seafood chowder, 2 Impossible Burgers, pig's ears, duck fat cauliflower, and house potatoes. 

The chowder had plenty of yummy seafood, though it was a little thin for me. The pig's ears were thinly sliced and crispy (yummy). The potatoes resembled patatas bravas, which I will not complain about. We decided to order cauliflower, so we fulfilled our veggie requirement for the meal/day. Those were quite good. 

Now, for the star of the lunch, the Impossible Burger. I was very excited to hear that Cockscomb served it during lunch. I am a huge fan of beef burgers and fries. I would eat it every single day if I could and not die early of heart disease or something. The Impossible Burger was disappointing. I really don't like mushrooms and the burger tasted very strongly of mushroom. The burger was juicy and there was a bit of a sear on it. But to say that the Impossible Burger tastes like a normal beef burger? That is simply not true. 

The food for the most part was good, and the service was good as well. I think I will be back, but not for the Impossible Burger.
author: Carolyn Z.

description:
I didn't actually have high exceptions for the this place, but everything we ordered was really good. The steak and sides were my favorite. 

TOMBO CRUDOMexico city style, agua chile, corn nuts, cilantro & tortillas-raw tuna and the flavors were great and fresh

BEEF HEART TARTARE grilled bread & greens-got scared cuz it said beef heart, but it taste just like regular beef tartar. Also it had a little bit of smokey flavor to it. 

BACON CHOP apples, brusselskraut, charred onion & sage-porklchop cooked perfectly

PIN BONE STEAK 28 day dry aged, bone marrow dip & seasonal vegetables-this was massive and cooked perfectly. It comes with potatoes also. I like the cute cow gravy holder it comes with. The sauces are yummy. 

"DIRTY" CRISPY POTATOES pickled peppers & country ham pure-one of my top potato dishes I've ever had. 

MUSHROOMS A LA GREQUE garlic, lemon & parsley-love my shrooms.

DUCK FAT CAULIFLOWER chili, garlic & mint-need veges in my life and it was delicious

There was some hot mess dish with meat and foie gras-can't go wrong with foie, but this dish was very heavy

Also they had clams on the menu-they were big and juicy. 

We def over ordered for 4 people, but we killed it. I was stuff for days. Portions are big and place is pricey, but excellent food!
author: Karen H.

description:
A night to remember!! The food here is AMAZING!! 

I ordered the squid and melon appetizer -- so delicious and TBH, I've never had an appetizer with the combination of squid and melon.  The nuts and the sauce (can't figure out what the sauce is made of and I really want to know what it is) really complimented both those items.  For the main course, I also ordered a pin bone steak with foie gras (3 pieces) & the duck fat cauliflower. It was super pricey for the steak and foie gras ($185) but SOOOOO WORTH IT. I would definitely reorder the pin bone steak with foie gras again. The duck fat cauliflower is tasty as well.  it was not too salty and the cauliflower was still crunchy and not overcooked. 

It was my friends birthday and I had put it in the reservation but no one really mentioned anything about her birthday.  At the end of the dinner, they surprised my friend with a birthday pudding and candle.  We were really surprised and full, but still enjoyed the complimentary dessert.  :) YUM!

I wished I came here with more friends so that I can order more and try more dishes!
author: Esther A.

description:
Made a reservation for 5 24hrs in advance with no issues. The entrance is on the side street just followed the neon sign. Downstairs there was a large bar and dayshift table type area. The hostess seated us on the second level. The restaurant was busy but they were still tables were available. The noise level was very high for the amount of people that were there. The atmosphere was like an old speakeasy, rustic,cute decorations, modern Art, and old style light bulbs. 
The waiter told us about the specials and then we decided to get the foie gras, "hot mess", cauliflower as an appetizer, some bread that we had to actually pay for, Black ink calamari, steak, and the lobster bake in chop dish.

Basically we give this restaurant 2-3 stars because every dish was Very salty. The steak was salty and chewy. It was served with a side of Vietnamese fish sauce/Bone marrow reduction. Did I mention salty?! We had a lot of the steak leftover and did not took it togo. 

The wait staff were very friendly and accommodating so that's why we gave three stars. If they have a menu change we will definitely try this place again.
author: Mellie M.

description:
This is a very interesting place. A meat lovers dream with steak, lamb and pig. I was here for a company party and it was a perfect venue for a large crowd. We shared large platters of different dishes. The Lamb and Octopus was my favorite, the Octopus being the better of the two.  The Cauliflower with Ducks Fat and Brussels Sprouts were really delicious.  
  They lost a star because we asked if they could bring out a little more steak that was well done and they brought out a plate that was entirely fat. I mean there was not one little piece of meat, nothing but white grossly fat - that was wrong. They also lost a star because it was so loud you had to yell in order to talk. They put three large parties in one room and it was crazy loud. Other parties would be trying to give a speech while we were talking loud.  
  I wish there were a little more choices on the menu to break up the meat dishes. I will probably go back though so I can try this place in a less hectic setting.
author: Ken A.

description:
I love Cockscomb! They take their protein very seriously (high quality, sustainably and humanely raised) and they don't shy away from bold flavors, which are both huge pluses in my book.

Candice G. describes Cockscomb perfectly: this is where you eat like a Dothraki. Pure bliss as long as you don't limit yourself. 

My friends and I came here on a Wednesday night during dinner peak hours. You'll need to make a reservation because the restaurant gets packed even on week nights. That being said, I made an online reservation the night before, so you won't don't need to plan months or weeks ahead like other restaurants in the city (perhaps you do for a weekend or Friday night reservation).

First off, I love the decor of the restaurant. Very rustic furniture, big wooden tables, marble and comfy chairs, with an open kitchen that smells amazing against the cool brisk SF weather. They offer delicious cocktails, including my favorite gin and tonic (with fresh strawberry purée)! They offer sparkling or tap water, or both! Their open bar is pretty amazing with more cocktails than I had time to drink.

For those of you who haven't been here, Cockscomb is known for big plates New American-Italian style, to share over good conversations with old friends. The portions are meant to be family style and usually my friends and I wouldn't have it any other way. Their menu is decided into: 7 categories (wine and cocktail on separate menu):

"oysters and shellfish"
"cured and raw" 
"starters and salads" 
"terrines" 
"shared supper"
"offal and butcher's cut" 
"daily requirements". 

Daily requirements are side dishes usually vegetables that is cooked in glistening animal fat. Honestly? I wanted to order and eat everything on the menu. Realistically? I'm coming back for more.

Between my friends and I, we ended up ordering too much food but that is usually as expected haha. The pig hearts were delicious! Definitely bigger, more tender and flavorful than I had thought. For starters, we shared the medium seafood platter of oysters ($48), Tombo crudo (hamachi crudo with interesting Asian inspired textures), pig skins with anchovy, olives and capers (this was amazing!). Both the smaller starters were $16 per.

For family supper slash big meat, we shared the beef heart tartar ($16), which was so interesting! Meaty, gamey with delicious marinade for the red meat offal. Their special of the night was a huge Wagyu T-bone shared supper. It was huge and smelled amazing. However, having recently returned from Japan where we had prized Wagyu and matsuzake beef, this was far less tasty and did not taste like Japanese Wagyu. While it was around $130, it wasn't nearly as good as what we had in Japanese because this was probably American Wagyu, another breed. It's also to be expected because even Wagyu in Japan is $$$ for a just few strips! Overall, it was still a delicious steak, superior to most I've had in America.

As for vegetables, our daily requirements were roasted duck fat cauliflower, crispy "dirty" potatoes, broccoli di ciccio and mushroom a la greque. All were delicious, well cooked and paired well with our rustic dinner bounty. Each daily requirement ranged around $7-9

For dessert, which we amazingly made room for, we shared the chocolate torte and another dessert which I don't remember anymore, other than they were tasty but were not mind blowing.

Overall, great meal that is a pricey but nevertheless worth the splurge and experience! It's always a lot of fun to share a huge spread of mouthwatering food, family style, which Cockscomb is great for! Worth a return! The only regret I have was having not taken much photos of our meal bc it was too good!

FYI, Cockscomb also does a New Years'
Special tasting or meal package. It is definitely on the $$$$ side, however I heard it's delicious. My friends went last year and shared 4 boxes of lobsters with claws the size of a novel for us to try!
author: Jenny Z.

description:
More hype than substance. In summary, you're paying for a Mercedes Benz SUV, but walkout w/ a Toyota 4Runner or Rav4. You can decide for yourself. Still good, but not great, especially for the price point. Came here around 9PM on a Saturday. Great atmosphere. Very friendly & attentive staff. An adequate variety of options on the dinner menu and there are daily specials not listed. Good selection of beers I'll say. 

We got the gnocchi. 8 pieces for $9. Conclusion = waste of $9. Nothing wrong with them but I felt like I was just eating uncooked pizza dough covered in olive oil. 

Got the special waygu ribeye with dirty crispy potatoes and roasted corn. The corn was very good and had great flavor. The crispy potatoes were crunchy but not burnt and had the roasted pepper flavor. Sides were great. The waygu ribeye, which was the centerpiece of the dinner, was a huge disappointment. The waygu ribeye (see picture below) can easily feed 2-3 people. I would say two. It was priced at around $160. For that price and all the hype I heard, I expected more. 

The steak was plated nicely in that it was on a huge wood board and overwhelmingly showered with peppers & potatoes. It was as if they were trying to hide something...the disappointment perhaps? It was all show. The few inner strips of the steak were cooked well, but the outer strips and edges were under-cooked and resulted in being very chewy. The steak itself was not hot/warm and borderline cold. Outside of the basic salt and pepper seasoning, this had nothing else. 

I understand sometimes you just want to savor the steak itself; however, for $160 and all the hype, in addition to the steak being unevenly cooked & cold, this steak was a miss. For a restaurant to be known for its meats, they failed to deliver. What we received was merely presentation and quantity rather than quality. The meat/steak is a chef's/restaurant's canvas and what you do with it, separates you from the rest. The end resulting canvas can be found at TJ Maxx HomeGoods. Nothing wrong there, I shop there. I don't believe they did anything different to separate themselves from any other restaurant or warrant the premium prices.

I wouldn't come back here again not because the food was bad, but mainly because you're overpaying for the quality you get. I wouldn't put this on the blacklist of restaurants because they definitely do some unique things that I don't consider to generally be offered elsewhere, such as pig ears, beef heart tartare, and duck. So come check it out for yourself, but you've been warned.
author: Michael K.

description: I had all of the veg options - incredible salad, gnocchi, and veggie sides. Great service. Fun vibe. Fabulous cocktails.
author: Vicki L.

description: Good food, great wait staff, terrible host. Very rude gentleman took my reservation over the phone and actually hung up on me before I could finish asking him my questions. Showed up and the same guy was under dressed and still had a bit of an attitude. The food, wine, and waiter made up for our party's experience!
author: Julian C.

description: Took my carnivorous husband to Cockscomb for his birthday last week - I had been wanting to try it for a while and it did not disappoint! Love the industrial/farm animal design and it was energized on this Friday night. We ate upstairs, which I really liked - it's a noisy restaurant (are there any in SF that aren't?) and the smaller upstairs room is a little less so. Plus I like the big windows with the early evening light pouring in. I'm a sucker for a place where everyone seems super happy to be there and Cockscomb is that kind of place. We started with the tombo crudo - deliciously spicy, and the kale and butternut squash salad - perfectly dressed. I chose the roast chicken, not being as much of a red meat type as my husband and it was yummy - parsnips and escarole, crisp, flavorful chicken - some left over to take home, too. My husband had the coulotte steak with bearnaise and pronounced it "perfect!" Added a side of mushrooms a la greque and we were very happy campers. Since it was a birthday dinner, we also shared a delicious chocolate concoction that was just the right size. Our waiter, who was on point and funny all evening, pointed to the pineapple dessert on the table next to us when reciting the choices and said "THAT is great to order if you're here with a group, but ordering that for two, I would call a suicide attempt!" Nice wine list, great cocktails, REALLY fun, friendly, and knowledgable staff - all in all a wonderful evening and a memorable meal!
author: Lisa W.

description: I wasn't super hungry so I got the grilled cheese and the chicory salad, and I can't get over how good both of those were days later.  A grilled cheese and salad might sound simple, but the sandwich had the best cheese, a nice duck egg, and was doused in some of the tastiest honey I have ever had.  I would love to know what honey they use.  The salad had the best dressing and flavor, you just can't beat the freshness of vegetables on the West coast.
author: Susie D.

description:
Best damn scallop I've ever had
Lil overpriced
Damn good food
If I lived in San Fran would not frequent this place, its too uppity for me personally...but like I said the food was delicious!
author: 2 Birds One Stone T.

description: I LOVE COCKSCOMB!!! One of my favorite restaurants in SF. I went here on a date w/ my bf one night and I love the ambiance of the place. It's very intimate and the kitchen is right near the seating area. We got their special duck for two. I think about the duck almost every day because it was so good. They also have happy hour 1$ oysters from 5-6pm and 10-11pm every day. I recommend the duck!
author: Amy C.

description: Holy cow this place is amazing. My husband and I are adventurous eaters and this menu catered to that. We tried the beef heart tartare which was so tender and beautifully seasoned. Then we tried a dish called the "hot mess" that was made with pigs feet. I'm not normally a fan of anything so gelatinous, but they paired them with fresh cranberries that cut through the fat so perfectly! This is a must if you like to try new things (and aren't afraid of something a little out of the ordinary)
author: Stephanie H.

description: Everything was soo soo good.  We got the calamari and pig ears as an appie - although we were a bit hesitant to order, it turned out to be delicious.  We also got the scallops and wagu steak - and both were out of this world! Cocktails were pretty delicious too! Definitely going back for the pigs head!
author: Lourdes Q.

description: Stopped by for a quick glass of wine, on our way to CalTrain. The upstairs bar has a great view of the chefs working in the kitchen below. We told the waiter we'd split a glass of the happy hour red. He returned with two healthy poured glasses. I ordered a half dozen of the raw oysters ($1 each), they were fabulous. Excellent service, ambience, and value.  We will definitely be back.
author: Ron C.

description:
Took my girlfriend here for our anniversary at the beginning of March. Top 3 meals of my life (it's hard to pick just one). We arrived a little early for our reservation, they accomodated us right away which they didn't have to do, and we got the BEST SEAT IN THE HOUSE, right in front of the grill and oven at the counter. We ended up ordering entirely specials, which were to die for. 

App was trotter w/ foie and fuji apples. Simply amazing, pure umami to start the dinner. Could have split it four ways and been just as satisfied. The girlfriend had never had foie before, so it was special from the get go.

Main was a 14oz American Wagyu w/ sea scallops and XO sauce. Amazing. Steak was done to the perfect doneness (rare, like they just walked it by the grill) and the scallops were the best I've ever had. I must also note that the specials menu was amazing all the way down. 

Dessert was a Sous Vide pineapple with sorbet in the shell, also amazing. They pull a better shot of espresso than most restaurants, even nice ones.

All in all, not the cheapest place on earth, but a lot of fun eating, super creative menu, and a really casual environment, not stuffy at all. Will definitely be back
author: Dom S.

description:
Came here specifically for the impossible burger.. the vegan burger that bleeds. There are only two places in the bay that have it and cockscomb is one. 

We made reservations for 2 at 12:30.. they only open from 11-2 for lunch so make sure you make reservations. It's a small cozy little restaurant that fits maybe 40 people. We got a front seat at the counter top where all the cooks are so it was pretty cool to see the process. 

The impossible burger starts off bright pink on the griddle and once done, stays pink in the middle and perfectly charred on the outside. Comes with mustard, cheese and pickles and a side of salad. Pretty good and different from other vegan burgers. A must try even for those who aren't vegan. 

Also, don't skip out on the house potatoes. Wow. Just wow.
author: Christina H.

description:
Yesterday my family and I had the most horrible experience here. Utter lack of simple compassion of staff towards a family with a baby says a lot about the attitude of this place towards its customers. 

We had reserved a table for 3 of us with a high chair. My baby fell to sleep right before we got there and was sleeping in her stroller. They didn't want us to keep the stroller next to our table and despite us reiterating that our baby is in deep sleep in the stroller, we can't / wouldn't want to take her out of her stroller, we were being asked to do so. This gentleman from their staff, who must be in his 50's was so boisterous and arrogant to us about it. He was least concerned with making us comfortable in any way. He didn't even care if the baby was sleeping and just kept on insisting that you take the baby out and park your stroller in one end of the restaurant. 
My dear "Chef Chris Cosentino", just good food doesn't run a place. I wish your staff was as passionate about serving their customers as well as you are towards serving great food.


#notkidsfriendly #rudestaff #chefChrisCosentino #Cockscomb
author: Parul V.

description: Amazing and unique food. We had the special, which was a de-boned half chicken... It was some of the best fried chicken we'd ever had! All the sides and appetizers we're amazing also. A bit expensive, but well worth the money.
author: Stanley L.

description:
I have not been this excited about a restaurant in I don't know how long. The menu just sang out to a crazy carnivore. Luckily I had a friend in town which finally gave me an excuse to have dinner in the city.

First off, Steven, the manager, is a lovely and welcoming guy. Our waiter Michael was also great, patient and Lord how does he memorize all those specials????

We had the Beef Heart Tartare which was wonderful. I had never had beef heart, tasted like beef tartare ;) But super tender.

My friend had the Culotte steak, done to perfection the sauce was to die for! I had to try the calamari and pig ears. OMG what a dish. Insanely good! No I mean really good! Who thought the combination was so right??

Was very hard to choose dessert, we did one of the chocolate cremaux that had a thin cookie on top that you smashed like a creme brulee. Sooooo good!

The bill for what we had was lower than expected and we enjoyed every sec! I will be back with my husband because he's super jealous ;)
author: Donna G.

description:
I've been wanting to check out Cockscomb's lunch menu for quite some time and finally had the chance to hit it up this week. I've been to Cockscomb for dinner and was really impressed with the fare/cocktail program but, this review is for lunch and more specifically, the meatball sandwich. 

Per the bartender's recommendation, I ordered the meatball sandwich which was basic by nature. But...the fact that it was no ordinary meatball sandwich is the reason I'm giving this a five star review. The provolone cheese, house made marinara and roll all worked in unison for an incredible lunchtime jam. I'm assuming there were multiple types of meat in the meatball but, it was tough for me to place. No matter, it was bomb. 

Cockscomb, I'll be back for more lunchtime sessions.
author: Benjamin F.

description: What a fun place!  We arrived Saturday night and were very enthusiastically greeted by our server (I can't remember his name!), and given explanations of all the specials.  We had to go with the Hot Mess which was trotters and fois gras with pickled strawberries (which my husband still can't talking about), oysters from WA, the beef heart tartare (my favorite of the night), and the crispy squid and pig ear (the citrus was the nicest bit!).  The only miss for us was the roasted tomatoes, they were not quite as tender as  I had hoped.  We sat next to a couple that ordered the pig head, and wow that looked amazingly rich!  We will definitely be back, with a group so we can get some of the larger format items.  What a fun fun experience, sort of tucked into an area under construction, but definitely worth the Lyft.
author: Erika K.

description: Amazing! I haven't had a meal this exciting and delicious in some time.  The tuna collar was my favorite! I didn't want to ever leave. Saw this restaurant on TV (Andrew Zimern) and I am glad I found this gem!  Will
author: Norman F.

description:
Went here to celebrate a birthday (just the two of us) and literally ordered what felt like half the menu because we couldn't eliminate any of the choices we wanted, so we ended up taking so very much home with us.

Items from Menu 93 that we ordered...
Starters
A selection of 13 oysters and clams
Beef heart tartare
Squid & Melon
Chef's Special - Hot Mess Foie Gras
Supper
Wood Oven Roasted Pig's Head
Sides
Gnocchi
Trucker's Corn
Cocktails - a lot!
Dessert - some sort of blackberry chocolate cake

Best parts - the squid and melon dish was probably my favorite starter, even though I'm not a seafood person.  The flavoring was really great.  The Foie Gras just melted in your mouth and was also delicious.   (I wasn't a fan of the beef heart - tasted a little too much the way canned dog food smells.  I expected it to be more flavorful and it was really just wet meat.)

The Pig's Head (half of a head, actually) was well presented, from the ear down to the snout, teeth and all.  The skin was extra crispy and the cheek meat was so soft and tender.  Great amounts of yumminess - although by this point I was getting so full I could only have a few bites.

The sides were pretty good.  Would have ordered more but at this point, there was so much to eat, they wouldn't have been appreciated anyway.

The dessert was complimentary for the birthday celebration, and I really only remember the blackberries because they were huge and deliciously ripe.  By that point I couldn't even see straight I was feeling so full!  Worth every bite, and definitely worth every penny.  I wish I could have tried everything, but there was no way that could've happened!
author: Jes G.

description: My must do anytime I'm in San Francisco. Chris Cosentino is the king of Offal cuisine in California. If you don't like offal, they have plenty of other dishes. Food is always amazing every time I've been here. Some dishes my scare you do to the ingredients, such as beef heart, pigs head, or others. My advise, throw away your fears and let their staff guide you to a fantastic meal. Since their menus changes often, any dish I recommend now will be gone by the time you eat there.
author: Craig D.

description:
Absolutely waste of money! The food not only tasted stale but the staff was rediculously rude!
Went to this restaurant on some good review of people. Beware, don't trust the good reviews. There are plenty of good places in San Francisco. Stay away from this one. They have no manners of talking to guest, no freshness in food and staff is rude like hell.

Chef: you need to learn to listen to feedback. Staff: learn to respect staff.
author: Rishav C.

description:
We've been meaning to try out Chef Cosentino's new restaurant for a while now. Finally had the chance last night when we grabbed dinner before seeing a show.

tldr: wow this place is really good.

It's a good looking restaurant. It has a woody yet modern feel. Very welcoming and warm. It is deceptively spacious, with a sizeable upstairs room that probably doubles the size of the main floor. One thing that it is missing is a large bar. This isn't a great place to show up early and hang at the bar because there isn't much of one.

Service was wonderful. David knew the menu really well, answering questions and steering us into the right quantity of dishes.

Drinks were good, but the key here is the food.

The Hot Mess is a rich dedication to fois gras. 

The Bacon Chop is a huge pork chop served with peaches, dandelion greens, and onions. Quite simply the best pork chop I've ever eaten.

The Liberty Duck is a big meaty bird with a nice crispy skin. You can get a half order, which is a reasonable decision if you want to have a little variety at your table.

The Duck Fat Cauliflower is every bit as rich as you think it would be.

The Broccoli di Ciccio is the only thing we ordered that wasn't an unabashed success. The broccolini was cooked to a nice doneness, but I personally found a little too much char on it which dominated the flavor. But I loved the spicy pickled pepper rings that it came with.

For dessert we had a nice flourless chocolate cake (good, not amazing) and a wonderful panne cotta - light and cool and a little sweet. 

It's not a cheap meal, especially when you drink the way we did, but ~$100/person (including tip) doesn't seem unreasonable for this quality of an experience.

I can't wait to go back/
author: Jason G.

description:
INTRO
One of the best anniversary dinners ever. Talking to Chris who came to our table after dinner and talk about the origins of food and his desire to have Cockscomb be known as a SF Brasserie was great. It's not often you can have that type of conversation. He spent a good 10 minutes with us chatting and gave me some great restaurants to check out in my upcoming trip to Washington D.C. (You'll have to wait for my reviews to see what his favorites are there :-). 

Chris is a fantastic and down to earth person who loves food and sharing the experience. Thanks Chris for an amazing evening.

REVIEW
We walked in and waited at the bar ordering a great Amaretto Sour as a starter drink and had a great conversation with the bartender on gins and small distilleries (they serve some great locals such as St. George's from Alameda along with some other great local distilleries.

APPETIZER
For starters we ordered the special for tonight called "Hot Mess". This was a plate of seared fois gras and pig trotters set in a wonderful sweet berry sauce that offset the richness of the dish.
5 stars

Next was the Grilled Cheese with honey drizzle and fried duck egg with a wonderfully creamy yolk that I popped and poured over the dish. I then flipped over the white to cover the top and cut it up in bite size pieces for the table. The cheeses were oozing out of the bread like a river of cheese working it's way around the bread on the plate. This is a do not miss dish if you like GC and want it with a twist.
5 stars

MAIN COURSE 1
Duck, served with the most amazing grilled squash. This is not the typical green squash squash bit rather various types with mottled skin that tasted very much like sweet potato and regular potatos perfectly seasoned with just enough salt to mix with the sweetness of the squash. I was surprised how good squash can be if care is given to think about cooking it differently such as tonight.

The duck skin was crispy and the amount of duck meat was surprisingly large. This feeds 4 easily.  The duck meat was tender, we'll seasoned and set on top of some duck au ju.
5 stars

MAIN COURSE 2
Pin Steak serverd with bone marrow sauce! Oh yes you heard it right. This is a massive sirloin with bone, cooked and served from rare to med rare so everyone was happy. The meat itself was fantastically seasoned and could stand on its own.  However, after you pour the bone marrow sauce on it and take a bite you want to yell " THIS IS AWESOME!".

I have eaten tons of steak and a lot of bone marrow in my travels but bone marrow sauce poured on your steak? Yes it is WOW.
5 Stars

SIDE DISH
Dirty Potatoes which are slightly fried potato whole and pieces lightly salted with creme fraiche and sweet hot red peppers. The peppers add some nice flavor and slight heat to the potatoes to really give you something different than your usual potato dish. Crispy outside and a nice soft center made this a great starch to go along with the meat.
5 stars

DESSERT 1
Chocolate flourless cake with pistachio crumbles and chocolate ganache. A very rich and semi sweet cake that was excellent. Smooth as silk, and topped with a scoop of caramel ice cream, this dish was done in 30 seconds by the 4 of us.
5 Stars

DESSERT 2
Lemon olive oil cake with fresh citrus fruits (grapefruit, oranges). This was very refreshing and light.  The olive oil cake was perfect, great smooth texture, and extremely moist. The citrus juices soaked into the cake for a mouthful of flavors. If you want to go light in dessert this is a great option.
5 Stars

Cappuccino and Americanos were great. A nice layer of very thick and creamy foam topped our cappuccinos and the espresso was excellent.

TIP: We came for the pigs head but they were out. Chris told me you have to come early (we had 8:30pm reservations) or call ahead and let them know you want one as it varies as to how many heads he can get daily. 

I will definitely be back to order the bacon chop and pigs head to finish off the large main meat dishes on the menu.

An amazing evening and incredibly well prepared food. Our wait staff were fantastic, friendly and engaging.  Causal dining has been taken to a new level at Cockscomb.

5 STARS

Song of the review: The Scorpions, "Big City Nights"

Chris, you rock!
author: Jay G.

description: I saw this place reviewed on Andrew Zimmer's program so i had to go. I didn't love it, but i am sure I will go back and order differently. I was very impressed that they have their own hot sauce, but i didn't like it on the oysters - too smokey and overpowering. The salad was just okay and the gnocchi was way too oily. That said, I loved the atmosphere and i will examine menu more carefully next time.
author: Richard M.

description: First time here- got the gnocchi because I wasn't super hungry. It was INCREDIBLE. Like best gnocchi I've ever had. I was definitely hungry for more and did try a bit of my husband's burger which was absolutely on point. Cocktails were great as well! Would recommend!
author: Maansi D.

description:
Came here with my co-workers.  I was not super thrilled to eat here, to be honest.  I eat out ALL THE TIME.  I honestly just wanted a chicken breast and some broccoli.  

Regardless, I was able to enjoy the seafood platter (oysters, mussels, clams).  This is a MUST do.  Delicious.

We ordered the scallops with steak and the duck.  I'm not a duck person.  Scallops and steak were perfection.  Broccolini was soooo good.  I nearly ate the entire plate myself.  

Great drinks, good service.
author: Carrie B.

description:
Cockscomb is a dangerous place for me.  Why?  Because I love meat and the San Francisco Giants.  Both are expensive habits, so I try to ration my visits accordingly (but probably unsuccessfully).  So far, I've limited myself to special occasions to dine here (my wedding anniversary, the wedding anniversary for some friends, and to entertain out-of-town visitors).  

First tip:  come hungry.  The portions are fairly big, but you want to try a bunch of different items.
Second tip:  make a dinner reservation, even during the week.  This place always seems full, even on random Wednesday nights.  Chef Cosentino is a big name in the culinary world, so plenty of tourists flock here.
Third tip:  if you are looking for the "Impossible burger," it's only served at lunch.  No dinner options for this popular (and curious) meal.
Fourth tip:  even though meat is the big draw here, leave some room for dessert.  After all the savory flavors, some sweet treats at the end of the meal are always welcome.

Since the menu always changes, I will just highlight some of my most memorable dishes:

Pin bone steak:  one of the few non-rotating choices, it's listed under the "Shared Suppers" section.  And they are not kidding.  I've ordered this for parties of 4, and all 4 people need to be pretty hungry (and love beef) to finish this.  Served with a bone marrow dip, the steak is luxurious and food-coma inducing.  

Wood oven roasted pigs head:  always a head turner, this "Shared Supper" (also a menu staple) is not for the faint of heart.  The head of any animal is underrated by diners, with some of the most tender and flavorful meat inside the cheeks and neck of a beast.  The pig's head is no exception.  The skin was crispy from the oven-roasting and the meat among the most tasty I've ever had.  In addition, the dish is served with 2 different sauces on the side, both made from the pork "drippings."  My wife & I shared this at one meal, but we had a difficult time sleeping that night, since that meal was so heavy.  You have been warned.

Country pate:  Sometimes this is offered by itself, other times as part of the charcuterie platter.  But it's the best pate I've ever had.  The meat is not so finely ground, but chunky instead, served with some very crusty bread.  I've been tempted to pick up an order of the pate to go and walk into AT&T Park with it, eating this while watching a Giants game (which would be SO San Francisco of me!).

Butcher's Choice:  this is usually one of the daily specials.  My favorite so far has been an order of cow udder, served with escargot.  I've never seen cow udder on any menu, but I plan to get an order every time it's available.  Literally, the best bite I've had here!
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
Cockscomb had a great ambiance that combines a very modern industrial flare with a natural organic feel elements of decor. I got good vibes walking having high hopes for excellent food.

My only favorite item and highly recommend that you order is the grilled cheese. We ordered 5 items and it was the item I was least excited about ended up tasting the best. The bread and cheese ratio was the perfect balance. There was an extra flair of flavor added to the cheese that just made it that much more savory but what really impressed me and made the grilled cheese unique was the added honey! The marriage of this added ingredient was well thought out touch that made a grilled cheese become the life of the party.

I was not impressed with the Bacon Chop. The fat ratio of the chop was extremely unbalanced and the texture of the Chop was not even a texture you can chew. Also not impressed with the Dirty Potatoes that everyone raves about. The spice was a bit strong and the the size of the potatoes was not cut to a proportionate size to the flavor. I was confused with every bite! The Pig Ears were ok. You need to put the lime on or the texture is just too dry and you don't get the max flavor.

Our server Alicia was extremely attentive and pleasant which I appreciate and as that hard to find in SF. But the food overall was nothing good. I only truly enjoyed 1 out of the 5 items ordered.
author: Kevin C.

description:
I've been a big fan of Chris Cosentino since I tried Incanto a few years ago. I lauded him for pushing the comfort zones of diners by offering the parts of animals that we're unaccustomed to eating. Naturally, I was excited to try his newest restaurant iteration at Cockscomb a couple of days ago. Everyone from friends to online reviews suggested trying the pig's head. I was doomed from the start.

Now, I consider myself a relatively adventurous eater, but I just could not get behind this shared plate. Maybe it was expectations versus reality, but you literally receive an entire roasted pig's head sliced sagittally. What I expected was something similar to Peking duck; meat served with a thin layer of crispy skin with accompanying sauce and condiments. Instead, it was just fat, and more fat underneath. Perhaps the only enjoyable part was the ear. After a few bites, I felt sick to my stomach over the amount of fat it had. I felt like a kid from that island in the Lord of the Flies. I would probably eat that head in that situation - only while stranded on a deserted island. Otherwise, serve me the duck or steak.

Other than that abysmal main dish, the sides were average. I was neither too impressed by the sage gnocchi nor the duck fat cauliflower (of which was mainly stems). However, I did enjoy the starters including the grilled cheese with duck egg and honey and the beef heart tartare. It was a challenging meal to say the least, but I would return to try some of their other offerings.
author: Bailey Z.

description:
Like other reviewers, I also can't wait to go back.

Sat at the bar w/the bf last Thursday before seeing Ready Player One at Metreon (that review will be 1 star for Metreon). Watched chef and the kitchen work. Really fun. Smelled like it after.

3 Kettle's on the rocks with nice olives

Had 8 oysters - 2 each of what they had. Fantastic. Dang. I ate them by themselves cuz I like my oysters just with lemon but really enjoyed tasting the accoutrements by themselves. Incredible mignonette, hot sauce and avocado sauce. 

Kale salad - needed more dressing or some massaging. Delicious crunchy seeds.

Special entree - 14oz (I think) wagyu steak and 4 U10 scallops with a big grilled oyster mushroom steak. Giant portion. Delicious onions (3 kinds) and puree of something underneath. So much steak that we fried up the leftovers a couple days later and got a second dinner out of it.

$200 with tip

Can't wait to try more specials, house made meats, and more seafood!
author: Loren R.

description:
BAD only because it used to be so GOOD.
This place has steadily declined, hitting rock bottom on NYE 2017.
The food was paler than mediocre, zero flavor, the waitress RUDE (got a 10% tip - half of what we usually pay) and I literally got sick afterwards. This used to be 'our' restaurant. A guaranteed good night out. No more.
Why do so many San Francisco restaurants go downhill after only a few years? Complacency? Lack of Motivation? Whatever it is, we are very disappointed.
author: Niloufar M.

description:
Okay, because my brain still acts like its a pubescent teen, I was attracted to this restaurant mainly because of the name! And of course we chose this place for girl's night! *giggles*

They have a very simple menu, straightforward with easy choices. They serve oysters, charcuteries, salads, soups and  main courses with land and sea options.

I had the Atlantic Cod "Stone Soup" with fregola, squash, & walnut pistou. It was kind of a half soup, half fish entree as the fish sat onto of this broth with a generous amount of couscous. The broth was delicious, flavorful, and surprisingly not fishy. Fish was fresh, yet tender and flaky.

Spaghettini with cured Sardinian tuna heart and egg yolk was simple yet flavorful and scrumptious. I'm not sure what it was but it had this strong fresh herb-y taste that I couldn't pin point what it was but I loved it.

Evening Standard Meat Pie - beefy stew like interior with a whole hollow bone with its marrow melted into the soup so the beef flavor was very intense. Hot and hearty, perfect for winter nights. The flaky crust hanging over the side of the dish was perfect with the beefy broth.

The location is intimate, but could get fairly noisy and busy. The staff are attentive and nice, explained and described the menu very well. Definitely would come back!
author: Janny S.

description: Been here a few  times.  The most memorable dish is definitely the pig's head.  Be warned, it is a big fatty  with beautiful crispy skin with very rich flavors.  It is a delicacy and they did a great job executing the dish.  The bar seats are good option as it overlooks at the action in the kitchen.  More seatings upstairs of the loft is fun too it is a separate dining area with a few tables.  It is always crowded here and is a great option before a game.
author: Edmond T.

description:
This place reminded me of an old apothecary shop at a time when I was not born yet. 

I give this place 3 star because of very slow service. My husband's bread took about 20+ minutes to come out and when he finally got his eager fingers on it, the bread was disappointingly toasted, but cold. 

The chicken dish I ordered was okay. The bison or bull's head that hangs above the entrance door really creeped me out.
author: Irina R.

description:
Wow, I didn't know this place untilyelped! Another hidden gem in the neighborhood. 

Had lunch on a Friday there. Loved the SOMA crowd.  I didn't have high expectations on vegetarian option in American restaurant, the vegetarian burger was exceptional. Very tasty, definitely a gourmet option for meat eater, seriously. The beef tartare and smoked salmon are great too!
author: Shell J.

description: I visited here when it first opened and loved it. Great food, cool vibe to the restaurant. Recently went back and had one of the best meals I have had in a long time. We got the steak dish with some potatoes on the side. Damn was it delicious.
author: Melissa Z.

description:
This spot was our first Friday date nights, which was also a good middle between his work and the ballpark that we were headed to afterwards. We headed upstairs to their bar for the happy hour and made it with 15 minutes to spare before 6pm. We ordered 20 of their $1 oysters, Crispy Pig Ears ($3), "Dirty" Crispy Potatoes ($4), and the Shared House Punch ($30). Although I enjoyed the atmosphere of the restaurant, the service was lacking. Our bartender ignored us a couple times despite the fact that we were sitting at the bar directly in front of him. As for the food, it was okay at best. The pig ears were definitely crispy, but tasted quite mundane. As for the potatoes, they came out smelling absolutely amazing. But after biting into it, the insides of the potatoes were soft and lacked flavors. You have to eat it with the pickled peppers for a good spice and flavor, which was the best part of the dish. Lastly, the oysters were the most disappointing. They were tiny, sandy, and only came with the mignonette sauce (although we also asked for the house hot sauce). The mignonette had a hint of sweetness that I actually liked, but the oysters were just too sandy to enjoy. I was making sure I didn't swallow pieces of the shell or sand with each slurp.

We did get a good buzz off the punch bowl, which filled up four glasses for each of us. It was definitely made to be shared with four people, but we finished it. There was a lot of ice in it as well. Overall, pretty disappointed in the dinner, but left with a buzz that was enough for me to not really care either.
author: Cindy Z.

description:
Ridiculously good - from setting to service; food to drink - just amazing

Love the low key look of this place and decor. Service was outstanding from the start, from our friendly and personable waiter who gave great recommendations and was a pleasure to talk to - to every  member of staff that stopped by to check on us

Great selection of drinks - and amazing mocktails - my daughter enjoyed a rhubarb and  strawberry drink that was rather amazing - to simply killer food

Enjoyed super fresh selection of oysters, best crudo I have had anywhere -  period. My husband and daughter shared the bacon chop - the accompanying vegetables were delicious with a great smoke flavor,  and  I had the out of this world tuna collar. 

Sides were equally delicious - duck fat cauliflower, Bok Choy and gnocchi and then dessert - wow - Gordon Ramsey needs to stop touting his sticky toffee pudding as Chris Cosentino and his version is way, way better

Loved everything about this place
author: Sam P.

description:
This is a hidden little gem of a restaurant in the city. It's not exactly something you will see with a quick glance, but it's tucked away in a little corner. 

They specialize in raw foods, and very unique match up of meats. It really caught us off guard, but the pictures looked so good that we had to try it out. Service was top notch and the pisco punch drink was fantastic. Had to have two. 

The beef heart tartar, was perfection and paired with a mini salad and bread. The hamburger was also great, and the potatoes it came with worked very well. 

The place also has a buffalo head on display, so be weary those of faint hearts. Still, I really loved the place and suggest trying it out.
author: Benny H.

description:
Great time at Cockscomb! Pine Bone steak was massive but worth it. 
Really has a sort of Northern Italian influence on their menu, wine list, and staff as well! La Bella Costanza mamma mia lei e bellisima. Costanza is a great server and very easy on the eyes she's from Florence Italy.
