Coffee is really good here as well, random to say I know but try it. I go there on my lunch break sometimes just for coffee.
author: Devin S.

description:
Great spot! Well attended, lots of activity with an open kitchen. Great view from upstairs bar of the chefs at work. 2 witbiers, and shared cauliflower, potato sides and the beef heart tartare. Excellent dining experience.

Second visit 3-31-18 great date, had a great beer, they had an octopus special to share. I did really want to try the pigs head for 2 though. Next time I will call ahead!
author: Ben S.

description: For the love of all that is holy - order the caramelized chili pineapple with coconut ice cream. You can thank me later. :)
author: Amber D.

description: One of the best restaurants in SF. I crave their grilled cheese appetizer. Sounds like a simple item but it is everything but simple. Yummy x100!
author: Vita V.

description: Warning - this place is all about meat but you can find something to satisfy that veggie requirement. We started with the DD Hot Mess Appetizer and it was terrific. Entrees consisted of the Bacon Chop (grilled peaches, baby dandelion greens and charred onions), Grilled Chicken (basil, waxed beans, crème fraiche and crispy shallots) and Risotto with summer squash and basil.  Everything was excellent and we had no room for dessert (also, with the time change, it was 10pm before we sat down to eat). Managed to snag a beer that I have not had in the past (my goal is to taste more than 70 new brews during this vacation.
author: Dave W.

description: We came here for a date night and everything exceeded our expectations. Delicious food + cool ambience + really great service!
author: Kayla G.

description: Great ambience, solid meat dishes and absolutely charming staff. We celebrated a friends birthday at this place, highly recommended prior reservations.
author: Kirti K.

description:
Tried this restaurant while on a work trip.  A meat lover's dream.  I will say I got the squid and pig's ears.  That is clearly $19 I could've have kept in my pocket.  The pig ears sort of tasted like the hard rind part of uncured bacon.  

but my pork chop was to die for.  It tasted like steak.  It was BIGGGG and juicy and tender.  I don't see how anyone could eat the whole thing, but the waiter said some people do.  

My friend also enjoyed her chicken which came with panzenella that was tasty and delicious.  

What I would say is that this restaurant would be great with a group of 4 people willing to share huge meat dishes.  The family next to us ordered a steak that looked like meat heaven on Earth.  Good times.
author: Tiffany H.

description: We are so glad we came here for lunch on our last day in town. The staff is so so nice, informed and the service was perfect. My husband had oysters, pig ears, and tombo crudo. We shared the strawberry arugula salad and I had the fried chicken sandwich (which is huge, just my leftovers for breakfast) one tiny bite of a pig ear (picky eater here). I tried all the sauces for the oysters, the tomatillo sauce was really good with just the right amount of heat, as was the hot sauce, which just got siracha tossed off our shopping list, we bought a bottle. Everything we had was SO good, you must go!
author: M G.

description:
$70 for lunch? What? Came for lunch for an impossible burger. Food was decent, but wait time and service were HORRIBLE. 

- wait time: 30 minutes
- service: not friendly, not fast (server just walked away when she didn't want to answer a question.. lol what)
- seating: we were seated next to loud talkers, i couldn't hear my own thoughts. holy cow.


///////////////  Food (3.5 stars) 
- POTATOES (4 STARS): very crispy, reminded me almost of a patatas bravas.

- CEVICHE (4 STARS): fresh, liked how citrus and acidic the marinade was, though the chip it came with was too oily IMO. 

- IMPOSSIBLE BURGER (4 STARS): bf liked this and said it was very similar to real beef, including the fat. how it pulled apart was more like a vegan burger, but he enjoyed the burger itself and the bread it was served on.

- CHARRED BEETS (1 STAR): this came with a cheese that my bf and i smelled before my food was even served. We asked - what is that horrible smell? Smells like burnt dog poo. WELL? so happens to be served with the charred beets.

///////////////  TLDR: sure, the burger is worth coming for at least once. $70 for lunch is highway robbery IMO, particularly with places like SOMA eats (great fresh salads) and Takoba (great fresh raw food)
author: Kristie C.

description:
Came for Happy Hour and definitely left a happy camper! I thought I was going to settle for a drink and some oysters but got hungry and ended up ordering their happy hour special potatoes, which were amazing! The potatoes were crispy on the outside, soft and fluffy on the inside, with just the right amount of seasoning... (The drink and oysters were also great.) Overall the happy hour prices were pretty affordable for the area (most places are $$$).

Am excited to come back and check out their brunch/lunch/dinner offerings. Will update my review accordingly.
author: Isabella C.

description:
Sad to say this place has really gone downhill.  I used to love it for the meat lover dishes & the pig fries. I organize all my team meeting lunches and this place was a regular on my list.  Not anymore.  

Let me count the ways.
1. We were a group of 12 and they have a $35 minimum per person, which seems a bit steep. 
2. The pig fries were disappointing. Not crunchy at all like I remember, but kind of chewy in an almost stale way. They were bland and sprinkled with too much wilted cilantro. And they should be hot! Such a let down on one of their signature appetizers.
2. The special of the day was a hot fried chicken sandwich. It had no flavor or seasoning, and the chicken was drenched in grease. There was a jalapeno aioli on it but it was also greasy and flavorless.  Everywhere I looked, there was mounds of aioli on everything, even under the healthy tuna confit salad my coworker ordered. They need to take it easy on the aioli.
3. I ordered a arugula salad with strawberry.  It was wilted from the overdressing. Now c'mon when someone orders a salad, do you think they want it drenched in oil? It should be lightly dressed and cold and refreshing. We picked out the strawberries.
3. Our waiter insisted that the potato side was too small for 4 people to share and literally ordered enough for 20 people. It felt like he was taking advantage of the fact that we were a group. That is not cool. For comparison I had already ordered 3 of 2 different appetizers for our group of 12. He ordered 5 of the potato appetizer, even though it was quadruple in size.  WTH?

The Impossible Burger is the only dish that warrants the 2 stars.  Everyone who ordered it was really happy. It does indeed taste like a real burger.  Also, the potatoes were crispy and excellent, even though we had way too many of them.
author: Josie M.

description: Beautiful interior, great drinks and lots of delicious dishes. Their focus seems to be pork. And some of their popular dishes may require a larger group to share as it may be too much food for a smaller group of two or so. Only downside is they were serving fish that day as part of their menu, and it was difficult to ignore the fish odor, which did not compliment our dishes in any way.
author: Kimberly H.

description: Cockscomb is a definite SF destination for meat-lovers. I've had the "ham" burger and the bacon chop as entrees, and I would strongly recommend them both. Also recommended is the sage and butter gnocchi, which is melt-in-your-mouth good, though I wish I got about twice as much of it for the money. Cockscomb is generally more expensive than the average SF dinner spot, but I feel that the quality of the food merits the heftier price tag. It's a good spot for dates and small groups, and I'd recommend making a reservation on Yelp at least a few days in advance.
author: Timothy P.

description:
Came for lunch and was really impressed.  What a great space, love the decor, and of course the impossible burger!  Service was excellent and I'll be back for sure.

My only complaint is that they close at 1:30 for lunch, which is early in my opinion.  I felt bad showing up at 1.  May be SF eats lunch early?  No big deal, though.
author: Lindsey W.

description:
I had the following at dinner:

- Pig skins, which came as a kind of small pasta. They were reasonably good.
- Off menu: a yellowtail. Served on a gigantic triangular platter that came about two feet off the table, it was enormous, perfectly cooked and very good, garnished with all kinds of spices and greens. This was the stand-out item for me. 
- The traditional burger did not live up to the hype, unfortunately. The bun was a little dry, and there was way too much of it. The combined bread and pickle flavors/textures ended up overwhelming the patty (rare), so it really didn't feel like much of a burger. I'm not even sure if I finished it. (Note that this burger is _not_ the renowned impossible burger, which they only serve at lunch.) 

I also had another starter that I've forgotten, but evidently it wasn't very memorable. My friend thought that his steak was excellent, so maybe I'll be back to give it another shot.
author: John L.

description:
Wonderful restaurant.  Great service. A must do while in SF. 
The appetizers were to die for. A grilled cheese sandwich topped with a sunny side up duck egg. You could have made a meal of it. 
We had a meal for for that included lobster, wagu beef, scallops and pork belly. Delicious!
author: Tim M.

description:
I've come here with a large group twice for the impossible burger (100% vegan burger made from plant proteins that is supposed to taste and look like real beef) and both times they've been very accommodating! There are 2.5 levels in the building so they do have a lot of seating with a super nice upscale ambiance.
The surroundings is a bit weird right now because of the construction, and you wouldn't think this restaurant would be so nice in that area.

The impossible burgers are pretty good - worth a try. I think they keep improving it, since it was better this time than a few months ago! The texture can do a bit more work to replicate the beef texture, but I think that's not on Cockscomb. Wouldn't get it instead of a real burger just yet, but it's getting there! Gotta try their burger with foie gras next time.

Everyone seems to have gotten the pig ears on yelp - i guess because it looks interesting. It was fried chewiness with too much salt and spices on it. Four of us couldn't finish one little thing because it was too heavy/much. 

No one seems to have gotten the oyster po boy! But it was so good! Super creamy sauce, lightly fried oysters, and warm bread! It definitely was not a traditional po boy.. the bread was more like a panini bread type of a deal but still great.

The service is super pleasant and friendly! Always had a nice chat with the waiter about the beers or the food. 
The food is on the more expensive side but worth!
author: Grace P.

description:
************** 1695  *************

What not to love about Top chef Chris Cosentino? From his TV show during the popular time till his famous restaurant in San Francisco and the charcuterie shop in the Ferry Building.

One thing I admire a chef is everything he does, he does it so well. So this new restaurant that's so popular every night at the bar and the opened kitchen. 

He opened up about his fight with depression and all the celebrity status success he has on TV, how it all changed him to be a better man. And how he's now an advocate for other upcoming young chefs in this profession to deal with the pressure and hard work, brutal hours. 

I got so much respect for him and what he has been through. 

Talk about the delicious food he creates here at Cockscomb. 

That chicken with sweetness skin dish was deliciously good. 

The pig skin Amatriciana hits the spot, what diet? 

Beef heart tartare and green was bomb.

Pig head roasted, for the adventurous diners, you are in for a treat! I love biting on that pig ears, remind me of the food I grow up with in Saigon.

Anything cured meat, is a MUST ORDER. Chef cured everything in house abs well as their pickles. 

The food is delicious. The drink and wine list are fun. And the service is on point.

And if you are lucky, you will see this humbled chef in the kitchen serving you a plate. 

Parking can be a challenged here! So Lyft it!
author: Manda Bear B.

description:
Of all the options in San Francisco, we picked this place due to the great reviews about the food. 

Right after placing our drink orders, the food order arrived for the table right next to us. They had ordered a lot of hot and steamy shellfish which my friend is allergic to so we scooted over to the empty 2 top table right next to us. When our waitress returned with our drinks we told her why we moved, she said it was "all good". Unfortunately, the young hostess felt differently. She went out of her way to come over to point out she noticed we moved and that "it would have been nice to ask". Seeing as to how the table wasn't occupied and she didn't seat anyone else at the other 2 top we vacated the entire time we were there her unnecessary need to come over and cop an attitude with us left a stain on our evening. 

Back to the reason why we came here. Our drinks were outstanding!The food was delicious and probably the best we ate during our visit to San Francisco.  I had the Coulotte Steak and he had the "Ham"burger. We also really enjoyed chatting with our waitress who was funny and personable. 

Great restaurant. Great cocktails. Great food. Great Waitress. Shitty Hostess.
author: Lori K.

description: Got here 30 monies before close  and they refused serving dessert.  Boo.  We walked all the way here, can't get a brownie or a cocktail?
author: Mike J.

description: Really good pork dishes! I've never had pork so succulent and Dungeness crab so buttery! Everything was rich in savory flavor. I'm happy. The service was well catered and they made sure our waters were filled. We ordered the crispy pig ears with squid, cauliflower with duck fat, and a shared entree of pork belly, loin, and Dungeness crab braised in a rich brown sauce. Would recommend coming here again!
author: Lina L.

description: great service, cool drinks, but way overpriced... :) $105 for a good steak is a bit much.... i thought that the heirloom tomato and stone fruit salad lacked imagination and was definitely missing burrata...
author: Zayka Z.

description: This place is a must for all the food is. The menu is very eclectic, the cocktails a great and have a good beer selection as well. Try to pigs head, you won't be disappointed!
author: John G.

description: Had this place on my radar for awhile and decided to come to the city one early Friday afternoon to try the infamous impossible burger. If you are reading this, I've gone vegetarian/pescatarian. No beef/meat for this gal. I made 11:30am reservations for 2, my cousin came out to dine with me. Btw, reservations are highly recommended! We ordered the impossible burger, side of those yummy crispy potato and baked cauliflower (which I didn't realize it had duck fat) but oh well still ate it. The impossible burger was out of this world. If I have a hankering for a beef burger i'd come here because it looks and taste like beef. When going to cockscomb, the restaurant is actually in an ally way, not on 3rd st if you are trying to find the restaurant.
author: Jocelyn T.

description:
Solid steak which I had tonight for dinner. We wanted the 28 day aged ribeye but the server offered us an upgrade to Texas Wagyu beef. I was skeptical about It, but I did enjoy the cut. Probably not $155 worth but for alright. 
Bottle of wine and the flourless chocolate cake and $380 later I left thinking how long do I have to run tomorrow. 
I wish I could run back from the restaurant to my friends house in Oakland but Bart is my friend tonight. I will try not miss my stop...
author: Anelya S.

description: Nice place, great service. Best mussels I had in a while. Good drinks as well.
author: Solange M.

description: Great creative menu. Outstanding service. Fun location-local crowd. Would highly recommend this place --cool wine list as well.
author: John B.

description: Came here while on vacation, we got the calamari, soooo good! And the mint julip is amazing!
author: Diana L.

description:
Been wanting to eat here for the longest time since moving to San Francisco. We were able to get reservations for lunch. Their menu was limited, which worked out in my favor since I am really indecisive when I have too many choices!  

I ordered the Italian meatball and my husband got the burger, as well as the cauliflower with duck oil.  The meatball sandwich was delicious! There was the right amount of provolone cheese in the sandwich, the meatball was spiced perfectly, on a toasted ciabatta roll, and the mint topped off the flavor. Hmmm. My husband got the burger and finished it before I could try any, so thats a good sign. The duck oil and cauliflower was also a hit. It had a kick to it with peppers and garlic mixed in. Never had cauliflower like that eeeeverr. Since our lunch turned it great, we are wanting to try their dinner menu. We will be back Cockscomb!
author: C O.

description:
Lets start with their HAPPY HOUR! $1 dollar oysters, $3 dollar pigs ears and $4 dollar for a big bowl of crispy potatoes and among other things as well. Yum! Before 6pm. House wine is $5. If you want something sweet and strong, try their **Negroni. On the happy hour menu. The bar is upstairs and you can see the whole kitchen and most of the dinning area. I really like the rustic decor.

For dinner we started with **LITTLE GEMS salad. Made with smoked strawberries & hazelnut dressing. It was good but nothing spectacular. **SPAGHETTINI cured Sardinian tuna heart & egg yolk. Yum! Very rich, maybe that is why it was a small serving but it was tasty. 

SPECIALS: 
**Seared Foie Gras with Pigs Feet. It was very good. Very heavy as well, especially cooking it with the pigs feet. 
**Tuna Collar - "THE BEST DISH of the NIGHT!!" Very flavorful, moist and HUGE.They cooked it with a lot of spices. Like the hamachi kama but 5x its size. So good.

Ended the night with their **Creme Brulee. It wasn't anything special but it was a good. The bartender, she was great. The server was friendly. Overall the food and service was good. But also because the company I had was amazing! Will definitely be coming back, especially for their happy hour!
author: Sandy B.

description: Went out for a staff luncheon. We try a different place each week. Some are hits, some are misses.....this was a hit! Both food and service were excellent. Everyone really enjoyed what they ordered. I tried a bite of someone Imposdible burger...the best meatless burger ever!!! I had the Italian Dip...great meatballs. Watch out for the crispy potato side....those things are addictive!!!! Odd location but around other good places too!
author: Cindy D.

description: Great decor, outstanding food, amazing FOH staff. Would suggest anyone go and try it out, wont be dissapointed
author: Daniel W.

description:
Reservations for larger group requires a credit card on file. They charge for cancellation under 24 hours.

Coulette Steak - comes with some parsnips. The sauce went really well with the steak. I ordered medium rare more rare and it came out to be medium. I ended up not eating the ends since they were too well done. Overall loved the steak

Fried chicken sandwich - the chicken was super moist and crispy on the outside. There was a hint of spiciness to the batter. Highly recommend this

Pigs ears - they were crispy and not chewy at all

Devil eggs - they were good but I wouldn't say they were amazing.

Steak heart tartare - surprisingly good. Had a slight more chewiness than the typical steak tartare. Very different fish that you should try

Dessert - they always have a chocolate, fruit and cheese dessert. I had the cheese dessert the first time and it's really just cheese platter with nuts and some jam/marmalade. I ended up passing on the cheese platter the second time around. The toffee bread pudding was just amazing nice and soft/moist. There was a fruit dessert that was pretty good that came with grapefruit and orange. Very refreshing. Everyone in my group didn't really like the fruit dessert as much.
author: Ivy L.

description:
We were so excited to try this place for our girls trip this weekend. Unfortunately, we are all very disappointed.

The $165.00 ribeye we ordered came out cold and under seasoned. Additionally, by the time the actual order arrived- which took about 45 minutes, we were all SO hungry we just dove straight into it. The other order of spaghetti we had was cold and under seasoned as well. 

While I waiter  promised big bold flavors, it was extremely under delivered. 

The chicken liver dish was overpowered by sunken puff pastry. And we found that all of our dishes were covered with capers. I mean almost all of our dishes. 

The waiter was definitely not attentive enough. Won't be back unfortunately .
author: Kathy C.

description:
I came here with a friend one night. This review is way overdue. So, bare with me. lol. Reservations are recommended. Service was excellent as well. Dinner with cocktails? :) Yes! I I don't remember what cocktail I had, all I remember, it was so divine. Thanks TM for eating dinner with me here. It was awesome! For dinner we had the:

1. Bay shrimp with halibut - cold and tasty.
2. Beef heart tartare - loved it. You can't go wrong with it.
3. Bacon chop - We both heard about this. So we had to try this. It was really mouthwatering and tasty.
4. Foie gras - I don't need to say anything about this...melting...not sure if they still have this on the menu or not.
author: Jennifer G.H. W.

description:
You'd have to be lost to find this hidden away joint, or know where you're going. It'll feel like you walked into a kitchen, making it obvious that this is a chef driven restaurant. Cauliflower sans-garlic and ham-burger are a treat. There's a psychological barrier you'll have to breakthrough to try the beef heart tartar. Though they have vegetarian options it's probably not a place to try out with a vegetarian friends as the smell of cooked meats permeates the space. 

Oh and that's what a rooster's Mohawk is called...nothing sexual, they said.
author: Blake B.

description:
Cockscomb is definitely as good as it gets! One of my favorite Chef (who was also on top chef)  Chris Cosentino, owns this restaurant. The server/service was right on and the everything I ordered was delicious. The environment is more on the cozy, dim lights based in the heart of SOMA.

If you see Chef Chris, don't hesitate if you want to take a picture with him. He's super friendly and is always willing to take pictures! He's a pretty cool dude :) 

Things I ordered: 
- ROASTED MILK FED CHICKEN  asparagus, potatoes & lemon
- NETTLE RISOTTO green garlic & ricotta 
- DUCK FAT CAULIFLOWER chili, garlic & mint
- SOFT SHELL CRAB on toast
author: Jenn L.

description:
Came here with friends, just to try out their dishes.

This place is great for meat lovers. Their food was rich om savory favor.

My personal favorite is the Grilled Cheese sandwich :)
author: Mega Team R.

description:
Meat lover's place, especially their large dishes for 4+ people. I had been here twice in 2 weeks for dinner, once in a 4-people group, another time in a 10-people group. Tried following large dishes (all in large dish, each cost $160 ~ $190):

- grilled aged pork belly with chinese black bean sauce, baby bok choy, with lobster and scallops
- pork chop with some belly, topped with 2 lobsters
- steak with 10 scallops on top
- (haven't tried but would like to) tuna collar bone and stuff

Also some small ones worth noting:
- some vietnamese salad with rice cracker
- duck meat with foie gras and some toast?
- dirty potatoes
author: Tian W.

description:
Sat at the chef's counter as a group of three for dinner. We ordered

1 - charcuterie platter
2 - foie gras with apple
3 - 28 oz sirloin with scallops
4 - bottle of syrah

The food is phenomenal and very flavorful. The staff is attentive. The head chef Chris was there as well. Sitting at the counter, we could see how diligent and meticulous he was. He was cooking, and checking food as well. I appreciate the passion and hard work displayed. The money was well spent. 

I'm not sure why there are such low reviews. This restaurant has superb quality. The only thing I wish was for the server to ask if I wanted any side dishes. I would've ordered a few to complement the sirloin.
author: Daniel L.

description:
Delicious date night dinner!

Started with half a dozen oysters, then on to the tumbo crudo (which should absolutely not be missed!) and entrees. I had the spicy fennel sausage, he had the Mt. Lassen trout. Both were very good. Portion sizes were large. 
We shared the chocolate dessert and coffees.
author: Maura K.

description: Went to dinner here while in the city for a conference. We shared the Wagu steak with scallops and asparagus. Side of cauliflower and side of mushrooms. It was perfect for two people. Steak was melt in your mouth and the scallops were cooked perfectly. For dessert we had the panna cotta. It was really smooth and tasty. Found it interesting that the man to woman ratio of people eating there was about 10:2. Matched the ratio of man to woman chefs which was 5:1. Is this because it is a steakhouse?
author: Marla M.

description:
Any place that offers a charcuterie board...gets my vote. My boyfriend and I came here for dinner for a celebration and we left fully satisfied. 

Ordered a couple of dirty martinis (shoutout to our waiter who made sure we got them extra dirty) and started with the charcuterie board and steak tartare. Yes, board. YUM. The meats were all delicious, juicy, and varied. (We love our cured meats and will ALWAYS try a charcuterie plate where we go). We also really really liked the tartare. Again, it's just one of those things that we'll always try if the place has it and we were not disappointed. It was so tasty and just the right amount of tart to it. 

For the main course, we both opted for the "ham"burger and boy was it huge and juicy. I couldn't even finish all of mine! Probably because we ordered so many drinks and starters...but it was worth the bite. 

Heads up - this place can get noisy, crowded, and their dishes are HUGE portions. Make reservations and be sure to come hungry!
author: Steph S.

description:
Work lunch of 7 (made sure to make reservations), was not far away from the office, so we walk on a nice Wednesday. It was a little hard to find, due to the construction in the area. 

It was not too busy and the interior is was rustic with beautiful wood tables. Overall, experience was good, as food and drinks came in a timely manner.

Food:
DUCK FAT CAULIFLOWER chili, garlic & mint: Perfectly roasted with strong garlic but could not taste mint and not overly oily. 
PIG'S EARS w/herbs & lime: My weakness, NOM NOM
OLIVES warm & marinated: Warm and salty, what more can a person ask for.
HOUSE POTATOES lemon, horseradish & smoked aioli: Did not taste the smoke or horseradish, but potatoes were roasted well.
"HAM"BURGER grilled onions, gruyere cheese, Dijon: Pork patty that my co-workers loved. Would get it again.
GRILLED CHEESE country ham, duck egg & honey: Nice balance of savory and sweet from the honey.
ITALIAN DIP meatball, provolone & marinara:Tasty but a little messy.
FRIED OYSTER PO'BOY remoulade, lettuce & picalilli: Not over heavy batter, was perfect after getting a little hot sauce (house made). Could use a little acid slaw, but worked well with some pickles.

Honorable mention for next time to try, as it looked super tasty at the table next to us: 
ROASTED LITTLE GEM NICOISE confit tuna fillet, potato, egg, olives & pickled onions
author: Mei L.

description: Honestly, I was disappointed in our dinner at Cockcomb. The pictures really got me excited... and that it's run by a previous iron chef. However, the pinbone steak fell flat. It was an ok piece of meat - had a lot of tough portions and didn't have great crystallization. Without the crystallization, it was almost tasteless. The potatoes also looked beautiful but really lacked taste as well. The octopus appetizer was actually pretty good, another at the table really liked the vegetarian carrot dinner. The spaghetti had great taste but was extremely dry (someone at the table said that she had it with more oil before and it was delicious). Overall, it wasn't worth the price.
author: Been B.

description: Great dinner spot.  It's a bit tucked away from the street which is nice.  There is a small bar upstairs that is real cozy and you can look over into the first floor of the restaurant.
author: Adie X.

description:
The Impossible Burger is no longer Impossible for me.  Let me tell ya, this was such a challenging burger to eat.  Our first attempt was to go on the weekend, all to discover that they don't serve the Impossible burger during dinner time.  I ended up making a reservation for lunch on a weekday.  It was worth the hassle  We missed our train which is located very close to the restaurant, and rushed from the Powell Bart station.

Everyone working here knows their stuff when it comes to the food they are serving.  Total pros.  I'll be back again someday.  Have fun my fellow Yelpers.
author: Michelle M.

description: We went there for Mother's Day Celebration. Love the different variety of food that they are offering. Great service as well. Our waiter was very knowledgeable of their menu and gave us a very descriptive of the specialty items of that night.  We ordered the tuna fish heads, pigs head, grill octopus, and hot mess. There were four of us and we shared the family meals.  Everything we ordered were delicious . We will definitely go back again.
author: L C.

description:
If you've ever wanted to know what it's like to eat like a Dothraki, Cockscomb is your place. 

Lamb Heart Pastrami 
Beef Heart Tartare
Sardinian Tuna Heart Spaghettini 

Eat your heart out at  Cockscomb while eating someone else's.

As a non-meat eater, you'd think I have no business having myself a reservation at Cockscomb but contrary to what they're famous for (those exotically cooked and cured meats), they actually do vegetarian and pescetarian tremendously well. Like, better than actual vegetarian restaurants do it. 

Of course, your options are more limited but I'd still say abundant and they don't go cheap on you with some salad or pasta dish. They KILL it and the truth is they don't have to. They're a meat place and everything from the name to sign will reinforce that but the Chef here still went above and beyond to create some incredible dishes for the non-meat and fish-eating friends and I really gotta give it up there because I've seen it done so rarely and even more rarely done well. 

Our server was too rad. I'd tell the table I'm waffling between some things because I want to ask about x and y and our guy would magically be right there with the answer just killing it. 

The cocktails were sinfully good. 
+ I got the Pisco Punch (Pisco based punch with pineapple & Nutmeg) and at just $11 I would get it again every time. 
+ My second round was the Escape From Alcatraz (Sloanes gin, elderflower, mint, lemon, & elderflower tonic ) at $13 and it is potent and perfect and so well-presented that the rest of the table followed suit in ordering it as well. 

For dinner my table split some stuff, most of which was meaty and hearty (literally, that lamb heart pastrami) and I did not partake but I did stuff myself with some notable delectable dishes. 
+ Broccoli Rabe Toast was something we shared but I wish I would've ordered my own because it was that good. 
+ The Grilled Cheese with duck egg and honey was the best grilled cheese I've ever had in my life. I'll be back for that, for sure. 
+ Gnocchi with sage and brown butter is crispy cream-yo-pants good.
+ Duck Fat Cauliflower was grand and a great portion. A nice sharing dish to accompany the larger meat plates. 
+ The charred/seared (I forget, those drinks are potent) octopus salad was tasty but for me the salad just kinda got in the way of the octopus and slowed me down... which isn't always a bad thing, but next time I'd probably try one of the many other vegetarian and/or pescetarian dishes that I wasn't able to time. 

Is it on the pricier side? Yes but for that atmosphere, service, and food, I'd say they're pretty spot on in what they charge. Four of us split the bill but with tax and tip it ended up being around $80 a person with 2 drinks each and we left STUFFED. Absolutely think that was a more than a good value.
author: Candice G.

description:
Their food was excellent we ordered the Tombo Crudo for appetizer and for the main course we got the Shared Supper Wagyu Beef with broccoli and peppercorn sauce, Bacon Chops, Spaghetti for our kids and Sticky Toffee Pudding for dessert. Everything was amazing. 

Service is wonderful. All staff were helpful and very knowledgeable of their menu. My husband pinched his finger with their door and made it bleed. The hostess was quick to help and offer some compensations, which was very nice and we truly felt their sincerity. 

They sat us in a corner table so that our kids will have enough space and far enough from everyone else that our kids couldn't cause other patrons any discomfort. The venue was very convenient despite of all the road constructions around it. Parking is a bit tricky but I figured that's how it is in San Francisco. Luckily, we were able to walk from our hotel in Sutter Street to the restaurant for about 20-30 mins, easy stroll. 

Overall, I would definitely recommend this place to everyone I know.
author: Cheryl S.

description: The food is really good. I love the Kyle appetizer and the salmon appetizer. Like the interior design. The time between courses is a bit longer.
author: Danyang Danielle C.

description:
LET'S JUST GET THIS OUT THE WAY....IF YOU WANT THE GOOD STUFF YOU GOTTA DROP MONEY , BUT TRUST ME YOU WONT REGRET IT!!! LOL



The place has a pretty cool set up, on the outside looks like an old store/warehouse feels but when you go inside is was NICE!!! The mood of this place is chill ahaha


Me and my friends was hungry so we yelp and pick this place...we got there and you gotta do reservations, but theres bars seating we were allowed to sit at, which we didnt mind at all....our server was pretty cool, she gave us the run down, and the today specials etc...shes on it


Ok so me and mt friend end up getting the pin bone steak AND OMG im a big dude we still couldn't finish it lol...but the steak wassssss on pointtttttt specially when you dip it into the bownmarrow dip OH BOY hahaha had to go for a walk im dtsf after that lol 



But anyways i would say 

Service is good
Vibe was chill
Food was BOMB


Oh the only thing is the parking, if your lucky you get a parking on the small street or pay for parking across the street from it where wells fargo bank is...or just dahm uber or lyft or even rent the scoot lmao 


But yes gave this place a 5 star a well deserved one!!!
author: Rofferson L.

description: I've been here for lunch and dinner. This was the first place I tried an Impossible Burger and I haven't found one as great since! Plus, the service is always on point and the staff is very accommodating. I have a service animal and there are never any questions asked. Just sincere folks who want to make sure I enjoy my meal.
author: Rona R.

description: A friend invited me to meet him for happy hour one Friday, and I said yes because I can't resist happy hour oysters. The caveat: the happy hour is literally only an hour, so show up early to take full advantage of the specials! Oysters are $1, and there are drink specials. The one that I vividly remember is the $5 negroni - you can't beat that. I decided to treat myself to a Hendrick's gimlet though, and it was amazing. The bartender was friendly and chatted up the other two people at the downstairs bar while I enjoyed my gimlet and 18 (greedy?) oysters. My friend arrived later, and we headed to the upstairs bar, which was far more crowded. Still, we were able to place orders and overall, we had a great time.
author: Sarah B.

description: I've stopped by Cockscomb twice for HH recently and really enjoyed it. They have HH from 5-6pm and 10-11pm on weekdays at the upstairs bar area only. A few of my favorites - $1 oysters, fried pig ears, and honey grilled cheese. I also tried the negroni (which was too bitter for my taste) and the house red which was good. There is limited seating in the bar area upstairs so I recommend arriving early/on time for HH. I've heard they're known for their specialty burger, so I'll probably be back to check that out on the regular menu.
author: Elaine N.

description: Been here many times always the best place with the best offal. Service is always up to par and well knowledgeable about menu and special. Could never go wrong with steak grilled cheese.
author: Ivan C.

description: We had lunch and it was a great experience. Fresh oysters on the half shell, the imposible burger and the chicken sandwich was very delicious! Also we order a carrot salad that comes with different presentations & ways to cook this taproot Delicious!! And the decor, ambiance and feeling of the dining room is awesome
author: Ricardo Q.

description:
I'd probably skip Cockscomb in the future unless I was looking for a large group meal in SoMa (ideally on someone else's credit card). Just doesn't feel like the food/service are worth the prices. 

They've got a ton of seating inside the restaurant, and there were a lot of groups of 8+ people around our table.

Unfortunately on the night we went, a single waiter was charged with serving a room of something like 50 people.  He was super friendly, just way overworked - so we ended up hungrily twiddling our thumbs for long stretches between appetizer and entrees. 

The drinks were great -- we had a few of their house cocktails, really liked their gin and tonic. 

I thought the food was just okay. We had the dirty potatoes, coulotte steak, and bacon chop. The steak was good, but the bacon chop was too fatty for my taste and the dirty potatoes felt overly-seasoned + not crisp enough. 

The tables adjacent to us both got the pin bone steak (giant $125 sharin' steak), which looked way more fun than our dishes -- I'd try to coerce my dining companions into that if I come here again. 

The price tags here are pretty heavy, which would be fine if they nailed the service/food, but seemed too high for what we got.
author: Ryan D.

description:
Review for the Happy Hour. (5-6pm Mon-Thurs, in the upstairs bar area)

Came here on a Wednesday to try their happy hour.  It is exclusive to their upstairs bar area. This restaurant requires reservations for the actual dining area, but luckily the bar does not! 

My friends and I ordered their $1 oysters, Crispy Pig Ears($3), Crispy Potatoes($4), and Grilled cheese($6).

The oysters were just alright. They were really small and kind of forgettable. If you are craving oysters, there are better places in SOMA for fresh oysters.

Everything else that we ordered was super delicious. The pig ears were nicely seasoned and crispy. A perfect "bar" food which goes well with a drink.  The crispy potatoes were topped with a ham puree and some sort of cream.  They give a decent amount for the price you pay for.  The highlight of the entire happy hour was definitely their Grilled cheese. It was simply amazing.  The bread is soaked in a slightly sweet honey with decadent melted cheese.  Definitely order this if you ever go to their happy hour.

For drinks, I tried the Calicraft: Winter sparkling ale.  It was a lighter beer which paired really well with the food their offered for happy hour. And for only $5, it was a great deal.  

Overall, their happy hour is definitely worth it. I have yet to try their dinner menu, but maybe some time in the future.  Don't let the $$$ scare you away from trying their reasonably priced happy hour. You won't regret it.
author: Jacky C.

description: One of the few places currently serving the Impossible Burger, they offer a few amazing vegan side dishes to go with the burger. Great service, friendly staff and awesome local artwork on display as well (could do without the animal heads on the wall) but otherwise the perfect place to have lunch in SOMA
author: Oz Y.

description:
I love good food and great restaurants, but I don't follow names of chefs.  I have heard of Mr. Cosentino but that is not why we ventured in.  I simply liked the brave offerings on their menu and simply have heard enough good things from their execution.

I like the look of the space, very casual.  Busy and loud on the ground floor, due to the kitchen and probably where the regulars hang out.  Urban loft look upstairs with dark, minimalist tones.  Urban art is riddled throughout the space, which I liked big time.

Started with Oeufs Mayonaise ($13) which is their deviled egg rendition.  Great, one of the better ones I've had.  Super creamy yolk that was bursting with seasoned egg flavor.  Nice herb mayo on the bottom of the plate to make it even more creamy and indulgent.  And a tiny sliver of crisp chicken skin as a garnish was a nice touch.  Almost wished there were more.

Sipped on their house Martini ($12) and it was extremely spot on.  Quality gin, herby vermouth and briny olives.  Chilled and perfect.  Stuck with these for the duration of the whole meal to counter all the richness of the food.

Smoked Oyster Chowder ($14) was on special and we couldn't resist.  Execution was precise and kraft-worthy.  Creamy with the perfect consistency.  Skillfully diced tender Yukon potato.  And maybe 3-4, mildly smoked oysters.  So mild that some of the oysters had a rawish texture.  And when put all together, made for a stellar soup course.

Since it was our first time, we indulged in their Half Pig's Head Dish ($69).  There's 2 things about this dish;  1) it is pretty hardcore and not for casual meat eaters;  2) it is a lot of food that can be shared amongst 4 people.  There were only 2 of us, so we didn't even come close to finishing it.  But they pack things up nicely.

I've had many different pig parts in my time, but I've never had all parts of the head before me.  It was good, real good.  But it is just so rich with fat and sticky gelatinous tissue that you seem to get your fill pretty quick.  Our version, the skin was really crisp.  So crisp it was hard to carve.  Super tasty, but super sticky on the tooth.

We enjoyed the diverse textures and flavors of the different areas.  Ears, cheeks and jaw muscles are all so different.  2 sauces came with, one an herbaceous jus and another some creamy mayo.  Both really good.  Lots of chicory salad to accompany, which is a great contrast to the rich meat.

For dessert we chose their Pineapple Upside Down Cake ($7) rendition, and I loved it.  It was a total twist on most other versions.  First the cake seemed like it had cornmeal or polenta in it, a little gritty.  But the slightly sweet corn flavor was great.  Some dried berry on top (could be currants or dried blueberry) along with the pineapple added the tart fruit component while soft cream tied everything together.  Very nice adult oriented dessert, sugar levels totally in check.

Now that I've knocked the pig's head dish off my culinary bucket list, I can now venture into the rest of their menu.  Their family style dishes all sound so good, from a sharable pin bone steak to a pork belly and scallop platter that seemed intriguing.  Man, I just can't wait for the next outing.

*looks in calendar for next special occasion*
author: D.wight L.

description:
Hmm... I have mixed reviews about this place. Cockscomb was good, but it wasn't amazing... I actually dined here twice over the weekend because all I wanted was the "Impossible Burger." I came on Friday evening, only to discover that Cockscomb serves it ONLY for lunch Mon-Fri. I repeat, the Impossible Burger is only served Monday through Friday at lunch!!

That being said, the server that Friday evening made the Impossible Burger sound so tasty and intriguing that I had to come back on Monday. Luckily it was a 3 day weekend, otherwise there would have been no way to try it. This restaurant can only serve it at lunch because the other restaurant, Jardiniere (sp?), only exclusively serves it at dinner... kind of ridiculous....

So back on dinner experience... it was okay. Server was super nice, and my friend and I split a few dishes and dessert. Because my friend was pescetarian, we were limited to options which I think weren't really the star dishes of the restaurant. We got the spaghettini, which was herbal-y and simple, roasted carrots with dates, which was delicious, and the grilled cheese, which had a nice sweet twist to it w/ the honey. Reflecting back on that meal, that was a lot of carbs/sugar, haha. Afterwards, we had the flourless chocolate cake which is super chocolately and paired very nicely w/ vanilla ice cream. 

Fast forward to Monday... I made reservations for lunch and we didn't get seated until 15+ minutes after our reservation time... I could see a couple other parties getting frustrated about getting seated late despite having reservations. I also noticed serve that day was extremely slow... 

And now... we finally got the Impossible Burger! It's good, but as someone with no dietary restrictions, it's not as good as a normal patty. It kind of creeps me out that I'm eating something synthetic. But it's still fascinating, and a good experience. Also, keep in mind even though the burger is vegan, it's quite oily with all the coconut oil... and the patty is crumbly and squeezes out easily. 

Personally, I wouldn't come back to eat the burger again, but do recommend people to give it a try. It's also pricy, for $20...
author: Janet H.

description: 3.5/5. When you first walk in you get the great charcoal bbq smell! It's an open kitchen style set up so you see everything going on. Most of the food is very unique so you should be ready to try new things. I had the "ham" burger which doesn't use beef. It was decent. All my colleagues didn't mind their meals with the exception of the codd. The seafood tower was decent too with the mussels and  oysters.
author: J P.

description: Great food, cool restaurant however my only complaint would be is it's very noisy.   If your a local or just visiting add it to your restaurant list.
author: Lisa I.

description: I had lunch here, so this review is for their lunch. We had gnocchi, duck confit cauliflower, cured salmon and Italian dip. I give two thumbs up to all dishes. I could skip the salmon next time. The ambience is very nice too. I love open kitchen settings. It was a chilly inside, so make sure you bring an extra layer if you don't want to sit with your coat on.
author: Meric O.

description:
Cockscomb, March 12, 2016

Expectations are high.  Heck, we're eating at the winner of Top Chef Master's restaurant, and so we're expecting to have a unique and tasty experience, and we do.

If you were in San Francisco on March 12, 2016 you know that it rained gently for a good part of the day, and then hard for a good part of the day.  As we are tourists, we had planned for a long walk that included parking near Cockscomb, a walk to the Ferry Building for the farmer's market, a walk down to Pier 33 where we can get on our Alcatraz 'cruise' to the island, and then we tour the island and then our day concluded with the walk back to Cockscomb.  Sounded like a great plan, and it was, and it's all being shared here so that you appreciate that we showed up at the restaurant early and soaked... They opened about five minutes early so we got some reprieve from the weather.

We had requested the opportunity to watch the chef's work, and so we were able to sit right at the kitchen and chat with the chefs as they were working. This was great, and I'd highly recommend this to you if you're interested in food, asking questions and chatting, and at this restaurant you'd better be prepared.  The chefs are not shy.  We spoke with probably five or six different people working in the kitchen and we found them all personable and fun.  I'm sure it's the culture that's been created at the restaurant, and, for me, it's a great culture.  The Top Chef was not in the night we were there, and yet his crew carried on.

On to the food, and know that the menu is very tempting.  My wife and I ended up selecting the 'bacon chop', as we planned to share it. We also ordered sides of cauliflower braised in duck fat, gnocchi, and grilled broccoli.  The 'bacon chop' is huge.  Picture, if you will, a New York steak that's thicker and longer than the biggest New York steak you've ever had.  My wife at a third, and I was forced to eat the other two-thirds, but I was able to suffer through it.

To summarize, we enjoyed everything, and Cockscomb is now on the short list of places we'd return.  I was surprised in San Francisco though, as we mentioned to people that we were going here for dinner, and they didn't seem to even know it exists.  As far as I'm concerned, that's good for us.  On the Saturday night that I was there, it was crowded and I'm sure that's good for the restaurant.  I like a place that can stay open, make money, and maintain quality, and this place seems to be doing that.
author: Thomas E M.

description:
Great group dinner at a cozy, gorgeous spot in SOMA! Chris Cosentino and his team served up some delicious fare that warrants another repeat visit.

The crowning glories of a cock's crest +'s:
+ Awesome space. Snag the top floor and grab a drink to overlook the patrons from this balcony post.
+ Great service. From the greeting to the upstairs bar to the downstairs meal--everything was well done. Attentive and courteous. Regular refills of water and new plates. Great suggestions for our group of 8.
+ Family style is the way to order for groups. We all shared the surf + turf and pin bone steak with some sides. Made it communal and fun!
+ Drinks. All tasty but Chef's Jam is my favorite.
+ Openers and sides were all hits. Duck egg on grilled cheese with honey! I could have this everyday.
+ Gnocchi yes.
+ Pin bone steak. Wow. Bone marrow sauce is mouth watering. 
+ Oysters yes.
+ Desserts vary and we ordered all four types for our group. They all got different votes but the clear winner was the cheese turnover.
+ Return visit? YES!

The tears on the crest -'s:
- Lobster was overcooked. Unfortunately this was so. I had to chew for a good minute to get that tail down my throat.
- Cauliflower in duck fat was ok. I wouldn't go out of my way to reorder.

Overall we had an awesome time and enjoyed the food! Many of us visited for the first time and aim to return. Top Chef Master was on the premise and stopped to chat with us. Very personable and asked about our experience. His visit was definitely a highlight to our evening!
author: Yiven C.

description:
Let me start off with a little disclaimer that this would have been a 4-star rating if our waitress/bartender had actually listened to our complaint and took us more seriously.

We went in for HH (5-6pm) on a Friday and set up at the standing room area in the center of the second floor bar. We started with a beer and the only cocktail on their HH menu, a Negroni they have on tap. I've never had one before, so I thought I would give it a try. Wrong choice - good thing it was only $5 and my roomie's bf polished it off when they joined us later on.

Food: From the HH menu, we ordered a dozen of their $1 oysters and their crispy potatoes. The oysters were pretty solid and I liked the sauce they served with it - very refreshing. The crispy potatoes were pretty good, but that leads into my one complaint that I'll save for later. Once my roomie joined us, she ordered the grilled cheese, which was pretty solid. Crispy, buttery bread, and just the right amount of cheese.

Drinks: $5 HH specials were pretty decent. Mostly a beer place bc they only have the one cocktail special.

Ambiance: Pretty cool. I like how they renovated the interior of such an old building. Very light and airy, though I did notice that my hair smelt a little like smoke just from the 3 min of standing by the wood fired kitchen area.

Ok, here's my one complaint: When we ordered the crispy potatoes, I took a snapchat picture to send to my roomie. When my bf and I first looked at it, we didn't see the ham puree on top and so we kept eating and figured it might be at the bottom. When we got halfway and my roomie showed up, we compared my snapchat to the other pictures on Yelp and YUP, NO HAM PUREE! Where there should have been distinct peaks of a brown mouse, there were none! I showed the waitress my snapchat picture and she literally glance at it for a millisecond and then said, "It's there!"  Um NOPE! I feel like she should at least give us the benefit of a doubt, aren't customers supposed to be right? Yes, the dish was half way eaten, but I had a picture from before we even touched it! We weren't looking for a comped dish - we were just looking for a confirmation that it wasn't there so that the kitchen would know.
author: Leana L.

description:
Pin Bone Steak, Surf and Turf, Gnocchi, fried pigs ears. 

Faves were pig ears and gnocchi which are the appetizers. The main courses were a disappointment as the steak cuts were a bit tough and dry. Great service and drinks but the food didn't live up to the expectations.
author: Eddie L.

description: Dinner tonight was such a treat!  I had tuna collar with duck fat cauliflower on the side. The tuna collar was so big it was served in a casserole dish. I was too full to eat the cauliflower but managed to find room for dessert. I had chocolate pudding which is hidden underneath the butter cookie wafer. This was one of the best meals I've had in a long time. Besides the amazing food, the service was excellent! Michael, the server, was friendly and knowledgeable. The host was also very charming and accommodating (unfortunately I didn't get his name but very nice man!) I look forward to coming back here next time I'm in the Bay Area!
author: Geegee G.

description: Second time here and it was even better from our first experience.  Made dinner reservations for 6 and was required to leave a credit card to make it.  Parking was pretty easy; we parked at the lot where Wells Fargo is located; it was $10 so not too bad.  The place remained industrialized manly chic decor just how I remembered from two years ago.  Service was great!  Our server was friendly, knowledgeable, and very attentive.  We ordered a bunch of plates to share family style.  My reviews on each plate is with the photos attached.  Overall, we enjoyed our dinner and drinks with amazing people!  Will continue to come here for sure!
author: Erna M.

description:
Apparently, I'm having mixed feeling for this place. I was a fan of Chris Cosentino's old restaurant called Incanto, but this new one just didn't satisfy my taste bud. 

We ordered: 

- Salad = basic arugula with strawberry and balsamic vinaigrette dressing. 

- Bacon chop = it was HUGE!!! Taste wise was underwhelming and lacking in flavors.

- Branzino = whole fish with too many bones and not enough meat. Eating this took too much time and was very messy (which I was not expecting). 

- Dessert = flourless chocolate cake with vanilla ice cream. I didn't care for it. 

- Cocktails = pretty looking drinks with cute straw, but that was it. I had better elsewhere. 

Overall, the food was a disappointment for me. As for the service, I didn't feel the hospitality at Cockscomb. 

I hope to give this place another try one day...
author: Owie N.

description:
I've only been here once, but am a fan!

We were extra hungry so we ordered the pigs head, which we were warned would be very rich for only two people. We aren't ones to back down from a challenge, so we ordered it. I also like to see restaurants that minimize food waste and celebrate the use of less traditionally used cuts.

The dish as a whole was very well executed - the chicory salad and bright dressing were a perfect complement to the mountain of rich pork. They also wisely deep fried the ears separately, giving some variety in texture

I'd love to come again with a bigger group and tackle the duck, or one of their specials (we just missed a crab & other seafood special which looked and smelled amazing!)
author: Neal B.

description: The grilled cheese with egg is the best you'll ever have!!! The service was great too!  And I love the steak with scallops, and the dirty potatoes are theeeeee best too! Will definitely try again!
author: Ethel C.

description:
If you're as perverted as me, then you bookmarked this place solely because of its name. Rawr. 

I'm just kidding--I guess I was also intrigued by the glowing reviews that this new restaurant received in so little time. But seriously...(insert creepy smirk here)

Despite the shortfalls with a few dishes we ordered, overall, our group had a fabulous dining experience here. 

I recommend: 
+ Little Gems Salad(Buttermilk ranch, radish & crispy pig ears) Crispy pig ears were legit  
+ Beef Heart Tartare Starter w/ grilled bread and greens
+ Lacinato kale and butternut squash (creamy garlic dressing & bird seed) 
+ Pin Bone Steak (Serves 4-6 people) topped with foie gras: This thing is colossal 

You can probably do without (these dishes were run-of-the-mill):   
+ Farro stuffed pumpkin (swiss chard, sage, & parmesan)
+ Duck Fat Cauliflower 
+ Zampini (pork & fennel sausage, fried oysters & smoked oyster remoulade)
+ Liver and bacon: I usually ADORE liver, but I wasn't feeling this liver because it tasted undercooked--strong metallic taste and its texture was akin to foie gras

The Pin Bone Steak was legit scrumptious--perfectly cooked to a tender medium rare and it had a delicate smoky flavor. We blanketed it with the bone marrow dip it came with. 

According to the reviews I've read, you may want to skip the wood oven roasted pig's head because it's supposedly unpalatably fatty and chewy. If you fellow chocolate enthusiasts are still up for it, after all the entrees and starters, then order the Mexican Chocolate Cake w/ pumpkin. This was so thick and rich---not overwhelmingly sweet. Great drink menu and accommodating service as well. 

+ Chef Chris Cosentino is a sweetheart
author: Merica S.

description:
Good presentation, but the food is bland and underwhelming. Service was also inadequate. The cocktails are good but overpriced. 

I think you should Skip and go somewhere else.
author: Dan K.

description:
Gnocchi - a bit disappointing and only like 8 pieces.
Duck Fat Cauliflower - this was excellent, but serving was really about 1.5 sides for one person.
Bacon Chop - this was excellent. The greens, the peaches, the crispy and tender pork all worked well.
Special (Steak and Lobster) to share - It was to be Steak and Scallops but they ran out of scallops. This was awesome. The steak was cooked perfectly. The lobster was also a cooked well and tasty.
author: Jay Y.

description: Food is just ok and everything overpriced. Med rare steak comes out mildly warm and the bacon pork chop is so fatty that you realize why no one eats a slab of pork belly like a steak. Salads are interesting but is not worth more than $10. Wines by the glass are terrible and doesn't complement the food. The pig head you find in Chinatown is better. Restaurant is comfortable and good for large groups and one of the few places where you can get a 4lb steak. It's an impressive show of meats and that's about it.
author: Jeffery W.

description:
This review is long overdue.  Our family (7 adults; 1 kiddo) went to Cockscomb to celebrate my sister's birthday last October.  Sadly, I was pregnant at the time, so I could not imbibe on any of the adult beverages.  Super sad face.  My sister and husband, however, assured me that their drinks were top notch.

We ordered a bunch of sides to share, including the Hot Mess special and Dirty Crispy Potatoes, which had a bit of a kick and damn good.  

But, the highlights were the Shared Supper Special of Cioppino and Whole Roasted Pig's Head (actually, only half a head).  The Cioppino wasn't your traditional cioppino, but it was hands down the best I've had in recent memory.

The Pig's Head was also delicious.  But, you gotta like crunchy, gelatinous pig skin.  A word of warning, however . . . it is so rich and fatty that I wouldn't recommend ordering it, if you only have a small party of 2-3 people (though the waiter says it feeds 2-3).  I couldn't imagine this being my main course, even with sides.  I think it only makes sense to order it with a large group, so you only have a few bites.

We also ordered a Chicken & Waffles plate for the kiddo.  The chicken was perfectly cooked, but it wasn't anything special next to the shared supper specials.  I'm not sure the individual suppers would live up to the standards of the shared suppers.  

I can't wait for the next time I can get a large group of people together and try some more of the shared suppers.  Everyone was stuffed for $570, which includes an 18% gratuity that was added due to our large party size.
author: Christina L.

description:
Waited 20 minutes to order drinks, then 20 more to get the server back without the drinks. Then ordered a 2-person special for $95, a pork belly and scallops with bok choy and Cantonese spicy black beans. The sauce overwhelmed the other flavors, and has no place in a restaurant with any subtle flavors. The dessert shortbread was not cooked through; blobby dough. The server asked how it was and we said it was not cooked properly and he didn't say a thing; no offer of another dessert; nothing.

It was $113 per person.

Obviously we'll never go again and will recommend against it any time someone mentions it.
author: David R.

description:
I had such high expectations of dining nirvana here but it was just not meant to be. I remember enjoying Incanto's head-to-tail dinner during Chris Cosentino's early days as its chef. I had not tried his latest venture before New Year's Eve when they were offering a special $110 four-course prix fixe dinner. Surely this was an optional choice. No, it wasn't. Since I made the reservation just two days in advance, I was left a message that there was a no-cancellation policy and that the prix fixe menu was mandatory. It struck me as rather restrictive, a reason to give me a case of pre-meat sweats. Would Cosentino's chops be worth it?

Now understand that since I tried Incanto over a dozen years ago, Cosentino has become a celebrity chef as he became a constant presence on the Food Network and the ultimate anointment, a friend of Anthony Bourdain when he came to town looking for local eats. So when Jamie W. and I entered the restaurant, the former Zuppa, we saw his staff hovering around him like acolytes near the grill oven (photo: http://bit.ly/1SYZAG7). We were squeezed against a banquette right next to a trio of obnoxious twenty-something hipster wannabes bellowed their conversation like it was a decibel-challenged nightclub. Cocktails were needed immediately.

Jamie ordered the $11 Pisco Punch, a sweet Peruvian elixir with pineapple and nutmeg added to the mix (photo: http://bit.ly/1V27tcD). I went for the more clubby $12 Boothby, a blend of cranberry juice, Douglas Fir bourbon, sweet vermouth, bitters and sparkling wine (photo: http://bit.ly/1NguYZG). It was almost enough to distract me from the 'dude'-laden dialogue inches away from us. For the first course, Jamie tried the Parsnip & Smoked Haddock Chowder, a buttery-salty blend that was indeed velvety good and gone all too soon (photo: http://bit.ly/1n6TzLa). I went for what I presume to be a Cosentino specialty, the Foie Gras Torchon with Cranberries & Brioche (photo: http://bit.ly/1PbtRC1).

Except for the sweetness of the cranberries, I found the foie gras quite bland and not lusciously addictive. The second course brought salads. Jamie tried the Castel Franco & Ricotta Salata with Olives (photo: http://bit.ly/1PlTeL7). Castel Franco is a mild form of bitter radicchio that was overwhelmed by the amount of ricotta shavings on the plate. Mine was the other choice, the Butter Lettuce with Hazelnuts & Blood Orange (photo: http://bit.ly/1PlTcmq). It tasted like a standard steakhouse salad, inoffensive and tasty enough but nothing more really. The entrees came next, and we knew this was the make-or-break point of our evening since Cosentino, by all accounts, knows his meats.

Jamie ordered the Pork Belly, Clams & Buddha's Hand Citron Salsa (photo: http://bit.ly/1OsmYZr), an odd surf-&-turf combo that just didn't quite mesh despite the richness of the belly. The citrus flavor of the salsa added another idiosyncratic note that made Jamie's shoulders shrug in indifference. I went for the Ribeye with Bone Marrow & Spinach, and at last the steak delivered the goods in its tender preparation and meltably good texture (photo: http://bit.ly/1ZwtnFZ). Strangely I would have thought the bone marrow would mean toast wedges would be forthcoming upon which to spread the marrow. When I inquired about this, I received a puzzled look of acceptance and then about ten minutes of radio silence.

When he did come with the grilled bread, I was done with the marrow and rather perturbed to find my request added to the bill later for $2. I just think for a restaurant at this exorbitant price point, a simple piece of bread could have been made complementary. Oh well. We moved to our final course, the dessert, and they were reasonably satisfying treats. Jamie had the Chocolate Cremeux & Golden Marshmallows, a mousse-like creation with its sole marshmallow given a bit of gold leaf (photo: http://bit.ly/1OB6GeK). I went with the Baked Apple with Gorgonzola & Honeycomb (photo: http://bit.ly/1PBxsDH). It was just half a small apple given the peasant treatment, but it was enough.

Nearly $300 later, we felt somewhat disappointed. It was less about the quality of the food which we didn't question but rather the indifferent manner which was pervasive throughout what should have been a more festive evening. The restaurant never did crowd up while we were there, and while we didn't expect Cosentino to stop by, it would have been a nice gesture. However, I could say the same about the staff overall since we didn't feel much warmth though it was clearly thrown at other diners around us. Alas, maybe we'll try the regular menu sometime as the burger looked like a good deal, but frankly we're in no hurry.

FOOD - 3 stars...considering Cosentino's reputation, marginally disappointing especially given the price point
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...doesn't look much different than Zuppa but that's fine
SERVICE - 3 stars...didn't feel the love
TOTAL - 3 stars...it should be more than the meat, right?
author: Ed U.

description:
Really wonderful little spot south of market in a nondescript building. Definitely come inside for some of the amazing food that lives in here.

Very cool modern restaurant with not only a great kitchen, but a big wood fire grill where they cook steaks and other delicacies.

Wound up sitting at the bar next to the expediter station - not the best seat in the house but overall fine even though if possible would rather sit at a table.

Great meal and fantastic spot.
author: Bob K.

description:
Vegetarian perspective.
I was really wowed as a vegetarian by this well known meat-centric restaurant!

They had several items on the menu that were vegetarian (including some delicious sides) and when we asked the waiter about vegetarian/vegan recommendations he went through EVERY SINGLE option on the menu and on how each vegetarian entree could be made vegan.

I was really impressed with our waitstaff, needless to say. And felt very welcome by the restaurant in terms of being vegetarian friendly.

We were delighted by the kale/butternut squash salad (the "birdseed" is out of this world), the charred beat entree (so filling and a different take on beets with full flavors and hefty portions), and the Chinese broccoli side (one of my favorites, they charred the basil on the side which gave it some amazing herby and umami notes). We did the vegetarian version of all these, did not opt for the vegan accommodations they offered.

PLEASE NOTE- the Impossible burger is not available at dinner.

SO, OF COURSE in our 4 day trip to SF, we made ANOTHER reservation at LUNCHTIME two days later to try the Impossible burger.

Thoughts on the Impossible burger- a good hack of a lean meat burger with some yummy gouda cheese and pickles on top. However, the "doneness" of the burger really seems to vary a lot between diners (our table ordered 4 impossible burgers) and mine was sadly more well done so I could not see the famous "heme" or raw red showing through. All in all, it was really worth trying, however I had to stop with a few bites left to go because it seemed too much like meat! Veggies rule.

Also- excellent mocktails.
author: Jessica L.

description: Returned to introduce my friend to an Impossible Burger.  Having learned from the first time, we requested potatoes instead of a pile of lettuce as the accompaniment.  Our waiter told us it would be less expensive to make an order of potatoes than to substitute for two sides.  Why the regular burger comes with potatoes and the Impossible Burger doesn't, makes no sense.  My waiter the first time at Cockscomb had said it was because the Impossible Burger was ordered by vegans -- but potatoes are vegan, typically.  Anyhow, the Burger was not as good this time as last.  My friend thought it tasted like a veggie burger, which is decidedly not the point.  But Cockscomb is a pleasant space, and seems to be thriving despite the awful 4th Street construction, now in its second year.
author: Robin W.

description: I absolutely love Date Night.  My hubby chose cockscomb and I must say...of all the bucket list restaurants on his list so far, this has been the absolute best.  Customer service is out of this world...5's all night long.  Alicia was our hostess/ bartender and we couldn't have asked for anyone better.  She catered to us from the moment we were seated in her area till the moment we walked out.  I love love love this place.   It's def pricey but my we don't mind splurging for exceptional food & service.  This is a must visit establishment.
author: Toblessedtobestressed G.

description: Based on great reviews grabbed dinner here. Service is good , food is good too but that's about it nothing special for the premium price unfortunately
author: Rana K.

description: The food was decent. What bothered me the most was the server pushing the shared meat plates on the 3 of us...relentless pursuit. She kept telling us to 'trust' her which immediately makes me not trust her.
author: Eric C.

description: Went here with a group of 8 and the food was amazing.  Be prepared to indulge in meat, meat, and more meat.   The shared plates are huge.  We ordered the pig's head and pin bone steak with foie gras and had leftovers.  Don't be afraid to try the pig's head, while it can be intimidating as it is served whole with the eyeball, teeth, and tongue, the meat around the cheek and neck is super tender and juicy.  The steak was cooked perfectly.  I did feel like I had the meat sweats after though as both dishes had a lot of fat.  The side dishes were yummy, but small compared to the giant shared plates.  It was one spoonful of mushrooms and cauliflower for each of us.  We also ordered the dirty potatoes and grilled cheese to start.  Both are a must.  The grilled cheese was probably the best I've had.  Order more than one if you have more than 2 of you eating it.  This was my second time at this restaurant and I wold come back for sure.
author: Joanne T.

description: Unique cuisine in a completely unique setting in SF.  Food was 100% on point, service was attentive and helpful.  Clean, visible, a great experience.
author: Derek G.

description:
A group of us came for dinner on a reservation. Not much places to park but doable. Going inside and the decor was nicely done--the inside of the building is 2 stories and ambiance was warm with light conversations all around. Not a bad place! I like! okay! Alright, enough of that--the menu can be pricey but doesn't really break the bank much if everyone is paying on their own. 

Now, let me tell you about the cooked steak on a charcuterie board--W T F. It is fucking sweet! For about $100 you get a huge steak that everyone at the table can share and it was cooked BEAUTIFULLY. Charred on the outside and whatever you want inside. The seafood platter combo we got--damn those oysters were freshly chucked and so good. The sauces provided with the seafood were actually quite good and not like some places where it was more of an afterthought. The food is top notch--good job chef!
author: Lucas P.

description:
I had the Impossible Burger for lunch. I've tried the burger before, so I knew what to expect. However, I wanted to see how the chef would prepare it here. It was cooked and seasoned properly. The crisp on the slider had a great texture. If you are expecting the taste of a Boca Burger (which I never cared for at all), it's not even close -- you'll forget that you're not eating animal meat. You'll definitely get a similar taste and feel of a beef burger -- satisfying your tastebuds without giving you the weighty feeling of a cow-produced burger. I'm definitely a meat eater, so I can validate that this is a tasty burger! It's definitely worth checking out. 

The service was excellent and very quick, which is perfect for lunch time.
author: Michelle H.

description:
Went here with a group of co-workers. I had never heard of this place.

Food was OK, service was a little slow, food took a while to come out.

They had an Impossible burger, which I tried and it was interesting. Wish I got the Italian dip. The pig's ears were surprising delicious.

Atmosphere is nice, we sat in the upstairs decor is unique and overall atmosphere is nice.
author: Kathryn Y.

description: The food was amazing. Happy that we like spicy because the bean sauce left or lips tingling, that made me smile. Felt like it qas a way to reamber a great meal a little longer. The bartenter from upstairs was so amazing she was on it as well as the rest of the staff. Will be back to try more dishes but the pig ears and oysters on happy hour are worth it alone for a revisiting. I never tell people to try the special because its always what the chef needs to get out before its bad. But Try the special!!!
author: Red C.

description:
Happy hour at Cockscomb is from 5-6pm and then later again at 10-11pm. You get seated "at the bar" which happens to be upstairs. There are two levels and the entire interior is so beautiful with a rustic charm. 

Getting to this place was a little confusing since the entrance was sort of in an alleyway/side street. Once we went in, the greeter directed us upstairs and we picked seating by the curved counter. The natural sunlight from the top makes for some nice photos. :)

OYSTERS $1/each: I thought the oysters were delicious but a bit on the small side. Granted it is not oyster season since the rule I just learned from my good friend Google is eat oysters on any month with an "R". Oops. But that won't stop me from getting my happy hour on. Amazing mignonette that comes with the oysters. Would definitely recommend getting a whole dozen for yourself.

CRISPY PIG EARS $3: Yum! Crispy and slightly chewy. The lime adds a nice touch. Besides a bit of chili flakes, there also is some basil leaves and cilantro tossed in. 

GRILLED CHEESE $6: Honey, I think there's a contender for best grilled cheese I've ever had. And it might be because of the honey. Duck egg and honey sounds like a fancy combo and really, it is the best thing to have ever been combined. It was grilled perfectly on both sides. The honey gives it a nice sweet start and finish and reminds me of eating French Toast but at the same time a grilled cheese sandwich. The duck egg seemed to be soft boiled and it gives the sandwich a nice salty balance to the sweetness of the honey. Bless this grilled cheese and bless all of the future grilled cheeses I would be eating here at Cockscomb from now on. I shared this with a friend but next time, let me just get a whole one for just moi. Sorry friend.
author: Diana C.

description:
When it smells good before you walk inside you have high expectations. The smell of the wood fire grill illicits thoughts of rich, meaty eats, and that's exactly what you get.

The bustling kitchen presented to the whole dining room is a spectacle itself, where loud shouting orders of pinbone steaks (delicous) and pork heads (amazing) punctuate the conversation in between sips of refreshing and creative cocktails.

I've been here several times, and the meal usually follows these rules. In general anything ordered can be trusted to be delicious.
author: Justin I.

description: My favorite restaurant in SF! I am 100% biased but even if I wasn't married to the chef I'd love this place. It's has a fun and lively vibe, with an incredible open kitchen so you can see the action. The wood oven produces some of the best roasted meats and fish I've ever had. The cocktail program is outstanding. The happy hour rocks. Even lunch is terrific. If I'm not sitting at the bar by the kitchen, I love the catbird seat from the upstairs bar looking down on all the action. Never a dull moment.
author: Tatiana G.

description:
Came here for happy hour and the first thing they asked us on a Wednesday night was do you have a reservation. So I'm guessing this place may get packed regardless of what day. However for happy hour (5-8pm Mon - Thurs) the top floor was pretty spacious and we had no trouble finding 3 seats at the bar. Waitress was very nice and asked for last call orders as we got there 15 minutes before happy hour ended.   

Top floor had a very nice top down view of the rest of the restaurant which is nicely decored with a hipster wooden clean modern barn feel. Really enjoyed my sights during this meal. 

GREAT LITTLE SNACKS THEY GOT HERE.

$1 oysters (miyagi size). These were the main sellers on the menu, however the least of my favorites out of all the dishes we got. To me, they had a too salty after taste to my liking to and to my experience. Wasn't the best I've had. 

$5 Honey Grilled Cheese - This was amazing. I almost ordered another all to myself. The toast was likely grilled with honey first so that it was soaked into the bread and the crusted the top while the cheese was later melted inside. So, much, cheese, porn. 

$3 Fried pig ears - first time getting pig ears an American restaurant. Usually get them at a Chinese restaurant. My oh my these were good. I like the rubbery texture with the salty crunch that is balanced with a little lime. 

$4 Crispy Potatoes - These were great omg. Perfect crisp to soft potatoe ratio. They also have this gravy and mayo sauce that makes everything the more sumptuous. 

As for drinks, all drinks are like $5, I usually get wine, but my friend didn't really enjoy his cocktail. 

Would have been a 5 star if it wasn't for the oysters. The prices for happy hour are not that bad especially for the quality of food. Wonder what it's like for dinner.
author: Tatiana T.
