description: EXCELLENT happy hour and staff. $1 oysters, $2 olives, $6 grilled cheese. The bartender was super kind, and she gave great recommendations. Their gin options are out of this world. Tried four of them and all were absolutely spectacular. I wouldn't have ever thought to try them in such a fashion. Worth a visit for certain!
author: Mal C.

description:
Located in an alley and upon entering, I was already lovin' the charm and seclusion that this place provides! 

Ground level for seating and you can go upstairs to a loft area and then further back, you meet another dining area that exudes communal vibes. 

Got their renowned pig's head that mightily feeds well over 3 people!  Be ready to do some sort of cardio before or after because the pig's head consists of mostly fatty goodness and crunchy pork skin!  They provide a large bowl of vinegary sauce on the side to thin the fattiness of the pork bites and aioli dipping that is made of brain parts!  This is the most interesting dish ever because I didn't know if it was a good splurge on getting my cholesterol level off the roof or not. 

To top the fattiness off, we ordered up duck fat cauliflower and raw oysters as an opening appetizer.  Luckily, I did heated yoga before this dining affair.  Otherwise, I would have been feeling superbly guilty.

Wine compliments all dining meals, so I got their Pinot noir from Oregon.  Clean touch to the palate.

Servers were very nice and hands on.  

We got whisked away to the window seating and it was pleasant to be at while feasting over the richness of the meal!
author: Tiffany D.

description: Cockscomb is never a disappointment. Great drinks and a new take on all your favorite comfort foods- trust me they do it better than your momma (esp. the grilled cheese ). This restaurant is a must if you're looking for a solid meal in an upscale spot.
author: Terrileigh P.

description:
Superb service and Food. Oysters, Ham-Burger and Foie Gras. Excellent pairing with the easy egg. Nice bar menu as well. 

Must come back!
author: mui d.

description: It was very tasty food. The service was very good when they often filled my water. Fast and high-quality, we love them. Recommended.
author: Valentina H.

description: Amazing restaurant. Fabulous food, ambience, and customer service. We sat at the counter and had the good fortune to watch the incredibly talented chefs prepare top quality and beautifully innovative cuisine. We can't wait to go back. We adored  the caring and friendly staff. We thoroughly appreciated the thought, care, and intention that went into our meal.
author: Nancy K.

description: Great food and love the atmosphere! My wife and I will definitely be back. This was our first time here and the service was great, loved their oyster selection and cocktails were delicious. We weren't feel adventurous to try the pig head but maybe next time.
author: Matt R.

description:
I came here with my brother and his gf as a classic third wheel. We ordered the pig's head here for a cultural palate excursion and thought it was no bueno. I realized I am not a fan of eating face. There was a lot of fat on the pig and no garnish. 

We also got some cauliflower dish, which was just okay. 

There is nice seating upstairs.
author: Juliana P.

description: Amazing. All of it. Steak and scallop special was to die for, as were the dirty potatoes.
author: Nuria S.

description:
Did I drink half a bottle of wine before I wrote this review? Maybe, but who's to say. For one, I seriously cannot stop fantasizing about the grilled cheese I had here on my birthday. I know it sounds so basic, "Like really, a grilled cheese?" UHHH YEAH! I don't know what the cheese was, but it was magic and then drizzled with honey and topped with a duck egg. 

Okay! So besides the grilled cheese, we ordered quite the selection for only two people. Because I've might've drank a considerable amount of adult grape juice, only a few dishes stood out. The calf liver (which was a special for the night) was delicious. It was cooked perfectly (slightly pink in the middle) and served with a mushroom sauce. We also ordered the pigs ear terrine as an appetizer, but I honestly didn't think it was that great. The best way I could describe it is like... a pigs ear prosciutto, but with no flavor. It actually reminded me of Vietnamese food, which I could get for a lot cheaper. The one thing that we HAD to get was the roasted pig head. It was tender and fatty with a crispy skin BUT it was way too much for just two people. 

With all that being said, the service was up to par. We were on the way from San Jose and had a little trouble with traffic and parking. All we had to do was call and they were able to accommodate us without a problem. Our server was attentive and since we were sitting at the chefs counter, the cooks were just as much. Would I come back and recommend this establishment? Hell yeah, effing right!
author: Kenitha Y.

description:
Had the impossible burger with no cheese. It was fantastic, there is mayo that isn't listed on the menu so if you're vegan ask for our mayo. The burger was so good, but creepy, it felt like I broke my veganism.

The plates were not all passed out at the same time four our group of 7 but they went above and beyond to make it up to us, and they did. Their professionalism and customer service were outstanding.
author: Skye B.

description: Staff was great, food was equally as good. Went there for a date night with the wife and had an awesome experience. If you can, sit next to the pass, you will see everything coming out. If you go with four people, share the Pin Bone Steak.
author: Calvin R.

description:
If you are ever in SOMA and want a local experience, come here.

This place is filled with really great, down to earth, cool and sweet staff from the front door to the kitchen.

The food is AMAZING. Even though I've mostly dined here with only one or two other people, I recommend coming with a bigger group so you can order and share more of their dishes!

Beef Heart Tartare
BEST OF THE BEST. Ask anyone, I love me some raw beef dishes, and this one is at the top of my list. The bread and greens served with it are PERFECT. Bread is toasted but still fluffy, and the greens cut the heaviness of the beef, its just a beautiful thing happening in your mouth.

Pig Skin Puttanesca
One of the best things I've ever eaten in my entire list. Ever. Ever. I love all things pig, and this pasta had a yumminess to it that can only be described with an "MmMmMmmmmmm" - if you like a little spice, get this. 

Impossible Burger
Vegetarian burger? With the same texture and look and feel of a real burger? WHAT? Yeah well, this $19 burger is worth every bite. The cheese really did it for me! Loved it. As a meat eater I would definitely order this again.

I've been here for lunch, dinner and my birthday and I will keep coming back for more! Stellar happy hour as well :)
author: Taylor S.

description:
Cockscomb recently popped up on my radar since they took reservations for lunch.  It's interesting how so many of the restaurants in SF don't take reservations for lunch since it makes me not want to try it in case they're too busy.  

We got to Cockscomb and we were quickly seated.  The drink menu was awesome and the drinks were well made.  

We shared the Tombo Crudo which was the best crudo I've ever had.  Perfect blend of flavors, not fishy at all, and the rice cracker on top just blew my mind.  

Grilled Cheese sandwich with duck eggs, country ham and honey.  I had a love/hate relationship with this dish.  It was tasty, but a bit too rich and salty.  I felt like I was having mini heart attacks as I was eating.  It went really well with my glass of wine though.

Pig Ears.  This was awesome and great to share.  It's cut into tiny strips so you can pick at it and it wasn't a huge commitment. 

We also ordered the duck fat cauliflower but it never came out.  Big pet peeve is when waiters don't write down my order, thinking they can just remember it all.  Most of the time they forget a dish or leave out a specific instruction like "no onions please".  

Those 3 items plus 2 drinks at lunch including tip came out to $80.  We left extra full and happy and would come back to try the other items on the menu. 

Another table had the potatoes and it looked amazing.  The burgers looked a bit dry though, so just a reminder to myself when I come back to not go straight for the burgers.
author: Vi Y.

description: Jasmine was our server. She was friggin awesome and so sweet and helpful. Really enjoyed the food, eminence, bar, and service all around. Highly recommended trying this place out
author: Matt V.

description:
Lunch review:

In order to prep my stomach for Turkey day I decided to prepare by eating here for lunch. The offerings for lunch lend themself to an easy service which depending on what you're after can be just fine or limited. Unfortunately, their lunch menu doesn't offer many of the more interesting dinner options. But what they do have is a modest selection of good sandwiches, drinks, oysters and cured meats. Hopefully this place gets really busy so they have the business to fire up that oven and offer some of their family style meat options to their lunch service. Until then it's a solid place to grab a good drink and reasonably priced lunch meal.
author: Darin E.

description:
I will always remember this restaurant as the time I ordered a whole pigs head on a platter. 

Let's just say that this meal was not meant for 2 but a small group. It's extremely rich and fatty! After a few bites you just give up but the experience was worth it! Just make sure you have at least 4 people to share this with or it becomes way too heavy to enjoy anything else. 

We also ordered the heart tartare with was delicious and light before the pig arrived. I highly recommend this. I regret not ordering the pork chop but where the hell will I get to order a whole pig head again?!  Overall, I had a great experience here and I'm excited to come back!
author: Jeanne L.

description: Incredible food! The way the chef combines seasonings is out of this world! We had the tuna appetizer special and it was delectable! I was pleasantly surprised to find a tempranillo wine on menu, which paired beautifully with the scallops and I had as an entree. We will definitely go back!
author: Bethany N.

description:
One word: FAN-FRIGGIN'-TASTIC. The Impossible Burger is incredible and is a must try even if you're a carnivore. 

My vegetarian brother came to visit from Kansas City so I had to do a little bit of research to find some good vegetarian grub because I can't take him to my usual favorite places where they have limited vegetarian items. This is one of two restaurants in SF that serves the Impossible Burger so I made a lunch reservation for us to check this place out. 

Our server was sweet but didn't seem very knowledgeable about the menu. I asked her to please point out the vegetarian items and she pretty much just said they had the Impossible Burger and not much else. Great way to fail on making a sale because I'm sure the kitchen could have left out some meat accoutrements if a special request was made. We ended up reading the menu ourselves to figure out what didn't have meat and I confirmed with her they were vegetarian before putting in the order. 

Our meal started with the gnocchi with sage brown butter and the house potatoes. Gnocchi was soft and fluffy and covered in awesome sauce i.e. brown butter sauce. House potatoes came perfectly crisped and brown on the outside with a delicious horseradish aoli that had a nice kick. For entrees we ordered the grilled cheese with duck egg and honey and OF COURSE the Impossible Burger. The grilled cheese must be eaten all together as in you must get a bite of the grilled cheese with the egg and honey to maximize deliciousness. Best part of the meal was without a doubt, the burger. It looked just like meat but texture is different from what you would expect from a plant based burger patty. It tasted to me almost like cut up shiitake mushrooms and had an incredible umami that's hard to describe. The pairing with the house made bread and butter pickles as well as mustard and cheese were just perfection. You have to go try it for yourself! We ended our meal with the chocolate dessert which was just a block of chocolate fudge with some cream and pistachios. I was expecting cake and am not a fan of fudge in general so didn't enjoy dessert at all. 

Restaurant is not very big so seating is a little tight. Be prepared to get cozy with your party and neighboring table! My one and only major complaint about this place is the lack of window coverings. Depending on the time of day, at least one person is screwed and will have the sun directly in their eyes because of the layout and lack of blinds or shades over the windows. We ended up finding one spot behind the hostess stand where it was shaded and requested to move. I would have been pissed if we were forced to stay where they initially sat us because my husband would have had the sun in his eyes the entire meal. 

Street parking is available but limited so best way to get here is probably by Uber or Lyft, or MUNI if you don't mind walking a few blocks. They lock the doors before the clock strikes 11:30a so don't bother getting there too early for lunch because you'll be waiting outside in the cold. 

Decor is really unique and has a sense of humor. You must check out the bathroom if you go and don't forget to open the medicine cabinet/mirror to take a peek! Hilarious!
author: Betty R.

description: This place is stupid for hh! They have 1$ oyster and thats why we came but they wouldnt serve oysters anywhere but bar. Whole seats are open and they would force customers to seat at the bar for oyters. I would never recommend this place for HH!!
author: Hazel I.

description:
Food +3: Delicious and impressive Impossible Burger (sadly only available for lunch weekdays, dinner soon maybe?) As week as fantastic dinner potatoes, great beer, and had a great cocktail and espresso also.

Space: +1 very pretty inside, close to convention center (10 minute walk).

Service: +2 bartender was very nice, had great suggestions, and was very attentive. 

Price: -1 more expensive location, probably better value elsewhere (Public house has a cheaper, but not as thich and delicious impossible burger).

Total price with tip = $73
Total score= 5/5
author: Chris O.

description:
I had high expectations for Cockscomb, but it turned out to be one of the worst dinning experiences that we have had in 2015. 

(Fact) We made reservations a week prior and took the earliest time for August 29, 9:15 pm. It was late for us but since we bought into the "hype" we made the trek from the East Bay. We met my daughter who works in San Francisco at Cockscomb. 

(Fact) We arrived at 9 pm  fifteen minutes before our assigned reservations. I was watching the other customers enjoying their beef steaks and crab. We waited till past 9:40 pm until we were seated up stairs. It was almost 10 pm by the time the server David S. took our dinner order.

(Fact) When I ordered the seafood platter, David informed me that they sold out on crab. I agreed to substitute the crab for some tuna tartar / poke thing. Definitely, not even comparable. 

(Fact) When I got to the shared Supper portion Steak, David informed me that they were out. So I ordered the Pigs Head. David informed me they were out. So I ordered the Coulotte Steak, David informed me they ran out of all beef items. I informed him of our table of 4 disappointment. I asked him what do they have since the menu was so limited. He suggested that they had a shared Pork Chop dish. It was 10 pm and our entire table was hungry and disappointed at the events and to be frank if weren't so late I would have got up and left. We settled for the Pork Chop dish. "oh what a mistake"!! A $75 mistake. It was as tough as any baseball glove I have ever owned and it was 50% fat. As we left there was over 3/4 of the dish left. But note to Chris Cosentino my dogs loved it.

(Fact) The one other notable failure is the sausage which was so salty that what was left the critters in my neighborhood.

(Fact) After the disappointment with the nights events, I wanted to take to yelp and write the review, but I thought the manager or the owners would want to know about our experience. So I waited till 5 pm on Monday when they opened again and spoke to Stephen the manager. When I told him the time of our reservations he was able to pull up the info. I informed him of running out of all the different items. If Cockscomb was unprepared to serve that late then they should not have taken the reservation so late, and on top of that people were still getting beef and crab after our designated 9:15 pm reservations. Stephen's response was " we had a unexpectedly busy weekend". He repeated this 3 times through out our brief conversation until I had to repeat it back to him. "No apologies." He said he would bring it up to the attention of the "higher ups". and get back with me. 

$330 for a meal of salted pork fat and lard.
author: George F.

description:
Grilled Cheese- #62 on the 2016 100 Things to Eat in San Francisco Before You Die List

3.5 stars but rounding up for the creativity in dishes and great service. I finally made it to Cockscomb after having it on my list since they opened. I was able to make reservations a couple days before for dinner on a Saturday night at 8:30pm for a party of 4. We were running about 15 minutes late, and they were super accommodating about pushing our reservation back. Our table was ready when we arrived, and I love how you can see the open kitchen from any seat in the restaurant. We tried:

-Grilled Cheese (Duck Egg, Honey, $12, http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=dVXnplIjbeppj50nVvbKAg&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Yum- their grilled cheese had the perfect cheese to bread ratio, and we were all surprised at how well the honey worked with the sandwich. A must try!
-"Ham"Burger (Caramelized Onions, Tomato, Gruyere, Served w/Crispy Potatoes, $15, http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=Ztg96lLfoQRq9plDBg_69g&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): This is an interesting take on the traditional hamburger made with beef, since they make the patty with ground pork instead. I liked the combination of ingredients for the burger, but the patty was a bit on the dry side so I probably wouldn't get this again.
-Duck Fat Cauliflower (Chili, Garlic, Mint, $7, http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=VdurBvGMkisR5cwc1A1j7A&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Very interesting combination of ingredients, and we all liked the mint in this dish. 
-Chinese Broccoli (Garlic, Shiso, $7): Good, but only get this if you like bitter tasting vegetables, since the chinese broccoli (gai lan) is on the bitter side.
-Summer Squash (Oregano, Chile, $7, http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=hrKO92EwgwoIUXIIcPtUNA&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Just ok for me since I'm not a huge fan of squash. I wish the pieces were smaller so more of the piece was seared instead of the mushier squash consistency- skip!
-Fruit (Polenta Cake w/Plum Jam, Figs, Wrapped in Fig Leaf, Drizzled in Olive Oil, http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=BgY_JWRewABAGz2QlKYn7Q&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Another unique item, and I liked this more than I thought I would. The polenta cake had a grainy consistency, but the flavors were really good, and I loved the plum jam, figs, and fig leaf. Recommended!

A few people ordered the pin bone steak, which they slice and serve on a platter, and it looked amazing!! I would definitely recommend ordering this if you're here with 2-3+ other people, since it feeds 3-5. The chocolate dessert also looked really delicious, and we were torn between ordering that and trying the polenta cake. Our server was great- super friendly and knowledgeable about the menu. I would definitely come back to try their other dishes. Parking wasn't bad in this area later on a Friday night, and there were a good amount of street parking spots available.
author: Amy D.

description:
I love this restaurant. It exemplifies all things SF - the location, the decor, the hyper local ingredients, and especially the Impossible Burger (only at lunch).

If you aren't familiar with the Impossible Burger - here is the elevator pitch...  An impossible burger is a vegetarian burger that has the taste and texture of traditional beef hamburger. Environmentally friendly, the impossible burger is made from "heme" which is extracted from soybeans and fermented in yeast.

I've been here several times for the Impossible Burger(lunch time reservations are highly encouraged) and I'd say the burger isn't going to fool anyone soon, but it's also far better than a bean or veggie burger.

But as with all things Silicon Valley/SF, the secrecy around the impossible burger is overly precious. You are not allowed to take any of the Impossible Burger out, even if you can't finish it, you aren't allowed to doggie bag it.
author: Madison W.

description:
It was our wedding anniversary and we are big fans of Chris.  Unfortunately we didn't see him there.  

We made yelp reservations so seating wasn't a problem.  It was a Tuesday night and parking wasn't too bad but if there was no parking; the one way streets would kill yah especially during peak traffic.

Service was excellent very friendly staff.

Food was good but wasn't worth the wait.  Even with reservations at 7pm we didn't get our food til an hour later.

For food, the starters we had were the hot mess and duckfat cauliflower.  I have to say the Hot mess was the best dish of the night.  Duckfat cauliflower we didnt even get til our main dishes arrive.

Wife ordered the Chicken and waffles.  seasoned perfectly tasted great.
I ordered the Hamburger with egg and foie.  It was messy but good.  I wanted to ask for ketchup with the fries but didn't know if I was gonna offend the staff or not lol.  

Overall being huge fans of Chris we did have high expectations for the food.  service was definitely met but wait time was bad.  I also overheard from servers that they were training 3 new people from the kitchen so maybe that was the issue.  If we got to meet Chris I'd probably bump this review to a 5 haha.

We might go again but this time with friends so we can try the pigs head or pin bone steak but not anytime soon.
author: Angelo I.

description:
I have been watching the chef on television for many years and I insisted on dining here when we were in san francisco for one night. My friends say they never come to this part of town and boy were they surprised.

We were a part of six and ordered a lot to drink and eat! The table next to us upstairs was a large party and we kept on watching what they were ordering. We needed up starting with salads and foie gras. We then moved up to the big boy plates. Pork and beef. The beef dish was so large my friend took it home and had leftovers for two meals! We were so happy with our experience. I cannot wait to come back again. You will not be let down! Enjoy.
author: David L.

description:
Two words: Grilled. Cheese. 

I'm not the kind of person who likes to order things at restaurants that I could make at home, but this is one of the best grilled cheeses that will cross your lips. Not joking.

The bacon chop is tasty, but the burger is juicy and great. Try it if you're into pork burgers.
author: Christina S.

description:
I used to love Cockscomb.... a lot! This was the place where I would satisfy my meat cravings. However, on my recent visit, I was feeling disappointed with the service and the food.  

I ordered the usual: 
1) Tombo crudo: nice raw tuna cubes marinated in Vietnamese herbs, served with rice cracker. I thought it was a nice dish/ appetizer. Bright, refreshing taste with nice acidity. 
2) Pepper squid and radishes: this was new for me. I have been here many times and this was the first time I ordered this dish. It was ok, a bit blend to be honest. Need some kick to it. Perhaps some acid?
3) Pig skin spaghetti: this is my ultimate favorite dish from this restaurant and I was so disappointed that it never made it to our table. I actually reminded our waitress that we ordered the pig skin spaghetti when they brought out new utensils after our appetizers. She acknowledged my message and said that she didn't want to bring the spaghetti with the other appetizers because the spaghetti is spicy and should be served separately.... yea whatever!
4) Coulotte steak: I remember this dish being very juicy and seductive and this particular time, it was looking pretty sad. I ordered my steak medium; the edges were looking more like well done and I saw some hint of pink in the middle portion of the meat but they seemed super dry... not very appealing unfortunately (they looked very pale and grey)... or maybe I was still upset that they decided to skip my pig skin spaghetti!!

Service was okay. The waitress didn't apologize about messing up our order or forgetting our spaghetti. Not sure if it's her fault or the kitchen fault. In addition, she didn't check if the steak was cooked to our liking! 

Maybe it's just me but I feel like the quality of the food is not as good as it used to.
author: Sam M.

description: Not only was the scenery absolutely exceptional, the part tenders for very knowledgeable about every ingredient that when's the drinks and we're very exceptional with customer service. I have and exceptional experience here compared to majority of the bar is not only in the area, but in all of San Francisco. This is probably one of the few bars that I recommend to friends and acquaintances in the San Francisco area.
author: Shelby B.

description:
Meat lovers rejoice for here is your sanctuary!!!! 

Portions for side dishes and appetizers are small. Meat dishes are huge portions. 

Service is one of the bet I've had in SF. Waiter was informative, friendly and most importantly, not pushy or quick to rush us to turn the table. 

Worth every penny. Go there now!!!... Unless you're a vegetarian.
author: Mandi W.

description:
I hate to write this review as I have a lot of respect for Chris Cosentino both as a chef and person, however the meal I just had at Cockscomb was bloody awful. There were four of us eating and we started with the beef heart tartare, little gem salad and a tuna collar special. Tartare was underwhelming and my wife said it had the consistency of cat food, it was lacking salt or any bright notes, totally forgettable, little gem salad was also missing some acidity and was a real snoozer. The tuna collar was described to us as being braised on a bed of aromatics, when it came to the table it was indeed on a veritable medley of stuff with varying degrees of edibility. There was roasted garlic but only the smaller cloves were cooked the larger ones were straight up lumps of raw garlic, the dish was also sprinkled with pink peppercorns which were also inedible, I felt that it was an appetizer minefield and was scared to take bites in case I was unfortunate enough to encounter something I didn't want to swallow, I will also say this dish was also lacking salt. Be careful what you wish for though because the entrees arrived and suddenly it became apparent what the kitchen had been holding on to the salt for. Three of us at the table got the coulotte steak, it looked great but the very first bite of the meat proved so salty I immediately started looking around for our server, the rest of the steak orderers were also pushing their plates away from them. Our server was great and asked if we would like the same dishes but with less salt, I opted to try the fennel sausage instead and the other two switched out to the pasta with bottarga dish.
About 15 minutes later out comes my sausage entree which was basically a sausage with a side salad....odd. One bite of the sausage and it was salt lick city all over again and if anything it was even saltier than the steak (which I considered to be only slightly less saline than the Dead Sea). Also oddly one of my dinner companions pasta was ok and the other one was also off the charts salty.
Needless to say at this point we cut our losses and asked for the check, the server was gracious enough to not charge us for any of the disastrous entrees.
Another thing that spoiled the experience for me was the constant yelling out of tickets by the expediter, is it really necessary to be so loud, I mean people are trying to talk and not get PTSD from the constant shouting. Maybe instead of yelling he could have put his mouth to better use by tasting the food that was leaving the kitchen?
The whole experience was solely redeemed by the professionalism of the front of house staff. Will never be back.
author: Leal L.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place for awhile... and I finally came for a bday celebration.

Lets get straight into the food! 

We had to try the grilled cheese! 
It was not like any grilled cheese I've ever had. It was nice, light and crispy with a syrup and an over easy egg. Yum, definitely suggest that!

We asked the waitress which sharable dish she suggest since we were deciding between the pigs head or the lamb. I was leaning more toward the lamb  since i did not think my guest and I would be able to finish a pigs head. However she assured us we can and said they ran out of the lamb on a Friday night at 630? 

Ok? So you've run out of 1 of the 3 sharable options?

So i guess we're getting the pig head, which is exactly what it sounds like. Ploup they brought out a  huge plate with the pigs head. We barely dented the cheek of the pig let alone the head itself! Meanwhile, the table next to us just ordered the lamb? Wait what? There was still lamb?

Waitress: "oh I guess they made more?"

Thanks for checking... while we eat a few bites of this greasy pig head which we can totally finish right? 

So my guest and i each bring back a brick of half the pigs head back home. Yum :/ food was good.... i would say if you have more than 6 people, the pigs head would he a good option. Not for 2 people though!
author: Mich L.

description: Food was brilliant and tasty. Came with couple of friends surely Cockscomb does not disappoint. Definitely will come again
author: Andrew B.

description:
I am so disappointed in this place. :( 

My boyfriend and I had dinner here about 13 hours ago. We have both been unable to leave the restroom for the past 4!! not cool. 

We ordered the appetizer special, Foie Gras with figs and trotter, and had the lobster and steak main course special with the mushrooms to share. We had the fig tart for desert. The food tasted great. In fact, we both said we would like to bring some of our foodie friends..... but then our dinner hit our digestive systems. 

I would bet it was the foie gras. Which is insanely disappointing considering the reputation of this place! 

The upside, our server was awesome! So thanks to that guy. 

But to spend over $200 on a meal to result in a few hour of violent illness is frustrating.
author: Leah C.

description: Two words. Pig head. Get it. You won't be disappointed. Bring some men with you or some really hungry ladies because it'll take 4 if you to finish it at least. The fried squid and ears was tasty as were the potatoes. Kohlrabi tasted like a Caesar salad almost, delicious! Only thing I would pass on in the future would be the cauliflower. That was oily and tasteless. Everything else packed a punch! Yum!
author: Breana T.

description:
I consider myself an adventurous eater-- one of my recent incredible meals was at a wagyu restaurant in Tokyo, where one of the multitude of plates was 子宮 (uterus!). It was exquisite and had both great taste and texture. Later on, I realized Chris Cosentino had previously done Incanto. A few Valentines Day back I was there and had a memorable meal of heart. I had no desire to eat the kæstur hákarl in Iceland but maybe when I return I'll try the svið. 

Anyway, I was excited by this restaurant as the Impossible Burger was talked up by my colleagues. We arrived early after work on Friday, and decided to adventure on the pig's head. It looked a bit gross, and we could hear the chatter from the neighboring tables.

How to eat it? Apparently, just dig in. There was some exquisite meat under the skin, which was dark and shredded, and reminded us of duck meat. The skin was a little dry and sticky, but it was okay. The big piece of pig rind was a bit more crunchy and had a better taste.

The fat!! Maybe our pig was extra fatty. You'd take a scoop from the face, and it'd be a blob of fat. You'd think, sure, I'll give it a try, it's on my plate. It tasty-- fatty, again not too delicious, but as the manager quoted later, 'rich'.

Apparently a lot of people don't feel well after eating the pig head. I'd even be willing to pay an extra $20 for them to carve it in front of us. Sure, give us the photo op, but don't expect us to know how to either eat or enjoy it.

30 minutes later, my vomit streak was set to 0.

+1 star for the concept of shared suppers
author: Isaac L.

description:
+ Delicious cocktails
+ Fun to people watch from the second floor
author: Margaret R.

description:
Califonian fare done extremely well. I'd recommend coming for lunch, I need to come back for a dinner experience. 

Fun and large set up on multiple levels. Nice spot to just hang out.  

Our Rami Malek look alike server was extremely attentive and made perfect and opinionated suggestions.  

We started with the Tombo Crudo. Amazing dish that perfectly combined Vietnamese flavors with California freshness.  Heirloom tomato toast was amazing and an absolute must before tomato season ends.  

The entrees are all sandwiches which come out fast making this a great lunch spot.  The fried chicken sandwich, not only tasted great with the maple aioli but it was light and didn't leave me heavy and greasy.  We also had "ham" burger with optional foie gras.  This was a bit boring and the foie was not additive to the burger. It was also small for the price.  Lastly we had the potatoes.  They were ok but I'd skip next time.

I'd come back, fun place, good food.
author: Trekforbeer B.

description:
Awesome Food!!! We order Wood Oven Roasted Pig's Head and Grilled Cheese.
The Wood Oven Roasted Pig's Head is delicious.
I told my friends that Wood Oven Roasted Pig's Head taste better than Filipino Lechon.
Grilled Cheese with duck head is so good.
I highly recommend Cockscomb!
author: Charina T.

description:
I came here a week ago for my friends birthday.  We were a decent sized group but didn't have to wait.  Our table was ready but a few of us went early and were enjoying happy hour so they let us hang out by the bar upstairs before seating.  They didn't pressure us to sit right away or keep us from enjoying $1 oysters.

At happy hour I had the wit and split the grilled cheese.  That grilled cheese tho!  It was absolutely delicious!  Just enough sweet with that savory cheese.  For dinner we had the pin bone steak and oven roasted pig head.  The pig head is just half of the head, but that and the pin bone steak (4 lbs + additional 4 oz of fois gras we added) were still more than enough for 6 of us (3 light eaters and 3 heavy eaters).

We needed some veggies so we added the duck fat cauliflower.  It was delish with a small hint of heat.  Everything was cooked perfectly and did not disappoint.  The cocktails were also very whimsical, fun and delicious.  I tried the Pursuit of Happyness and another with coconut milk in it.

Service was a 10.  Our server was very friendly, easy to talk to and was very helpful with answering any weird questions we had like "will the Pursuit of Happyness make me sleepy?"

I can't even remember what we ordered for dessert because I couldn't even make it there.  I think 11 of us split 1 dessert.  Haha.
author: Tammie S.

description:
Good. Not destination worthy. Gin centric drink menu and rather unimaginative dinner menu, below expectations given the head chef's media persona as a master of delicious organ meats. Some of the items we got were named misleadingly on the menu, which was another spot they underdelivered. Food was good though. Definitely edible.  

This is probably a good spot for happy hour if you live nearby however.
author: John R.

description: Been here twice now for my birthday it's so great! The food is amazing; the staff are attentive and friendly.
author: Susan B.

description:
I had the rico cocktail. It was fine. Exactly as advertised. No demerits there.

Entrance: i walked in with no reso. I felt like i was treated like yesterdays trash. I came in at an early time (6pm sat) to not have been treated as such. The entire reataurant was basically available/un sat.

I was taken tonthe dungeon aka the upstairs bar. There was no light. I moved myself to a stand up table.  

Ordered the grilled cheese w egg. It was fine toast and nothing more than exactly what it was.

I ordered the burger w foie gras. I saw the raving reviews. Yelp elite didnt have much to say but i was craving a burger. 

On a side note I couodnt even see what I was eating w the obstructed light so I couldnt tell if Ihad food on my fork at some points.

Top chef got it right. Not worthy of a top rating. Not even worth me trying ever again.

Upon leaving, the staff didnt even greet me fairwell like i was the peasant they sat at a table with no light. Mind you i had just spebt 70$ in 20 min meal.

NEXT
author: Foodie 1.

description: Came here for a birthday with about 8 people , the service was pretty good ... and thats the only reason this place gets 2 stars  , the food was awful and totally over priced .. was expecting a lot more knowing this chefs previous work . Don't go to this place , unless you want to be over charged .... NOPA is a way better restaurant in this category
author: Micah W.

description: Really tasty lunch here. The Mexico City ceviche is 5-star, best one I've had in San Francisco. It was perfect. If you can get over the psychological hurdle, the beef heart tartare is not to be missed as well. It was as tender and taste as the tuna tartare cousin. Compliment with a healthy Nicoise salad to round out. Other dishes we had were the tasty duck fat cauliflower, it was good, but standard and the fried pig's ear was good, but would not order again. On a previous visit I had their ham burger, which was good, but considering all the other options, I see no need for that. Looking forward to a next visit.
author: Brian J.

description:
What a dining experience! You enter the restaurant from a not-so-flashy entrance to a beautifully decorated interior. Open kitchen, ambient lighting, eclectic decorations, it makes for a perfect SF dinner.

We called for a reservation and found out that for parties of 5 or more, they require putting down credit card information. We ended up being just 4 people and arrived 45 minutes earlier than planned. They were very accommodating and were able to seat us right away. 

The service was friendly and very quick. The server was knowledgeable in the menu and gave great recommendations. The most impressive was that we were not looking to spend a lot of money and she didn't seem annoyed by this. She gave fantastic recommendations for saving money and still getting enough food to fill us up. 

Some of our selections were grilled cheese with duck egg, HAM burger, and Zampini. The food came out faster than expected and was delicious. I thought the grilled cheese was good but not great. But it definitely changed my life for the better because who would've thought to put HONEY on grilled cheese??? I wasn't that big of a fan of the duck egg on top, maybe I just don't like the consistency of duck egg. The HAMburger was delicious, probably my favorite of the night. The patty (made of ham, obvi) was juicy and tender. The dish came with large heaps of roasted potatoes. This all came out to be just $15, well worth it. Lastly, the Zampini. I really struggled understanding what this dish was at first until it came out and it was a ring of sausage. The sausage itself was good, but nothing too special. However, the corn and tomato succotash of sorts was the highlight of the plate for me. Not sure what seasoning they used, but it was a weird but delicious flavor. 

I took off one star because for a restaurant with the price that they charge, the menu items weren't that appealing to me. I chose the grilled cheese appetizer as an entree because nothing else sounded THAT amazing to me. To each their own though, I think the food was still fantastic I would give the other items a try next time. Definitely a fun place for date night or getting a SF dining experience if you're from out of town.
author: Chelsea C.

description:
Chef Chris Cosentino! Thanks for the excellent food!

Came here for a birthday dinner on Saturday night. We had a reservation for 5 and I was the first to arrive 15 mins early, but our table was already ready and after I was brought there, the staff showed me where the bar was and suggested I could either hangout at the bar and waited at the table. Very thoughtful service!

It's not a big menu but all the dishes names sound very tempting. And since it is so hard to decide.... we just went ahead with the "Shared Supper" items and got both of them plus two other appetizers.

#Beef Heart Tartare - Appetizers ($16): A.
Beef tartare is pretty common but beef heart? It turned out to be pretty delicious. The meat definitely contained a lot more fat, and the texture was more smooth than regular beef tartare. I actually almost felt like eating fatty tuna tartare. Used it as a spread on grilled bread. Wonderful.

#Octopus A La Plancha - Appetizers ($18): B.
Not sure about this one. Portion was very small, and there were only few pieces of octopus plus some vegetables. Not recommended.

#Pin Bone Steak - Shared Supper ($110): A+.
First off, the price did justify at least from the portion point of view - this dish alone could have fed 6 people. And the steak itself was bomb! Very, very nicely cooked. Even though the bone size was enormous, every piece of meat I tasted was almost at the same level of rawness (borderline of rare and medium rare). Very juicy, very tender. This dish came with two sauces: bone marrow sauce and red wine sauce. Honestly I could not taste much from the bone marrow sauce, probably the flavor from bone marrow was sort of on the light side. But the red wine sauce was definitely worth to be put on the steak. Some vege that came with this dish definitely helped balanced my stomach a little bit.

#Wood Oven Roasted Pig Head - Shared Supper ($65): A+.
This dish alone could have fed another 4 people! What a big head. For anyone that has tried Chinese style roasted pig before this dish actually reminded me exactly that. The skin was crispy (not brittle enough to a point that it would break once you bite on it though) but the meat / fat underneath was WOW. It was actually a huge amount of fat. If it was not cooked properly it would actually feel pretty nasty to put so much fat in your mouth at the same time. Nothing like that from this dish. Very flavorful and the temperature was just about right. The meat tasted like moist pulled pork with lots of flavor too.

Some other notes:
- Cocktails were great. We tried "The Towering Inferno" (gin and ginger beer based) and "About Cherry Sling" (gin and cherry based) and both were very refreshing, not too strong and tasted very fruity.
- Service was wonderful. Our server was wonderful and very attentive, and very energetic when explaining the menu to us. The cocktails above were actually suggested by him, he surely knows what's good there.
- At the end of our dinner Chef Chris Cosentino walked out from the kitchen, sat down at our table chatted with us for quite a bit of time! He explained his philosophy of this restaurant, his goal about customer experience, what new dish he is working on etc. A very nice and passionate chef. We got to take a picture with him too!

Overall, a wonderful dining experience with amazing food. I may not be coming back too often because the dishes were just too meaty but if I can manage to gather a big group of friends from out of town, Cockscomb will definitely be the few on top of my list for dinner gathering.
author: Simon C.

description:
MEAT SWEATS...I think I still had them 3 days later!  Thats also how long it took to finish the left overs!  Nestled right across the street from where I used to live in SOMA, it is unassuming in front, but once inside, it is well laid out, seems bigger than it is space.  The open kitchen makes the dimly lit room more lively and exciting than your standard $$$ dining room.

But really, this place is about the food...and when I mean food I mean the different meat platters!!!  Okay, so we started off with the Grilled Cheese with Egg and Honey.  As far grilled cheeses go, you really can't get better than this.  Well you can, I was slightly disappointed that it wasn't the Truffle Grilled cheese I saw in pics on yelp, but I guess its not truffle season. Never the less, excellent grilled cheese.  The next dish was the pig ears and cabbage salad.  Similar to a Vietnamese salad dish, it was a bit tangy and spicy.  However, I probably would have enjoyed the pig ears by themselves, without all the cabbage and dressing.

After wetting our appetites, we continued on to the heavier plates.  The beef heart tartare was delicious, but not for the faint of heart...  BEEFY is the best way to describe the flavor and the bread was perfectly grilled and buttered!  SO GOOD!  The butcher's choice was lamb heart with yellow zucchini.  It was well seasoned and cooked, but it just wasn't my thing.

The main event featured the heavy weight of the heavy weights!  Pine Bone Steak with Bone Marrow Dip!  The steak took a while, but after the seeing the size of it, you understand why.  Must have been at least 3 pounds!  The charring and seasoning was excellent.  The edges were a bit over cooked but it was darn near perfect the rest of the way.  The bone marrow dip was so flavorful and added an extra kick for your taste buds.  Of course the Au Jus kept it moist and juicy!  

Overall, I loved the experience at Cockscomb!  Will definitely come back for the pig's head!!! And maybe bring more people so we can get that Pin Bone Steak again too!!!
author: Veasna H.

description:
This place was on point. Service was amazing and added to the overall experience including great recommendations for the table. The whole place smelled amazing and when the food began arriving no one was disappointed. The grilled cheese was so delicious I barely have words to do it justice. Everyone in our party was more than happy with their dishes and we all shared with each other to try and determine whose was best. 

Throughly enjoyed the experience from start to finish and cannot wait to go back again.
author: Karina B.

description:
I love this place cos I love meat.

The love the food, ambience, service. I would come here again (maybe not recommend it to everyone cos then I wont be able to make reservations).

We went here for my birthday (every top/hip place to eat in the city were fully booked). The ambience was really nice, post industrial chic with metal work and exposed beams. Very nice. Our server (I am sorry I forgot your name) super lovely woman. She gave us so many tempting ideas on what to eat (I can tell she loves the food). We ordered lobster with pork belly, I think hanger steak, cauliflower in duck fat, and other things I cant remember. Everything was so good, so luscious. Even the vegetables tasted like meat (I think they were braised with pork juice). I only survived this fatty goodness cos of the awesome wine selection.

I will for sure go back. I need to exercise first.
author: Herb D.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place for a while, and what better night than a date night on Friday.   When we got here it was packed on a hot SF summer night, but the ventilation was keeping us cool. We sat at the bar, always fun to see them make the food, especially here, with some of the creative dishes.

We got the hot mess, bruschetta, steak and roasted beets. 

The hot mess, was a bit of a mess, the flavors overpowered the foie gras, and the brioche under it was soggy. I would have liked more foie and less mess.  But the flavors were nice.

The bruschetta was ok, nothing special, it was salmon with dill, great bread, but overall very forgettable.

The steak was great, the heirloom tomatoes with it also really yummy, we shared everything and it was a great dish to share.

The beets were good, with goat cheese, not as tender as I expected, nice pairing but not anything I would run back to.

Overall, I really liked the vibe of the place and food, it's fun, social and creative with some fun surprises on the menu.
author: Inga W.

description:
The food was good but the service is at most two stars. But also the drinks sucked. Ok mine. I got the bulliet and it was way too sweet contrary to the menu description.

Slow service meant we missed out on the pigs head. Tried to substitute the liberty duck but she lagged so much they ran out of that! Took at least 25 minutes to even take our order  even though we said we were ready from the get go. I mean, who even goes without scoping out the menu!!?? And the server kept trying to upsell different items which ate into our previous time. We ordered quite a few dishes (6 for 4) but she kept pushing for more.

The food was great but missing out on the main attraction due to slow service is a real shame.
author: Deanna L.

description:
They change their menu quite often, so what you see on yelp isn't always what you'll get. I was hoping for the bone marrow regular entree to be on the many, but they only had the $125 one.  

I had the beef tartare and duck liver bruschetta. The beef tartare was okay,  I was hoping for more of a citrus flavor.  The duck liver brushetta was great, slab on pate on bread and I'm sold. It came with mushrooms which compliments it well. Both neighbors of ours had the pork head to share, very entertaining to see them a bit in shock of how huge it was. 

The drinks were good,  apparently they specialize in gin.


The servers and bartenders were great,  friendly vibe. Also, love the music. Would come back during peak uni season and for the bone marrow!
author: Mandy D.

description:
I was hoping to like this place as it's close to where I live, but alas, it did not meet expectations.

I ordered one of their appetizers of the day, a foie gras and roasted peach dish, with a side of roasted cauliflower. Everything tastes good, but nothing tastes amazing.

My boyfriend ordered the chop, which was huge! Definitely enough food for two to share. I tried it and thought it was a bit bland. 

Nice cozy environment, but not my top pick for soma.
author: Cynthia X.

description:
I had a fantastic meal here. Partly due to great company but food was easily 5 stars. I held back 1 star because I felt that the prices are extremely inconsistent. $105 for clams and pork belly?!?! That was the special of the day. Not sure what they can possible do to the pork belly and clams to justify the $100 bucks but I was not about to order it to find out. We just moved on to another special they had, pig skin linguini. It was a reasonable $18 and well worth it. It was creative and delicious. Another example is the lemonade (non-alcoholic). It was $7. And no, it did not come with refills. It was super sour, I had to ask for simple syrup. 

The dish that really blew my mind was the kale salad with butternut squash and bird seeds ($14). It was unique and packed with flavors. 
Pigs ear terrine ($13) - was reminiscent of a Vietnamese salad, which had great flavors. The pig ears were thinly shaved and not chewy. 
Squid and tomatillo ($15) - the squid, grape and tomatillo pairing was super refreshing.
Bacon chop ($34) - it was moist, smokey and flavorful. 
Pin bone steak ($125) - This was a fun dish. Yes, the price tag is shocking but it feeds at least four. The steak came on a butcher board the size of our table. I do think it was under seasoned but nonetheless it was a great cut of beef. The sauces that came with it was great as well. I wish our server had told us it was that big. Not knowing, we over ordered.

Desserts were the weakest dishes of the night. We had the panna cotta and a fruit popover. Both were fine but were overshadow by the great savory courses we had earlier.

I suggest coming here with a group of 4, order a few apps and the pin bone steak. You'll thank me later.
author: Andy W.

description: The service here is incredible. I highly recommend sitting near the kitchen so you can see their work. I love meat but ordered the carrot entree because it sounded so interesting - it was delicious! My partner had the roasted chicken and it was divine. We also had the duck fat cauliflower - it was a little too spicy but otherwise delicious. The raw button mushroom app was so light and flavorful. Wish we had room for the whole pineapple dessert - it sounded amazing!
author: Tiffany S.

description:
Came here with two foodie out of town colleagues. Food (fish, steak, cauliflower side, charcuterie platter) was outstanding and the service excellent. The waiter steered us toward exactly the types of wines we each wanted. 
I'm not taking a point off for this, but they really need to offer gluten-free crackers or bread. I want to come back with my husband who needs GF option.
author: Christina F.

description: I really wanted to like this place. The pictures make it look amazing! However the food was a bit underwhelming. We ordered some oysters (fresh and delicious!), the grilled cheese with duck egg and honey (nothing spectacular) and of course the pin bone steak for the main course. While the steak is a fairly sizeable portion, there just wasn't any flavor to the dish at all. I kept pouring on the bone marrow sauce to add flavor. The steak desperately needed salt! A good steak ought not to depend on sauce for flavor. Aside from the oysters (which you can get at other SF restaurants), the only dish I really enjoyed was the side of crispy potatoes!
author: C C.

description:
Love this place! I came here for a work outing, we ordered the family style set menu. The space was really cool, it had this rustic-farm feel to it. The food was excellent, dishes that would excite the person who loves to try dishes they've never had before. A few honorable mentions include-
-Tuna crudo
-Yellowfin tuna collar 
-beef heart
-pigs head

Yeah that's right, a whole pigs head on the table! Everything was amazing and I'll be back hopefully sooner than later.
author: Thomas R.

description:
Between the 5 dishes we ordered, the Beef Heart Tartare was my favorite and stood out the most.  That's pretty much it...

3 appetizers(crudo, tartare, squid), plate of veggies (summer squash), 1 main course (albacore), and a non-alcoholic beverage comes to $109+tip

I'd come back and give it another try.

They have a Happy Hour Menu for $1 oysters and $5 beers (no wine) 5-6PM & 10pm-11?, didn't get to try it but saw it.
author: Angelica C.

description:
I finally got the chance to visit Cockscomb on a date-night with my husband. We ordered the Bacon Chop and Deviled Eggs (amongst other items, but these were our favorites).  The service was excellent!  The waitress was able to answer all of our questions regarding how a specific item was prepared and even made some recommendations based on our preferences.  

The bacon chop was very tasty and paired well with the roasted brussel sprouts, onion and apple-mustard sauce.  I am usually not a big fan of brussel sprouts but these were well seasoned and fit in nicely with the other elements of the dish.  The bacon chop on its own was very flavorful and had just the right amount of fat on it.

It is rather pricey but I would definitely come back here again.  There are items on the menu that you can't find at other places (prepared the same way) and the atmosphere is lively.  We sat by the cooking line and the griller answered any questions we had about what he was cooking - never seemed bothered that we were right there watching him or talking to him.

Chris Cosentino was there that night - actually working the line with his staff!  It was great to see him involved!
author: Carlana U.

description:
Third visit.

Lamb heart - 3/5
Grilled cheese - 3/5 - They should bring back the truffle version, it was much better. 
Sausage dish - 2/5
HAMburger - 5/5 
Pluot upside-down corn cake - 5/5

Overall, Cockscomb is always "as good as it gets."
author: Mark O.

description:
TL;DR - The food is good, but not particularly memorable.

I've been to Cockscomb 3 times already. Twice for dinner and once for happy hour. 

Honestly? I wasn't dreaming about the food.

The atmosphere is cool and kinda like... modern, rustic vibes? All the staff working there are great. But..... when you go eat, its really for the food...amirite?

The pork chop is good, but I don't usually order pork chops. Didn't love it, didn't hate it. The lamb (was a special I think) was a crazy huge portion, but again, I was unimpressed as it seemed very underseasoned. I've also tried most of their starters and sides; standouts are the toasts and the gnocchi. 

For happy hour, I ordered the cocktail they have. Super strong, but not in a good way. I'm not really a fan of campari. The grilled cheese was kinda just... a grilled cheese. I make it better at home. The oysters were ok... There were too many bits of broken shell in my order for me to even finish a dozen. 

Will I be back? Probably not unless there's additions to the menu. Or brunch.... Because I am basic like that.
author: Crystal Z.

description: Stumbled upon this place when I tried to get a table for 3 at Marlowe with no resos. Not sure How I luckily found a table here but it was perfect!! The food was omg-delicious. We ordered the full duck, iceberg wedge salad and dozen ousters. Oh and the flourless cake + cocktails are not to be missed! Before we left we decided to tour the upstairs quickly. To our surprise we were wowed by yet another floor of great seating, perfect lighting and charming detail interiors. One final note: unlike the restaurant literally beside it (I won't name names), the wait staff is courteous, attentive and well mannered. You feel like you are dining amongst family. Five stars all around!
author: Anisa M.

description:
I would take any dude friend here. This place is a place where a dude can spend a lot of money and feel like he got his money's worth in terms of food. Caveman portions, ridiculous meats, what else could you ask for? 

Grilled cheese, as recommended by everyone else, very good!! Not eating grilled cheese without runny yolks ever again.
author: Cassie C.

description:
My boyfriend and I just got back from Valentines Day dinner here, and I had to Yelp about it immediately. I made reservations about a week and a half ago, and had to put down a credit card to keep the reservation (standard for a high volume night, I suppose). The place is awesome looking, by the way. A nice atmosphere. While I didn't spend any time at the bar, it was very cute looking. We were seated immediately upon arrival, given a choice of table or chef's counter. We were seated at a communal table, which did disappoint me at first since I had made reservations, I was expecting a private table. However, we shared the long table with two couples over the span of three hours, and it didn't bother us at all in the end.

Our waiter was the best waiter I think I've ever had at any place I have ever eaten. His name is Sam, and I trusted him, wholeheartedly. He was very attentive, and knew the menu like the back of his own hand. He didn't even write down what we ordered, he just remembered, and we got everything we wanted in a very timely manner. The wine here is pricey (expect to pay about $100 for a bottle), but the bottle I chose was very good. It was the Arietta Bordeaux, 2014, and took about 20-30 minutes to fully open up, however Sam offered us a decanter (something that no other restaurant has ever offered). This wine paired well with everything we ordered.

We started with the grilled cheese. This was good. Could I make it at home? No. It uses incredibly expensive ingredients. Could I mimic it? Hmmm maybe. For our mains, we ordered the bacon chop, the sweet potato, as well as the spaghetti squash (a side dish). At first I found the bacon chop to be quite salty, but then I ate it with the tangerine slices served with it, and voila! Perfectly balanced. The sweet potato dish was delicious, no extra comments needed here. The spaghetti squash had a spicy kick that I wasn't expecting, but I welcomed it.

For dessert, we ordered the first thing that we heard (Sam recited the whole menu, and we never even saw a physical dessert menu). All of it sounded amazing, but we got a chocolate flourless (? I'm guessing because I can't remember since I didn't read it), cake with pistachios and a small scoop of coffee ice cream on top. So good. Order this.

Overall, we were never rushed and we both felt very at ease. We had a lovely dinner, and would like to thank the staff and the owner for giving us a pleasant and romantic Valentine's Day dinner. I'd also like to add that I was sending photos of the food to my dad, who I found out had actually been here before with a group. He said that he ordered the Impossible Burger for lunch, with an expensive bottle of wine, but that it was all very good, and worth the price.

I'd come back for either dinner or lunch.
author: Natalie M.

description:
Inspiring menu by Chris Cosentino, who has become somewhat of a celebrity.  Nice to see that his presence still graces the restaurant.  

Radish Salad with Crispy Pig Ear:  A+
Execution and seasoning was perfect.  Pigs ear was crispy and was almost like a pork rind crouton.  Greens were refreshing and incredibly fresh.

Foie Gras with Trotter and Medium Ripe Strawberries:  A
A very homestyle dish if I ever tasted one.  Trotter offered excellent pungentness, and foie gras provided excellent texture and richness.  It was soaked in ju and served atop a slice of bread (which soaked up all the goodness).

Roasted Bone Marrow:  A
Cooked to perfection.  Generous serving.  Topped with bonito flakes for seasoning.

Asparagus and Radish with Salmon Roe:  A+
Refreshing again, seasoned with a natural kick from the salmon roe.  Ingredients were superb while dish was simple.

Tongue Bruschetta with Tuna Aioli:  A-
Tung was a bit tough, but still extremely tasty nonetheless.  Perfect marriage of fishiness, gaminess, and crunch.

Mussels with Fries:  A++
Delicious white wine based broth.  Mussels were fresh, plump, and cooked to perfection.  Fries were actually potato balls that were deep fried.  Ended up soaking the broth.  Excellent juxtaposition of textures.

Panna Cotta:  A
Excellent execution.  Served with a lime cookie.  Simple but delicious.

Overall a great dining experience.  Will definitely be back again.
author: David C.

description:
I appreciated how involved the management was on both floors. Definitely a positive, clear presence. I liked how the cocktails tasted, but they weren't strong. Disappointed that I didn't feel anything. The beef tartare lacked a kick, but it was good, as was the accompanying bread. The liver bruschetta was solid. It was a bit odd that we got the last liver bruschetta, apparently, and the tuna bruschetta only became an option at that point. I'm not sure why we weren't offered our choice of both from the start. In general, the start of our meal, once we were moved from the bar, lacked explanation. The table next door volunteered a run-down for us. That needs attention for sure, as the specials aren't self-explanatory. 

Bring back the uni bruschetta and the normally priced (vs. $125) bone marrow. Those were items we would have ordered. But, alas... Can't wait until the seasons roll back around.

Not the cutest location, but it's conveniently right off of the freeway. If you're hungry before or after a Giants game, this place is super close.
author: Paulina F.

description:
I wanted to like you, cockscomb. I really did. 

I was dying to try this place for the longest place. And I liked to annoy my friends by saying, I want to go eat cock..scomb. Yup, grown woman and still immature. Besides the name of the restaurant, I was excited to try the pig's head or pin bone steak. 

The pig's head was a huge disappointment. It was literally no meat and just fat, fat, fat and oil and bone. Literally, that is a heart attack waiting to happen. I guess I should've known better. The waiter who was cleaning our table told us the pig's head was basically 80% fat. 

I did enjoy nibbling on the skin of the pig's head and dipping into the sauce made out of the pig's brain and mayo. The only dish I enjoyed out of the meal was the mussels & chips. Definitely love their spin on "chips". It was fried potatoes in this amazing sauce. 

The service was on point. My table sat on the second floor and it only had 1-2 waiters waiting on about 9 tables. Our waters were always filled. And if one of us left to go to use the restroom, came back to a neatly folded napkin on the table. 

I guess I'll cockscomb a second try, just to try the pin bone steak. Sorry, no pig's head for me.
author: Kathleen U.

description: We are on a holiday/foodie tour of San Francisco, and this was our second night out. The staff was wonderful. A family of six (with two babies) is often a handful. We get it. It doesn't (and never will) stop us from going out and having feasts. The food was great. We ordered the lamb for the family. Delicious. We got the pigs ear salad, which was yummy. A couple of veggie sides. Really good experience. Thanks for the great food!
author: Brian W.

description:
Randomly night. Random craving for oysters.

Came here on a Friday night for the reverse happy hour. We got there 15 mins before HH which was on the second floor of the restaurant in the bar area. We started 2 drinks while we waited for 10pm to roll around. Then for HH we had a dozen seacows which were small and sweet ($1each), and the fried pig ear ($3). I guess we were more hungry then expected so we had another round of the same thing. But this time they ran out of the seacows, so we were give another type of oysters that was also from WA. Also delicious!

Now I know where to go for HH oysters late at night!
author: Tiffany C.

description: One of the best restaurants that i've ever been to. They weren't kidding when they said cali had great food. My girlfriend and I have been to many steakhouses in NY and believe me when I tell you this restaurant that's not even a steakhouse almost tops it all! The 64oz steak with bone marrow sauce is just amazing. This was also our first time actually taking a steak home to go as well cause it was so big... Usually we finish 64oz steaks but I guess they're not truly 64oz with double bones. The ambience is great and overall just a very friendly environment. I'd come here again, with a group of friends if I were to travel to SF again.
author: Dennis K.

description:
Met a friend at Cockscomb for Happy Hour after work as it was near the Caltrain station and it's how I get home. They have a $5 drinks menu but my friend doesn't drink so we both opted for the "nonalcoholic special of the day," a basil infused pink lemonade. We sipped as slowly as possible and ordered a couple of happy hour food items: The grilled cheese and the $1 oysters. The oysters were good, fresh, great presentation and garnishes. The grilled cheese was literally just a sandwich, we cut it in half and shared. Very hot, very melty, as good as cheese and bread can be. 

The decor is cool, I liked the atmosphere. We sat in a little loft of a bar. Only two things I didn't like about this place. One is that the bus person came to our table every minute asking if he could take things, trying to take things before we were done with them. Not sure if that's management pressure or personal preference but it was overbearing and annoying. Two, we got the bill and our lemonades were SEVEN DOLLARS! I could have had booze for five and should have instead of feeling weird about drinking alone. When everything else was so cheap for happy hour, that really stuck in my craw. I'll probably come back but next time, I'll definitely be drinking.
author: Angelique L.

description:
I've been here a few times and the food has always been good.  The Ham-Burger is amazing and the oysters are always a good call. My problem is the level of service provided at lunch.  

On average you will have to wait 30-45 minutes depending on what you ordered.  Order a hamburger and you will often be served right away, well before others.  Order anything else and you will be left waiting.  I saw 2 different groups come in after me, and both had their hamburgers and drinks before I even had my appetizer.  They also received their bill and were out of there before I received my meal. 

To add insult to injury, my waiter came over to ask how I was doing and then took my knife and fork to only pretend to replace them with a new knife and fork! He pulled the silverware from my plate, passed it around behind me, and put them back on my plate; giving the appearance of having changed silverware.  When he walked away I noticed that he did not have any silverware in his hands or apron.  This is not apart of this review as I believe I had a shitty waiter and this is not a repeat issue.

If you plan to come here, order a burger....or be ready to wait for your food.
author: Brian S.

description:
Once you walk into this place. The smells feels like you're at a woodsy cabin and a farmers market at the same time. The smells of this place is amazing. Right off bat you can smell the freshness of the food from you're table. It's that fresh. 

Our waiter James hosted our visit for the evening. He discuss the specials and broke down what's on the menu. 

This restaurant is not suitable for vegans nor vegetarians so stay away. This place is not for you. This place is a carnivores dream. Mind you it's a hipster steakhouse with a San Francisco twist.

We ordered several items on the menu. Every bite we had our mouths is filled with deliciousness. I will post pictures of what we had on here. Perfectly seasoned well. The meats aren't heavily salted. This establishment wants you to eat the pure essence taste of the meat. Hence to why there's no salt on the table!

The service is top notch here. You will be taken care of. Trust me. 

Absolutely love the open air kitchen. And there is no microwaves at this place. 

Oh by the way this place is owned and operated by Top Chef Master Chris Cosentino. Did you know that! We were able to meet Chris at his fine establishment. 

And yes it's pricey worth every penny. Because the service and food cannot be beat. 

Just like that BOOM be there.
author: Linda N.

description:
Lawd, have mercy.

I keep coming back here.  It doesn't matter if I have lunch or dinner, the food is always fantastic.  Cockscomb is a hole in the wall of an alleyway, and the hole was created because the place packs a punch in flavor and serving size.  Atmosphere is urban rustic... lots of .com professionals seem to frequent this establishment, so feel comfortable in knowing that you're surrounded by chill people.  Music present in the background, but not so overwhelming that you can't hold a conversation normally across the table.

Service is also stellar... even if all you're having is water with your meal (I'm on a diet, so no reviews on drinks, alcoholic or otherwise), they are constantly topping off your glass.

I haven't found a menu item that has yet to disappoint.  My personal favorites are the fried chicken sandwiches during lunch, the "Ham" burger during dinner, and the peach tart off of their dessert menu.  Amazing presentation all around and just the right amount of sweetness.

Enjoy the food & save a seat for me!
author: Trish R.

description:
I'm going to extremely honest, I can hardly say Cockscomb without giggling. Now that we've got that out of the way, on to the meat of the experience. 

We came here for a birthday and managed to snag reservations at 8:30 for Friday that same week. Since we had a fairly large party, we decided to go family style. 

Here's what we ordered:

- Beef Heart Tartare: The taste of this dish was forgettable, but the only unforgettable piece is when the birthday boy said that the texture reminded him of brains. 
- Duck Fat Cauliflower: Delicious and flavorful. 
- Grilled Cheese: BEST OF THE NIGHT! Who knew something as simple as grilled cheese with honey can be so amazing.
- Bacon Chop: Meh. I thought it was going to be much juicier than it was. 
- 4lb Sirloin topped w/foie gras and a bone marrow au jus: It was good, but not amazing. The flavor was all there, but I found it to be a little dry. 
- We also ended up ordering almost every dessert on the menu and nothing was disappointing. 

Overall, our experience at Cockscomb was not bad. My only gripe is the long wait in between the bacon chop and the sirloin which killed our appetite. However, I'm still giving Cockscomb a 4 star review simply because our waiter was nothing short of amazing. The menu was 2nd nature to him and he gave each dish such a mouthwatering description that it was extremely difficult to not order every single thing.
author: Tiffany U.

description:
This artsy-fartsy restaurant is located in SOMA, and has nice atmosphere, and from what we hear, however... terrible attitude abounds from the time you step through the door, to the wait staff, to the "Manager".  You can forget about them accommodating a special request, and criticism of the customer for complaining due to the same. 
Couple that with impossible street parking, and servers and cooks who can't complete a sentence in anything but Spanish, and you have a less than desirable experience. 
Avoid this debacle, if you have other options...
author: Pete S.

description:
I got a referral to come here and was very excited to try it out.  They suggested I try the celery dish that was sensational but it wasn't on the menu so maybe it is seasonal.  They were quite busy and we had to wait a very long time for a table (with a reservation), but they were friendly and apologetic about it, which made it better.  They also served us a complimentary plate of melon & prosciutto right when we got our table as they must have known we'd be starved by then.

I liked the ambiance and the decor of the restaurant, but the food fell short for me.  We had the Halibut Crudo, Grilled Cheese, Meat Pie, Duck Fat Summer Squash and Escarole & Anchovy.  The plating and appearance was nice but the food was mostly a bit bland and unexceptional. The Halibut was good, the Grilled Cheese was also, but the Meat Pie although adorable, was lacking in flavor. The squash dish, although I could taste a bit of the duck fat was also quite bland and boring.

All I can say is that they were very nice, it's a cute place, but the food won't bring me back.  Maybe we hit it on a bad day or ordered the wrong things, but it didn't do it for me.
author: Kathleen S.

description:
This was one of the greatest restaurant experiences I've ever had. I arrived extremely early (5pm) and they treated me like I was a celebrity. I had an idea in my of what I wanted to order prior to going but the server Gabriel made some pairing suggestions that made the meal flow better in his opinion (and lord was he spot on)

The beef heart tartar was my first starter. Everything you would want in a tartar but better! Stronger seasoning, stronger iron flavor, and great pairing of greens to go with it! Phenomenal

Hot (Haute) Mess was my second course that blew me away. Grilled sourdough, grilled foie gras, braised pig trotters and sweet/sour strawberries. This dish had your mouth exploding from sweet to sour to salty to savory. Flawless dish 

The chef Jay and server Gabriel were kind enough to bring a small plate of the pig skin carbonara for me to try. Such an original dish and something you won't find anywhere else! Thank you
For this 

And the bacon chop?!? Really?? Thick cut pork chop with the belly attached!! This thing was timed and cooked perfectly! They fired it early in the process to crisp up the edges and makes the skin/belly crunchy while keeping the center medium rare! 

From Stephen who booked my reservation, to Gabriel who provided his server expertise, and the chefs Mike and Jay....these guys crushed it!

Well done and Thank You!
author: Ryan O.

description:
We were very disappointed in Cockscomb. The quality of the food was poor and the prices were high. In particular, the Pin Bone Steak was terrible. It is a dish to share, priced at $125. Our waitress said it would feed four of us. It arrived at the table looking and smelling great, pre-sliced on a larger wooden platter. However, almost a quarter of it was bone, fat and gristle. The actual meat was tough, by which I mean, hard to cut with a steak knife and somewhat rubbery to chew. It came with peas and carrots, both of which were extremely al dente, almost uncooked. Our side dishes of gnocchi and duck fat cauliflower were equally disappointing. The gnocchi were mushy and the cauliflower was almost raw and poorly spiced. Our two appetizers: grilled cheese and Kale salad were okay, but nothing special. The only part of the meal I enjoyed was the Fort Point IPA, but they also compromised that by charging $9 for a diminutive twelve ounce pour. I left the restaurant feeling annoyed and still hungry.

In my opinion, the place is overpriced and pretentious with mediocre food. We will not be going back.
author: Duncan L.

description:
We live in the era of the celebrity chef which is at once a great thing because it brings recognition to a industry full of hard working people and rewards the talented people that work in the industry, but the other side of the coin is that with the notoriety, book deals and television appearances these people get put on a pedestal and the expectations become nearly impossible to meet. 
 
Cockscomb does not have that problem, the place simply DELIVERS, this is the level of food, service and dedication that I expect from a chef that has all the accolades this guy has achieved. We got the whole pig head, beef heart and a couple of drinks, the food was brilliantly presented, perfectly seasoned and the portion size was HUGE! 

The seating was kind of cramped and I could totally tell the space use to be a warehouse of some kind, I feel like they could make it a little warmer and inviting BUT you know what, at the end of the day you can't it ambiance, but you can eat the food and it's freaking delicious!
author: Sunday S.

description: Impossible burger, Gnocchi, and kale salad were amazing. Cocktails were on point and service was phenomenal.
author: Ashley F.

description:
My boyfriend and I tried this place for date night. I was pleasantly surprised by this place. It was pretty decent!

Grilled cheese with honey and truffles: 5/5: my favorite of the night! I didn't imagine that cheese, honey and truffles could taste so good together. It was amazing , I would have eaten it all by myself. It was a tad greasy but that's expected with a grilled cheese.

Rock crab bruschetta : 4/5: it was pretty decent. They have a pretty good amount of crab and with some avocado it was pretty good. Just felt that it wasn't seasoned enough but it was still pretty good.
