Bacon chop: 4/5: it was flavorful and pretty good. Some parts were a bit fatty. But overall it was well seasoned, moist and pretty tasty.

Pot pie: 3/5: most disappointing part of the meal. I really wish it had tasted better but it was standard. It was pretty watery for the filling. I definitely should have stuck with the getting the steak instead. 

Overall, a great date place. I would come here again. It's got great food and portions are great! The meats are what stand out here and would get them again!

Total for 2 w tax and tip: $150
author: Stella J.

description:
Phenomenal dinner. Pinbone steak was incredibly good. The service was outstanding. Everything about this place is top notch, and less expensive than expected. 

I don't know if it's a plus or a minus, but I emerged from Cockscomb smelling like wood-smoked bacon.
author: Josh M.

description:
Friends and I stumbled into this place are failing to find a suitable happy hour spot with food. The restaurant is cute with a great date-night feel to it, but I was sadly disappointed with my overall dining experience.

Don't get me wrong, the drinks were great. Our waitress was really friendly and recommended us some really yummy drinks while waiting for food. The actual "supper" food however was really underwhelming. Between the three people in my party, we tried:

- Duck Fat Cauliflower: just a side dish, but the only thing I really liked.. 
- Zampini: huge but wayyyy too salty. 
- Babette Steak: definitely not worth the price at all. It was about $33 but the steak was so small and subpar. If it was actually good, I would be totally ok with the price/size of it but it wasn't. Definitely would not recommend. To make things worse, this dish took FOREVER to come out. We would have canceled it if we weren't so hungry.

All in all, I just didn't leave very satisfiedl I'm giving three stars instead of two because I guess it would be a cool spot to stop at for drinks if you're in the area, but there are plenty of better spots around if you're looking to eat as well.
author: Estelle C.

description:
One of my favorite dining experiences. Love the environment provided by Chris Cosentino and his team... amazing, crowd-pleasing food in a non-pretentious environment. 

Called somewhat last-minute for a large group celebration and the restaurant was very accommodating, even as I continued to add people (20x people by night's end).  

We ordered multiple specials o' the day to include: Leg of Beast (6x pounds of fall-off-the-bone goodness), extra large hamachi collar, and more. As recommended by other reviewers, the pig's head was hearty and rich and the pin-bone steak was sufficient for a viking's smorgasboard.  Also, ordered their largest seafood platter which included an ample variety of oysters, mussels, clams, ceviche, and lobster.  

And as simple as it is, the grilled cheese sandwich starter was a favorite for all.  Chris met with us at the end of the meal and was ever gracious as he shared about his food philosophy.  

Wonderful time!
author: Dan K.

description:
Service was excellent - our server did a great job! 5 stars for him :)
I tried the Boothby... and sent it back (which I almost never do). I was hoping for a rift on a Manhattan, but it was not that... The classic Manhattan I ordered was great.
The red wines by the glass are all a bit dry and the Pinot is a bit thin - I would have liked a bit of a variety there (maybe the Pinot could have been Sonoma or Russian River or the Cabernet could be a bit more fruit forward)
Oysters were great. As was the grilled cheese starter.
I had the steak - very nicely done, though the peas and carrots were a bit undercooked for me. Spouse ordered the Bacon Chop which was awesome -- it's big, but there's also a lot of fat on it you may or may not want. The gnocchi were AMAZING.

... only real complain is the dessert menu. panna cotta something, a cobbler, cheese plate, and something else... nothing with chocolate, peanut butter, nougat, caramel, etc. We had the cobbler... it was good, but not great. Mostly just a bowl of cooked berries with a little bit of crust and some cream on top. 
Cool place, glad we went.
author: Mr R.

description:
I made a reservation for this place about like 3 days before going so the times were really off and ended up getting 5pm reservation for right when it opens. 
We were running a bit late but we called and the hostess said it was okay. She sat us at the bar right next to the expo station which was pretty cool because we got to see everything in the kitchen and what all the people were doing. There are hooks under that bar area where you can hang your jacket or bag. We had a waiter but the guys in the kitchen let us know that if we had any questions or anything we could just ask them too. My bf wanted to try a piece of the ben's ham but it was only available on the charcuterie platter. One of the guys ended up just giving him a slice, which was awesome. 
Our waiter was very helpful helping us choose beers because we didn't want anything too heavy for the food. We ended up ordering the pork skin puttanesca, duck fat cauliflower, beef heart tartare. 
The pork skin puttanesca reminded me of the yunnan jello noodles. It was really heavy though and I only ended up eating 2 bites of it. I really like the cauliflower though. It had an interesting taste to it that we couldn't figure it....a salty type of flavor. We asked if it was fish sauce but nope. Nonetheless I devoured the whole plate. The beef heart tartare was also good but the thing I like most about that dish is the bread. That bread is so good. I thought the beef heart tartare just tasted like a regular tartare, but then again I eat beef heart like sliced or whole....it was still tasty though! 
Everything was more on the heavier side so we didn't order too much and it was a lot of food for 2 people. I would give the food like an A- but the staff A++
author: Jasmine Y.

description:
Can't believe I paid $130 for this meal. The service was very good however the food was terrible. I got the onion soup which tastes like apple pie(not in a good way), and the gnocchi. The gnocchi had 9 pieces for 9 dollars and it didn't even taste like gnocchi it tastes like burnt bread. My friend got the spaghetti with tuna and it was something we could have made at home. Bok Choy was soggy and bland and the squash spaghetti tastes super weird. 
I emphasize that the service very very very good and atmosphere was good , but I can't get past severely overpriced Terrible food. We probably should have gotten meat because that is their specialty, but you can't only serve one good item, everything on your menu should be good. 
I left hungry. 
Not coming back
author: Malina M.

description: Very rare for me to give 5 stars but everything was perfect. Got seated right away, the drinks were good and the food....the food was scrumptious. Like the idea, Cockscomb goes outside the box in creating their cuisine. The pigs head was delicious, especially the cheek. It was soft and melted in your mouth. The only thing I was disappointed, my new umbrella I recently purchased, someone took it and left me their broken one. Cockscomb should invest on those plastic umbrella bags so the patrons can take their wet umbrella to their table. But Claudine did offer to give me a gift card. She's amazing! Other than that, I would recommend eating here.
author: Kathy T.

description:
Earlier in the week my friend A and I were planning to get together and have dinner. We are both the type who like to go out and try new places and she mentioned Cockscomb. I didn't know about the place and did my research. I was so busy during the entire week I forgot to call the reservation line at 3PM. We decided to be rebellious and go on a Friday night and try our luck. Oh boy did we luck out! We didn't have to wait because there were seats upstairs by the bar that overlooked the entire lower dining room. Sick view, great food, good drinks and amazing company. 

It was Friday so we started with some cocktails. I got the Pisco Punch and A got the Boothby. Both drinks were good. Mine had a nice tartness to it that I really enjoyed and the boothby was nice if you enjoyed a tropical coconut type flavor. 

We decided to go all out on food and try everything that stood out to us. We started with the "Hot Mess" - seared foie gras. This was my first time having foie gras since they lifted the ban here in SF. It was definitely melt in your mouth, but not sure how we felt exactly about it being cold since it was seared. Good, but could have done without.

Next up was the grilled cheese with honey and shaved truffles. Now this was a palate pleaser. The cheese and the honey complimented each other so well and the saltiness of the truffle was a little undermined but still a nice touch to the classic sandwich.

For our main courses we had the Quail Tetrazzini and the Coulotte Steak.

These two by far were our favorite dishes of the night. The quail had an amazing flavor to it and was complimented with this delicious white wine sauce with mushrooms and had some crispy noodle pieces to really give it that extra texture. The steak was seasoned to perfection and had a great charred taste to it. My taste buds were singing of joy. 

The restaurant has great service. Everyone was pleasant and our server/bartender/do it all girl was amazing and brought us one of their house drinks that was AMAZING. Super refreshing and if I ever find myself at Cockscomb again, that WILL be my drink of choice. I'm not sure what it was called exactly, but I think it was one of the drinks with gin and jasmine.. or was it lavender water? (It's on the menu.)

Overall: *RECOMMENDED*
author: Tiff C.

description: Awesome ambience, great service and unique food options. I would definitely go there again!
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Review is strictly for Happy Hour. Happy hour is from 5-6pm Mon-Thurs.

Came with a couple friends to celebrate a birthday, so we decided to go somewhere nice like here. I heard their happy hour is amazing. We arrived around 5:50pm, cutting it close, and asked to be seated. Apparently this restaurant is so amazing that it requires reservations. Good thing we only came for happy hour, which is located upstairs at the bar. Okay now there's only 1 small bar (seats about 5), 1 counter table curved against the balcony (seats 6) and 1 island counter (seats 4-6). I'm not sure if the back room applies to happy hour as well, but here's hoping it does for the next time I come back. Servers were really nice and attentive to our needs. I thought we had to order at the bar first, but I assumed incorrectly; they come over to take our orders.

FOOD:
1) $1 Oysters: (4/5) I thought these were good, but oysters are whatever to me. To my friends these were just okay. The size of the oysters were really small, but what do you expect from $1 oysters? Good quality for the price.
2) $3 Crispy Pig Ears: (5/5) I've never had pig ears until now, but this dish sets a high standard for any pig ears I'll ever have. Reminds me of pork rinds almost. The lime juice, chili, and garnish complimented the fried pig ears really well!
3) $4 Crispy Potatoes: (4/5) Crispy potatoes is right. Well more like hot & fresh out of the oven potatoes with a crispy exterior, and it's topped with ham puree? Yes please!
4) $6 Grilled Cheese: (5/5) CAN I GIVE THIS A 6/5? You haven't had grilled cheese until you've had this! Oh my goodness, its like a sweet french toast with hot and stringy cheese melted in between. The bread is toasted and soaked with a light sweet honey which complimented extremely well with the cheese in perfect harmony. I'm not kidding.

DRINKS:
$5 Negroni, Sauvignon, & Ale: (3/5) Okay the Negroni I did not like at all. Both the sauvignon and ale were really light.

One of the best Happy Hours in SOMA!
author: Kevin S.

description:
I'm coming back again...and again. On non-game nights, so I can park nearby for the low-low price of 25 cents per hour. =) 

Since it opened, I'd been meaning to check it out. See my review of Incanto, I'm in awe of Chef Chris Cosentino. Probably because growing up Chinese, we eat everything of the animal, and Chef (arguably) made offal acceptable in mainstream food. I mean. Come on now. The animal consists of more than steaks and ribs!

We started off in the drinks area, and the bartender was super nice. I, per usual, had no idea of what alcohol I'd like other than...alcohol. He made me an aviation that was really delicious. And super alcoholic. I win. We then meander to our table, which was very spacious. They have 2 levels here, with the bar being upstairs. We went slightly further up for our table. The food:

Pigs head: Really yummy. If you like pig skin in many forms, this is the perfect dish. I'm pretty sure I had pig skin in any cook-level I wanted. And it was sooo good. Though, no one was brave enough to eat the eye. I'm sorry, eyes aren't something I eat despite my heritage. 

Pinbone steak: GIANT portion, and HELLA good. I'm easily amused, and that cow jus holder just amused me. My friend commented that I don't go to American steak houses...which I don't. Steak was really nicely done, and sliced for us! Though a knife was provided for extra slicing

Pot Pie: The pot pie that night was escargot, pork belly, mushrooms, and escarole. It was really good, though I'm kinda thinking the escargot could have been replaced with something else. It got a bit too...fishy for me. But still good. The pastry was super flaky and good

Panna Cotta: Get this. I don't care what flavor. The panna cotta here is yummy. Texture alone is worth it.

Chocolate: I can't remember what exactly this was, other than chocolate with marshmallow. It was good, though I prefer the clean taste of the panna cotta. 

Overall, it was a great meal. The staff were amazing, and very friendly. On more than one occasion, I was either told or noticed how well they work together. I know the place has only been open for a little while, but it had a family feel to it. And not the dysfunctional "I'll stab you in the back" family. Or the creepy TV families where you just KNOW something is off. Like. A real. Family.
author: Lily W.

description:
You gotta see the roasted pigs head here, it's such a spectacle. Better yet, you gotta eat it! 

For $65 it comes out served on this large paella pan along with an endive salad (blah), this chimichurri like dipping sauce (decent), and they mix the brain matter along with some mayo to make a sort of BRAIN-O-NAISE. Brilliant! It would be awesome if you ordered this on your birthday and the waitstaff came out to sing happy birthday to you like they do at Red Robin!  Or better yet send a crew of scantily clads with sparklers and a bottle of Ace of Spades! So cray, I know....  Oh btw, I ATE THE PIGS EYE! What!??!?!? (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=pDfL8xt8F8ls0-kQIG_ADg&select=-VkYrDGcnoevl2hFQ0rQHg)

With that being said, the service here was exceptional! Chef Chris Cosentino stopped by our table, I didn't get the idea of the Ace of Spades until now, otherwise, I would have told him then. 

Another recommended dish is their HAMBURGER ($15). It's a ground patty of meaty ham on a brioche bun with butter lettuce, grilled onions, dijon, and gruyere cheese. Surprisingly, it wasn't too porky. It reminded me of something that I'd get at Umami burger, same price but double the size. Yum! I liked the manliness of the extra fried potatoes. 

The BEEF HEART TARTARE ($16) was good, couldn't differentiate the taste from any other beef. (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=pDfL8xt8F8ls0-kQIG_ADg&select=Voi88s3-FU-EAf7pPb9ElA)

I'd skip GRAMMA ROSALIE'S TRIPE ($14). Hardly any tripe and I was chewing 
this inedible piece of rubber that was like a rubber ring. No bueno. 

Cocktails are solid. How could I resist a cocktail named the "Big Trouble in Little China"!?! ($11)  dark rum, coconut milk, pineapple, mint. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cockscomb-san-francisco?select=uDwuaYQuZ72qy-vjivWHpg#uDwuaYQuZ72qy-vjivWHpg)

Great spot for a guys night out dinner or bachelor party! Solid place for groups!
author: Earl G.

description:
Cockscomb definitely reminded me of Bestia in LA. The menu offered all sorts of things I would never normally try, but always ended up tasting amazing.

I'm sure the dining experience would have been better at an actual table, but our party sat at the bar instead and shared a few dishes amongst each other. From what I can remember, the most of the food was delicious.

I'm glad when I try things I'd normally never order because it always ends up being really good. For example, I never had fried pig ears and I never had the desire to eat them. Once I had a little bit of liquid courage in my body, I tried a few bites and it was SO good! It was zesty from the lime and every bite was full of flavor.

Beef tartare is something I've had at other places, but a small part of me gets grossed out after a few bites. Unfortunately for my friends, that wasn't the case this time. I found myself going back for more bites.

The grilled cheese was my safe option until I read the description and I really didn't want to order it anymore. HONEY? In grilled cheese? It seemed blasphemous, but then I was proved wrong once more. It went so well with the melted cheese and bread.

When I said "most of the food" there was one thing that I was kind of gross after a few bites. It was some sort of mashed potato, but it was SO SALTY. At first the bites were good and when washed down with water, you would be ready for another bite. After awhile the saltiness was just too much.

If you're a picky eater, you should try to do what I did and just give everything a chance. What I thought would be gross actually ended up being something I would definitely order again if I could go back to Cockscomb.
author: Kurtis C.

description:
Wed tried out Cockscomb for any early dinner on Wed 4/22/15.  It's on 4th St, not far from the bar Hotel Utah.  We walked down and it wasn't too bad or far.

They have Happy Hr menu M-Th 5-6pm and 10-11pm with some food & booze for cheap, but only at the Bar - there is 2 bars: one on the ground level, one upstairs.  We picked upstairs.

Oysters at HH are $1.  We got a dozen.  Not sure what kind they were, they were plumb and tasted fresh.

Grilled cheese sandwich $6 - taleggio & honey.  Tasted ok, not sure I like grilled cheese that's sweet.

Crispy pig ears $3 during HH - small bowl of fried pig ears.  He seemed to like them.  I passed on them.

Alcohol - glass during HH $5!
B. got Almanac and a glass of wine Diseno - he liked them both.

I had the house Still Water - tasted fine.

Zampini $18 - a coiled pile of sausage pork & fennel, 2 fried smoked oysters, & some celery root remoulade.  I found the sausage really salty, didn't try the oysters, and the celery root like a cold mayo-filled coleslaw.  Meh.

B. got the Coulotte Steak w/ peas & carrots $32 - He liked the beef which was 8oz medium, carrots & peas he liked too.

Panna Cotta dessert $7 - part of his "classic" dessert - tasted fine.  Cookie in a shape of rooster tasted bleh.

Bathrooms: 2 unisex downstairs.  Charged the meal.
author: Ann L.

description:
Ate here tonight and I am torn.  Our server was horrendous!!! The food was good but not good enough to ignore the terrible service.  
Came in early and hostess gave us a choice to sit at a table or the chef's counter; we chose chef's counter and lucky us...Chef SASHA saved our day and the restaurant from earning one star!
Our server started off strong.  He seemed to know the menu, made some recommendations and came around in beginning accordingly.  He highly recommended the hot mess and asked if we wanted to place some starters, which we agreed to try, said great then disappeared for 10 minutes.  He returned to take the rest of our order, said nothing our first dish and looking into the kitchen, the chefs didn't seem too busy and were waiting for orders to come in.  We placed the rest of our order and 5 minutes later the first dish arrives: 

celery victor- refreshing , light, well balanced in texture especially with the crispy chicken skin
once we finish, 2 minutes later, and a change of dishes,  the baked oysters arrive: good texture, fresh, but the flavors just  didn't seem to go together for me.

I'm wondering now.....what happened to our hot mess????? Ordered first? 20...20 minutes ago???? I ask the server, and he looks at his book, he forgot to place the order! One dish....that he HIGHLY recommends and said great when we agree...forgets to place the order????  Then asks if it's ok if he brings it out with our entrée.  I mean foie gras, quail with crème fraiche, and steak all at once?  We might as well have a heart attack right then and there.  LUCKILY, chef SASHA over hears this and saves the FIRST disaster.  She said: don't worry, I will make you one right away, before your entrée comes out.

If this special, Hot Mess is available, ORDER it!!!! Sorry for all those against foie gras, but for all the foie gras lovers:  trotter pieces in broth, herbs, sautéed dates & mushrooms, bread smothered with date puree accompanied with a perfectly piece of seared foie gras!!  Need I say more? Best dish of the night, hands down. (glad the server couldn't ruin it for us yet....)

Bavette Steak-cooked perfectly, deliciously charred carrots lightly flavored to bring out the flavor of the meat

Duck fat cauliflower- no taste, reminded me of freezer burned vegetable

Quail tetrazzini- first time it came around, the skin was soggy, and when I cut into the breast, it was raw!!!! And where was our waiter 5 minutes later?? 
We would STILL waiting........AGAIN, Chef Sasha saves the day and asks if everything is ok.  We show her the quail and she apologizes as well as the nice chef next to her and brings it back to the chef who made it so he can finish cooking it.  When we finally get it back, it is perfectly cooked and super juicy, with beautiful sautéed crispy angel hair pasta and mushrooms. Yum!

At this point, maybe I might have given our overall experience 3.5 stars....THEN...
Our server misunderstands me and brings me the bill, which I say no, I would like to see the dessert menu and apologizes....then disappears for 15 minutes and never returns!!!! Finally as I am trying to flag him down, he realizes, he never brought over the dessert menu and asks a fellow staff member to do so. SERIOUSLY???? After forgetting an order, not check on our entrée which is severely under cooked, you forget to bring us the dessert menu?  Where is the attention to detail or energy to attempt to make up for your previous mistakes?  If it wasn't for Chef Sasha, our night would've been ruined and this restaurant may have gotten 1 or 2 stars from me.
author: Nguyen L.

description: Came here for the impossible burger. While I wouldn't come back for that alone, I definitely would come back for the amazing cocktails and impeccable service.
author: M-E C.

description:
I hate to give 1 star, but I was very disappointed in the service we received at Cockscomb. Upon entering my boyfriend said to the hostess "Hello, we have a reservation for 8", but knowing that might have sounded confusing he corrected himself and said "I'm sorry, a reservation for 2 at 8". The hostess then replied in a condescending way "yeah,
I know". We noticed how unnecessarily rude that was but brushed it off. Then, once we sat down, she said to me "Let me take your coffee cup. We don't allow outside beverages" (I had a paper coffee cup). I gave it to her and said "If you would have told me you didn't allow it, I would've finished it outside", she then said, "well it looks tacky in a paper cup, so let me take it and put in another glass". How was I supposed to know that's what she was going to do with it?! She made it seem like she was going to throw it away! For whatever reason that you don't except outside beverages, you DO NOT indirectly insult a customer by telling them that it looks tacky. I don't know why she felt the need to validate herself by being rude to the customers she is paid to serve, but it's really disappointing receiving such terrible service as soon as you walk in the the door. We couldn't help but feel bothered the entire time. I would return to eat here, but I would hope they would do something about the hostess. It looks like others have had similar experiences with this hostess, so we aren't being dramatic. Once again, I hate giving 1 star, but we just wished for a more well rounded experience.
author: Ashley E.

description: This place was okay - it's fun eating & drinking here family style with a group, but I didn't think the food was 4 or 5 star worthy. Drinks + Apps were fun with oysters and charcuterie. For my main I had wagyu which was okay - I've had much better wagyu elsewhere. It's also insane that this place serves an entire Pig's head here.. no thanks to that, but some carnivorous patrons love it.
author: Pratul L.

description:
Came here for happy hour and was informed that this was Top Chef Master winner, Chris Cosentino's restaurant so my expectations naturally grew. I had the grilled cheese and the oysters which were decently priced! ($6 for grilled cheese and $1 oysters)

The grilled cheese had a mild flavor and the honey on the toasted bread gave it a nice twist, but I wasn't super sold on it. Perhaps it's because I am a loyalist to strong nutty cheeses but it was good nonetheless. The atmosphere definitely plays a big part at this restaurant: swanky and slightly industrial with moody lighting and close seating. I ate on the upstairs area which was fairly limited (I also think they should get hooks for bags and coats when sitting at the counter)

The thing that slightly annoyed me was the service- it was TOO MUCH actually. I was having a conversation with someone and a server asked us if we were done with the oysters at LEAST 5 times. Other times, he would hover around and peer over our shoulder to see if we were finished. The last time, the hostess actually came by to try to take our tray but we had two oysters left. I don't get what the rush/urgency of this matter was, but it was distracting to have them consistently interrupt the conversation lol.

They have good prices and interesting cocktails here though, I would come here again for some small bites with friends and to try some of the dinner creations.
author: Amanda K.

description: I love this place and always try and go when I'm in San Francisco. The staff is friendly and professional, the decor is laid back and cool and the food is absolutely delicious. I am dying to try the half pigs head when I can go with some other adventurous eaters! Definitely recommend!
author: Katie R.

description:
New kid on the block alert! I am a big fan of Chef Chris Cosentino after watching his innovative style on Top Chef and of course his restaurant Incanto. The appealing menu includes interpretations of SF's classics, ranging from pork, quail, green goddess dressing on little gems, crudo variety at the bar.

Reservations are highly expected. 
There are two bars: one is on the main floor, and there's another on the upstairs mezzanine. The layout is like a loft, has a clean and universal look. Has an open kitchen and a long wood counter. Spacious and modern. Menu is seasonal, so expect some items to change.

Food: 3.5 only because some certain items I wasn't too thrilled about.

Grilled Cheese w/truffle & honey-YUM!!! and not your average home cooked sammich but they did deliver.

Beef Heart Tartare- grilled bread fries & greens- Yes I like it raw with no complaints!

Little Gems-green goddess, radish & cracklins-Refreshing 

Duck Liver Terrine-pickled fruit & grilled bread- A little bit gamey for me. Acquired taste.

Duck Fat Cauliflower-red fresno, garlic, caper & mint- I didn't like it. Kind of soggy and was bland.

Broccoli Rabe-garlic, lemon, chili & breadcrumbs-Reminded me of Chinese Broccoli and kind of bitter. Not a big fan.

Bone Marrow-hay smoked fried oysters, watercress & horseradish. The star of the show! I was very pleased and I'm a sucker for it.

Toasted Oats- maitake mushrooms, kale, poached egg & button mushrooms-I guess I'm a snob because I did not like this dish at all. I believe toasted oats is a breakfast item and the mixture did not like my palate.

Bacon Chop-apples, brussellskraut & mustard-HUGE!! but where was the bacon? lol the pork chop itself was cooked to perfection, tender and grilled on point. My only complaint was the large amount of fat on it. 

I would like to give Cockscomb another chance and try other items on the menu, but for now 3.5 stars. Service was impeccable and informative-Kudos to the staff!
author: Kathy V.

description: Good concepts - love that they use heart, head, eat and others. Stir fried lamb heart. Pig head is good but too one dimension - how Taiwanese cook pig head is much better. Egg was horrible. Good service, deco and clean
author: Anya C.

description: Amazing drinks, amazing food, amazing oysters. Best place for an anniversary date. AND I was totally starstruck by Chris Cosantino making menus at the bar next to us! Will definitely be back!!
author: Gwendolyn R.

description: We came across this amazing restaurant in the middle of an awesome alley in San Francisco. The service was great, which is why I'm giving this place 3 stars. We ordered 2 expensive vodka sodas and an order of the gnocchi. The vodka sodas were great and we couldn't wait to try a famous chef's gnocchi. The gnocchi was so greasy and tasted like it was cooked in bacon fat. I was so disappointed! It was an amazing atmosphere and so fun seeing what the table next to us ordered. Maybe if we go back another time, it will be better if we don't order the gnocchi.
author: Emily D.

description:
Interesting dining experience not for the faint hearted. Glad I tried it as I think it's a unique restaurant which says a lot in SF. They do clearly care about quality here.

Beautifully designed place that is casual but upscale and has a lively atmosphere.

For two people we got the little gem salad, beef heart tartare, and the pigs head. We had too much food and could have ditched the salad cause the pigs head came with a huge side salad.

The little gem salad was nice and surprisingly light given it has crispy pigs ear. The beef heart tartare actually tastes like a normal steak tartare but was still very tasty. 

The pigs head is half a head and still maybe too much for two mostly cause of grease and fat. It's very tender but you get overwhelmed by the fat -- my girlfriend in fact felt physically sick after. I felt a bit too greasy myself. Maybe if you split it with 4 people it'd be okay.

The side salad helped balance the grease out as it was nice and a little bitter. It may have helped more to include bread.

I was surprised they don't have tea after such a heavy meal. I ordered a cappuccino and it tasted off -- like the very acidic espresso had a topping of milk foam but it didn't add up. They replaced it with an americano which was also very very acidic. They didn't have regular drip coffee. They were nice enough not to bill us for that.

Service is nice and they definitely don't rush you.
author: Victor W.

description: Have you ever had grilled pork belly? Me either, heck I wouldn't have even considered it. Let me tell you though, served with some grilled whole lobsters and you will want it again and again. We orders this for the table and it was plenty. You gotta check this out and hope they have it on he menu the night you want to go.
author: Jeff T.

description: Went for impossible burger and worth the price (under $20) side dish is salad. Nice decor although surrounding area just ok n full of construction
author: Freya-Loki O.

description:
THE GRILLED CHEESE IS SO GOOD.

My friend and I came here for dinner. This place has two floors, but it isn't that spacious so get ready to get cozy with the table/party next to you. My friend ordered the "ham" burger while I got the grilled cheese ($12). It was sooooooooooo delicious. How do you make grilled cheese so good... There was also a sunny side up egg on top that made it even better. After we finished eating, we found out it became happy hour (m-th 5-6pm, 10-11pm if i remember correctly). If you come for happy hour, there is no sunny side up egg on the grilled cheese, but it's also $6. and oysters are $1 and drinks on the happy hour menu are $5. whaaaaaat. good thing i live a block away because i'm coming back here x234234234 for happy hour!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Annie S.

description:
My 2015 NYE resolution: "eat more".
No wait - "WAY more".

Official Scoreboard
Me: 1 :: Big Tons Of Shellfish $148: 0
Me: 1 :: Pig's Head $65: 0

Unique dishes
Great service
Dance tunes

Make '15 the eatingest year ever.
author: Dan B.

description:
Got a rack of lamb to share for 8 people. It was epic to order and looked amazing. 
Lamb itself was a little dry.
Ambiance is amazing, drinks are strong and delicious
Really good option for a large group meal.
author: Jean Marie C.

description:
Review #888 goes out to Cockscomb!
(Yes, I'm Chinese! Lol!)

My friends and I have been waiting for a chance to go to Chris Cosentino's new restaurant Cockscomb. Who doesn't want to eat a whole pig's head?! Thank you Peter L for arranging the reservation and making this happen! We had a party of 5 people.

Drinks:
*Big trouble in little China ($11): dark rum, coconut milk, pineapple, mint
*Boothby ($11): pomegranate infused bourbon, sweet vermouth, bitters & sparkling wine
*Milk punch ($11): pisco based punch with a combination of rum, citrus & exotic spices
*Bullitt ($15): old potrero rye, cynar, grapefruit bitters
*The martini ($11): old Tom gin, noilly prat dry vermouth served up, finished with lemon disk
*Cascina roccalini: barbaresco, italy, 2010 ($68)

I had been nursing a hangover all day, so I really only had my drink which was the Bullitt. Dark and boozy and not too sweet. I had a sip of the red which paired nicely with our dinner selections.

*Bruschetta ($19): uni and lardo
This was my favorite appetizer. The bread was rustic and crusty. And the uni with lardo was delicious!

*'Eggs, eggs, eggs': salmon roe and tarragon aioli ($14)
My gf really liked this. She loves eggs. This was great on their toast. The egg yolk was like liquid gold! So rich and creamy.

*Pickled sardines: giardiniera ($13)
This provided a salty contrast to our other dishes. I loved the veggies that came with this.

*Duck liver terrine: pickled fruit and grilled bread ($14)
Deliciously creamy! I love liver pate and this didn't disappoint.

*Grilled cheese: truffle and honey ($16)
I love truffle so I would have really enjoyed this without the honey. I only had a couple of bites since I'm not a huge fan of sweet and savory.

*Wood oven roasted pig's head: endives, capers, parsley & lemon ($50)
This is a thing of beauty to look at! If you can't stand looking at fat, I'd say stay away from this. The dish is definitely like digging for moist delicious pieces of meat through layers and layers of fat! Due to richness of the meat, I could only eat so much of this. The crispy skin however, I kept picking at. It was like delicious pig chips! Yum!

*Bone marrow mixed grill: watercress and horseradish ($20)
This was actually a huge disappointment. The big bone marrow barely had an marrow in it. And it was quite difficult to dig marrow out of the smaller bones. We basically gave up.

*Bavette steak: roasted carrots, onions, thyme and kombu butter ($33)
Yum! Tender and cooked perfectly! And the serving was enough for each of us to have a slice. Definitely my favorite main.

*Broccoli rabe: garlic, lemon, chili and breadcrumbs ($6)
I love having veggies with dinner, so this was a great side! We needed some contrast to all the richness.

With all these dishes, we were stuffed! There was a party next to us who had ordered a delicious looking seafood tower. I may have to come back just for that. It looked amazing!

I saw Chris Cosentino upstairs saying hi to a table and downstairs while they were closing up. But I was too shy to ask for a picture. Maybe next time, I'll say hi! Or perhaps, I'm just making up an excuse to come back!
author: Elena N.

description:
LOVE this place. There's so many restaurant choices in SF and this is one of the very few places we've come back to several times. I've been here with a small group, for a large birthday dinner, and also for happy hours. Every time, service was excellent and the food was amazing. This is one of the few places I highly recommend to anyone who's visiting the city because if you love meat, then you'll definitely love this place.

A couple (of the many) dishes that are my favorites are:
-Pin Bone Steak: yes it's pricier but it's meant to be shared with the whole group. Ordered this twice and I loved the hell outta it
-The grilled cheese sandwich that's on the happy hour menu (dunno if it's the same as the regular menu) but holy shit this thing is AMAZING. The honey on it made it so WOW for me. Hell, we ordered it twice in one sitting because we thought it was so good.

But honestly every dish was pretty damn money so I don't think I had a bad dish here. Do prepare for a bit of a wait since it gets pretty popular but it's totally worth it (and try to make a reservation beforehand!)
author: Diana Y.

description: Great food and service. Had the half a pig's head, the grilled cheese, cauliflower with duck fat, and some toffee dessert. Very good and decadent, especially the pig's head.
author: Sam T.

description: This place always has great meat dishes. I had the impossible burger here once and it was horrible but that's not cockscomb's fault
author: Martha S.

description: Loved the happy hour menu with discounted apps. The giant pork chop was cooked amazingly well. I'll be back for sure and I'm not even from SF.
author: Conor N.

description: Hands down the best service I've experienced in SF.  Catered for a group member who is both celiac and dairy free.   Food was amazing and just all round fantastic experience.
author: Jonathan M.

description:
My three hundred pounds I brought to the table.
My three hundred pounds of hunger and hope.
The hope for one pound of Pork Belly sandwich.
One pound of pleasure.  One pound of dope.

Oh Pork Belly sandwich, One pound of talent.
Oh Pork Belly sandwich, One pound of bomb.
Oh Chris Cosentino you make people happy.
Three hundred ONE pounds are leaving Cockscomb.
author: Boris G.

description:
I came here to celebrate a friend's birthday and really enjoyed the meat dishes here. Especially for large groups, the presentation of wood oven roasted pig's head and some of the other meat dishes were quite impressive.  It reminded me of luau dinners in Hawaii or huge meat dishes at Momofuku Saam in New York. Only come here to eat when you are feeling very carnivorous that day. I would also recommend to course the meat dishes out so that you could try each dish when they are at their best (hot).

My favorites:
Wood oven roasted pig's head - don't miss the crispy pig ear that one could tear off and the skin was some of the best part of the dish.

Roasted butternut squash - well flavored and just the right texture. I hate cutting up squash so getting it at the restaurant was convenient.

Solid:
Leg of Beast - very meaty, don't order it unless you are feeling seriously carnivorous
Lamb shoulder - tender meat

Avoid:
Steak heart tartare: a bit too strong hint of organ meat for me. Seems a bit gimmicky on using steak heart.

Little gems salad - lackluster. A bit too salty.

Golden chard - mediocre.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Got there right at 8:30 for our reservations for 8.  Celebrating my husband's 40th bday.  Wait wait...by 9:15 we had to complain because we were all HANGRY and they told us 20min ago the table before us was paying for their bill.

Finally sat down at 9:15 and we ordered the two specials of the night:
1) lobster with pork belly
2) sirloin tipped w/ seared foie gras and melted bone marrow sauce 

#2 was awesome and totally devoured.  #1 was awful.  The pork belly was just grilled and was pretty tasteless.  Because it was grilled all the usually yummy fat was super chewy and just went to waste.  Lobster was ok.  Nothing special

We ordered the sides: duck fat cauliflower and starchokes.  Pretty standard.

The waiter said the 2 specials would easily feed our table.  But we were still craving something...maybe some carbs? 

So we put in an order of the crispy russet potatoes with garlic butter sauce and they gave us some bread.  And added a pin bone steak. These last 3 were yummy! We should have just ordered the pin bone steak and special #2.  The bone alone was massive! We brought it home for dogs which took them hrs to finish :)

So minus 1 star cuz of the long wait and another minus 1 star for not mentioning my hubby's bday. 
Service was okay...nothing spectacular but they already charged us 18% tip for our large party so why try, right? I want to give this place another try.  Maybe just an off night
author: J B.

description:
4.5 STARS

Mr. NSS: "Where are we going for dinner tonight?"
Me: "Cockscomb."

Mr. NSS: "Uhhh, is like dinner and a 'show'...like Penthouse?"
Me: "Yah, kinda."

Mr. NSS: "Whoa, whoa, whoa now....I don't want to see no beaver cleaver dangling in front of my face while I'm eating!"
Me: "Well, NOW you'll know how I feel!" *Hmmmph*

Don't worry folks, Cockscomb is not what you may think it is...it's Chris Cosentino's newest restaurant in the old Zuppa space (alleyway next to Fringale) that's grand opening tonight. The meat-centric menu was SO enticing that I came here back-to-back just to sample more of the menu. Unlike the new restaurants in SF, most of the portions were huge for the price so I highly recommend going in a group so you can sample more items.

~ * ~ D R I N K S / FO O D ~ * ~
(Sorry, pics are poor quality because of the dim lighting.)

D R I N K S
Cocktails were creative, stiff, and delicious ($11-$15) and they have 5 varieties of fernet! Wines by the bottle were $40-$120.
*Classic Gin & Tonic ($12): http://bit.ly/1yuRvh6
*Chef's Gin Jam ($11): http://bit.ly/1yaFdwL
*Big Trouble in Little China ($11): http://bit.ly/12jWzZM

My fav was the Chef's Gin with housemade strawberry jam; nicely sweet, tart, and refreshing.

A P P E T I Z E R S 
*Little Gem Salad w/ green goddess dressing & crispy pig ears ($11): http://bit.ly/1tDTmuH
*Grilled Cheese w/ shaved black truffles & honey ($16): http://bit.ly/1vJxRNh
*Eggsx3 w/ trout roe & tarragon aioli ($14): http://bit.ly/12eQVsN; yolk porn: http://bit.ly/1wcejnf
*Beef Heart Tartare w/ grilled bread & fries ($16): http://bit.ly/1FHB2Y8
*Bone Marrow Mixed Grill w/ watercress & horseradish ($20): http://bit.ly/1FJ35IC
*Uni Bruschetta w/ Iberico lardo ($18): http://bit.ly/1yBGnA3

All the apps we ordered were excellent. The little gem salad which was nicely dressed and had a great porky crunch from the pig ears (I wish there was more of it though). The grilled cheese could have had more cheese but the shaved black truffles added a great luxurious earthiness. If you like oozy yolk porn, the eggx3 is a must order!

The beef heart tartare was one hearty dish (great for sharing) especially with the deliciously crispy fried potatoes. The trio of bone marrow was slightly disappointing as we found it hard to dig out marrow from the other non-beef bones. The pairing of uni (sweetly briny) and iberico lardo (pork buttah) was pure ambrosia but would have been better with a less carby bread and sans the radish and greens.

E N T R E E S
*Bacon Chop w/ apples, brussellskraut, mustard ($32): http://bit.ly/12jWDJ4
*Bavette Steak w/ roasted carrots & kombu butter ($33): http://bit.ly/1v4pFmX
* Wood Oven Roasted Pig's Head w/ endive salad & salsa verde dripping sauce ($50): http://bit.ly/1CygR2B; pig ear: http://bit.ly/1tv8zz8

The bacon chop is a must order for carniwhores! It's 2 lbs of succulent, meaty deliciousness. There's a thick layer of fat lining the chop which keeps it incredibly moist. The bavette steak was uber tender and had a subtle umami flavor from the kombu butter. The pig's head was a wondrous sight that would make most carniwhores cream...and vegetarians scream. I expected it to be uber crunchy like Chinese siu yuk or Filipino lechon but the skin was fatty and gelatinous. To get into the prized cuts of meat like the cheek, you'll have to pry through the thick layers of fat. We barely made a dent into it so I have the leftovers (carcass and all) in the freezer to make pozole at a later time. The leftover salsa verde made with the pig's drippings makes for a great crusty bread dipper. 

D E S S E R T
*"Classic" Mandarin Orange Mille Crepe Cake ($7): http://bit.ly/1pH6wvE
 It was too soggy and wet for my liking. 

~ * ~ S E R V I C E ~ * ~
You would have never known it was their soft opening because the staff was spectacular! From the hostess, waiters (Josh and David), busboys, and floor managers, everyone was so welcoming, attentive, and knowledgeable (of the menu). Chris Cosentino even made his rounds around the dining room chatting with customers. Food service was also very timely. Best soft opening/grand opening that I've been to in 2014!

~ * ~ A M B I A N C E / D E C O R ~ * ~
Dark and contemporary with concrete walls, dark furnishings, and Edison bulb lighting. In the main dining room there's 5 two tops, 3 four tops, 1 communal table and 12 counter seats in front of the open kitchen. Additional tables and the second bar is in the mezzanine level. Capacity is 120+. 

~ * ~ P A R K I N G ~ * ~
Difficult street parking due to ongoing construction. Parking is available across the street at the Wells Fargo lot for $10-$15 (depending on the night). 

I'm already planning for a group dinner at Cockscomb after the holidays. Pin-bone steak for 4 with bone marrow dip, I'm coming back for you!

Note to self: Next time, come in head-to-toe spanx. =\
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Fun dinner. The giant seafood tower is good for a group. Loved the grilled cheese and the sausage, too. Can get loud.
author: Carl B.

description: So if you don't eat pork this may not be the ideal place for you.   I had the steak and the others in my party had the share platter.   They really seemed to enjoy it.  My steak was also very flavorful.  The atmosphere is very nice and makes the experience an overall good one to enjoy.
author: Amber L.

description: The albacore neck is to die for.... It was big enough for 4 people to share (along with a few other side dishes). I love the atmosphere here and customer service is great! I'm planning to come back soon!
author: Jenn N.

description:
The atmosphere and Chris was awesome . Best way to spend new year's. Service was on point as well. I wish it wasn't a set menu because I would like to try more of what they specialized in. 

I'm glad we were able to get the pig head! Such a guilty pleasure.

Chris was extremely lively and you can see the passion he has for food. Although he sprayed is with champagne lol I didn't mind since he made up with champagne on the house . Really dope guy!
author: Amber H.

description:
Don't know why I felt the need to order a Roasted pig head. We had no clue what to do with all of the fatty bits which was most of it. 
However, everything else we ordered was great. The downstairs interior is designed well but lacking if you have to sit upstairs.
author: Pam P.

description:
Was always a fan of Incanto and I will miss my yearly trek of Head to Tail dinners plus the whole beast and other special meals. As much as  I liked it, getting to Incanto and parking was always a pain. Being near the train and in an area that has plenty of parking during the late night makes it an ideal upgrade to me. Dropped in w.ith some friends for a last minute dinner before I left town. 

Nice list of Amaro to start with. Pork Belly Chop, Meat pie, Benton's country ham and sweetbreads rounded out the savory. Everything was delicious though the salsa verde on the sweetbreads unfortunately cooled them down too much and the dish was lukewarm. The chop is huge and is the bacon from the meat pie with snails really brought on the carne. Country ham was solid but not in a tremendous portion like the others. Next time Im bring a large group and we need to tackle the pigs head and pin bone steak and make like Bengal tigers. 4.3 stars
author: Kim N.

description:
Came here for dinner in late December on a weekday night. The place was still quite bustling though not quite full. I liked the open kitchen and the lofty ceilings. We were seated on the second floor balcony overlooking the seating area below. Great place for a special occasion or a night on the town.

Halibut crudo was a fun starter, and I especially liked the huge, homemade circle of rice cracker to go with it. You could crush it into the crudo or use it more as a cracker, which I chose to do. The flavors all complimented each other nicely and the cracker definitely added a fun crunch and flavor.

For the main course, I ordered the Cornish Game Hen, which was very tender and juicy. The skin had a bit of crisp in it, which I thoroughly enjoyed. The persimmons and molasses also went great with the chicken. We also ordered this really fatty pasta dish that I can't remember the name of (and I don't think it's on the menu any longer). It was basically fat that was rendered into the shape of pasta noodles, which was extremely heavy. It was fun to try, but don't think I'd order a full order of this again.

Duck fat cauliflower was a solid side that you can't really go wrong with. They were nice enough to give us an order of the duck liver pate on the house, which was so tasty and really put us over the top. 

Escape from Alcatraz was a great drink -- love elderflower pretty much any cocktail! 

The food here is definitely very rich and servings of meats and oysters are not for the faint of heart.
author: Audrey L.

description: Omg maybe we not used to eating fatty food?? Pork belly pork chop..  Or the oysters???Good n yummy.. But we have major tummy pains for 6 hours...yikes!!!!!
author: Crisy G.

description:
I was yapping on the phone. A thin, tall and erect man in a dark sports jacket and stripe shirt, with dark jeans to complete the mandatory SoMa biz look was waiting outside of the restaurant. The last sentence I said out loud was "banana bread and pot brownies." Just a lovely way to impress the man in a dark sports coat. I bumped into him on purpose for I lacked the usual grace. He informed me there seemed to be a lot of Asians who just walked in. Our reservation was for 6:45. The maitre de led us to a counter space facing the kitchen. We both said, "Dining at the counter was my favorite" and then caught ourselves agreeing about something unintentionally. He scooped my stool closer to him so that we could find a suitable distance to discuss the comings and goings. 

Cockscomb has been my secret obsession ever since it showed up in an Urbandaddy review. Any friend of mine who dined with me recently would know that I could not shut up about it. It was only a matter of time I'd come here. After canceling the prior two reservations, we made it finally. 

I noted a man I knew was sitting two stools down, I did not greet him for I was lazy. We caught up on our lives. His cousins were in town. He's headed to New England for a trip before New Years, and his father's 90th birthday was coming up and his flight to his Midwestern town required a mandatory stop over in Chicago. I asked about the timing for I had always wanted to check off several midwestern states that I had never been to and never intended to go: Nebraska, Iowa, Indiana, the Dakotas.  You know, the bucket list that says "Those midwestern states you swear that you'd never set foot in but you did anyway."  He laughed and invited me to a future trip on that account. 

Having accomplished that, I started to review menu. Really good selection of odd yet familiar items. The bone marrow three way, the spicy tripe, the little gem with fried pig ears. The entire pig's head. The steak that is big enough to share with the entire village. Difficult choices but I all of sudden realize why so many Asians. We love that shit. The strangely familiar items on the menu spoke to Asians. The strange sounding comfort food that you'd see served in a different way in a Chinese restaurant, The ingredients that made some cringe and others jump up and down for joy. I'm the other. 

We had a few things but I was not hungry as I should. The man to the left of me, the one I recognized but failed to say hello to earlier, was sharing a two pound pork chop with his lady friend, who could not have been his wife, so I wondered. The man to the right of me, the companion who was waiting for me outside earlier, was impressed by the tripe, but not so impressed with the aged ham. He claimed that back in his home town they knew how to really do the hog right. I reserve the right to get smarter and will hold him to it. 

You don't need to be a Asian American person who grew up on pig's head or an Iowa Irish pig farm boy to appreciate the unusual combination of other worldly goodies Cockscomb cooks up.  It is a new age comfort food concept done right.

I have a a few more friends that I'm anxious to drag into this scene. I'm also just plain juvenile. Any chance I could say Cockscomb with a straight face, I'd be gunning for it.

Next up, the pork chops and the pig's head.
author: Victoria E.

description:
Food was good. 
If you make a reservation you should not be sat at the bar. If that's the case - you should state "you will possible sit at an uncomfortable bar" that is to small for the dinner you just spent $145 for 2 on.
author: David F.

description: My hubs and I ate here with a gift certificate that a friend gave us; the friend is a butcher and is infatuated with using the complete animal and "farm to table" concepts. If you are also interested in those concepts, then this is definitely the place for you! Otherwise, some of the menu items are rather heavy and unusual. (cured tuna heart ???  kidney pie ???). Nonetheless, I ordered a steak and it was well prepared and tasty (if a little salty). Cockscomb has an open kitchen and we sat at the bar overlooking the wood oven and grill. While it was interesting to be so close to the excitement of the kitchen, it got rather hot from all the fire, and when we came home, we smelled of smoke and BBQ.
author: Bonnie G.

description:
OFFAL EATS!!! 

Okay, maybe a bit of exaggeration on those two words just to coax you to read my review. Nothing offal eaten and no presence of a cock in the building except for the male species enjoying their liberations or the picture icon on our plates. And not as offal as Incanto but as tasty as expected from a Chef Cosentino restaurant. 

Since this restaurant is "hot and new" it's highly recommended to make reservations. Can be tough getting a time slot of your liking. Parking it's that bad but do not expect front door parking. Service is pretty good but I felt a little rush when waitstaff kept coming by wanting to take your plate away when you are still "nibbling" away. And most importantly, THE FOOD, was pretty good. However, wish the plates had better presentation to be Instagram worthy because in no way it was foodporn quality. Still happy to get a table here and experience the food. I mean, What should you eat the night before lent... MEAT!!!

OYSTERS - check the chalk board. price varies depending on type. They were very fresh and already disconnected for you. Just slurp as I did! The servings come with 3 type of dressings, but oyster lovers know not to coat the oyster because stand-alone quality raw form is what will speak to your palette. 

BACON CHOP - apples, brusselskraut, and mustards. The side serving of veggies blanket my bacon chop making it's photoshoot tribute for Instagram not too worthy. However, the dish itself was super delicious. The chop was very fatty and only saw a sliver of bacon on one side of the chop but I still enjoyed each bite. It was tender, juicy, and "meaty". The portion was huge and can possibly be shared. I highly recommend this dish. 

BONE MARROW - hay smoked fried oysters, watercress and horseradish. From what I've gathered, it was just OK. There's better out there. 

PANNA COTTA - perhaps I'm bias because my favorite dessert is panna cotta and when the waiter came by to show us the desserts... I went tunnel vision. The panna cotta had a very nice firm yet silky texture. Pretty good panna cotta but not as rich and silky as I've had at his other restaurant. 

Will I be back? Sure. I want to try other items. 

JABA APPROVED. Until the next review...
author: Jane A.

description: I was rather disappointed. Despite much ado over the chef's whole animal approach, I found my meal (shared pin bone) to be rather more chewy than edible. Despite informing the waiter of my allergy to chili peppers (capsaicin),I was nevertheless served two sides which contained them. All in all, a masticatory nightmare. Good cocktails, but I doubt I'll go back.
author: Sandra B.

description:
We were there for a Surprise birthday party.. Service excellent, Presentation beautiful, food only okay.
- bread: dry and burnt
- beef tar tar-  pretty delicious, nice flavor
- steak : cut on the wrong bias, lacked flavor, and super super chewy and tough.
- duck: crispy on the outside, but too too raw.
- pig head: very tender, but lacked flavor.  The dip look like mayo but it was flavorless so not sure what it was suppose to be.
- grilled cauliflower: good
- grilled bokchoy- very fresh and crispy 
 
I've never been here before, but it seemed to be a happening place with lots of customers, so maybe they were having an off night?
author: kimberly C.

description: This place is a carnivore's delight. The portions are massive so it's a great place to go in larger parties. We ordered the day's special - tuna collar, along with spaghettini, sausage, cauliflower cooked in duck fat, crispy potatoes and grilled cheese with duck egg. I would give solid recommendations for the grilled cheese, tuna collar and crispy potatoes. The grilled cheese is extremely simple, but the bread was crispy and fluffy and sandwiched a light white cheese that set off the runny duck egg. I would not recommend the two main dishes we ordered - the spaghettini was dry and tuna hearts don't have much flavor and the sausage wasn't very well seasoned (the side salad was delicious though). I am neutral on the cauliflower...perhaps my palate was just overwhelmed by the heaviness of the duck fat. I would give this restaurant another try though - I thought the dishes were creative and the chef was certainly adventurous. The server noted that they were on menu version #93, but this did also make me wonder if perhaps they should focus on their strengths rather than endless variety.
author: Aileen C.

description:
The food was ok. 

Pros:
I was impressed by the venue itself. I love the setting. I've heard seats by the kitchen are much better. The bar here is awesome. Drinks are good. The celery victor tasted better than expected. 

Cons:
I am not a fan of the pork chop. It was tender, but lacked in flavor. The bone marrow was good but not as amazing as I expected from reading all the other reviews. Not a fan of the bruschetta; way too much bread and the rind was extremely tough. 

I think I would give this place another try, but this time, definitely get different things on the menu. The atmosphere itself does make me want to return.
author: Marlene T.

description:
What can I say..... ever since I saw a picture of the wood oven pig's head..  I've been wanting to try this place out for a looooong time. So, when my anniversary was coming up I thought it would be the perfect place to take my boyfriend. 

We had the following: 

Little gems 3/5: We both actually thought this was the crispy pig ears by itself but it actually came as a topping to a salad.  It was still good, but we both felt the buttermilk ranch dressing was a little too much.. too much dressing and a bit salty. 

Beef heart tartar 5/5: This dish was delicious. Everything about it was perfect. The seasonings, texture, flavor, and even the crusted bread that came with it. Highly recommend!! 

Wood oven's pig head 5/5: Although this item was really rich (as everyone says), I feel like it was still really good. Great crispy skin and flavor. People who complain about the head being too rich and knocking off points for it is being unreasonable. I feel like this dish isn't meant for just 2 people to eat it.. and it isn't a MAIN dish.  Because it's so rich, it should be shared and even having a little portion of it is enough.  My bf and I decided to get it because we just had to. You can't find anything else like that in the city. 

Old Fashion 5/5: The bartender made this drink perfect. 

Overall, we had a great anniversary dinner here. We were seated by the bar in front of the oven, which was fine because we got to see them cook and they were kind to answer any questions. One thing I loved was that Chef Chris Cosentino was there and checked every single plate before it went out. It's nice to see a successful chef still hang around and work in his restaurant. I was being a stalker and took a picture without his knowledge.. but I think he's okay with it. :)

We're coming for you next time Pin Bone Steak!
author: Meemee T.

description:
Cockscomb is HEAVEN. It really is. Anyone giving this place less than FIVE STARS can not be trusted, they are clueless fools, do not listen to their faint cries! (see the fool below my review, he is the enemy) YES Cockscomb is pricey and it should be, silly. This ain't McDonalds. Did you really think Meat-Heaven on a plate brilliantly crafted by THE GODS themselves would be cheap? If you are trying to save a buck just stay home you whiney cheap asses, those of us that want to LIVE and EAT like KINGS will support Cockscomb! 

Chris Cosentino is the GENIUS behind Cockscomb, if you're a bay area "foodie" you'll remember he was the man behind INCANTO. Can we just make Chris president of the United States already? He is a supernatural FOOD GOD, yes he is, and I will WORSHIP at his feet until I die of clogged arteries! At this visit I had the opportunity to sit at the bar area and watch the cooks work their magic, having worked in restaurants for years when I was younger it was a real treat to watch how ON HIS GAME Chis and his staff are, he runs his kitchen flawlessly, and they make an amazing team. Chris is a master. And the food coming out of his kitchen is some of the best in all of the Bay Area. Trust that and believe it. 

My wife had The Ham-Burger topped with and egg, I had the same but with a succulent hunk of Foie Gras on top (Because I'm a MAN dammit). I gotta say, it was one of the best things I've ever had in my mouth. Oh and The Duck Egg grilled cheese dish gave me a rock-hard erection too.

Everything here is perfect.
 
Next time that whole roasted Pig Head will be MINE. Oh yes it will. 

I'm already planning my next trip. This place is sexy as hell.

And its so much fun to say COCKSCOMB too.
author: Shawn L.

description: Had a fabulous dinner with my parents and boyfriend. the food was AMAZING. we had the fish collar, which we ate so fast since it was so great, we also had the crispy potatoes which I would eat everyday for the rest of my life. Everything that we got was amazing and I will be back again!
author: GIna K.

description:
Yes... It's one of my favorite restaurants .. Amazing creative dishes .. Not only with a beautiful presentation, but with perfectly seasoned vibrant taste making me wanting more! Crudo tombo - reminds me of ahi tuna ... Crack the rice cracker and use it to scoop up that delicious mixture!  Beef heart tartare - if u don't like raw, this one will make u live raw! Seafood chowder - so flavorful and full of seafood - leaves U dreaming for more! Duck fat cauliflower will turn u into a fan of cauliflowers. Anything duck fat is worth a try! Pork belly sandwich - oh yum yum
Yum! And the house chip is so addicting ! Absolutely loved the mushrooms .. Wood roasted must be their secret. And if you really want greens - both the Little gem & the kale/butternut squash salads are wonderful! I will need to come back many more times so I can try everything on their menu !
author: Jay S.

description:
*** In Short ***

All. The. Meat. Vegetarian? Yeah don't come here.

*** In Depth ***

Ah, this is an hard review to have to write. I was definitely on the hype train for Cockscomb, given all the great things that I'd heard from friends about it. We came as a group of six, and, unfortunately, had to limit our pork options since one person in our party didn't eat it, leading to orders of the:

* Squid... something - Probably the tastiest dish of the night, which is unfortunate because there were six of us, and one of this little appetizer/side. And, yet, oddly, none of us remember exactly what it was we ordered: I'm inclined to think it was a pasta dish, but don't quote me on that.

* Pig Skin Noodles - My hearing must not be what it once was, because I completely misheard/understood how this dish was prepared, after asking our waiter, thinking it was pig skin inside a noodle dish. But nope, the noodles themselves are actually made from pig skin :o Tasty, and, as you'd expect, incredibly rich and fatty. The texture of the "noodles" is, well, chewy and squishy, so prepare yourselves.

* Pin Bone Steak - So, this was the centerpiece. Some tables went with the pig head, some with this, and others with both. Given the aforementioned pork limiter, we opted for the steak, and... any disappointment I had lay almost entirely in this dish. Yes, the quality of the meat was quite good, but our medium rare steak ended up coming out more as a rare steak, and one that seemed unseasoned, almost. I'm not usually one to complain about bland food, since I eat lighter than most, but EVERYONE in our group thought this was bland, even with the provided jus and bone marrow dip. It was bland enough that we had to bust out the salt shaker, which I haven't done since... 15 years ago?

* Panna Cotta - Not something I usually order because, well, I'm lactose intolerant, but that I've somehow probably had more of than any other fancier dessert. And theirs was QUITE delicious, creamy, and rich.

Side dishes aren't enough to save a restaurant, and, while I rarely given two star first experiences a second chance, there's a good chance I will with Cockscomb, since my friends insisted that this was probably a one off fluke. So, until then, 2.5 stars for the place.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - I can't speak for the main floor of the restaurant, but they do have an elevator that goes up to the second floor, where I'm guessing the larger parties are seated. Given that, I can't imagine the ground floor posing much of a problem.

Bathroom - Didn't try.
author: Johnny W.

description:
+ simply amazing food, the pin bone steak is insanely delicious and lots of food
+ drinks are top notch, the bartender made a perfect drink not on the menu
+ service is world class, waiter always checking on us making sure everything is perfect
+ the flavor of the food was unreal!

Cons:
none. i can't find a single thing wrong with this place.

bonus: the chef yelling at his staff to make perfect dishes is a fun show
author: Jonathan Q.

description:
I will start by saying that Chris Cosentino will not care that this is a bad review since he's very well known in the food community having been on TV and all that. Regardless, I still felt the need to dust off my Yelp account (literally I haven't written a review in 5 years) to warn folks of this place....

I give it 1-star for our experience of having to hear Mr. Cosentino BARK constantly at the cooks which is incredible off-putting to hear while dining. The kitchen is open and we were seated very close to Mr. Cosentino who stands on the outside of the kitchen near the bar seating and just constantly BARKS out orders and demands to his staff. Those seated in other parts of the restaurant probably couldn't hear it and honestly, I'm certain other restaurants are just the same. But maybe take a moment and realize that people coming in don't want to hear you sound like a COCKS....(the restaurant name is all too fitting....) Perhaps leave those few seats, right next to your loud and obnoxious voice, empty so everyone dining can have the same pleasant experience. 

So a tip for those going. Request NOT to sit near the kitchen. Unless you like to hear demands and watch the staff look anxious. 

As for the food.... We had the Impossible burger there at lunch. It's one of two places you can currently get it in SF other than the food truck. Thus we didn't have much choice in order to try it. The wait was not long and the burger is quite good. Expensive, but good. Worth trying once, and only once.
author: jen m.

description:
Carnivores delight!  I have heard a lot of good buzz about Cockscumb, albeit... the name threw me off at first.  It's pretty awesome see Top Chef winner Chris Cosentino walking around his restaurant while we were having dinner.  I like the atmosphere here, it is industrial rustic but still refine.  All the food, specifically the meat, was DELICIOUS.  Really full of flavor.


Hot Mess
Butcher's Choice of daily fall offs
^ Confession: I had a hard time distinguishing which dish was which between the hot mess and fall offs, but both were GREAT.  I know that there were utters involved, and I was utterly impressed with how delicious they were.  Also, there was foie gras.  I want to say the utters were the fall offs and the hot mess had the foie gras, but don't take my word for it.

Tombo Ceviche- wanted something light to balance the meat
Sugar Snap Peas with parmesan- self explanatory.  Needed greens. 
Gnocchi-  shu mai sized gnocchi.  delish
Classic dessert- basically banana flambe.  Can't go wrong
Cheese dessert-  two words that I love.  It was great.  

I had a great experience here.  The ambiance, food, and service was top notch.  I recommend coming here, and can't wait to come back.
author: Lyn C.

description:
I would like to like this place, but I just can't.  We waited over an hour for the food to arrive during their lunch seating.  Because we were in the loft, we watched the kitchen as they worked the orders.  The fried chicken that I ordered was forgotten in the fryer for about 15 minutes and was then promptly thrown out.  The second attempt went much better, but was forgotten once plated.  Our other dish was the seafood chowder.  No prep required, but it still took over twenty minutes to plate after the chicken was ready.  By the time we got the food, the chicken was cold.  The seafood chowder was bland.  Chowder is a misnomer as the base is a clear broth and not a creamy broth, not what we were expecting.

Gave the restaurant a second chance.  Wanted to try the impossible burger.  Service was so bad that we walked out.
author: Pietari G.

description:
Food: The food quality overall is pretty rich in flavor especially the butchers choice and pigs head. However, if you do plan to order the pigs head definitely get some bread to balance out the fattiness from the pigs head. As for the sides, cauliflower was a little too salty but the mushrooms were flavorful. 

Service: To the gentleman that approached my table during dinner...a chefs table consists of a TABLE NOT A BAR, just to be clear. I made a reservation and requested a table that has the view of the open kitchen, the hostess seated us on 4 bar stools at what looks like a bar. We asked if it would be okay to get a table instead because we did not realize the chefs table would be just the bar so the hostess was nice enough to seat us at a table instead. We sat down for about 5 minutes and this older gentleman came to our table and in exact words said "you asked for the chefs table and then asked for a regular table so I need this table back by 8pm". First off, that was not a chefs table if you knew anything about chefs tables and second, if you are the manager of Cockscomb, god help the future of the restaurant because someone with your attitude should not be managing anything none the less a restaurant. As for our waitress, she was a sweetheart so she definitely made up for the bad attitude so called "manager". 

So just to be clear...the waitress and the food is the reason why I am giving three stars!
author: C C.

description:
Ugh I hate that I have to write this review as the food and drinks here are quite delicious and the place is an adorable little spot. I have also had great service the few times I have been here. 

But today I came for lunch with my coworkers and a candidate we brought out to lunch as a part of our interview process and it was a terrible dining experience that I would expect a lot better from a place of this quality. Our server was super awesome and sweet and I don't think the mistake that happened was at all his fault.

The candidate and I ordered the EXACT same burger and my two coworkers ordered something else. The candidate's burger came out at 12:40pm.... They brought no one else's food. We told him to just eat as obviously a burger isn't the same cold. After 10 minutes pass I get up to inform our server that only one persons meal came out and no one else's. I worked in fine dining for years with Chefs like Thomas Keller, so yes I have high expectations but this was beyond me having high expectations. The rest of our food did not come out until 1:05....

THAT'S 25 MINUTES LATER...!!!!!

The only reason why I know the times was because it was SO AWKWARD.... to have the candidate we barely know feeling like he didn't know if he should eat or not and us just twiddling our thumbs until he finally gave in and ate because his food would have for sure been cold. He finished his ENTIRE meal by the time we finally got our food. Normally, I wouldn't be this upset but it caused me SERIOUS anxiety and I couldn't enjoy our meal or carry a normal conversation. Having worked in the food industry it's worse than nails on a chalkboard to have this happen. 25 minutes is NOT acceptable.

But here is the kicker.... Even after I very kindly mentioned to the server none of our food came out except one person, the manager thought an acceptable way to make this better was to just bring him out another burger for him to have something to eat while we ate. ?!?! He JUST ate an entire burger there was no way he was going to be able to eat a second so when they brought it he was like well.... can you wrap it up togo, cause I am pretty full.

I honestly was flabbergasted that he not only didn't comp the burger but didn't send us any extras or comp anything at all off the bill. We had to pay the full bill. There is no way in any world that this is acceptable. Again, I am speaking from restaurant management experience. We paid $40/each which obviously the whole dining experience goes into that price. We still got charged for a super shitty dining experience. 

To management: I would have let this all slide and not have written a review if you had righted your wrong but the manager on duty hardly even apologized he just said it was weird and shouldn't have happened. The server on the other hand did apologize profusely even though it wasn't his fault. This makes me feel terrible for the servers that have to work here. Most people blame all these problems on the server and tip poorly because of it. Fortunately, I knew he still deserved his full 20%. But by the managers not supporting their servers and comping things that 100% should be comped makes me think they treat their servers pretty poorly and I don't support business' like that.

This is my first ever review on yelp so that can give you an idea of how much this really irritated me... I didn't even have to pay for the meal so I honestly don't even care for free things I just wanted the manager to make an effort to fix our dining experience instead of me leaving with a terrible taste in my mouth. :/
author: Olivia c.

description:
Missed out on my reservation about a month back but made sure not to miss out again. First off there have been multiple reviews stating the long wait for food so I can confirm that piece. They cook large pieces of meat that take multiple steps between the brick oven and fire pit so it does take time. 

For the food, I had the ceviche, bacon chop, tripe, mushrooms, and heart tartare. All of the food was fantastic except for the tripe. I had high hopes for this one but whether it wasn't cleaned right or the quality, it had a gaminess to it. The bacon chop was well rendered and very tender. The heart was well flavored with a good organ flavor. The highlight of the night was being able to chat with Chef outside the restaurant.
author: Khanh N.

description:
If you are looking for an adventure on a delicious meal. This place is for people that think out of the box. The food is exquisite and the service is 
outstanding. Also don't miss the Happy hour because of great value on wines, oysters and delicious food
author: Ed C.

description:
DELISH!!!  

Food is rich and very tasteful!  I could see and taste WHY this restaurant is highly rated!

Nice to also meet and converse with the Main Chef (from Master Chef, too!)  Chris Cosentino!  :)
author: Nan P.

description:
0 stars for the surly and rude host/manager (stocky, 60-year old male). Downstairs part of the restaurant is really loud and the table they wanted to seat our table of four at was in the middle of the dining room. We asked if upstairs was quieter and was told yes. The hostess asked the host/manager who asked us in a really annoyed voice, "so what's wrong with this table?"  We were ultimately seated upstairs; since there was clearly room upstairs, I don't know what the issue was. This pretty much tainted the rest of the night. 

3.5 stars for the food. Beef heart tartare was the star of the night. Dry aged steak was good, but not as good as most dry aged steaks I've had. Bread pudding was sub-par and served cold (bread pudding at a restaurant should never be served cold).  

Don't plan on coming back, largely due to the surly host/manager.
author: Karen C.

description:
First, let me say that we drove for 6 hours from SoCal to Norcal for a birthday surprise.. Sure they tell you they take reservations until 10pm, but they don't tell you that the kitchen closes at 10:30pm, and if I knew that, we would have gone somewhere else. 
Only the bar is open late... so take that into consideration. 

Highly disappointed! 

Lets just say it's elevated bar food. The menu looks fancy, the idea behind the dishes are great, until they arrive to your table, and you take a bite... poor execution, poor taste... 

The bar options are great, the wine is great, the ambiance is great, however, the food, eh...

We ordered a half dozen of every oyster on the menu, unfortunately, every oyster also came with some shell shards... 

So excited to see foie gras on the menu... another let down!
Its just a poorly executed twist on a deviled egg.. with no taste. 

The Spaghettini was disgusting. Idea was amazing, however, it tasted like a bowl of stinky long beach ocean water.. seriously.. And I love seafood, sushi, anchovies, however, this was not a hit by far. 

The potato dish was expensive loaded potato skins.. that were dry and flavorless.. 

Not sure if the food we received was poor because it was the end of kitchen service, however, our $300 check for 3 people does not justify the food we received.
