The table next to us ordered the roasted pig's head and they were also disappointed with their food and barely ate anything. They even asked us to try a bite to ask our opinion... so sad, that was like a $100 dish.. 

So, the only great thing we had to eat, was the pork chop that was recommended by our waitress... That piece of meat was fantastic.. but that was it! 
$300 bill for 1 great pork chop and wine.. me thinks not. 

Granted, the service was great, our waitress was amazing... came with a complimentary dessert for the birthday girl, however, that was dry and flavorless as well.. 

This was an extreme let down for not only the San Francisco culinary scene, it was a huge let down for food period.

 We will not recommend this place to anyone..

Chef Chris Cosentino and partner Oliver Wharton should be embarrassed.
author: Rachael H.

description:
Came here with a reservation at 6pm in a weekday. Really odd that it was so empty, but the place did get packed by 7pm. Also odd that they have me bar seats for reservations in an empty place. They were nice enough to switch it for a table. Service here is good. The couple next to us tried to sit side by side for a tiny table that is meant for sitting across from each other. They squished into me on the booth side, but the manager/hostess noticed right away and told them they had to sit across from each other or move to the bar if they wanted to sit side by side. I thought that was a nice touch since there was obviously not space for them to sit side by side.

 The food, I thought was just ok. To eat we shared the broccoli appetizer and grilled cheese sandwich. But were just ok. For the main course we had the branzino, which I was very excited about since it's hard to find Branzino on the west coast. Actually chose this place for the branzino. Problem was, the fish was tiny and didn't taste very fresh. We also had the basil creme brulee, which was just ok. I did like that they had calicraft buzzerkely on draft though. Overall, food is just ok. I give this place 3.5 stars.
author: Lisa T.

description: Great service with healthy options and just the right amount of portions.
author: Salleha C.

description:
Great food, bad service. 

What should have taken 30min, took 2hrs. I don't think I will find myself coming back anytime soon. If they are still open after 3months, Ill see what the reviews are of their service to even consider it. Plenty of choice locations in this area, not the end of the world to skip this place. Its not exactly a destination eatery in my book.
author: Juan G.

description:
A meaty South of market restaurant with famed chef Chris Cosentino.  We can for lunch, to try the Impossible burger.  We might return, but were not overly impressed.

Picks:
Grilled Cheese ($14) country ham, duck egg & honey was good. A nice sweet top on a crisp sandwich. The ham was like prosciutto, making it hard to rip apart between bites.


"impossible Burger" ($19) lettuce, dijon, caramelized onions & bread and butter pickles was the reason we came!  We would say it is 80% of the way to mimicking a burger.  Cooked with a crispy top and tender meat, the nitpicks are consistency and not having a robust beef flavor. Still pretty impressive for a first effort.  Well worth trying.

5 years in the making and bankrolled by Bill Gates and Google, Instead of beef, the Impossible Burger contains heme (the molecule that gives beef its reddish color and metallic flavor), textured wheat protein, and coconut oil.

It has a way to go. The regular ham burger costs $15 and is almost 3 times as big.

Just OK:
None


Would not reorder:
Fried Oyster Po Boy ($14) Bland and not fried well.

Ice Tea ($6) Expensive and nothing special

Overall - Very Good
Food - Very Good
Decor - Very Good
Service -  Good
Value -  Good

Would we come back - Maybe
author: Ellen H.

description:
Thank goodness for my foodie friends who are in the loop about new yummy SF restaurants, plus it was in good timing with the CA ban removal of foie gras (yes please!!).  We went to Cockscomb on a Friday evening.  

The entrance seems sort of secretive down a side street off of 4th Street in SOMA.  My friend and I are huge truffle fans so we could not resist the grilled cheese with shaved truffle on top (yes, please, the truffle was such a nice sweet balance against the cheese) and of course, as soon as the waiter said, "Now I know you know that foie gras is now available again in Calfornia...." My friend and I eagerly asked, "Do you have any??"  He said, " Yes, we have a...."  "We'll take it!!"  Do you think we have been deprived?  I say yes.  Haha, when the foie gras arrived, I cut myself a piece trying not to be too greedy because I was sharing the dish with two other people....mmm, I closed my eyes and savored its flavor.  I know it's a controversial dish and it is not completely ethical but I just can't help myself.  Why does it have to be so good?  

Anyway I digress - we also ordered the pig skin spaghetti (my friend didn't care for the sauce, a little to salty?, I didn't mind at all, I thought it was tasty) and the bone marrow (creamy smooth, yummy).  All of the above so far was tasty but not necessarily all good for the heart so we also ordered some sauteed chard - that was a good balance (well, let's just say it was).  

For dessert, we had cheese with honey and walnuts and a layered crepe cake with fruit.  I'm not a big dessert person but I liked what we had.  

Chef Chris Cosentino came by and took a picture with us after dinner - now who couldn't love that after I had seen him on TV with Anthony Bourdain a number of times!!  I went to Incanto for the Leg of Beast before it closed, and was waiting to see what Chris Cosentino's next move would be - nice one!!  I'll be back!
author: Maile N.

description:
Drink: The Towering Inferno
Appetizer: Leeks (I liked the crunchy bits and you really should have a few greens in the meal we were about to have) Beef Heart Tartare (a must order)
Eat: Bacon Pork and Pigs Head
Dessert: ALL OF IT but eat in order of light to heavy.
author: Kathleen W.

description: Had to try the impossible burger and it was awesome! We decided to pop in last minute the 23rd of December for a lunch to kick off the holidays. The hostess was accomodating on the phone and sat us at the chef's bar where we able to watch the masters at work. We saw about 10 impossible burgers going down, so had to give one a try and we weren't disappointed. My husband got the "ham" burger which was essentially a huge piece of delicious smoked ham with an egg on top, the thick cut fries were to die for. We also ordered a few cold beers and the duck confit cauliflower, totally worth the extra calories! Loved the ambience, staff was great, and for an upscale restaurant in SOMA we felt totally comfortable in hoodies and sneakers for an impromptu lunch. I want to go back and have some oysters, charcuterie, and Negronis (they have my favorite cocktail on tap!?). All around great experience for a date, out of town friends, or the foodie in your group. Will be back :)
author: Lisa H.

description: Awesome, well crafted, well seasons, cooked perfectly food. We had the deviled eggs with fried chicken skin (You had me at fried chicken skin), and a steak over a salad which I cannot remember the name off. Awesome.
author: Tony H.

description:
Fairly disappointed by the pin steak! 
We are a party of 3, walked in without reservations, first time here. Ordered an appetizer (the cockscomb terrine which is good), and asked about the pin steak. We were only told it was a sharing dish. I now feel mislead, this steak could feed 5-6 people easily!
The sauce was ok, I like the carrots on the side a lot.

Oh. Also had to send some parts of the steak back. We ordered medium rare and a couple pieces were more to the blue side. 

I wish the waiter would have been more helpful in recommendations (he rattled on too fast), and should be more clear on the size.
author: DT Y.

description:
Hip and cool new restaurant, while retaining a down to earth vibe. It was very exciting to see the chefs in action in the open kitchen. Chris Cosentino, of course, lead the action. 

We started with the 'Eggs Eggs Eggs', the Beef Heart Tartare and the Bone Marrow. An egg is something that seems so simple yet can be prepared exquisitely, as Cockscomb did. Of course, the flavors of the salmon oil and tarragon aioli added to the well-cooked eggs. The heart beef tartare was a wild adventure in my mouth. Slimy yet firm and flavorful at the same time. It was perfect on top of grilled bread! The Bone Marrow was a combo of beef, pig and lamb marrow.
 
For the main show, I got the quail tettrazine. Absolutely heavenly! The quail was deliciously tender and the creme fraiche was perfect with it. My sister got the Bacon Chop which was humongous! It's definitely a dinner for two light eaters like me. It looked pretty porkingly overwhelming, but boy was it delicious!!

Chris was gracious enough to come over and say hi as well as to take pictures. Of course we were pretty giddy. 

Next time, I'm going to grow a pair and tackle the infamous Wood Oven Roasted Pig's Head!
author: Carmela A.

description:
My favorites of the night ended up being both starters.. each delicious enough to be a main! For the seafood lovers, order the bruschetta topped with dungeness crab. So good. The grilled cheese is indulgent. It's ever so slightly sweet. They're both great portions too. No tiny and disappointing plates here.

Cocktails are great too!!
author: Samantha L.

description:
Bland, underwhelming and overpriced.

Nice looking if oddly laid out space with attentive servers and staff. Food however is very much hit and miss. No reason to recommend and certainly will not return.

Ham burger is an interesting concept that falls flat with the first bite. Everything is tasty except for the ground pork shoulder burger which was completely void of flavor. The fried potato accompaniment was very good... but it is nearly impossible for fried potatoes to be bad.

Roasted pepper appetizer was tasty as was the hot mess. Both needed some bread however to soak up the flavors.

Beef heart tartare was very bland, really needed capers or something acidic to bring out some flavor.

The medium sized oyster platter also fell flat. Tiny gritty oysters apparently shucked with a hammer. Whoever was responsible for the oysters really needs to reconsider their career choice. Three so-so clams when the menu states six, and their tombo tuna poke which was overly salted. The hot mussels in wine were good, but oddly enough planted in the middle of the ice covered platter. It was not possible to get through the mussels before they had chilled far too much.

Spaghettini with tuna heart was decent, but really just one flavor note. Three bites and one is ready to move on.

Finally there was the bacon chop. While it was a good sized piece of pork, it was bland and a little dry. The sides looked like an afterthought... literally four brussel sprouts and a tiny mound whatever the apple slaw thing was.
author: Easwud C.

description:
5 stars for the food but had to deduct a star for the uncomfortable seating. 

We made reservations and were seated at the bar, except it was at the very corner by their super hot oven. Great for food but not so much for a human...

I was sweating through dinner and given that a community table was right behind us, we felt very uncomfortable with the lack of space. I'm all for crowded restaurants but add heat and back-hurting bar stools- no thanks. 

Anyways, the service and food were excellent. The grilled cheese is so perfect with the egg and honey. I wish I could just eat one after another. 

The burger was very well seasoned and perfectly cooked. The Dijon mustard made it a tad salty but overall, it was very good and juicy. The potatoes on the side were the best I've ever had. Seasoned so well. Highly recommended. 

My boyfriend got the hen. It was seasoned well and moist. Not a star but good. 

I wish we could have stayed for dessert but like I said, I was dying in front of that oven. I wish they had warned us before seating us.
author: Shireen J.

description:
We are long time fans of Chris C., so we had to try out his "new" (a year old) restaurant. It was the day before New Years Eve, so there was a lot of prep going on for that night. The room is beautiful, rustic, earthy, and just right for the foods being served.

 First, it's way more convenient to park, at least the night we went, compared to Incanto.  Second, the happy hour was phenomenal!  We had a dozen fresh and tasty oysters, a big bowl of crispy potatoes (a melange of cream, cheese, bits of whatever, a crispy creamy potatoes) and a bowl of crispy pig ears.  I had a delicious cider, and my partner had a white wine.  Divine, and too much for snacks, but too good to miss.  We sat on the balcony overlooking the kitchen, where we could see all the prep.  

We then had dinner at the kitchen bar, and could watch the careful attention to detail and all the various dishes coming out of the kitchen, and the woodburning oven, and grill created a wonderfully warm ambience and excitement.  We had four dishes:  heart tartare, (a wonderfully rich helping, with bread); the cockscomb terrine (how I miss the charcuterie platter from Incanto), and wood fired mushrooms in beef broth, and the highlight, a pig-skin pasta in ragu that must be tasted to believe (really, pigskin cooked and forced through a pasta machine to resemble a translucent pasta). The meal overall was leisurely, exciting to watch, and memorable.  

After seeing several "pinbone steaks" coming off the grill, I'm coming back with a larger party to try that... the care in preparing a huge cut of meat was amazing... just to get the doneness just right!

Can't wait to come back... Good job, Chris!
author: Gary Y.

description:
Had everything on the menu that didn't involve seafood or "vegetarian" misguidedness ; plus a few things that were not on the menu.

Everything was great but the full lobe of foie gras was the clear winner.  Perfection.

See picture.
author: Chris E.

description: Oh my goodness, if you are a fan of good food and want to take a magical ride on the gastronomic amazing this is the place for you. Now I showed up and was having a bit of difficulty with the menu, no problem at all. Got a quick run down on the ins and outs of what was good, different and amazing.  I love good food, was a executive chef for years and now a firefighter and the primary cook for the shift. I can only tell you that this place is on my top ten of all time, like #2. I'm not going to tell you what to get, show up and tell them what you like and enjoy the experience.
author: B B.

description: Just had the most epic dinner experience! First, the food was absolutely to die for, one of the best restaurants in the city for sure! Second we got to meet the chef who was so fun and nice! The service was phenomenal and it was one of the best girls nights out for a bday yet! Thank you Chris!
author: Amanda N.

description:
had a great time here. good food and really prompt, friendly service. i thought the food was nothing to write home about (and also a tad too pricey for the portions), but delicious-- i probably would have been more of a fan if i bit the bullet and ordered their specialty whole pig's head (a conversation piece, to say the least). 

ambiance is cozy, with not much space in between tables and also the clearing for the bar in the back. there is an upstairs area. no entrance or receiving area to speak of-- you kinda just open the door and them BAM! the whole restaurant is gawking at you. the noise level is lively but tolerable. 

overall, a bit overrated but i love that you get to see chef cosentino almost always there, working and conversing, unlike other celebrity chefs.

do go if you love offal and meat. oh and desserts-- amazing desserts!
author: Vanessa D.

description: Always love coming here and it was great to share it with my coworkers. They always offer such delicious, innovative and creative combinations that you can't go wrong. The Hot Mess version tonight was just stellar and the cranberries with it provided the perfect bite to cut the richness. Meat pie with bone marrow was stellar and although rich, it was far from heavy and overwhelming. Such a fun, innovative, delicious spot. I look forward to my visit every time I am in town. Bravo Chef and team, as always an awesome job!
author: David M.

description:
Came here tonight with Ben for the 10 - 11pm happy hour and woww, did it delight!! The resto is a convenient 2 blocks from the Caltrain and a convenient 2.5 blocks from B's place!

Happy hour was located upstairs..and even though the address says 4th Street, you enter through the entrance tucked right on the corner of 4th and the alley. (Just follow the "drinks & cocktails" sign!)

We ordered:
1. Oysters (half dozen) - super fresh and only $1 each! Would've been better with cocktail sauce and tabasco, but thats just me.. mine were a tad gritty, so definitely had better.

2. Crispy pig ears - super chewy and really yummy with the lime. I loved how perfectly seasoned it was..and with a sprinkle of lime, the flavor was amazeballs!

3. Grilled cheese - my most favorite item of the night!! Cheese was perfectly melted and didn't turn rubbery when it cooled down. The toast was PERFECT. ..crispy and chewy..and drizzled in sweet honey...gahh lovee..

4. Crispy potatoes - Ben's fave thing of the night! This is a super generous portion..and meant to share amongst 3 or 4 people. We killed it between the 2 of us..but we love dem taters!!

Total bill for all that PLUS 2 drinks? $27. Amazing. 

Need i add that we had hh right next to the chef? Next time I'll have to say hi! :)
author: Jennifer S.

description:
A well-known but literal hidden gem in a city filled with small portion- expensive ass Michelin star restaurants, even having Alexander's around the corner. Don't get me wrong, there's nothing wrong with those, but sometimes you want to step away from that ambience and step in to a night of sharing and devouring meat without feeling like at any moment a waiter is going to come over and wipe a crumb from your cheek. Cockscomb embodies this, in my opinion. It holds the fancy up-scale feel but with a more rustic-casual touch (if that even makes sense). 

The restaurant is located in an unpretentious area and you could very easily miss it. Parking will probably be close to impossible on a busy night but on a random weekday, we found parking just down the alley.  

We were seated at the very top of the restaurant, snuggled right into a corner booth. Our waiter, whose name I really wish I remembered, took our drink orders: inside out (gin/cranberry/egg white) and a beer. 

We started off with oysters and the charcuterie platter. The oysters were a mix of local (T. Bay) and Washington (go huskies!). All were, not too big and not too small, and a good balance of sweet and salty oceany flavor. The charcuterie platter was a great size to share for two-came with slices of bread and pickles! The meat choices themselves had a variety of textures and levels of saltiness. My one gripe is that the edges of the bread felt like it was cutting my mouth because it was really toasted. 

We were going to do the pigs head but I read too many reviews stating it was pure fat- then we moved on to the pin bone steak but our waiter (thankfully) said that it would be way too much and is usually for a group of 4+. We settled on one of the shareable specials: ribeye with whole crab served with veg. Not only was this the perfect size for us but the presentation was on point as well. I was scared I was going to be flinging crab shell everywhere but the shell was so soft! The meat inside was cooked perfectly and had amazing crab flavor/texture. Our steak was seasoned nicely but just wasn't as tender as we would have expected. The veg (brocolini?) stood out to me because the added lemon juice or citrus on there helped cut the meat/crab/butter. Usually sides of veg are just bleh in flavor but this was really really good! 

For sides- we just ordered the gnocchi per waiters suggestion. This was literally melt in your mouth. Other gnocchi I've had in the past usually has a bite to it but these.. wow. Had to pack it up to take it home but still delicious! 

 We didn't have room for dessert so ended our night there. Incredible service and food, a lovely change up from our normal anniversary dinner setting. We will be back to try more shareable plates ( pin bone steak I'm coming for you..some day).
author: Alli D.

description:
Happy hour at Cockscomb? Yes, please!!

I love HH, but good ones are hard to find. Cockscomb HH is short (M-Thurs 5-6pm) but sweet. Some features: $1 oysters (rotating - we had some from Washington state that were very creamy), $5 negronis on tap, a selection of $5 beers (and not bad ones either!), and $3 crispy pig ears. GET THE PIG EARS! These chewy, cartilage-y, porky crunchies are perfectly seasoned with lime, herbs, and chili and pair great with a beer.

During our time at Cockscomb we saw Chef Consentino taking orders and getting the line ready. It's always nice to see an executive chef present at the restaurant - clearly, he's doing something right!
author: Clarice W.

description:
Thank you to Ford for #EdgeNightOut! Ford had a promotion for their 2015 Edge models last night and partnered with Cockscomb to provide a 3 course meal with 2 drinks per person after going for a test drive in their new cars. 

The restaurant conveniently texted me to confirm my reservation, which I absolutely loved. I was able to easily reply with "1" to confirm my reservation while at work. About 10 minutes before my reservation time, I was called to confirm that I was on my way. When I arrived at the restaurant, which is right off the main road in what appears to be an alleyway, I could see many people waiting outside. After going for the test drive, I entered the restaurant, showed my wristband, and was immediately seated in front of the kitchen area where you can see the wood fired oven, the steaks being prepared, and the salads being carefully hand crafted. 

We were presented with special menus for the night and started off with the Honey Grilled Cheese, Farmer's Market Salad, a Cali Craft Buzzerkeley and Negroni. The honey grilled cheese was not your typical grilled cheese. It was made with what seemed to be possibly goat cheese with just the right amount of honey on top, a great pairing and a delight for grilled cheese lovers everywhere. The salad was presented well. We ordered the Coulotte Steak and Cornish Game Hen for the main portion of our meal. The steak was sliced into small pieces and was delicious, just the right portion for a small person such as myself. The Cornish Game Hen consisted of a much larger portion than the steak, enough so that we were able to eat until satisfied and have enough for lunch the next day! The hen may appear to be burnt in the pictures on yelp but it has a lot of flavor and a good amount of meat! Don't let the pictures deter you from ordering it. We had 2 more Cali Craft Buzzerkeleys and ended dinner with a chocolate and pumpkin cake and Eton's mess. All in all, a great place for drinks and dinner! Would definitely return. :)
author: Saachi G.

description:
Came here for a Thursday night dinner.

Pros:
Great food
Attentive staff
Decor

Cons:
None that I can think of
author: Simon C.

description:
Came here for the impossible burger during lunch (only time offered). The waitstaff was great, very quick in the refills and not long to place our order. The burger itself was pretty tasty- tasted real to me, and more importantly to my meat-eater husband. I can't wait till they start selling it in retail stores. 

So why 3 stars? Because that's all that was good. The side salad was so salted I couldn't eat it. The burger toppings and bun used were very meh, and for $19 you think they could afford a bun that is the size of the entire burger. I didn't eat the potatoes (not vegetarian) but my husband said the sauce was overdone and overpowering -and he loves horseradish. The gnocchi was just sad. The sage was black and burnt, which if done right doesn't happen. The gnocchi was fried, they used so much oil! It came out in a bed of oil, you couldn't taste the sage or brown sugar, just the oil. Definitely won't be returning here as there are much cheaper, higher quality options for the same items I to bay area. Will keep my eyes out for the impossible burger patty though.
author: Rebeka T.

description: Cockscomb is my go-to restaurant when entertaining out of town guests. It simply doesn't disappoint. Ambiance is great, the restaurant is clean throughout, food is innovative and always perfectly done. If I had to offer a criticism, it's that depending on table, it can get a bit tight. My favorites are the hot mess, 'ham' burger, the pig's head, grilled cheese, pig-skin spaghetti. Simply, a carnivore's heaven.
author: Mike S.

description:
How do I love thee.....

I can count about a dozen ways....

1.  Grilled Cheese (our neighbors shared)
2.  Squid
3.  Seared Cauliflower
4.  Mushrooms
5.  Oysters and Clams
6.  Kale Salad
7.  CORNISH GAME HEN!!!
8.  Bacon Pork Chop
9.  Country Ham
10.  BEEF HEART TARTAR!!!
11.  Sidecar
12.  Beef Coulette

Lord have mercy, this was a good one. Our gang of four ladies managed to take this meal down, almost. We had one to go container. 

Everything was delicious. The squid was the best squid I have ever had. Not sure what they do but it was marinated perfectly and a great surprise. The beef heart tartar to die for. My favorite was the Cornish Game Hen. The most succulent bird I have ever tasted with a perfectly crispy skin. I could go on and on.   

Already planning our return.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Cockscomb offers a rich and amazing dining experience blending a variety of cooking styles to produce delicious and unique dishes found nowhere else in the city. From cocktails to dessert, everything is incredible, and the staff couldn't be more friendly, attentive, or professional. 

There's no going wrong with lobster or oysters. They serve only the best from the sea. The tuna tartar appetizer is to die for. 

There is an incredible pig's head on the menu, and my chicken waffle came complete with a foot! I'm delighted and impressed by the fact that they don't waste anything. They even have brain mayo! 

While some of this may sound odd or extreme, just remember, it's all carbon in the end. Be adventurous and take a chance. The price point is fair, and the experience will be memorable.
author: Ahsan A.

description: Pretty darn good restaurant.  Great food and a fun atmosphere.  Very creative food in a cool spot.
author: Richard D.

description: Wow! This place is delicious. Everything from the food to the cocktails to the service. I have bed. 4 times and can't wait to go back. The whole animal tastes better than you think.
author: Lynnet S.

description:
Ok, I must update my review. It really pained me to write the previous one, as angsty as I sounded, I swear, I didn't want to go to a negative place. All that being said, I gave it another go and returned for lunch last week. 
I made a reservation and was seated right away even though my lunch date hadn't shown yet. I was sat at the bar as I requested in my reservation. I ordered the impossible burger and it didn't disappoint. It was great! I loved the addition of the gruyere and caramelized onions and all the other toppings were spot on. The patty itself was interesting, in a good way. It didn't really taste like anything else I have had. I think the best part is how much it resembled a pink, medium cooked beef patty. It was juicy and tender, it was kinda bizarre but wonderful at the same time. 
Our server was wonderful, very attentive and let us linger after our meal without making us feel like we needed to hightail it outta there. 
I'll come back again for dinner and chalk up my first time as just bad luck on my part.
author: Sarah M.

description:
I only dropped in for happy hour, but it was great!  You could get beer or a negroni on tap for only $5.  I opted for the negroni and it was well made - only thing is it was served on ice cubes so I had to fish out several of them to prevent my drink from getting diluted too rapidly.

For bar snacks, we shared some $1 oysters and the crispy pig ears ($3).  I forget the oyster variety that day, but they were fresh and creamy (and also huge!) and served with a lightly sweet celery mignonette.  But onto the crispy pig ears... wow.  There were two types of texture - crispy and gelatinous, and they were slightly spicy and served with fresh herbs (cilantro, basil, chives) and with a little bit of lime juice, it was divine.  I will definitely order these again and again on subsequent visits!

Lastly, when we came for HH on a Thursday (on a non-Giants game day) it was not too crowded - I guess not many can make the Mon-Thurs 5-6pm HH.  Luckily for me, Cockscomb is just a few blocks from my Caltrain commute!
author: Beatrice W.

description:
I really wanted to like this place. I'm a huge fan of Chef Cosentino. Incanto was one of my favorite places in SF for a nice dinner, and when that closed and Porcellino was opened, Porcellino was a nice casual fare. The nduja potatoes!! Soooo good. 

Maybe Cockscomb is still trying to find its place. The most disappointing dish was the duck liver. Now I'm a fan of offal, and I've tried all sorts, whether it was at Incanto or just with traditional chinese cooking. The duck liver was really livery and irony. It definitely wasn't to my tastes, nor the taste of the other diners at our table. We even tried the liver on the toast with the picked peaches. It helped with the flavor a bit, but didn't save it much. 

Grilled cheese with truffle. Wasn't amazing either. I think the cheese wasn't gooey enough and the bread wasn't butter/fried enough. The truffles were a nice taste, but I didn't think it complemented the dish well. 

The special sausage plate was the best part of the meal. The sausage had many dimensions of flavors and I loved the potatoes that came with it. 

Maybe I'll try this place in a year or so. But for now, it's not my cup of tea.
author: Vanessa K.

description: Very impressive young restaurant, south of Market.  We were turned on to Cockscomb by a friend who has a tech business in the area.  We went before a Giants game and were very happy we did.  Super service and interesting food that cover anyone's taste.  Not cheap but I though the pricing was fair.  I will be back.
author: J B.

description:
Service - I ate at the bar here on a Wednesday night and found my server (wish I remembered her name!) absolutely delightful. She was so kind, friendly and attentive. Food came promptly, and drinks perhaps less so but I understood that she was very busy.

Food - I ordered the Lardo with figs, olive oil, cracked pepper and Rosemary. A small plate but so tasty and unique. I also ordered the beef heart tartar which was good, but a bit heavy for just one person, wish I had someone to share it with that night ;)

Cocktails - yummy!! I ordered the Boothby and the Maltese Falcon, preferred the former
author: Jessica N.

description:
Came alone and sat at the low bar beside the chef's station. The culotte steak had superb flavor, and everything they threw on that grill looked incredible. Will return and highly recommend.

Careful: sitting close to the wood fueled fires leaves you smelling a tad like smoke.
author: Matthew C.

description:
We had a Birthday Dinner for 7 last night. Around the table, we had everything from the Crudo to the Bacon Chop. Everything was amazing! Personally, I enjoyed the "Hot Mess". It is an amazing combination disparate ingredients including Foie Gras and pickled strawberries (and I'm not sure what else.) I have never had so much flavor on one plate. Wow! 

Service was great.  Attentive, but not hovering. To finish off a great meal, the Panna Cotta was incredible.
author: Bill D.

description:
This place was a gem.
A few friends from out of town accompanied me for dinner here. We ordered quite a spread from the tuna collar, to a few salads including the little gems salad. The oysters were fresh and on point, and the drinks (according to my friends) were impeccable. 
A cute, cozy, hidden place just slightly off the beaten bath with an small upstairs bar to boot. Their menu is always changing, and always so good.
author: Mima G.

description:
We came here for happy hours or our team get together.

Ambience was great! 
Drinks were amazing, I recommend the bourbon cocktail.

Food was little different for my taste. 

We ordered appetizers and finger food and things. I felt full but not satisfied.

I think I need to come back and order the $100 pork chop!
author: Jenner B.

description:
We went to try the Impossible Burger, which was okay.  It was excellent for not being meat, but when compared to actual meat, it's only okay.  It has an odd crispy grill texture and it tastes vaguely like almond butter.  The patty itself is small and the burger is sort of sad.  If you're vegan or have a vegan friend or have made other unfortunate life decisions then the Impossible Burger is worth keeping in mind.  Otherwise, eh.

What you SHOULD get and what earns FOUR STARS is their "Italian Dip."  It is a pork sausage sandwich served in a bowl of marinara sauce.  GO GET IT RIGHT NOW.  Also have a cocktail, their cocktails are pretty great.  And the beef heart tartare!  Eat it in front of your vegan friend eating the small dry oddly-nut-flavored burger-thing.
author: Kevin S.

description:
Went here 2 nights back to back. On the first night, I went with a group of 6. I made a reservation via seat me yet for both occasion did not seem to be necessary on a weekday night. Our group ordered their special 4lbs pinbone steak, topped with foie gras. We also ordered a few sides to accompany the main dish. I was really drawn to this restaurant due to he circulation pigs head pic I've been seeing on some friends' Instagram. Coming to he restaurant with a Jewish person was not the best situation in trying to order it though. Anyway, the pin bone steak was great. Perfectly seared foie stop a massive peace of meat. We asked for it to be cooked medium, yet the steak came mostly medium rare. It actually worked in my favor since I do like my steak medium rare, but if you're the type that is particular with bloody steak, i suggest you go a little more cooked than your usual. The sides were good, I think the mushrooms were my favorite. For dessert we shared the Chocolate cake and a dessert with citrus fruits with whipped cream. Quite honestly, the desserts where a little underwhelming. 

The following night, one of my other friends texted and we decided to go back for the sole purpose of the pigs head. if you like chicharon, crispy skin, this is your meal. I do enjoy crispy skin but as an entree, with all the fat, and barely any lean meat, it got too much. Although I'm glad I went for the experience. Come on, how many people can say they ate half a pigs head? To top that dinner, we had a couple of dessert again, we had the creme brûlée infused with lime and the apple tart. The creme brûlée is definitely the best dessert there, although it's a shame that the sugar brûlée did not crack at first strike.

All in all, it's a great restaurant to experience food.

I forgot to mention that on the second, I met the chef, Cris Cosentino. He was nice and very down to get a picture with anyone who asks.
author: Jan R.

description:
Wanted to looooove it but I didn't. However, that's not to say it was a bad experience.

We ordered several apps and an entree to split. Felt like it was just the right amount of food. The crudo was fresh, my BFF liked the beef tartar (I'm not eating red meat but had a teeny bite and it was flavorful albeit rich), I'll pass on the squid stuffed risotto (mushy and fell apart), albacore was cooked perfectly but was too spicy as was the summer squash. I'm ok w/ spice but the BFF wasn't. While the food wasn't bad, I wasn't blown away.

The service was great and the faux cocktail I had was refreshing. We were seated promptly for our reservation which is always a plus. The restroom is clean. I'm sorry but I've been basing my reviews and reservations of late on the restroom cuz it's important. They passed here.

Apps are priced from $10-$15 while entrees are about $30ish.

They also have specials and items to share that can run up to $100+.
author: Julie L.

description:
We had a group holiday party there, and it was ok. Our choices were the Pinbone steak, some sort of pork thing with lobster on top, various appetizers, and liquor. I get the feeling this is a place that is pretty popular with the paleo crowd as everything was 100% compliant with that diet. The only thing I could have passed on what the various organ meats that were used. They were prepared well, however beef heart, liver, and lung aren't really my thing.

The drinks were very good, however this is one of those places where the staff introduces things with words like "This is a bourbon forward drink..." and so forth.

Get the second mortgage on the house worked out before you eat here, it's awkward to do it at the table when the bill comes.
author: Danny Q.

description: Party of seven on a Wednesday night. Had the best table in the house next to the grill, " the chefs table". the food was so fun and pretty tasty. All the desserts were ridiculous, especially the panna cotta. The pin bone steak with the bone broth was bomb, just ask for medium or medium rare otherwise it comes out rare. The pig skin pasta was rad. Chef Chris is such nice guy, I really appreciated him talking with us for 15 minutes. Go there! Thank you!
author: Justin M.

description:
very underwhelming :(
went here for lunch for my gf's birthday
ordered the root salad w/ anchovies to share. probably the highlight of the whole meal
I ordered the fried chicken sandwich referred by the waitress. it was just ok. seems like the chicken is pounded out too thin or something because it was very tough. almost to the point of chicken jerky. not what anyone is after when it comes to fried chicken but still edible.
my gf ordered the burrata salad. pretty gross. the burrata tasted like it had spoiled. I had to spit it out when she asked me to test it. we are big fans of burrata and I have never had one that was even remotely close to this far past expiration.  the salad was also served with toasted bread from the flat top. also gross. the bread just tasted like old burnt bits from the flat top and burnt oil. 
the menu looks great and the restaurant is really nice. cool looking bar inside but just completely failed the execution with our lunch. with too many options out there no reason to go back :(
author: nick H.

description:
Originally I fell in love with this restaurant when we came in late one night and sat right next to the expediters station! WOW! Based on that experience and the INCREDIBLE service we received from our server, the sous chefs and Jose the manager, I decided to surprise my guy for his 50th!

We began our evening with a small intimate PERFECT 50th birthday party "pit stop" for a CARNIVORE'S TOAST at the BEGINNING of our "progressive" evening of food, champagne and birthday cake on our rooftop deck later that same evening...

BUT we STARTED at Cockscomb with the Wood Oven-Roasted Pig's Head and Pin Bone Steak with bone marrow dip! Added to this "appetizer round" were the grilled cheese with honey, beef heart tartare and the crudo!! AMAZING AMAZING AMAZING!

Jose and his staff were beyond helpful and gracious to our group and the personal "Happy Birthday" from Chef Chris was the cherry on top!

As a private concierge, my guests are out-of-towners (mostly CEOs, Celebrities, NBA, NFL & MLB players) and Cockscomb is the first restaurant I send them to when they arrive! I tell them how they created the BEST 50th birthday experience and each one of my clients receives the very same treatment and JOY eating at Chef Chris' fantastic eaterie! THANK YOU!
author: Carmen M.

description:
Beware of shady business practices!!! Made a reservation for 5 tonight at 9pm (we placed the reservation at 2pm through Yelp). 

Had to put a credit card number down but no where did it say you will be charged $100 if canceling within 12 hours prior to reservation.

Of course our friend's flight is delayed so we called to cancel and thus found out about the charge policy. Steven, the manager, said there is nothing he can do to change the policy but he can send us a gift card to go to the restaurant some other time. 

Thanks, but no thanks. I will never patronize such a business.
author: Ryan C.

description:
We had pasta made from pig skin, "ham"burger that was all oink, no moo and one amazing rib eye. Nights like these make me glad Im not a vegetarian.

We also had the cauliflower, mushrooms and crudo and finished with the brûlée and chocolate pudding (I don't think I was actually pudding but it was similar). 

I'd been waiting to get here for a year and it was more than worth the wait!
author: Kerstin A.

description: We made our reservation through Yelp and it was a breeze. The atmosphere is fun and the layout is cozy. My favorite part of the restaurant is the people who work there...the gentleman who greeted us, the bartender upstairs while waiting for a table, our server, and everyone else who visited in between . My second favorite is the food. We ordered a delicious bottle of rose, the seafood tier, the brown butter sage gnocchi, and the heirloom tomato toast....and ended it with the panna cotta. You must try!!!! We will be back!
author: Gina F.

description:
Other than the host being quite rude, I found the our server and the runners very pleasant.  The server was quite bitchy after he showed us to our table and we asked for the other table farther away from the door. He responded, "its the same seating".  Really now???

But that didn't bother me to have a great dinner. My friends and I shared the pigs head and the bone steak.   Both are  excellent dishes.   

The pigs head dish is a glorious dish.  Half a pigs head that is roasted and cooked till crispy.   All the head pieces were moist, juicy, and flavorful.   I was so enthralled by this dish that I even ate the the pigs eye. 

I am not an EYE person!. Yuck. Ick. Sick.  But the pigs eyes was a gelatinous object of goodness.   I can see why my partner loves eating the fish eyes.

The bone steak was a huge piece of steak.   This with the pigs head was way too much for the 4 of us.   The steak was cooked an excellent medium rare.  Everyone on the table loved the steak.  I was lucky to take home the leftovers and the bones. Darn good to have marrow for breakfast.

This is a great dinner place for a large group.  Great service, minus the host.
author: Marck N.

description: Fantastic restaurant with great food and quality service. We ordered several dishes. The notable dish was the massive pork chop, which was cooked to perfection. It was flavorful and juicy. The duck fat cauliflower was also quite tasty. One of the better restaurants I've tried in San Francisco. Would come again!
author: Keith L.

description: Dinner was amazing and the service was great!  This was our second time eating here and it did not disappoint!
author: Amanda M.

description:
We were here for a bachelorette party on a Saturday night. Venue looked quaint at first glance! However, I gave it four star instead of five because our reservation was at 8pm and we were not seated until 9pm! Food was good but a bit on the pricy side.

Otherwise, awesome place. I would say the salad with the crispy pig ear and the grilled cheese (yes! grilled cheese!!!) were my favorite. We also ordered the steak and the bacon chop. Steak was waaay undercooked for me. I couldn't cut it with the knife provided so either the meat was still raw or my knife was dull hah. The bacon chop was perfectly cooked and tasty! Eggplant dish was okay. They did give us free champagne and free shots for the table to compensate for the late reservation but unfortunately, most of our table were non-alcoholic drinkers. Cute date night/girls night nonetheless.
author: Vivian N.

description: The Impossible Burger was amazing! If you get the chance to try it, do it. It's the food of the future, and the staff is knowledgeable, friendly, and professional.
author: Kyle P.

description:
We went in last night with a group of 10 or 11 for dinner and Cockscomb did not disappoint. The dining started out with the 'Big' tons of shellfish. The little necks (clams) were amazing as were the oysters, personally the Fanny Bay's oysters are favorite but all varieties went wonderfully with the house Mignonette (that had an intriguing kick to it). The table was setup for the shared supper format, the courses  included fish collar , Liberty Duck, the spring Lamb, whole seabass and pig's head.  The addition of  the Asparagus (absolutely amazing love the Bearnaise), rainbow chard and duck fat Cauliflower were our accompaniments. The lamb was definitely my favorite but the seabass and fish collar were out of sight as well. Just because something may have been my favorite however doesn't mean everything else wasn't cooked to perfection with flavor profiles that begged for second helpings. I had the house gin martini with a twist, red wine flowed at the table but was much as i like wine i didn't catch the label but the bit i had was very good. All in all the dining experience had a touch of perfection that in San Francisco we can readily find but it is very difficult to emulate. 

The only complaint i have is that i forgot to request to take the Leg of lamb bone for broth at home... what a mistake! 

This restaurant is pricey but if you can afford to have a night out the presentation, freshness, complete flavors and service of their offering were impeccable in my opinion. I'll be back, this restaurant was impressive. 

Thanks!

Andy
author: Arnaldo C.

description:
My friend invites me to this peculiarly named establishment.  I didn't comprehend the name until he broke it out into syllables: Cock as in chicken and comb as in a hair comb.  After that, it was easy for me to Yelp it and grab the address.  Cockscomb is located on the corner of 4th and Freelon but the more familiar streets would be either Brannan or Bryant.  Street parking is your friend and usually there's a good amount of metered parking on Bryant Street.  There's two floors available and I personally think the top floor is slightly quieter than the bottom floor.

The waiter is friendly but extremely animated when it's his turn to describe in detail the various offering of today's menu.  I'd say he has a mutant power of memorization because he recited all of the little bells and whistles of each and every item.  We had to ask about a few items due to allergies and the waiter alleviated our concerns with confidence.  Anyhoo, here's the feast we ordered:

- Pig Head = Half of a pigs head cooked for 45 min in their secret oven.
- Bone Marrow = Bone marrow with bread
- Bacon Chop = Pork chops
- Grilled Cheese = sandwich
- Hot Mess = Foie Gras special
- Duck Fat Squash = Squash drizzled with fat from a fowl
- Little Gems = Salad.  The only veggies we ordered.
- Apricot dessert

The pig head is the signature thing you want to set your eyes on.  It's half of a pig's head braised for hours? (or days?) and cooked in the oven for 45 min before served to you.  The meat is extremely soft and tender.  The ears are crispy and chewy.  You may want to save them ears for your dog at home because it's a great treat.  This item serves 2-3.  The other notable items I want to point out are the Hot Mess and Duck Fat Squash.  The Hot Mess isn't always on the menu (it's a special) but it's basically Foie Gras.  If you're a fan of this delicacy, you don't want to miss out on it.  I mention the Duck Fat Squash because it's one of the best squash I had.  It could be a little on the saltier side so please remember to drink lots of water.
author: Ronald L.

description: A very unique, fun and whimsical place for dinner! Perfect place to celebrate 40th birthday for beloved cuz. Tomato salad, honey grilled cheese and ham and fig were awesome. The pigs head, was the highlight of tbe night. It came out big and glorious, nice presentation. The steak with bone marriw sauce was awesome too! The only dissapointment was the crab and clam. The hot mess fous gras was really tasty too! Server John was gracious and professional. Chef Chris was really nice to come out and meet our birthday gal. Totally enjoyed the memorable night!!!
author: Wendy T.

description: First time with a large party. We ordered almost everything on the menu and it was all amazing. The flavors were exceptional. The Farro and Squash was the table favorite as was the kale salad of all things.
author: Alexandra J.

description:
not bad, chef :) i've been waiting to try this place - never run enough in the morning to justify the hearty hearty food they serve here. but boy's friends were in town sooo why not. made same-day reservations (WHAT?!) for 4 and were seated upstairs. the restaurant is loud, so i wouldnt particularly recommend it for dates or family gatherings where you probably want a more intimate feel. 

we ordered - lots of cocktails (NEGRONI ON TAP WHAT?!), beers, wines, etc. awesome selections. then we ordered - dozen oysters, the foie gras app, tartar, and the surf and turf special to share (crab and pork belly).  everything was delicious - a tad on the saltier side, but i think that was pretty expected for chris' style ha. everything was delicious - albeit very very fatty haha.. i mean it was full on pork bellyyyyy.

i'll be back for their awesome happy hour though! ridiculously good deal.
author: Christina L.

description:
Solid option if you want something walking distance from the Adobe Office.  Big fan of the open kitchen - you're not going to get many opportunities to have line of sight from from the front of the house to the back of the house. Food Rundown:
 - Steak Tartare B+
 - Halibut Crudo A-
 - Cornish Game Hen A- 

Rounded up since there are so few options walking distance from the office.
author: Jeff F.

description:
Impressive food, and a fine selection of wine. We attended here for a company event, and boy were those steaks huge! They're completely shareable for 3 people - which we did. We ended up trying a few of the steaks, added in the surf and turf (which also was shareable for 3), and topped it off with some delicious chardonnay.

Had a blast going here - our team had an enjoyable time. Their service was quick, their venue is super "chill," and the food quality is great.
author: Albert K.

description: I had the worst gastroenteritis from this place. I had projectile vomiting exorcist style and spent a big part of the night hugging the porcelain bowl prior to my trip to Hawaii.  I almost didn't make it on the plane! Another person in our party had worse symptoms. I think it was the undercooked crab in the surf and turf special that we both ate. Never again! Consider yourselves warned.
author: Nan H.

description: Was in San Francisco on a field trip with my culinary class. Came here for lunch. We loved the food. We got a little bit of probably most of the food. One of the main reasons for coming here though was to try The Impossible Burger. A burger with no meat. The burger patty is made out of plants and other ingredients like a synthetic hemoglobin. Its made to look and taste like actual meat. It really did look and taste like meat, but it was a lot lighter. I would describe every item we ate, but we had so much food that this would be a super long review. Overall we all loved the place and our teacher got the Chef and Owner Chris Consentino to come and talk to us.
author: Matthew N.

description:
Ok, honestly, I am very torn. Based on my visit last night, fairly, the experience was more of a 3.5 stars but I am a big fan of the Chef Chris Cosentino, and there were several things that were 4 stars worthy last night.. so lets just say I'm being generous and I'm rating this 4 stars

We walked in around 5:30 on a Wednesday without a reservation & the bar area upstairs looked crowded for "Happy Hour" but the dining area downstairs was still empty & Chef C was briefing some of the kitchen crews before someone, presumably "also a chef" friend walked in and Chef C took her around to check out this new restaurant (we later spotted Chef Traci Des Jardins walking in).

We decided to  sit in the dining room since my hubby was not too crazy about $1 happy hour oyster & $3 crispy pig ears (he's not that adventurous *sigh!).

The waiter was cordial but not personable. He gave us one of those vibe of a salesman who tries to sell us what we don't need with the attitude, "oh, you never been here before, really?". The two female hostesses were certainly very kind and sweet & gave us that warm welcoming feelings as we walked in (and patiently waited for us as hubby & I discussed about whether we would take the bar seating or the dining room). So, in terms of service, it was a bit of a mixed bag!

There were lots of OFF the menu/specials that the waiter verbally informed & described to us. While the waiter did a great job describing every single off the menu dishes verbally, it was hard to keep track of as there were like 5-7 different things (lamb heart salad, blood sausage dish, pig skin spaghetti, shared surf&turf dish, and a couple other things that I can't remember! too much verbal information!). My suggestion to Cockscomb is to have the dishes WRITTEN down, especially since the dishes come with fancy "gourmet language" components.

We ordered the "last supper", an appetizer size dish that comes with a slice of toasted bread, a sunny side up egg, a blood sausage, 2 poached oysters and and pinch of greens tossed in vinaigrette dressing with some broth-like sauce. There were several component in this dish, enough to get my hubby (a non foodie) confused how to eat it (I had to think how to tackle the dish!) perhaps, instructions from the server would have helped. What I did was, I cut and spread the blood sausage on the bread, topped it with some of the greens, fried egg and a bit of the oyster and then using the spoon, pour the sauce on top. It truly was a delicious dish! I was a bit worried as the sauce alone was very salty. However, after putting all the components together, the sauce was just right. The oysters were perfectly poached, not over- cooked (a bit fishy, but tolerable), very creamy, even the non-oyster-eater-hubby liked it. This dish was $22, not cheap, but I gave the chef kudo for the "creativity", bold flavors and the fact that he made blood sausage, as gross as it sounds!, tasted good. fyi, this was words from my non-adventurous husband!

For main course, I ordered Coulotte Steak which to my surprise, came out as if it was a steak salad. The Beef was very tender and flavorful but I wasn't fully in love with the fact that the steak (already sliced) was served on top of cold fresh tomato & green salad. Although, the tomatoes, actually made the plate "worked" as I wasn't too crazy with the flavor of the vinaigrette dressing with the beef...but the sweetness from the tomatoes (they peeled the skin off) made the dish delectable. I also wish, it was a bigger sized dish... there were perhaps about 6 oz of beef on the plate. The price tag for this dish was $32. 

 Hubby ordered what he thought a regular hamburger (beef patty) but it was a "pork" burger! The burger was thick & big, I appreciate the portion was big for $15 (this was the most bang for your bucks on their menu). The pork was very tender, not dry,  & thick (lots of meat!). BUT, it lacked flavors, wish they would salt it a bit more. There was a bit of caramelized onions, & too few greens to even taste them & it was hard to get all components in 1 bite due to the thickness (the bread was also thick). The burger was served with crispy fried potatoes, good but also very fried. the sauce that came with it was some kind of garlicky cream cheese, yumm. Hubby didn't finish his burger and the buss boy packed it to go for us. To my surprise, he also packed the sauce, awesome!!!

For dessert.. the menu was again just very short.. "Chocolate, Fruit, Cheese" $7 each was very surprising as everything else was pricey! We opted for "chocolate" which was like chocolate ganache thing with sea salt, orange marmalade & mascarpone cheese. Yummy but not spectacular, not overly sweet, a good ending to our dinner date in the city.

Overall, this is not a traditional fine dining place. The place screams modern new-cuisine restaurant & suitable for those who are adventurous with no dietary restriction.

I would like to come back when I feel adventurous again.
author: Yun C.

description:
Perfect place to take a hungry carnivore that wants to gnaw on a huge hunk of steak swimming in bone marrow or feast upon a roasted pig's head smothered with its own brain mayo.

For people looking for lighter options they have salads that seem innocent enough with little gem lettuce and goddess dressing but then, out of nowhere, topped with crispy pig's ears. Plus they offer a grilled cheese sandwich topped with a duck egg and drizzled with honey!? Game over, Cockscomb, you win.

Chef Chris Cosentino is usually expediting and they have an open kitchen so you'll more than likely see him right as you walk in. He's super cool and besides being a Top Chef Master, he has also guest-starred in a comic book with everyone's favorite Canadian mutant, Wolverine. Seems about right because if Wolverine were real and was in SF, he'd definitely be eating at Cockscomb.
author: Vincent V.

description:
Calling all meat lovers! Cockscomb has very quickly become one of my fave spots to grab a hearty meal and drinks. I'm also a huge fan of offal meat and love that I can find them sprinkled throughout the menu.

My favorite items on the menu so far have been the Bacon chop (thick, juicy, and perfect for splitting) and the Hot Mess which was one of my fave dishes at Incanto (I was beyond overjoyed to hear that it was on the menu. It is seared foie with strawberries on brioche. Drool.....)

I'm looking forward to returning with a small group so I can take on the Pig's Head next time. Yum!
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
I loved Incanto and I love Cockscomb! Chef Consentino does it again. 

Ordered the pig's head and brought home the skull.  It was primarily fat, but the parts that were not were delicious. Not for the faint of heart :)

Truffle grilled cheese with honey? Genius.
author: Jess C.

description: Impossible Burger is phenomenal. It is now on my must stop lunch spot when in the city.
author: Georges A.

description:
I didn't know about celebrity chef Chris Cosentino before coming here, but now I understand the buzz! We came on a Wednesday night at 6:30 PM and the restaurant was already full. For all you meatlovers and daredevils, this is heaven. The meal was so meat-heavy that I didn't crave meat for days. Actually, I ate so much that the thought of meat made me uncomfortable. The menu offers pretty much any part of the animal that you can think of. Like pig skin, pig trotters, beef heart tartare, tons of liver, and pig head so get ready for an adventurous meal! 

The setting works perfectly for large groups especially when you're trying to share a whole chicken, a 4 lb. sirloin, and 10 other dishes. But this is not to say that you shouldn't come here on a date night. Just be prepared to eat and unbutton your pants after 15 minutes. 

-- Orders --
----------------
- Special: 4 Lb. Bone in Sirloin [Recommend - Best dish of the night!] 
- Special: Whole chicken (including the feet and the head) in a pot with potatoes, carrots, and shallots
- "Hot Mess" Pig Trotters with Foie Gras & Strawberries [Recommend]
- Halibut Crudo
- Oysters
- Roasted eggplant
- Bacon Chop with peaches and greens [Recommend - very nicely spiced]
- Oven Roasted Beets
- Summer Squash
- Butcher's choice: Pig skin spaghetti (which actually had a chewy texture like spaghetti) 
- Dessert: Fruit "Cobbler" [Recommend - Perfect conclusion]
- Dessert: "Panna Cotta"
- Dessert: A type of "Chocolate" Mousse
----------------

All the "Supper" and "Shared Supper" items were huge. The 4 lb sirloin is a must-get if you have a big enough group to finish it. They included foie gras and something that resembles fermented and spiced cabbage. We had eight people in the group to devour this and paired it with veggies like the eggplant and the squash for a more balanced dinner. The foie gras with the strawberries was succulent!! I loved the strawberries..It worked really well with the foie gras and the trotters. Everything melts in your mouth. 

Oh, and you have to get a dessert, no matter how full you are. The fruit cobbler was soooooo good! There were some granola or oat crumbs with a variety of baked fruit. It was my second favorite thing after the sirloin which left a lasting impression. Because not only is the meat good...but the desserts are also spectacular. 

I regret not ordering the bruschetta, pig head, beef heart tartare, and the grilled cheese. But I'll be back!! Plus the butcher's choice and the bruschetta changes so there's always something new to try.
author: Ingrid C.

description:
I just can't seem to figure out what the big deal is with the SF hipster restaurant scene, and Cockscomb didn't help me out.

I came here for lunch. I'd imagine the Impossible Burger tastes like real beef...if you're a vegan. For me, the only thing "impossible" about this $19 "burger" is that I'll choose to eat it again when I can enjoy a better burger at In-N-Out (and for a fraction of the price). Yes, I compared a plant-based meat burger at a restaurant run by a celebrity chef to a beef burger at a fast food restaurant. Why shouldn't I when there's such a huge price-to-enjoyment disparity?

I had higher hopes for the grilled cheese sandwich, but despite the addition of honey and a duck egg, I wasn't impressed. A $14 grilled cheese sandwich had better have magical properties, and magical it wasn't.
author: BR C.

description:
Chef Cosentino what more do we need to ask for? The menu at Cockscomb is filled with wonderful goodies. I had the pleasure of going to Cockscomb right after foie gras was back! I was able to try a variety of dishes. The great thing about this restaurant is a lot of the dishes rotate on the menu depending on the season/day and you can often get treated with a surprise item on the menu.

The bone marrow with smoked fried oysters and watercress was cooked to perfection and maybe one of the top bone marrows I have ever eaten. The ingredients in this dish come together very well.
The Bavette Steak with roasted carrots, and onions was perfect. The meat was cooked perfectly to temp and the vegetables were also very well prepared.
The Wood oven roasted pigs head was the star of dinner. Served with chicories, capers, and brainaise (mayo + pig brains). The skin was crispy and  the meat was mouth watering and pulled apart. The vegetables helped to cut the fat but every bite was perfect. Everything was hot so the meat was not overly greasy or what some may think it would be like eating a nice fatty head of pig. I would order this again in a heart beat! 
Hot Mess pig trotters, foie gras, and grape jam this dish was great. The pig trotters were probably my favorite component of this dish.  Foie gras is always great but to make pig trotters shine is a great thing. Every component of this dish works together flawlessly.  If you have a chance to order this dish I would recommend it also.
Mandarin Orange Mille Crepe Cake, and the other dessert I ordered was great. Nothing was too sweet and the flavors all worked together. 

This was enough food for 3 people to eat. We were all able to share the food and have left overs. From service, location, food, ambiance I have to give Cockscomb 5 stars. If you're in SF and want a great unique experience try Cockscomb!
author: Alex V.

description:
Yelp is turning less into a place for me to review businesses and more of a way for me to remember the amazing things that I eat.  

grilled cheese
albacore collar (special)
mushrooms
pin bone steak
bacon chop
blueberry cobbler
profiterole


The grilled cheese is delicious.  The sweetness of the honey...the richness of the egg...the saltiness and melty texture of the cheese.  It's really well balanced.    

The albacore collar is huge!  I thought we were getting a small piece of fish collar like what you'd get at a Japanese restaurant, but this seemed like the tuna's entire collar!  The herbs and peppercorns that it's roasted with taste really good even without a bite of fish.  The meat is tender, fatty, tasty.  This is a must try if you see it as a special again.  

The portion of mushrooms was a little smaller than I had expected but they were good.

What carnivore doesn't want a massive board of steak?  The pin bone steak has both the bottom and top sirloin.  I'm a medium rare guy, and it was cooked to perfection.  On the side you have an au jus that's good, but I really loved the bone marrow sauce that also comes on the side. Spoon a little bit over your steak and you're living the dream!

The bacon chop...a giant, roasted slab of pork belly.  Wow!

The blueberry cobbler wasn't your standard heavy cobbler.  You get a lot of fruit topped with some granola and a thick quenelle of a lemon cream.  It's not very sweet.  I would have preferred a little more sweetness but everybody else at the table really enjoyed it.  

This isn't a true profiterole...I just don't remember what they called it.  This dish had a profiterole-like texture but was shaped like a thin bagel, cut in half and filled with chocolate and whipped cream.  This was definitely sweeter than the blueberry cobbler and I loved it.

4 hungry people ate this meal.  I'm glad that my wife and I didn't eat much during the day because this was a massive amount of awesome food.   We had enough leftovers to feed a 5th person, but that was on purpose.  We were super satisfied with our meal.

Come here with friends and share lots of food.  I need to come back to try the liberty duck so please invite me!
author: george g.

description:
There is a special delicacy that this restaurant serves which isn't on the menu, but some lucky guests will get to experience it: Grade-A black-angus bullshit.

I made a reservation here 2 nights in advance and confirmed it via text later. The reservation was for 8:00 pm. I showed up with my girlfriend at 8:02 and told the host we had an 8:00 reservation. So, she tells us we can sit at the bar. Now, mind you, there is an open table right in front of us.

Me: "Um, what about that table right there?"
Hostess: (in a very condescending voice): "That one is reserved."
Me: "I made a reservation 2 days ago."
Hostess: "Well you didn't specify whether you wanted a table or counter, so..."

I was pretty flabbergasted. Never in my life have I seen anyone make a reservation for a counter seat. When you make a reservation, a table is implied. So, if you messed up the reservation, please don't insult my intelligence with that BS.

I was pretty fumed at this point. We tried to sit at the counter, which was extremely uncomfortable, packed elbow to elbow, and loud. We bailed 5 minutes later. Had I not been there with a date I would have probably asked to speak to the manager. That hostess they hired sure is a pretty terrible way to represent the business. I assume that she only got the job because she probably took a liking to the owner's meat, if ya know what I mean.

F*** this place.
author: Eugene A.

description:
Had pinbone steak (they charge $125 for it). I am still trying to figure out what I was served. I would not feed that steak to my worst enemy or my dog. Tons (I mean literally, COVERED) in fat. Of the ~25 pieces of meat, maybe 1 was edible. And even that 1 piece tasted awful. Mushy and had a very odd taste. Also, the steak was basically charred beyond recognition. There was a layer of black char measuring at least 1-inch thick.  It is insulting that somebody could be OK with trying to charge me $125 for that pathetic excuse for a steak

Would be better off buying steak from wal mart and cooking it myself. I complained and they gave us 50% off, and I still feel like I was ripped off. They asked if we wanted to pack it to go which we obviously had no interest in doing. Also FYI if they tell you they only have "1 left" of any of the pricier specials, don't fall for it lol

For as bad as the steak was, I'm amazed they did not offer to remove it from our bill entirely. Any legitimate fine dining establishment that is willing to put its $ where it's mouth is would have immediately offered to make this right. This is a text book example of how to NOT run a business and avoid securing repeat customers: there is no chance we will return. Now I'm not surprised that the head chef/owner already had a restaurant close fairly recently
author: Equity C.

description: I love this place, I'm Chris consentino's fan for years and when I moved to the Bay Area from New York, went here for dinner with my lady and we both loved it! & she knows about food since she's has traveled around the globe.. I'll be back when I'm in town again.. arrivedercie!
author: Fernando G.

description: Love this place. I tend to to make an appearance for happy hour to catch a piece of the oysters, grilled cheese, and pig ears. Pair that with a red wine and it's an excellent combo. I'd say this is my favorite restaurant in the SF area.
author: Cisco M.

description:
Chris Cosentino: Get the Bronzino ready!

Chef 2: YES chef!

Chris Cosentino: Don't forget to add the gold to the pigs head.

Chef 3: YES chef!

Chris Cosentino: Alright, let's DO this!

No, I'm not at a live viewing of Hell's Kitchen or Master Chef.

I'm at the brand new Cockscomb, sitting at the chef's table, right in the middle of all the action. Pretty much, this is the seat where I was drooling over all the items I didn't order, but wanted to... like this MASSIVE pin bone steak with bone marrow dip.

This is Chris Cosentino's latest restaurant in San Francisco. He's the winner of Top Chef Masters and even had his own show on the Food Network (Chefs VS. City).

For all you meat lovers and red-blooded carnivores, this is where you NEED to be. Trust me. The menu reflects Cosentino's background in butchery and his love of offal is obvious: there's even a wood oven-roasted pig's head on the menu.

Side: The HUGE pig head kinda freaks me out, so if I'm feeling a bit more ballzy next time... I might order it.

Now moving onto the food, here's what we had:

+ Beef heart tartare is unlike anything I've ever had ($16). It comes with a helping of arugula and seasoned potatoes which were so on point! The quality of the meat was super fresh and it got me really excited for everything else to come. It's probably one of the best appetizers on the menu.

+ Crudo of the day ($16) was dressed similar to a ceviche style, using lime juices to bring out the flavors. Thin slices of jalepenos were added for a nice kick, and cucumbers brought a crispness to each bite.

+ OMG this bacon chop ($32). Ok, so.....this thing is huge! Every bite was super tender and it's perfectly grilled and juicy on the inside. We couldn't finish half of it since the other dishes were pretty large as well.

It was honestly one of the best bacon chops ever, but I found it a little toooo fatty (I had to remove the fat to prevent next-day bloating and meat sweats).

+ This quail tetrazzini ($35) is absolutely heavenly! The quail was deliciously tender and the creme fraiche went perfect with it. I thought it was the best thing of the night: juicy, flavorful, melted off the bones. The garnishes also added a nice crunch to each bite. This is a MUST GET.

And if you happen to come here with a vegetarian (not sure why you would), but this whole roasted branzino ($35)  is a great option.

To sum it all up:

Cockscomb is the kind of place where you go with friends (meat lovers). And when the food comes out, everyone stops talking. It's time to eat.

I made the mistake of coming here with only my boyfriend. So we ended up sitting at the counter while drooling over everyone else's food.

The tartare and quail are MUST GETS. If you're feeling adventurous, get the roasted pigs head (they only make a certain amount and they run out every night).

For more pics and deets, visit: http://cyneats.com/cockscomb/
author: Cynthia L.

description:
Cockscomb was exactly what I was hoping for! We were a party of 2 at 7pm on a Wednesday night. The restaurant was fairly quiet which was great as I imagine if packed it's very loud in that space.
We were sat and greeted immediately and our server was very thorough in covering the menu. The special app that night was seared foie gras over braised pork trotter & figs (delicious)! Entrees chosen were the spaghettini and roasted chicken. The chicken was probably one of the best roasted chicken dishes I've ever tasted, sometimes I like that my wife is not an adventurous eater or I would have never tried the chicken.
Will be back for sure next time in SF!
author: Mark P.

description: When you walk into a restaurant and the hostess takes your fresh cold brew coffee and pours it out into the bar sink because they have a "no outside drinks" policy.... I can't believe this just happened????? My Impossible burger WAS cooked to perfection - but I will say this... LAY OFF the  Dijon mustard because its WAY too overpowering. Gross man. What a disappointment.  I really wish I hadn't spent $25 on a impossible burger here because this place got it all wrong. Very disappointed all around and I WILL NOT be returning.
author: C J.

description: Cockscomb is good, but be sure to be in the mood for meat. My friends and I had dinner here and enjoyed most things. We did end up with a lot of food and wine. They had this fantastic smoked pork belly special that was awesome. The reason for 3 stars is we did have a reservation at 8:30, but weren't seated till about 9. It also is pretty pricey. Not entirely sure it was completely worth the price. I did enjoy the food, but am not dying to go back. Definitely worth a try if you are a meat lover in sf!
author: Gabrielle C.

description:
Exceeded expectations! Absolutely delicious!!

The service was amazing despite us being 30 minutes late.
author: Sidia D.

description:
We had an awesome evening. Service was outstanding. 
We had the charcuterie and pin bone steak. Really good. Also had sunchokes and the dirty crispy potatoes. God the potatoes were the highlight for me. 

Cocktails not great. Really disappointed with the Paris brest. 

Other than that solid five star.
author: N B.

description:
Interesting menu!  Bean appetizer was nondescript. Cesar salad was excellent.  Fantastic pork chop  - one of the best I have ever had. Great wines! Excellent service! 
Loud so be prepared to sit close to one another to carry on a conversation.
author: Natasha H.

description:
First time to Cockscomb on a friends recommendation.  Immediately seated for lunch, attentive service, lively background music (but we could hear each other talk) and all round fun atmosphere. This is going to be really good we thought!   And, I would have really liked to have given 5 stars, but had to take one off for 2 of the 3 menu items.  

The Impossible Burger was "delicious and moist" and consumed to the last morsel by my friend.  We shared the Salmon Bruscheta which was really spectacular except for this one piece of more gray than pink salmon - maybe it was too close to the skin?. Then my entree, the Grilled Nicoise was beautiful and tasty except for the tuna - which was plentiful, but appeared more poached than grilled????  Anyway, taking a star off for the combined (really they served it this way?) on those two items, but would like to go back and try Cockscomb again!
author: Shana B.

description:
I literally have been waiting for 6 months to come celebrate my birthday here and eat copious amounts of meat. Over a month ago, I made a reservation clearly stating I would be celebrating my birthday here. I have been dreaming of the Pig Head continuously in my head every night. Oh, please let me devour you! 
Two weeks before my actual birthday dinner, Tony's schedule change so he was able to grab a reso at an earlier time at 6:15 and wrote in the notes it would be for his girlfriend's (not stating number!) birthday. 
We ended up showing up 15 minutes to a friendly hostess and then promptly put against the wall in a extremely tight two top next to larger parties to the left and right of us. Um... did you want me to have an anxiety attack on my birthday on being squished. Did you remember that it's my birthday? Did you read any notes on OpenTable? 
Maybe I am just spoiled but generally I at least get a welcome "Happy Bday" or a nicer table due to the event. 
On to service. The server was nice enough, not particularly engaging but she had a great recommendation for wine. We ordered the Charcuterie plate, Broccolini and the Cockscomb terrine to start (because we are gluttons). Oh, I would love to comment on the Broccolini but that never showed up...
Charcuterie Plate was tasty and I was very happy with the portion, as with the terrine. When she came by to take our entree orders she let us know that they had already sold out. 
WTF.
This is the only reason I came here. Sold out by 6:15? On a Tuesday? But apparently, this restaurant hates me so I guess I am to expect this. Didn't see much of the server after we placed our entree order that didn't consist of the Pig Head. 
I ordered the Bacon Chop instead and it was all fat; not good fat but hardened fat that I couldn't cut into with a knife. I give up. 
Oh, I also loved my port for dessert; would have been nice with a candle for my birthday. Oh wait, she never once said anything. The memo was not passed on or OpenTable ignores all messages made by the BF. 
In conclusion, I was severely disappointed because I had been counting down the day for the Pig Head and hearing such rave service and accommodations from friends, I was expecting maybe a tad more on their part.
author: Kelly T.

description:
So delicious... I am salivating as I write this post. Came in on a Friday night and my bf and I were fortunate enough to sit at the bar and watch all the action happening with the chefs preparing food and shucking shellfish. Phenomenal site!

Food:
We started with the little gem salad and hot mess (foie gras with strawberries). Little gem salad was a little underwhelming for us, but the crispy pig ears that were served with it were absolutely delicious! The foie gras with strawberries, I loved! The flavors blended so well together and I love me some yummy foie gras (CHEERS to SF lifting its ban!).

Entrees were the bacon chop and "ham"burger. The bacon chop was really fatty and chewy for my taste. The bf seemed to enjoy it. The peaches served on the side were amazing - perfectly sweet and grilled! Yum! Now to the piece de resistance! The "ham"burger... oh man, words cannot even express how ridiculously good this was. Seasoning, preparation, FRIES... oh dear, the fries. Heavenly, crispy... so good! Might be hands down the best burger and fries I've had. Get this! You will not regret it!!

Wine:
