Impressive cocktail and wine list. I had two glasses of a delicious bubbly and the bf had two cocktails. All delicious and thoroughly enjoyed.

All in All, great experience, and looking forward to coming back for two "ham"burgers and fries soon, Cockscomb!
author: Kimberly M.

description:
Have eaten here a few times. Always love visiting this restaurant. Great food, great ambience, and super cool servers and bartenders. Very friendly place and even though it is an expensive restaurant, the food is delicious. The crispy pig ears, the hamburger, the lamb's heart, and oysters were amazing this last time we visited. 

The time before I had the beef heart tartare, the roasted beats and the pork chop with grilled peaches. All very good. 

Next time we go, we plan to order the pigs head and a few more of the Old fashions. 

Can't wait to go back.
author: Tanya C.

description:
Was super excited to have GNO here, the company was great. Food was EHH OKAY. 

among the 5 of us we shared...
clams- good, can't go wrong.
pig's head- crunchy skin, fatty areas, sticks to teeth. some juicy parts of meat, find it if you can! nice sauces that accompany it.
pin bone steak-...first piece yummy...after that super tough and fatty..turns out more rare than medium rare when we had a good look at it the next morning lol
duck fat cauliflower- cauliflower sauteed in fat...yum.

the cocktails I had were really good though. the meat just was a bit salty and underwhelming...we all ate the veggies that came with the steak for sure. For about $80 pp, it definitely wasn't a meal to remember. Fun atmosphere, great company, but food fell just a bit short for something that expensive. We did have plenty of leftovers though.
author: Christine M.

description: I couldn't wait to get to Cockscomb to try the much-hyped "Impossible (veggie) Burger."  The "Impossible Burger" is simply delicious and lives up to all the hype (and more).  I would gently suggest that they need to ease off the heavy-handed loading up of the "Impossible Burger" with way too many grilled onions way too much cheese, way too much mustard, etc.  But having said that, the "Impossible Burger" is terrific.  And the bun is off-the-charts perfect.  Great job!  I need to not-so-gently say that Cockscomb needs a complete re-work of their approach to service.  We waited 20 minutes after being seated at lunch for the waiter to make his first appearance -- not acceptable.  Our drinks arrived AFTER our food arrived -- not acceptable.  The people next to us nearly got up and walked out because the wait for their food was so long (they were already seated when we arrived, and they still hadn't received their food when we were done with our food!).  Employees are busy running around but don't seem to be focused on the very customers they are there to serve.  The service needs to be raised to the high bar that the "Impossible Burger" brings to the table.  Because the "Impossible Burger" is sooooo good, I'm giving five stars in the hope that Cockscomb will do a major tune-up on their service, because what they are doing is not worthy of the amazing "Impossible Burger."
author: Thomas M.

description:
Last night i attend this place for my birthday dinner. We order family style , we wanted to share and taste everything, which was a good thing we did.
Oysters and mussels= very fresh
Egg honey toast= must try ,delicious.
Spaghetti= i believe it like a vegetable seasoning( very flavorful)
Pork= thick and not flavorful
Steak ( we order the big platter) it was just okay , i prefer ruth chris steak was better!)
Cauliflower= yummy
Overall good to come and experienece something different , love the atmposhere and the rooster decorations. Its not a must i would not come back .
author: Hoa T.

description:
We came.  We ate.  We conquered.

I have been hearing great things about this spot, as well as drool worthy pictures, so four of us came here for dinner.  We made reservations, and we were seated right when we arrived.  The front entrance is down the ally, and the place is always packed.  

The service was great, and it's a huge part of your overall experience.  Our waiter told us the specials, and we quickly ordered the seared foie gras.  We also ordered two dozen oysters (1/2 dozen of each ones they offered), duck liver (piped into little profiteroles), the pin bone steak, side of potatoes and asparagus.  I was glad the waiter suggested a starch, and who doesn't like potatoes with steak?

I was disappointed when we arrived and I didn't see Chef Chris Cosentino, but on the way out I saw him.  He was so busy, and I really felt bad interupting him to ask for a picture, but I worked up the courage to approach him.  He asked me to give him a few minutes.  A few minutes later he walked over and took a picture.  I told him the food was awesome and we really enjoyed ourselves, and he was super friendly.  I love when you admire someone, and have this image of who they are as a person & they live up to your expectations.  There's nothing worse than meeting someone you look up to and find out they're a complete a-hole.

I totally recommend this place.  Come with at least 4 people because it's a feast for sure.  Fat, full and happy.
author: Sara T.

description: Went with a group of friends for dinner we order family style and had the pin bone steak which was very very good the meat was very juicy and just perfect. It actually came with the bone and if you have a dog, it's a good treat for your dog. The food is on the larger side and probably better for sharing!
author: Joyce K.

description:
Bartender service, charm and drinks were great. (Bartender was cute! Introduced me to pisco pomegranate option.)  Pricing fair.

I think our server was waaaay more interested in flirting with girls at neighboring tables, and with them you could observe him being extremely professional while also being proactive, prompt, and charming. He was notably more interested in tables with groups of at least 2 girls; then he was all interest, energy, etc. Working for that tip I guess. My table, with a male friend; and eventually the couple that arrived next to us -- not such attentive service. Had to literally flag/wave him down. We tipped generously, but he definitely didn't deserve it. 

Especially because I told him at the start it was my friend's birthday. No effort was taken at the start to wish him a happy birthday, to offer a little something in celebration (free drink? extra app? scoop of ice cream? SOMETHING?), or to even SAY "Happy Birthday." He just shrugged and said, "Okay." Yeah, you know what, now that I think of it, I'll just say the guy was a bit of a dick, if you want to add it all together. Stop trolling for girlfriends and fat tips and get over yourself.

Anyway, to the food -- it was "good," but kind of on the 3.5/4 line and then the service just took it down to 3. Pate came to the table with literally 3-4 thick baguette-stubby slices of bread. The pate was the size of a sandwich slice. Does that make sense to you? I appreciate getting more pate but perhaps you should provide more bread, or halve its size (the pate) and offer thinner crostini-thick slices of carb to better facilitate the pate?

All the dishes kind of blurred together as rich and meaty. Shepherd's stew (I think that was the name) was pretty good. "Chef recommends that you break the crust on top down into the stew before eating." Perhaps, but, we are nibbling on this and if we did that at the beginning this would make our crust soggy, which is sacrilege my friend.

Desserts were pretty good, especially the crema fruit thingie that was all whipped -- reminded me of a dessert featured on Top Chef that Chef Colicchio said was his "all-time favorite in the history of the show." Nice texture, very light play on textures and layers and crunch and air.

Probably won't return again. I do love meat but rarely, and if you add on the attitude/service issue, just isn't worth it. Better food and service elsewhere.
author: Miriam W.

description:
Impossible burger, more like impossible to eat burger!

I was kinda disappointed but kinda not? Showed up for lunch wanting to try the impossible burger. Im some what a strict vegetarian, I don't eat dairy or eggs but after looking at the menu it had no where listed this burger would have cheese, ordered it and it came with cheese, I can honestly look past that though, scraped it off. For the impossible burger each chef has their own interpretation/presentation, this one looked great and each component was great too. This was the kinda burger you see at your local gastro pub. 

The patty itself was composed of shredded like meat? The texture was like a burger, the taste was exactly like a burger. However the patty sorta fell apart. Along with that was a greasiness that the sign of a good burger, a surprising feature for a reverse engineered burger. 

The bun was what we all hoped for in a burger, soft, but structurally secure.

as far as the stuff between the buns, not a fan. It seem that a lot of gastronomical cooks and chefs love adding shredded lettuce in a burger, but in all honesty it is just gross, the bun cooks the frail lettuce creating a sort of steamy sad salad in the middle of a burger, the sauce was a bit strong competing with the burger itself. As for the pickle, loved it.

All in all a great burger, probably the best Veggie burger I ever had, but in the end it was quite heavy for a veggie burger, I felt sick walking back to the bart station, but it could just be me being weak over a burger. Service was awesome.
author: Nelanne C.

description: The place was absolutely packed.  We had a group of 6 and we regretted picking this place right away because the noise level was deafening.  We were yelling at the top of our lungs and could barely hear each other.  The server had to repeat the specials for each end of the table, that's how bad it was.  The food is just OK.  It feels like the kitchen is trying too hard just to be trendy, using unusual items. I know it's all the rage now, but my mom used to cook these things because we didn't have enough money to buy better cuts of meat.  Glad I didn't pick the place.
author: Andy H.

description:
NOT A PLACE FOR CHILDREN*
They made our newborn in a car seat sit on the floor because the hostess messed up and couldn't put us at a table to accommodate 2 high chairs. Only 2 hours after speaking with them by phone clearly understanding that we needed 2 high chairs. 

The food was good, over priced. I think Marlowe restaurant 1 block away has better food quality and staff.
author: Mark A.

description:
Overpriced, 2 oysters for $8?

The waiter was complaining on why we didn't spend 20% tip on a $130 bill (for 2 people).
He started lecturing me on the formalities in the US, and all the BS. Really??

We felt that in-n-out burger has 100x better burger than their burger, and costs 100x cheaper, plus you don't get harassed by anyone regarding tips.
author: Karl B.

description:
Poorest customer service ever, especially the manager.  My friend ordered the smoke salmon sandwich not knowing that it is raw fish.  We asked if they cook the fish like lightly sautéing it, but the waiter said no.  My friend just ate the bread.  The manager was even more rude and said "you should have known, all smoked salmon is raw."

Unlike another time at another restaurant with another friend, we had the raw salmon issue.  At the other place, that other waiter generously apologized and simply told my friend to order something else and was charged for one meal.
author: Art M.

description:
One of my best friends and I had a double date here last year and left the restaurant rather perplexed. 

The portions are massive, the vibe is trendy and the ambiance is chic. Yet, the food is quite mediocre. We ordered the infamous wood oven roasted pig's head and let me tell you -- it's a freakin' pig's head alright. This dish is completely filled with lard. At one point, my friend poked her finger into the pig's face, and it was mushy and fat juices just squirted all over the place. I'm one of the largest advocates of fatty dishes and it was way too much for even me. We were a group of 4 and only made our way through 1/4th of the pig's head. By the end of the meal, we all felt like we were sweating pig juices and felt uneasy and slightly disgusted. 

We also ordered a few appetizers, including the beef heart tartare, and although they were certainly better than the pig's head, they were still only OK -- nothing to write home about. We pretty much downed our wine to make up for the lackluster experience.
author: Priya S.

description:
Loved the ambiance of the restaurant, upstairs is a bar and another dining area. I would prefer to dine in the main dining area however. 

For a table of 5 we ordered...
-- (5/5) Grilled Cheese sandwich with honey and egg
 so yummy and will order again, rich savory and sweet, surprisingly delicious combination
-- (5/5) Pigs Head
 Definite winner of the night. "brainoaise" mayonnaise mixture with pig brain, and accompaniment of greens was wonderful! The skin was so crispy and the meat was so tender and soft a really wonderful dish. 
-- (3/5) Pinbone steak with the special of the night, lobster
The steak was good but nothing special, same with the lobster. The serving for the steak was huge enough for 5 people, also since we ordered the pig head we super full and did not enjoy this dish as much.

Overall, we really enjoyed our dinner would skip on the pinbone steak and lobster, unless we have a bigger group.
author: Julie B.

description:
- We started with oysters, which were unimpressive compared to Anchor, Leo's. They were almost as decent as Hog & Rocks brunch dollar oysters, but did not cost a dollar.
- My entree (the trout) was delicious. It was also $40. I'm not sure it was quite that delicious, so I waffle on this.
- Dessert was the meringue and complicated fruit compote thing, and I would recommend it if you're into sharp and complex sweetness.
- Ambiance was just okay.

Decent choice, not sure I will return unless for the meatless burgers at lunch.
author: Elise L.

description:
Here lies the best grilled cheese sandwich I have had in my entire life.

That is all.
author: Elaine N.

description:
I know i was borderline annoying to the staff because of the sheer volume of my repeated gushing. This place is ridiculously good - which is the part that i expected. What i didn't expect was friendly, warm, fun staff and incredible value. The prices are that of a mid level gastropub -  yet the food is world class. We went in to snag some seafood off the raw-bar menu and had the pleasure of being seated in front of the steak chef - what a treat to watch that guy do his thing. I can't recommend this place enough. 

NOTE: If you dig watching masters at work as much as we do, ask to sit at the Chef's counter. It'll add a killer visual element to a great culinary experience.
author: Helmut R.

description:
With all the mixed reviews, I came here slightly hopeful--but with a somewhat of a low expectation. My dining mate and I had reservations but we came early and were able to be seated right away. We came around the beginning of dinner service so we were one of the few patrons there, however when we left, it was really crowded. The ambiance and the music was really good. Tables are really close together as most SF restaurants are so that was pretty understandable. Our server [Justin I think?] was really on point in describing the specials and gave us a thorough run down of the menu. Coming in with an idea of what we wanted-- we ordered barely any of those because of his great recommendations.

Oysters: For $3 each and a minimum of 1/2 a dozen, we stuck to the west coast oysters because  I generally like the smaller ones more. Nothing really stuck out about the oysters so I'd probably recommend skipping it. Its very easy to find fresh oysters in the city so you're probably better off saving room for other yummies.

Crudo: The crudo of the day was a white fish in the mahi mahi family which the name totally escapes me right now. It was dressed similar to a ceviche style with nice lime juices to bring out the flavors. Thin slices of jalepenos for a nice kick, and cucumbers to bring a crispness to it. A good dish, but again, not something I'd order again only because you can find this almost anywhere in the city.

Beef heart tartare: YUM. Get this. I was pretty disappointed that ours didn't have a quail egg that I've seen boasted everywhere online/yelp. Ours came with a mustard-y sauce that didn't really add anything to the dish except make it easier to mix? This dish comes with two pieces of crostini/toast so my dining mate and I each got one. I went for the route where you slab a heavy layer of the beef heart tartare on and spread it then top it off with the arugula. The arugula was seasoned really salty by itself, but together with everything it was a beautiful dish. This is probably the best way to approach this dish. It comes with a helping of their seasoned potatoes which were also on point! The crispy skin was so nicely seasoned and not over powering. The potatoes were cooked just right so they still had a nice texture without being too starchy. 

Little Gems: Needing some greens to go with our meal we opted for this salad with fried pig ears. I let my mate eat most of the pig ear because they weren't that special to me. I really enjoyed the salad and munched on that. The dressing was really nice and I don't know if its because I haven't allowed myself to have salad dressing in a long time, but I couldn't put my fork down! However towards the bottom of the salad it was pretty drenched making the salad lose its crisp. Maybe opt for the dressing on the side next time.

Grilled Cheese with Truffles: My mate loves grilled cheese. He loves cheese, period. When looking at the menu the night before he said he was probably going to pass on this dish, but upon hearing about how it is there most popular dish, he changed his mind. I am so happy he did! It ended up being a really good dish and one of the top dishes of the night. Judging the pictures doesn't do this dish justice. The beautiful art of having the right consistency for a grilled cheese is really important. Cheese ratio-- not valid because the more the better. The toast complimented the cheese in its beautifully browned texture. The secret to this dish is not the truffles that are on top, but the honey that is used. With a taste in every bite, it was well rounded and delicious. Not overpoweringly sweet, but made a beautiful sweet symphony with the cheese. This portion of the meal was quiet due to the lovemaking of the sandwich and I. 

Butchers Choice: Clam linguine with pork belly-- This dish was okay. I have been craving pasta for awhile so I thought this dish would help satisfy that craving. Sadly it did not. The texture of the linguine noodles were definitely different and was borderline udon noodles. The sauce was a lime citrus sauce that was really one note. I had to ask for some crush red peppers to give this baby a kick. The clams were okay and I didn't really find any pork belly. Pretty oily and would probably recommend skipping.

Butchers Choice: Hot mess-- YISSSSS. YES YES YES. Foie gras on top with a beef patty/croquette it seemed. My mate found the beef patty to have too much going on with a strange consistency, however when he spread the foie gras over it, turned his world upside down. Like, moment of silence, put your fork and knife down good delicious. This ritual happened after every single bite. I don't need to write much on this dish to convince you to get this because you know when theres silence at a dining table, theres magic.

Though we left room for dessert, none of the options were really that impressive. The crafted cocktails were really good and but they need to lose the paper straws!
author: Crystal V.

description:
I freakin' loved this restaurant... ever more than I loved Incanto! For one, the foie gras preparation was perfect. It was a saucy dish combined with flavorful pulled pork and the 2 proteins complemented each other beautifully. And bacon chop was the juiciest, most flavorful piece of pork chop. Probably the second best pork chop in the bay area (after Wood Tavern, of course...).

I will be back for the pigs head and giant steak... just need to find other fatties to dine with me.
author: Betty T.

description:
Beef heart tartare: 4/5.

Pin bone steak: 5/5.

Roasted milk fed chicken: 5/5.

Duck fat cauliflower: 5/5.

Strawberry shortcake: 5/5.
author: Clarence H.

description:
Don't bother coming to this place if you aren't hungry, don't like big portions, don't like meat. Stay away if you hate the sweet smokey smells of a wood fired burning oven. Run for your life  if you hate dark and rich charcuterie boards, the freshest shellfish, including oysters, crab, clams, and lobster, iodine rich and smelling of the sea. 

But if you do like any of these things... Then this place is for you! 

Earlier this week we sat down to one glass each  of Mumms Brut Champagne & Mionetto Prosecco while we perused the straightforward yet innovative menu. The prosecco was dry and crisp, while the Mumms balanced dry with a hint of butter. 

We started with a cherry tomato salad ($12), served with fresh herbs and an interesting celery vinaigrette. Light, refreshing, and bursting with summer-garden flavor, we both agreed this dish was a winner. 

Next up came the charcuterie ($25 for a platter $45 for a board). Dark, sweet prosciutto, terrine, and njuda, which is a spicey spreadable salami. Curiously perfectly,  good bread had been brushed with olive oil and toasted.. in advance - so by time it got to us it was cold, slightly stale and a bit tough. 

During all this, we were seated at the bar overlooking the open kitchen, a front row seat to all the action. And what action! Sous chef plunking down a 1.5 pound lobster in a saute pan for the night's special? Check. A truly gigantic lamb shoulder, bone in, being prettied up with herbs before serving in it's own all clad roaster for service? Check. Pin bone steak, cooked rare, being sliced on a board for service? Check. After spying the lobster and seeing it plated for customers, we asked, 'why don't we know about this?' Turns out our server never mentioned the night's lobster on special, you can add it to supplement a steak or bacon chop, ($65) or have it on it's own. 

In the end we opted for the bacon chop with lobster side with summer corn/king trumpet mushroom succatash. Then we had to choose, the double chop or single. Seeing the portions coming outta there I knew the double could feed 4 people not 2, so we opted for the single. Good call, 'cause that single chop was humongous. Lobster served pan roasted with spices and a dipping sauce that was both spicy but low in actual heat. 

Moving on from our bubbles we each had a glass or two of the Pertinace Nebbiolo ($12) which pared well with the rich and abundant fare. 

Finishing off, we ordered a peach tart, made with a butter crust and fresh whipped cream. Impressed, the host came over with two small glasses of brandy, on the house. 

I can whole heartedly recommend Cockscomb, somewhat pricey but you get what you pay for 10 times over. Service was very good too.
author: Jordan N.

description:
Where do I begin...

Excellent service, being our waiter actually hand crafted our experience. From helping us order drinks to our actual entree, which was AMAZING.

Aside from chef Consentino being a culinary genius with his hand picked selections... His staff does an amazing job on execution. I don't know if I'll ever enjoy chicken again, being now all I want is Cornish Game Hen.

Magnifico, I'll be back!
author: Molly S.

description:
The upstairs bar area is a great place to fall into for a drink or two and full access to the menu.  Their drinks are outstanding and are always on rotation or their standard negronis are outstanding.  The food...oh the food.  I don't really get down on the more exotic meat things, though I am lifelong meat eater, but everything that I have ordered here is outstanding!  The Tombo is killer, their 'ham'-burger is amazing, the impossible burger as an italian sandwich was absolutely mind blowing and just for good measure, I had the best grilled cheese of my life with emmental cheese, fancy bread, fancy honey and covered in black truffle.  Super friendly staff and chef (he's just a great dude), the bartender is alway super friendly to talk to.  Also, great ambience, I love the style of this spot.

My advice, just go, sit upstairs hang out for a while and enjoy the things!!!
author: David P.

description:
Came here on Saturday for a feast to celebrate a close friend's birthday. I knew about Consentino but hadn't heard about this new restaurant too much. So this is everything we ordered:

wood over roasted pig's head
pork belly with lobster
pin bone steak
beef heart tartar
little gems salad
duck fat roasted cauliflower
duck pate
foie gras

I'm not exactly in the mood to break everything down but let's just say the pig head and the pin bone steak were my favorite along with the foie gras of course.

Our waiter was incredibly knowledgeable about each dish and I'm glad he came over from Vegas to work here.

I had the chocolate cake for desert and this was also executed with care and expertise.

Just come here for dinner and skip out on lunch so you can be a glutton!
author: Art O.

description:
My brother and fiancée were visiting from the UK and wanted to give the impossible burger a try so I made a reservation for the 3 of us plus my 7 month old baby for 11.45am last Monday! 

When we arrived the host couldn't be less welcoming. I had made our reservation for that day and time knowing I would have my son with with me, so we could have been in and out before the place got busy.

I was asked to put my stroller down a corridor, next to a side entrance out of my sight. No effort was made to assist me, then I had suggested to take it upstairs with me where there was more than enough room... no couldn't do that either. Sorry but I'm not leaving my stroller which is worth more than $1000 out of sight next to a side entrance, with 3 homeless people in the near vicinity. Given the fact that another moms stroller was stolen out an establishment in on Berry ST in a similar situation a few weeks ago, I was not prepared to do so and left with my son and went for a coffee near by until my brother finished his meal.

Management should be ashamed, if you can't accommodate infants at all especially when there is barley anyone in the restaurant, you should state so on the website. Also "host" screwing your face up and shrugging your shoulders..... how about I'm ever so sorry next time or at least try to help. I look forward to the day you have a child and someone ruins your day!!
author: Jenna B.

description:
Had a wonderful anniversary meal here, the surf and turf special we had was delicious.  We both noted how well the lobster was cooked, sometimes can get that rubbery/chewy texture when the overcook it.. this was anything but.  Served on the side of this was sauce that seemed like an Asian themed savory bean sauce that tasted great on the lobster.  Get ready to roll up your sleeves, put on your lobster bib and get into some shell cracking for this one though... you will have to work for all the little pieces of meat in those claws too.  

Then, right below it, on the same "platter" if you want to call it that, was a fantastically cooked pork tenderloin that was huge, I thought we would be filled up eating just a third of it (both of us) but it had a surprisingly light/braised texture to this piece, almost like they braised it first and then they put it under what I thought was a salamander.  I was corrected by the waiter, when I inquired: "No, they put it in the wood fired oven to finish it off."  However they did it, it was crispy on the scored skin top of the loin, a mostly rendered layer of fat below it that kept the braised portion below nice and moist and you could almost skip eating it (the fat).  Instead, I would eat the crispy skin and then the braised meat so that I didn't get that "just ate a whole chunk of fat" sensation that I get sometimes with other cuts of meat.  

We also had an appetizer that was a play on foie gras, not as spectacular, but the home made mayonnaise was well done.  The Hitachino Nest beer from Japan was excellent.. a light wheat beer that paired perfectly with the appetizer.  The classic dessert was not very memorable, but we took that pork loin home with us (we surprised ourselves and made it through half of it) for a second meal and the skin was still crispy and delicious the next night!  

The ambiance of the place is pleasant, it has a bit of a rustic feel to it that goes well with the theme of the restaurant, its a bit chilly downstairs, so don't dress too light in the afternoon/evening.  This place is a bit hard to find, I am not sure what kind of destruction the city is wreaking on fourth street outside, but the signage and fact that its behind a construction zone on their side of the street made me miss the place and drive right by the first time.  We rode a motorcycle, so parking is always easy for us, but parking looks a bit limited in the area.
author: Eric R.

description:
Eating here feels like pure gluttony. I cannot remember ever eating so much rich food in one sitting. It has original food, a comfortable yet upscale ambiance and it pays attention to detail. Coming with a larger group will make it a much more enjoyable experience.

The item everyone wants is the pigs head. Pretty amazing to see this on a menu and even more surprising to see it in person. People walking by stop and ask to take pictures of it. It is huge and incredibly fatty, we had most of ours bagged up to take home. The waiter said it goes great with eggs. The crispy ears that it comes with are amazing. I wouldn't recommend ordering this as everyone's main course, it is just too fatty, but a very fun and unique dish.

Beef heart tartare was another original dish that I have never seen anyone else do. The waiter describes it as having fuller flavor, like steak tartare would have been 60 years ago before they started having hormones pumped into the meat. It was a spot on description. Full of flavor. This was my favorite dish of the night.

The duck liver terrine was incredibly strong. If you are a big liver fan you will enjoy it, but if you are at all on the fence about such things it might be a pass. It comes with some jammed fruit and thick toast to help balance it, but the ratio leaves not enough bread. Had to ask for additional slices to finish it.

The pin bone steak was huge and would have fed four people as a main entree. The cool factor in this dish was it being served with a chefs knife; very empowering. It was good, but not remarkable as far as on the bone large cuts go. It comes with some toppings which were tasty additions. The steak knives were very sleek Shun knives, which made the meat like a cloud to cut through, really excellent cutlery. 

The desert was phenomenal, and was only $7. An olive oil cake with a lemon cream and brûléed blood oranges, which were fantastic.

Wine by the glass was a bit lacking in variety, only about four choices for red. There were some good reasonably priced options tho. The wine was served in Spiegelau glasses.

As with most new restaurants, the price of eating there soon after opening is dealing with some hiccups. None of them major, but for the price of the restaurant they added up. We arrived on time for our reservation but had to wait 15-20 minutes for our table. With the larger items on the menu it is unclear how much to order and I feel our waiter made the pigs head seem like less food than it was. I've never left a restaurant with so many leftovers.  Ordered a coffee after dinner and it hadn't come by the end of desert, so we just canceled it. Also we ordered an additional side of bread to finish the terrine and they charged $1 for it. It seems petty to see a one dollar line item for bread on a $300 bill. On the plus side, there was a miscommunication on what we ordered for one of the dishes and they took it off the bill, nice touch.

Overall would recommend this place out of the sheer uniqueness of the food.
author: Michael S.

description: Attentive, knowledgeable staff, friendly in a genuine way. The food here is great for carnivores like me. Clean, well-run (you can see the kitchen at the chef's counter). Atmosphere is nice but relaxed, which is perfect for the neighborhood. Make a reservation! It's crowded on Fridays and Saturdays. I live in the neighborhood and this is one of my favorite spots and well worth coming out here even if you don't live in SOMA.
author: Tony C.

description:
Grand dining experience -- the food, the company, the staff. Had a medium seafood platter; tumbo crudo; and fennel sausage. Dessert was chocolate and pound cake w/rhubarb.

Fellow diners were jolly company. The staff was so indulgent. We felt spoiled.
author: Karen O.

description:
Two people and the bill was over $300.... and yes, it was worth every penny.

Here's what we ordered:

- a bunch of fantastic cocktails
- oysters and clams
- an assortment of hams
- the Butcher's Choice of offal ("fall offs")
- an oven-roasted half a pig's face (they call it a "head" on the menu, but it's basically its goddamn face.)

Delicious, decadent, and mind-blowing are miserably inadequate words to describe these foods - especially the pig face. 

I'm of Filipino descent and there's a dish we call Crispy Pata. It's basically a deep-fried pork hock that's dipped in vinegar sauce. The skin is pockmarked with bubbles from the frying and is incredibly crisp. The fat is almost like butter and the meat literally falls off the bone. 

My mom calls this dish, "Killing Me Softly."

Take that and multiply it by about 50 times. 

That's what the luscious cheeks of the oven-roasted pig face taste like.
author: Byron E.

description:
I'd heard so much about this place that expectations ran a little high.
Happy to say my meal did not disappoint (much!).

"Hot mess" (foie gras) - lovely balance of the fatty with the acidity of the green and red strawberries.
Beef heart tartare - interestingly springy, on the border of being spongy, but a lighter version of its typical predecessor. Potatoes were too randomly sized and had the consistency of bad breakfast potatoes from a diner. Greens were good for texture variation.
Bacon chop - I should have read up on the size of this beast! What a hunk of meat! Rhubarb accompaniment was sadly too tart.
Panna cotta - nice, light & creamy. Sugar cookie in shape of a rooster was nice touch and good contrast.

It's crowded and noisy, so prepare to yell a bit over the table. 
I'll be back to try the other dishes I missed!
author: Tina W.

description: Cockscomb was AMAZING! Best food I've had in a long time, would absolutely recommend. Service was also incredible.
author: Kate H.

description: Came here for my birthday with a party of 8. Food was delicious and simply amazing! My girlfriends and I ordered the family steak entree topped with foie gras. It supposedly can feed 4 people. When it came to the table, it was large enough for at least 6! We were able to share with the others easily. The staff were friendly and accommodating, and answered all of our questions.  Parking was little hectic since there was a Giants game that night, so even the meters around the restaurant were $5/hour. Swing by and get a Boothby to start off the night!
author: Jel O.

description:
Friendly service.  Great fare.  Delicious lunch menu.  Bold definitive flavors with artful presentation.  Easy to like.
Very noisy... probably all the happy eaters!
author: Geri S.

description:
I have always wanted to try this place and my wife was able to get us reservations.  We were lucky enough to sit at the chef's counter directly next to the expediter.  It was a marvelous opportunity to enjoy the view of the line and the theatrics of the cooks and wait staff.  If you are lucky enough to have this chance do not pass it up.

We started off with great oysters, followed by the grilled cheese with duck egg and honey. Everything we ate was fabulous and perfectly prepared. Chris Consentino was in the house and took a few minutes to chat with us.  His entire staff was excellent and attentive.
author: Dan R.

description:
Met another couple (and their daughter) who were in from NJ last Saturday. Different day at Cockscomb, same result as we enjoyed a terrific early dinner. Ordered a bunch of stuff and shared. Starters were the pickled sardines, celery victor and bruschetta same as last time and also ordered the half dozen baked oysters boccalone nduja & breadcrumbs  All were winners.

Instead of individual entrees we went for the Pin Bone Steak which came with roasted squash, bone marrow dip and au jus. The steak was massive and easily fed the five of us. More importantly, it was a perfect medium rare and had excellent flavor. Had the broccoli rabe and duck fat cauliflower on the side, perfect with the steak.

Our friends wanted to sample the desserts. One was the chocolate terrine (very good again). Can't remember the other two but they were gone by the end of dinner :).
Brought a couple of wines, started with a Lynmar Pinot and had a 2002 Seavey Cabernet with the steak. It did not suck :).

Service was very good and the menu was given a full explanation.
Cockscomb is the home of the mighty protein and if you are in the mood it is tough to beat.
author: Tom D.

description: Overrated and loud. Very expensive for the food that you are getting. You can get comparable fare at a place that is less expensive, such as cotogna or wayare.
author: Carter C.

description:
Had our best meal at CC last night. Been there many many times but this was stellar. The pin bone steak with roasted squash was so tender and good. I rarely eat red meat, and this is something I crave. 

We had 8+ dishes, and everyone had a different favorite, but none were a miss. My favorites: the oeufs mayonnaise: deviled eggs with foie gras. And the Hot Mess, figs and foie. And the roasted squash. Perfect and rich and yummy. Also had to order the tuna heart pasta since it was my fave at Incanto. It's lemony and umami-Y and so good. 

Service was spot on. Ashley was friendly, warm, attentive, and knowledgable. 

Super dinner. I recommend going with a group so you can try more dishes.
author: Sy D.

description:
The night did not start off well. I come in 7 min before my reservation to check-in and the hostess tells me "ok well you have 4 parties in front of you so you can wait in the bar"....said with an attitude. 

Everyone else on the other hand was great. The bartender at the second floor lounge was excellent!We got drinks and minded ourselves, but she went ahead and continued to check on the status of our table and gave us an update every 15 min. Note that we did not get seated until more than an hour after the original reservation! The only thing that kept us there was the friendly bartender. 


The food that we got was great! (Pigs ear salad, raw clams, beef heart tartare, and Pin bone steak. The chef also comped us the smoked ham and pear appetizer which was delicious). The restaurant did an awesome job of compensating for the fact that 1) we got seated and hour+ late and 2) they ran out of their signature pigs head dish.  The pigs head was the biggest thing drawing us to the restaurant, and the waiter probably sensed our gross disappointment when he said the last one was just ordered. 

Although the front of the house hostess was rude. I could be persuaded to try it again just to taste the pigs head.
author: Angelito R.

description:
I had the most amazing birthday dinner here last night. It started the moment we stepped inside Cockscomb. Managed to get here right on time for our 6:30 pm reservation and were seated immediately. Perfect table for our first visit here to observe and absorb all that intense energy right in the middle of the dining room.  Very cool.  The whole place was buzzing and after our delicious and potent gin cocktails, so were we. Yeah!

The "hot mess" of foie gras - best birthday gift ever!  I didn't expect it which was even better. Thank you Chef! Next was the most delicious beef tartare. WOW! This one just really blew us away. It was light and creamy at the same time, but so fresh, delicate and citrusy as well. Perfectly seasoned - highly recommended. So glad I got to watch his video on prepping beef heart as it made me truly appreciate this dish and loved  devouring every morsel. Who knew? Had to get the wood oven roasted pig's head and so glad we did. Never had anything like it. Cute dusting of gold flakes around the nose - nice touch. So decadent. 

Bottom line, we LOVE gin and pork. So does the Chef. Already made reservations for my husband's birthday next month. Can't wait!
author: Jane F.

description: The service was great, waitress was wonderful and attentive. We ordered the pigs head and pin-steak to share between 4 ppl. The pigs head was meh its something you only want to experience once. The pin-steak was good with the bone marrow sauce. Only complaint is that it was warm when it came out. Indicating it was made a while back. Drinks was on the expensive side $14-$16. At the end of the night we paid around $100per head. Probably wont be coming back too soon.
author: Annie T.

description:
I was in town for the weekend and my sister made reservations to this place. Given that it was Chris Cosentino's restaurant, there was a greater expectation than usual. 

We ordered/shared the chef's special which was Pork Belly with Alaskan King Crab. The pork belly came in a big slab in which you had to cut in to pieces. This was shared amongst 3 women. I had a bite of the pork belly and was sickened by the fat. Had the pork been seared a little longer and the fat was more of a crisp, I think it would have been more edible. 

The Alaskan King Crab was a little overcooked for my taste. The meat wasn't smooth and soft, which is what I usually expect from crab meat. But this dish was served on a large skillet so I assume the crab was cooked more from the skillet. In this case, the chef should've undercooked the crab a little so it could be cooked to perfection on the skillet.

That plate was $105. I'd rather go to a Chinese BBQ place to get roast pork for a fraction of the price and probably steam my own whole crab!

I gave it 3 stars because we did have their Chef's special appetizer, "Hot Mess" which comprised of foie gras and orange marmalade. It was delicious. I'm assuming we just ordered the wrong main dish. We should've definitely tried their Boar's Head or something!

Nonetheless, I'd probably give this place another shot. The service and drinks were great. I just wish we ordered something else and that dish wasn't $105!
author: Helen G.

description:
I swear we were going in for the pig's head, but our dining companions opted for that night's special - pork belly and lobster. I know, disappointing; but mild disappointment would be the theme of our evening.
 
The asparagus (green goddess, fingerling potatoes & radish) was fine but ordinary. The soft shell crab (deep fried), the same. The oysters were excellent, but the accompanying mignonettes were forgettable. The gnocchi (pecorino & black pepper), how could it go wrong? Well it didn't go wrong, it was just...ordinary. Well what about the oeufs mayonnaise (foie gras & crispy chicken skin)? Couldn't taste any of the foie and the skin was too minute to matter.
 
For whatever reason I expected everything to be more heavily seasoned. All great restaurant food has to push the salt boundary.
 
So what do I mean by ordinary? When you spend as much money (as you will) at the 'trendy' restaurant of a trendy chef, you don't expect to eat food that tastes like something made by a very good home cook.
 
That pork belly and lobster? Low flavor, the pork belly could have been tenderer, and the lobster was both overcooked and slightly fishy tasting (i.e. not tasting like lobster).
 
Did I give this place a fair shake considering that I was directed away from something more 'representative,' like the pig's head? Possibly. But here's the thing, as adventurous as that would appear on the plate, would it *taste* any good? Would the meat be perfect? Would it be seasoned aptly? Would there be anything more memorable than its visual appearance? I'm skeptical.
author: Brski B.

description:
3.5 stars Why?   Made reservations we were the first customers so they offered us a table or the bar.  We opt for a table.  Then they sat the next two... where?   Next to us!   They had all these open seating even if it's for two people maybe the host could have chosen to sit the other two a table a way, just a suggestion.  A total of four people being dined.  They chose to keep us four together.   

Dinner 

Crudo of the day - 1.5 stars Simple version - poki very bland.  Missing sodium and lime.  

Grilled cheese - 5 stars- truffle shavings  and honey.  Simple yet amazingly delicious.

WOOD OVEN ROASTED PIG'S HEAD chicories, capers, parsley & lemon  - 4 stars
Their specialty, based on pictures posted on yelp.  Served with Brain + mayonnaise. Unique concept for a main entrée.  The skin was crunchy and the meat behind the skin was so tender.   Let your waiter know ahead of time because it takes 40 min to prepare.  Warning - a lot of FAT with drippings.
author: Jay B.

description:
GREAT NEW PLACE, CLASSIC COSENTINO

When Incanto, Chris Cosentino's old place on Church Street, closed to become a high-end sandwich shop, I was devastated.  Where would I go to find Chris' signature blend of odd cuts and offal, stylishly presented in a unique culinary experience?

Welcome, Cockscomb, my new favorite restaurant in San Francisco!  Chris is back on the stage, better than ever, in a more down-to-earth location South of Market.  Can't wait to go back again and again to savor the entire menu, including, soon enough, the roasted pig's head!  One caution:  Plates are generous.  It's easy to over-order.  But you'll never regret it!
author: Paul S.

description:
Came here for dinner with a group of friends and the service and food were both great, but as my fellow Yelpers have said, Vegetarians should stay away from here and expect to dole out the cash to dine here. 

To start we ordered a couple round of drinks, and the favorites were definitely the Towering Inferno and Fresca Kid. To start we had the bruschetta, which is seasonal and the seasonal one we got to try were the cranberry with duck mousse and it was delicious, but the portion was a lot smaller than we expected. 

For dinner we went went with the waiter's suggestion of the Pin Bone Steak, the steak was perfectly cooked on some pieces and over cooked on others, but the bone marrow dip was to die for! 

While the dining experience was good, the food just wasn't great enough to justify the price.
author: Elizabeth C.

description: Absolutely fabulous!!  Visiting from Arizona and were so pleased to find this place on our first night.  Wish we would have just came here every night.  The staff, the service and the food are all top notch!  I love that you can get a reservation too.  Highly suggest sitting at the counter on the left.  You sit right next to the chef who is calling the orders and get to see the entrees fired right in front of you.  Very unique!  Hope to return someday!
author: Shaun N.

description:
Kumodo Oysters 4.5/5 - they were so plump with a little sweetness.  A little fishy but great taste.  Not a restaurant rating, just an oyster rating.

Beef Heart Tartare - 5/5 - Only had beef heart cooked (which I thought was good) but this was much better. So much put into this tartare, not just plain, raw beef.  It's good alone but definitely meant to eat with the bread based off salt factor.  Bread is fantastic as well.

Kale and Butternut Squash Salad 4.5/5 - kale, squash, dressing were perfect.  I liked the bird seed for the texture it brought but thought there was a little too much of it.  It's a personal choice, but the overall taste was fantastic.  They give you an enormous bowl of it and I basically finished it.

Service 5/5 - I dined alone and they sat me at the chef's table.  I was also super indecisive because I wanted to try a little of everything.  Definitely come with a group cause the portions are big (can't complain) and everything sounds/looks so good.  Ashley was patient with me and good at keeping some conversation with me, which I appreciate when I dine alone.  Got to sit right next to expediting and see everything they make (ridiculously amazing 64 oz steak presented beautifully).  Listened to Chef Chris explain so much of his food.  It was awesome to see the staff spend some of their free time there because you can see they all appreciated what was happening at this restaurant.

Update: got food poisoning :( Maybe the tartare?
author: Richa S.

description:
Ordered the Pin Bone Steak w Marrow Dip. Huge portion of meat! Insanely good.

Great meat, probably don't need the marrow dip.. which is like a meaty ginger scallion sauce.. that coagulates if you don't eat it fast enough.

Kudos to the team at cockscomb!
author: The Missteak S.

description: Definitely one of the more memorable meals I have had and well worth the trip if you are in San Francisco.  Yes, it is celebrity chef driven, but the quality and preparation of the food is excellent.  I was with a large group and we had house made pastrami, duck, oysters, pork belly, and sweetbreads.  I really cannot find anything to criticize.  Taste, presentation, and overall satisfaction of the entire meal exceeded expectations.  The restaurant is small and a bit loud, but the high-energy atmosphere adds to its appeal.
author: J C.

description:
Four-star for food, 2.5-star for service.

The menu is creative and daring.  Beef heart tartare?  'Nuff said.  

The grilled cheese was really tasty.  But then again, how can anyone possibly go wrong with cheese, good bread, and LOTS of butter?

Now let's talk about the service.  I think our waiter really tried, but as the place got more packed, he simply stopped coming around to check on us.  I had to flag someone else down to go get him so I could order a second round of drinks.  We spent the last third of our meal watching out for him so we could order another drink or get the check.

And when the check finally arrived, it had a $52 item on there that we didn't order, which meant our check went from $110 to over $160.  Of course, the waiter apologized and took it off the bill, but still.  If we weren't paying attention, we'd have overpaid by about 50%!

Anyhow.  If you find yourself here, order these:

- vertigo fizz, a fantastic cocktail with egg white
- the grilled cheese sandwich

Other than that, the tripe dish was well seasoned but otherwise nothing to write home about.  The egg egg egg dish was basically glorified hard boiled eggs.  And the mussels were just so so.
author: Kristen S.

description:
Flawless.  

The menu is extensive, with a lot of vague items, which need explanation from the server, b/c Chef wants to be green by not reprinting menus. 

The cheeky art pieces and signs displayed are humorous and added to the charm of the restaurant.

Seating, if you're a party of two and want a little seclusion, I would choose upstairs, we got a nice corner booth seat, plenty of room and far enough away from most of the patrons.  We were given a choice, downstairs looked into the kitchen and provided more energy to start the evening, but it's typical elbow to elbow SF dining.  

Eats:
*Grilled Cheese, this was AMAZING, crunchy edges, perfect portion of cheese and the honey was a surprising element, decadent.  Four people can easily share this.  $16, but totally understandable seeing as cheese is $48/lb and $300/lb truffles
*Little Gem Salad, great dressing and even better were the fried pig ears
*Beef Heart Tartare, entrée size, great herb salad and spices
*Uni Lardo Bruschetta, SOO good.  LOVED, ask for it.
*Last Supper, lovely to see him resurrect one of the courses from Top Chef Masters, blood sausage, poached oysters, egg, I would like the sausage ala carte
*Pin Bone Steak, take heed the FOUR person denotation on the menu, they are serious, the platter was RIDICULOUS, could have easily fed 8 people if they each had an appetizer.  Steak cooked a perfect medium rare, served with au jus and a sinful bone marrow dip.  The wilted dandelion greens and parsley were seasoned with fresh anchovies, Meyer lemons, generous olive oil and went fantastically with the meat. They include the bones also, which really showcase how large the animal was.  Needless to say, we brought over a 1lb of meat home.

Even though EVERYTHING is meatcentric, Chef manages to sneak in fresh, beautiful produce throughout.  I personally think you can skip the salads.  

A few quibbles:
-Unisex bathrooms get a little sloppy.  Wet around the bowl and no toilet seat covers.  
-most courses involved the famed Tartine bread, but when you bite into it, the crusty edges rock the roof of your mouth, proceed with caution, or use a knife.

Parking: super easy and stress free, $15 parking across the street.  

Definitely make reservations ahead of time, same day on a Saturday is impossible for walk ins.  

Just my two cents, best Bay Area restaurant opening in 2014.

Will be back again AND again, but not too often, my future cardiologist will thank me.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
Cockscomb - delicious. Everything here was absolutely filling, delicious, and all-things-porky.

Drinks are solid (Chef's Gin Jam was my favorite and so was the Negroni on tap) and just about every dish here was outstanding as well. The WOOD OVEN ROASTED PIG'S HEAD ($65) is fall-off-the-face-amazing...... omg. It reminded me of pork belly heaven. We also ended up getting the bacon chop ($32), Bone Marrow ($20) and the "Hot Mess" which included foie gras.. it was a never ending meat-fat- feast.

The space is interesting - cool, cement walls surround the open-kitchen. There are several bar tables, communal tables, normal tables, and also additional seats/tables in the mezzanine level.

We were a party of 4 seated at a communal table that was shared with another party of 4. While it was fine - it wasn't the most private experience - so make your requests ahead of time if you mind this when planning to come here.

Overall - this isn't a spot where you would take your vegetarian friends to, but for foodies or meat-lovers - this is an awesome dining experience. Highly recommend coming with a group of 3 or 4+ so that way you can try as many dishes as possible.

Make reservations!
author: Veronica S.

description:
Really good food but extremely slow service during lunch.
We were seated at 11.45a. The server came around at noon to take our orders and the main dishes did not come out until 1.17p after several check-ins with them.
After I informed them that we absolutely needed our food because we had to go back to the office for meetings, the server said "oh, i didn't realize you had meetings..." 
Why would that matter?! 
Waiting more than an hour for lunch is not really acceptable, regardless of whether we had an office meeting. 
Unfortunately because of that, this review is focused on their slow, unapologetic service instead of the stellar food
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
I love this place! Food tends to be very rich, but it is so damn good. Tonight we got the roasted pig's head. It says it's good for two or three but it's so rich that it was enough for five of us. We started with the stuffed squid appetizer and the zapping both of which were really good. But it was all about the pig's head tonight. Yum!
We did not have the beef heat tartare tonight, but it is really good and absolutely worth trying.
author: Suzanne F.

description: Quite expensive- which would not be an issue if the food merited the price. Sadly - it did not.
author: Uri L.

description: Great food and cocktails!  We started with the appetizer special, Foi Gras & Trotters.  Decadent  and delicious!  For dinner, we shared the Roasted Pigs Head.  Yummy!  Delicious cocktails, and seats in the balcony made for a perfect, fun meal.  Highly recommended!
author: Rick G.

description:
We pigged out!  The food and service were terrific and we highly recommend the Bacon Chop.
Yes, it's huge but so delicious and the fat is perfectly cooked to melt together with the date sauce. Thinking about it is making my mouth water. The oysters are a good way to start your meal along with some bubbly. Then don't be shy about ordering the vegetable sides, you won't  be disappointed. Next time we'll be even more brave and try the heads.
author: Natasha Z.

description:
Service: 3 Stars
Had some friends in town, and we made a reservation at Cockscomb for a Friday night for 6pm. We had asked for 6:30 or 6:45 so another friend could make it, but they refused - when we got there the place was over 50% vacant and remained that way until 7pm. Was disappointed that they could not accommodate that.

Food: 5 Stars
We got the Gem Salad, Grilled Cheese with Quail Egg, Market seafood (tuna & calamari poki) as appetizers. All of these were great - the Grilled cheese is the sleeper hit. You could come in and just order one of those and a side and escape without paying over $25.

We then split the Pork Belly & Marinated Crab main, and got the cauliflower and carrots as sides. The crab was good, but super messy and I didn't feel like we were given adequate tools to deal with it. The pork was fantastic, it tasted even better the next day with an egg for breakfast. Blanched and seasoned collard greens came with the main - they were excellent as well as the bacon fat cauliflower and curry roasted carrots.  Very complete meal.

We didn't order any drinks because we arrived already drunk and needed to sober up, and our bill for 3 was still over $200. Pricey - but we did get a lot of quality food.

I would return if I'm in the mood for a meat & fat heavy meal.
author: Ross H.

description:
Update: I visited a second and a third time. There can be too much sauce served with the quail that it gets soupy, too little flavor on the steak, the pigs head meat is delicate but there isn't enough flavor. The tartare remains excellent. Seems like the kitchen is still fine tuning the details but I do enjoy the flavors of the unique dishes, the high quality ingredients, and the atmosphere.

-----------

The food is homey and interesting at the same time. It's comfortable and yet novel. 

Dishes I loved:
Uni and lardo bruschetta (bread should be thinner)
Cauliflower
Beef heart tartare
Quail Tetrazzini

Also enjoyed:
Sweetbreads with salsa verde (not on the menu-need more sauce)
Pickled sardines (taste like herring)
Truffle honey grilled cheese (nice amount of truffle)

The half-pigs head was flying out of the kitchen but I didn't try it. Next time. One of the steak dishes feeds 4! Lots of opportunities for family-style eating. 

As far as service, great for day 3 but the kitchen seemed on the slow side - either because they're still getting into the flow or perhaps it's because we ordered the meat pie with dough crust.
author: Marina N.

description:
This place is really good.  Every part of the meal was delicious. We had the beef heart tartare, eggs eggs eggs and the Bavette steak. All recommended strongly  and without reservations. My gf got on-tap negroni  and the bullitt both of which she really enjoyed.  I got the milk punch and vertigo fizz. My only complaint is that the fizz tasted a bit too floral for me due to the lavender content. 

The interior design was also really cool from the taxidermy on the walls to the wallpaper in the bathroom. Awesome attention to detail.

Strongly recommended
author: X P.

description: Fast service during lunch. Good beers. Impossible burger was tasty. Tastes 99% like beef.
author: Reza H.

description:
- Beef Heart Tartare was phenomenal - fresh meat and very well seasoned

- Bacon Chop was HUGE, but very good! Tender, juicy meat and very delicious sides

- Broccoli Rabe was a fantastic side - garlic, breadcrumbs, yum.

- Excellent service

- Very trendy, fun atmosphere
author: Kari L.

description:
Roasted Pig head chicories, capers, parsley & lemon:  LOTS of Fat under the skin, a lot of the skin parts were more rubbery than crispy, our ear came out separately, i'm guessing they deep fried it for us to ensure that it was crispy.  Good juicy flavors in the meat however.

2lbs Bacon Chop apples, brussellskraut & mustard: Bacon chop had a decent sized bone in the middle side of the meat which was hard to cut around.  That brussellskraut STANK!  It was pretty foul smelling for me.  Took one bite and...nope, not for me.

Bone Marrow hay smoked fried oysters, watercress & horseradish: Kind of a standard bone marrow, they brought out our bread/toast after they dropped off our plate so we started to eat the bone marrow without it.  Kind of standard, I've had better and worse.

Clams cider & pickled ramps: Maybe slightly over cooked because the clams seemed a bit tough but was easily edible and flavorful.  

Butchers choice (daily fall offs): Foie Gras.  It was the firmer style foie gras mixed into a melody of greens and other randoms, it was good.

Duck fat Cauliflower red fresno, garlic, caper & mint: Cauliflower was cooked well, it was nice to eat something a bit lighter to the palate because just about everything else we ordered was so savory.

3.5 Stars.
author: Mike K.

description:
I am a vegatarian....so I did not enjoy this place. They serve half pig heads and 4 pound steaks...
THAT SAID.
It is a classy restaurant with a fantastic and knowledgable wait staff. They food "looks good and presentable". But as a pescatarian, I was only able to drink the beer and the raw halibut, both good.
This place has a fun, hipster vibe. We were a loud group and they were able to accommodate a group of ten without issue.
This place is expensive. Like a side salad is $10 expensive. A pig head is $64 and the four pound steak is $110....
I won't come here again but if you like enormous piles of "amazing" meat (according to my group), you should give this place a try.
author: Loryn F.

description:
This is one of the best places I've found in SF and I'm a native. I've gone to michelin star places that Cockscomb could easily rival. 

Atmosphere: Super wonderful mood lighting and very San Franciscan in theme. 

Price: I can see that it's listed as a $$$ restaurant right now but it's definitely a $$ if you ignore the pin-bone steak everyone here seems to be excited about. And honestly.. DO ignore the steak because this place has some unbelievable dishes to try out. Happy Hour is awesome too, with $1 oysters.

Dress: Like any good SF restaurant, anything from workout clothes to formal attire would fit in alright here. But you'd look weird in a full tux.

Tips:
Get the grilled cheese and use it to soak up the incredible sauces from just about any dish here. You won't regret it.
author: Rebeka J.

description: Cool ambience and upstairs area.  I had great oysters and amazing chicken.  Planning my return trip already.  Tucked in a side alley.  You could easily pass this place and not know its there.
author: Nick K.

description:
Feeling full and satisfied, Chris Cosentino absolutely delivers with his array of comforting foods.

Upon entering Cockscomb you come into a comfortable urban vibe with dim lighting, and a bit of taxidermy on the walls. We arrived early as a group of four, and thus headed straight to the bar to grab a few cocktails. Highly recommend the Bullitt, and Chefs Gin Jam as it was very refreshing. 

When we made it to our table our server Josh was very friendly, and attentive. We started with the Beef Heart Tartar, Uni Bruschetta, and the Duck Liver Terrine was one of the best I've had. As an entree we ordered the unbelievably good Pin-bone steak with bone marrow dip for four that was more then enough to fill us up! We capped our meal off with some decaf espresso and the Mandarin Orange Mille Crepe Cake that looked and tasted delish! Will definitely return.
author: Courtney C.

description:
Was here a month ago and the food was too salty for my taste.

This time taste was much better but two of our mains were under cooked. 

The bacon chop was a little under cooked at the thickest section but that was fine.  After one or two bites we had enough.  It's just brine bacon.  Nothing special.

The Cornish game hen was cold/raw in the middle and bloody at the bone.

Unfortunately our wives already ate a few bites.

The manager was nice enough to comp our appetizers but our dinner was already ruined.

While waiting for them to make another dish for us I asked the manager for a round of drinks for our wives.  He became defensive and said "On top of the appetizers!?! How about I just comp the whole dinner?!"  He might as well just have'd said get out.

We didn't wait for the new dish.  Left a tip for the busser and walked out.

Checking and cooking food to the right temperature is the most basic skill.  If you can't do that right you don't belong in the kitchen.

Comping the appetizers or whole dinner does not help to clam the concerns of our wives.  If the people who just ate raw chicken that you served asks for drinks, you give them drinks without questions.

If you can't assess these situations and be clam about it then you don't belong in the service/hospitality industry. 

I do not recommend this place at this time.  Maybe in a few months or a year.
author: David C.

description: The flavors are scrumptious. We had the "Hot Mess" special and shared lamb, more than enough for 3. Impeccable service.
author: K T.

description:
Amazing new place in SoMa!  Tucked into an unassuming little alley near 4th and Brannan.  Went there with a group of friends on its opening night and it was definitely a special experience. 

The atmosphere is great and the food both unique and delicious.  The seafood tower was a perfectly fresh combo of oysters, clams and crab (with special sauces) and the pin-bone steak was a massive centerpiece to our meal.  Have never had a cut like that before.  Huge and flavorful!

Everything we tried, we loved. Will surely be back for more!
author: John S.

description:
Great, great meal.  Got to sit by the food prep area where we got to observe all the amazing stuff they make (ie. tons of grilled meat).  Got to talk a bit with Chris Cosentino who seems super down-to-earth and really hands-on with running the restaurant, which is fun to see.

As for the food:

My wife's cornish hen was one of the most amazingly succulent piece of poultry I've ever had.  Ribeye was great--didn't get asked about temperature, which I love (medium-rare is the only way to go :) ).  The term "spiral fruit cake" really makes you think it'd be a brick, but it was awesome--I'm getting it every single time I go.

Taking my buddies here next time to get the 4-pound pinwheel steak.  Yum!
author: Dave K.

description:
Drinks:
Not why we came here and a little heavy on the bitters (why is this a thing these days). Ice cubes were nice and clear, so you can tell the bartender really cares about things.

Food:
We had the pig head. My heart still sings when I think about it. I ate the snout. 
Everything was amazing... try the veggie side, makes you feel healthy with that head.
Cant remember the starters. 
Seriously, just order the head and let the waiter choose your sides.

Service:
Meh. Our server was an ass. But we openly discussed as much when he suggested that the head was too fattie for us, so maybe that made things worse?
author: Kate M.

description:
We made reservations for two and were seated at the bar overlooking the open kitchen. When I make reservations, I kind of expect to have a seat at a table. I always thought bar seats are for walk-ins. 

From the bar you can see all the action going on in the kitchen. We saw chefs being coached and yelled at. Kind of cool, if you are in to watching a live episode of Top Chef or Hell's Kitchen. Not the best environment for conversation. 

We shared a bunch of dishes including the Grilled Cheese, the Beef tartare, and the Bacon Chop. The grilled cheese was probably my favorite. The Bacon Chop was tasty and I liked that the skin was crispy. It was a big portion enough for two. I was a little annoyed that it didn't come with a better knife. I wound up hacking at it with my butter knife.
author: Meredith M.

description:
If you are not adventurous, then this place is not for you. 

You're not going to find a pounded chicken breast here nor will you be able to order a filet mignon with some wine reduction sauce because that is BORING.

Chef Chris Cosentino is known for his creativity and ability to use an entire "beast" and transforming it to gastronomical goodness.

That said....my recent visit to Cockscomb did not disappoint.

My husband and I tried the following items:

GRILLED CHEESE truffle & honey - this dish was so delicious: creamy and a nice balance of sweet and salty. I don't feel that it was lacking in truffles like other reviewers did because it would have thrown off the overall flavor.

LITTLE GEMS green goddess, radish & cracklins -  very light, fresh, really flavorful dressing. I love cracklins and I could have gone with or without them on this salad.

BAVETTE STEAK roasted carrots, onions, thyme & kombu butter - nice flavor, prepared medium rare, the roasted vegetables are a perfect accompaniment. Nothing fancy. Just a good piece of meat!

WOOD OVEN ROASTED PIG'S HEAD chicories, capers, parsley & lemon - MY FAVORITE. Really tender (buttery almost) and a real treat for any carnivore. I had plenty leftover and I ate it for breakfast for the next 3 days. I did not waste a single part of it. 

CHOCOLATE CAKE with toasted MARSHMALLOW - dense but light (I didn't think it was possible). a perfect sweet treat with coffee (I think they serve Blue Bottle).

---
The service was excellent. Very attentive but not annoying and smothering.
Our server knew the menu well and was able to provide a bit of insight on each item on the menu.

Our drinks were replenished as needed, we didn't feel rushed, and I really didn't have a problem with the service at all (so, again, I am not sure why other reviewers had a different experience). All the staff members who came by our table were friendly.

The restaurant has a nice vibe. The décor is rustic with some cool elements (roosters, cool art and wallpaper, etc.). If I had to complain about 1 thing - then it is the space (or lack of) between the tables. The tables on either side of us were definitely closer than I liked.

I'm definitely a fan and I would go back. Even my husband, who isn't super adventurous was pleasantly surprised by the whole experience and is already talking about what he would order next round. I am definitely looking forward to my next visit!
author: Aimee P.

description: I won't bog you down with the details, but after 2 visits, I am a die-hard Cockscomb fan. The one thing I will absolutely recommend is the "Hulk" cocktail. With gin, kiwi and celery water, it's in my top 10 cocktails of all time. Chris was there on our 2nd visit. Definitely sit up at the chef's counter if you can - the chefs are true craftsmen.
author: Sarah B.

description: Not a great place if you're trying to talk amongst 5 guys.  (NOISY). Lots of sharing dishes which is okay unless you're with picky (vegetarian) diners.  So...ordered separate entrees and they all looked good.  I had the halibut and could have eaten twice as much.  All in all okay experience.
author: David F.

description:
When it comes to Nose to Tail, there's really no other than Chef Cosentino that I want to experience it with. Our dinner at his last restaurant Incanto was probably one of our most memorable, and this evening's dinner at the chef's table was on par.

We started with a half dozen oysters and the pulpo. The octopus was just right, and I swear there was duck fat somewhere. The mignonette with the oysters was very innovative, even though naked oysters are my favorite.

Main course... Could have had everything, but the special did me in, and I had the Hot Mess (aka foie gras and trotters) and Ranjit had the "Bacon Chop". For the daily requirement, we shared escarole with anchovies. There is nothing better in my world than a beautifully seared, melt in your mouth, buttery foie gras. But with the trotters and the house jam, Divine! The escarole cut through the buttery fat with the acid from the lemon and the salt of the anchovies. Perfect. Ranjit's chop was moist and probably the best we have had in years.

For desert, we had the eclair, which had cherries nestled within the chocolate cream filling. Paired with a port, it was a perfect finish.

If you haven't tried nose to tail, start here. If you have, you haven't really experienced it until you eat at Chef Cosentino's table.
author: Laurence B.

description:
We ate here a few months ago but my experience was consistent with earlier experiences.  I have two issues:  first is the use of 'weird ingredients' just for the sake of the weirdness, without worrying too much about making them really delicious.  We tried the cow udder braised in milk.  It was really pretty disgusting, not even as good as it sounds.  Maybe this is why we don't usually eat the udder, but I'm definitely not inspired to try it again.   

I do have to give kudos for TRYING.  

But the second, more disturbing issue is the execution -- the milk-braise liquid was very bitter, with a strong flavor of almost-burnt garlic.  Burnt garlic is never acceptable but especially not at this price point.  I don't think the kitchen should have ever sent this dish out.
author: Jaina S.

description:
Dinner was better than the other two times i went! We had the corn with mushrooms, steak, pig skin pomodoro, summer squash, and the calfs liver. The pig skin pomodoro was unbelievable it was so good I'm still thinking about it. We sat in front of the line and all the chefs were very nice. Chef chris even gave us a free dish!
Can't wait to go back.
author: Krystal R.

description: Came here for happy hour at night! They have $1 oysters and they are prob the best $1 oysters I've had! The ambience of the restaurant is nice. Not really a beer person, but I enjoyed some of the beers that my friends had ordered.
author: Mary X.

description: First time here for a friends birthday. It was pretty good and the portions were huge. We ordered a whole pigs head which pretty much was like roasted pork that you buy at a Chinese resturant. The oysters were good and fresh we ended up ordering a 2nd order of them. The steak was great, a little too raw when we got it but all in all the food was great. It was a bit greasy to my liking but I def recommend everyone to at least try it once here.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
Great service, great food, great environment, great restaurant!

Dined on a Friday night. Started with the country ham and melon and grilled cheese with egg and honey. Bacon chop with peaches and steak with arugula and tomatoes for dinner. Everything was cooked perfectly and had amazing flavor. Paired with great cocktails it exceeded expectations.  

Great work guys, we'll definitely be back!
author: Joseph H.

description:
Restaurant small and quaint. Seated at the chef's bar overlooking the kitchen. Staff very friendly and accommodating. Menu outstanding. You have to try the grilled octopus appetizer. One of the best. Entree was fresh catch in a citrus soup. Chris , the chef has a wonderful palette because the dish was well balanced with perfect citrus notes. Service really great. I had a wonderful waitress who went out of her way to accommodate me. I met people at the chef's bar that I didn't know but we began to share our plates and had a wonderful time. 
Highly recommend
author: Mun Yei C.

description:
My favorite dining experience in San Francisco so far.

Got reservations with a group of friends for a Saturday night. We were immediately seated downstairs next to all the action in the kitchen. Such treat to watch Chef Cosentino work! When he stepped away from the kitchen he made the rounds in the dining room to greet customers- even playing host and seating guests at one point! Very cool dude.

As a group we ordered the bruschetta special to start (holy deliciousness) and shared the pin-bone steak (adding foie gras, as well). My life has been forever changed.  The steak was perfection and more than enough food for 4 people. We barely spoke during this meal, except to occasionally whisper "oh my god, so good" while stuffing more meat in our mouths. 

Additionally, cocktails were spot on and the server was wonderfully attentive and super personable. 

I really can't wait to come back and try that pig's head.
author: Amanda G.

description: Went here with a friend for lunch when doors opened at 11:30am. Cute, rustic, farmhouse-chic ambiance. Attentive, well-mannered, and expeditious wait staff. Amazing company =] We ordered the famous 100% vegetarian (vegan without the cheese) Impossible Burger (with a side of potatoes) to see what all the hype was about. With regard to presentation, portion, and overall flavor: flawless. It really delivered and really looked and tasted like a burger! The potatoes were decadent and came dressed in a decadent, seasoned aioli. My one gripe is the veggies on the burger + the bun = all soggy. The bun was not at all toasted, which soon turned into a sponge of grease and condiments with every bite. The (butter?) lettuce and pickle chips quickly wilted and lost their crunch under the hot burger patty. Otherwise, the Impossible Burger is quite inventive and flavorful. Would recommend... just ask for a toasted bun and the fixings on the side.
author: K. V.

description:
If you are a veggie lover then STAY AWAY from this restaurant. Although they have some good veggie dishes but you are here for the meat and seafood. We (4) came here on a busy Sat evening, place is packed by 6pm and it is pretty loud. Very cool setting and you can see the chef working hard with his kitchen staff to prepare that delicious meal for you. 

We started with cherrystone clams from WA, pretty good, very sweet, followed by the special of that night, which is fore gars, the fg itself is pretty small, buried under some shredded pork, not too bad. Then comes the beef heart tartare,I am not sure if this dish is really raw beef heart but it tastes great! it goes really well with the grilled bread. after that we had the bone marrow, I am not a big fan of it but my friends really enjoyed it. 

Then the waiter clear the table and about 20 min wait, comes the roasted pig head, they say it is for 2 to 3 people to share but we had plenty of left overs after we were done with it. I think maybe I was expecting a lot, since this is kind of like their signature dish, but sadly I only took couple bites of the skin and meat then that was it for me, any more I would throw up. I guess it is the greasiness...The skin was not that crispy, and it kinda stick to your teeth, for me I had to scrape off the fat attached to the skin, otherwise I don't think i can eat it. The other part is that you have to dig through all the fat under the skin in order to get to some lean meat and the digging part is kinda of... I don't know, it is just not for me. The dish came with some dipping sauce, it is pig's brain mixed with mayonnaise or they called it brainaise, not a big fan of it.
