There is also some sauce that dripped off the pig's head when roasting it, the chef mix it with some herbs which you can dip the skin or meat with it, again not a big fan of it. To be honest I wish the chef used the hoisin sauce as one of the dipping sauce, it would take some of the greasiness away... just a suggestion. The pig's ear that came with it was deep fried a bit, therefor very crispy and I like it a lot.

Almost all the meat dishes come with some good portion of veggies. My wife had the little gem salad and it was pretty good. She also had the quail with mushroom (she was not too fond of the pig's head), and she loved it, I tried it too and I would choose the quail over pig's head. 

I think I will be back couple more times just to try other dishes on the menu. Place is not very big so it fills up fast, I was told you have to make reservations month in advance... Service was great, wait was very friendly and attentive. limited choice on desserts so we just went somewhere else.
author: William C.

description: Creative flavors in a chic barn setting. My criticism is more about the style of service then the slightly too salty fare. It did not feel like a restaurant that has been open for three years. We were asked repeatedly about ordering before being able to enjoy our time out as a family or fully decide on our shared meal. We felt rushed and had bussers trying to take food away that we hadn't touched. As well as being asked multiple times within a few minutes if they could clear. The waiter was friendly but no one seemed relaxed. It felt that the push to turn tables was stressed so hard by management that the service style was not creating an experience of being there but one of to how to get you out. At the same time empty glassware lingered on a table that couldn't fit all the food ordered. Having food come as ready also means as it fits on the table which it did not and I had to actually hold plates and bowls to take the food off and serve to then hand it to a busser. Dessert was not ordered because we had no time to digest and didn't feel like staying after what we had been made to feel during the meal. I really wanted to like them but too many great SF options to go back.
author: Allegra R.

description: As always Chef Cris didn't disappoint. I've been to his old restaurant & the flavors wowed me. I brought my sister here for her birthday & she loved it. Even their cocktail drinks are awesome. My gin & tonic included orange & lime rind but also included juniper berries, it was so refreshing. We started our meal with the watermelon salad, so refreshing with yogurt & mint. The sour, sweet, with the refreshing flavor of mint was an awesome flavor dancing in my tastebuds. I ordered the grilled chicken which was excellent with the crispy shallots & my sister ordered the halibut. My sister enjoyed the fish a lot. For dessert we ordered the panna cota which has rest strawberries with a balsamic reduction, again all these layer of flavors which I know Chef Chris does so well. Will definitely go back again.
author: Grace A.

description: Impossible burger was impossibly good. The smoked salmon was delightful. The lemon fruit desert was light and delicious. I highly recommend sitting at the chef counter, it is entertaining and interesting to watch the action.
author: Astrea W.

description:
Chris Cosentino's new spot and it's definitely a winner. A variety of local and seasonal ingredients that meld together to create some interesting dishes. 

Sat at the bar and the service was great. Chefs are engaging and fun to talk to about what goes into each dish. 

We decided on 4 dishes between two people. It was so much that we had leftovers. The portions are quite large, so bigger the party, they better. 

Bruschetta with uni butter and crab 
very light and the perfect amount of salt. A good light starter to kick things off

Beef heart tartare
I could eat this all day long. Per the chef, it's mixed with some capers, red onion and something else that i forgot. Don't be scared ordering this, it has a fresh taste to it and it's definitely a winner

Foi gras with Pork belly and strawberries
the duck and pork gives it a very rich and creamy texture while the strawberries give it that acid and tartness to break it up. It's a good combination that works well together

Bacon chop
Ok, so.....this thing is huge! I mean you can share this with 3 people and be full. It's perfectly grilled, juicy on the inside topped with flava beans and rhubarb. We couldn't finish half of it since the other dishes were pretty large as well. I'll put this up there with NOPA's pork chop, but i still think NOPA has the edge in my opinion. 

Sitting at the counter, there are a few things i want to try still. The burger looks awesome as well as the sausage. I'll definitely be coming back for those. Oh and they blood sausage that's sesasonal...ahhh music to my ears! 

They also do happy hour that is from 5-6pm and 10-11pm. $1 oysters and specials on their beers.
author: Andrew S.

description:
I was tantalized by the pictures on Yelp along with the plethora of 5 star reviews on Yelp.  It is with great regret that I cannot continue that trend.  Sometimes restaurants can fool the senses with superficial beauty, and that is what I believe Cockscomb did to me.

I made reservations for a birthday dinner and was promptly seated.  Service was impeccable but a tad impersonal...borderline cold.  We ordered:

1.  duck liver on toast: 2/5.  I can handle liver in small doses (unless fois gras), and while duck liver is a level up in decadence, they piled too much on the toast where it was just not savory.  The bread was delicious, however, the amount of liver just overpowered it.  We had to ask for extra toast to divvy up the liver.  

2.  grilled cheese: 4.5/5  This was the best dish of the night.  A simply grilled cheese with duck egg and honey.  The cheese was very rich...i am not sure the blend.  A duck egg topped it off.  $11 for a grilled cheese is pretty redick in its own, and while this sandwich was good, it wasn't heavenly by any means.  The honey was a nice touch.  

3.  pin bone steak: 3/5  This is what I came here for, and in terms of presentation, it did not disappoint.  The steak was perfectly medium rare and the bone marrow dip and au jus were ono grindz to the extreme.  However, beyond the presentation, the meat was a little too chewy.  Pin bone cuts are the most succulent of the sirloin steaks, however, this dish did not meet that billing.  I left Cockscomb -$110 for this steak as well as a jawache.  

We got some other dishes like halibut and some desserts.  To me, the dessert did not even qualify as a dessert.  One was an apple covered in a mountain of cheese...ehhhhh.  The second was some blank cake.  

I really wanted to like Cockscomb.  The decor and motif of this place is super legit.  However, the food was lacking to me, especially for that price tag.  When you leave an eatery with a very light pocket and bummed out taste buds, that is pretty much the worse combo.  Hugs are appreciated
author: Brian V.

description: Would have loved to give this place a glowing review as they really do have good food, however I ordered the "Incredible Burger" with no bun, and specifically asked the waiter if there was any other "bread/breadcrumbs or anything like that" and he said no. Shame on me for not just saying gluten, but I feel like the waiter should have caught on that I may be avoiding wheat, and after eating it (it was, in fact, very good) we got the info card on the product and the second ingredient is WHEAT protein.  Annoyed at myself for not saying "wheat/gluten" and annoyed at the waiter for not being more perceptive. Ruined my experience and impression of the place.
author: Kelley N.

description:
Cons:  Very high noise level in top room.  Raw bar oysters not good at all. Waited far too long for food, upwards of 50 minutes. Lead waiter basically ignored us when it became obvious food was delayed.  Charcuterie platter uninspired & meager for the price. 

Pros:  they recognized the problem with food delay and gave us 3 free deserts which were good. 

Very disappointing experience based on previous yelp reviews.
author: Kevin S.

description: So happy with my "ham"burger (like its name, the patty meat is pork versus beef) which was perfectly cooked. The meat was thick and juicy with a horseradish Dijon, Gruyere cheese, and accompanied with a side of extra crunchy potatoes. My friends ordered the zampini (a fennel and pork sausage) which was a generous portion & came with 2 fried oysters, along with a separate side order of roasted sunchokes. My only complaint: the dishes were very oily--the kind where you feel slightly guilty and sick for eating so much rich food afterward, so I recommend eating slowly (or ordering tea). I was impressed with the chefs--extremely astute and made sure every dish coming out was nothing less than suitable by the executive chef (who was a meticulous enforcer sparing no exceptions)!
author: Valerie F.

description: Not only is the meat incredibly tasty and beautifully prepared, but so are the veggies! We also love the gnocchi. The cocktails are great. The service is warm and attentive. A fun meal
author: Kat M.

description: What a great meal. We ordered a whole lot of food and everything was amazing. The raw bar options were fantastic. There was so many decadent items available. The space was well lit and I didn't need to scream to talk to my guest. The space is big and the open kitchen is a great focal point
author: Elaine L.

description: Sat at the bar for a great meal. Thanks Steven and your staff for the wonderful service and attention. Dishes were great. Atmosphere awesome. Highly recommend.
author: Mohammad G.

description:
5 Star food.  

2 Star service.  The host is an unhappy man who doesn't understand how to properly make use of empty tables.  The Bar/Wait staff is friendly if a little awkward, and could use some proper hospitality training.  

Back of house is killing it.  Front of house leaves a lot to be desired.
author: Andrew R.

description: The impossible burger tasted very similar to the real thing. Hey only serve it "medium", so no pink in the middle or bloody parts, which I was frankly most curious to try. Still, the future tastes great!
author: Ben A.

description:
I really enjoyed my meal here -- and we didn't even have enough people to try the big shared dishes. What we did have, though, was all great. 

To start, we shared the beef heart tartare, clams, little gem salad, and Benton's aged country ham. All were excellent, though the ham and the beef tartare were my favorites (not too surprisingly). 

For my main, I tried and highly recommend the "hot mess" special -- foie gras and pig trotters over toast with pickled and fresh strawberries, and I think also a strawberry jam -- AMAZING! The strawberry really helped to cut the fattiness and I was able to finish the whole thing. We also had a side of roasted carrots, which were very good. And for dessert, we tried the "chocolate" which was a very rich chocolate terrine, and the "fruit," which was a concoction that I can't exactly remember, but was light and citrus-y and refreshing. I couldn't believe how much we ate, but everything was so good that we didn't stop until we'd cleaned all of the plates.
author: Shing H.

description: This place had one of the best appetizers & steaks I've had in a while. The food was really flavorful and the steaks were really tender. I would definitely come back and try the other dishes.
author: Diana C.

description: My son wanted to dine here for his 19th birthday. The dish he wanted to try was the special off the menu 1/2 pigs head! We started with the beef heart tartare which was very delicious. The steamed mussels are also very good. The broth was seasoned just right. The only negative was the broth and mussels were luke warm. We went all in and order the Beef Leg of Beast (shank) along with the 1/2 Pigs Head. The beef shank was HUGE and so was the price - $140. For that price I was expecting amazingly flavorful beef flavor. It was super tender but sadly had zero flavor. The pigs head was as anticipated. Perfectly crispy skin. Fat and rich meat that you could drizzle with the two included sauces. Very well done and highly recommended. We had the heaviest "doggie bag" to take home!
author: Mr S.

description:
This place was pretty great but our main server pretty much disappeared after he took it order and reappeared with the check. I know most people don't mind this but it annoys me.

The food was really great, we had the pigs head that was cooked perfectly. I really enjoyed the uniqueness of this place.
author: Christina Y.

description:
Atmosphere = Good
Service = OK
Cocktail = Really Good
Food = Did not meet price expectations

No doubt expectations for my group of 3 were high after seeing the menu prices and reviews. Although the above were good, the group agreed that a rating of 3 was fair and unfortunately disappointing. If considering Cockscomb order carefully.  All three of us had the 'Ham' Burger with egg for $18. Too much bread, lacked flavor, and potatoes were to be dipped in overly rich mayo.  We will not come back. 

Best of luck!
author: Jerime B.

description:
Came here for my brothers advance birthday treat. He is a huge fan of Chris (he's already been to his other restaurants) so i thought of taking him here. 

As soon as we were seated we were given the menu, and told us their special for the day. Actually i have seen the menu online and have been drooling to taste all of them prior to getting here haha. 

We wanted to try as much dish on the menu so the four of us kept ordering food. (You'll see pictures later). Everything taste so good. Each ingredient on the menu was carefully thought of. The bone marrow, the foie gras, the grilled cheese with truffles ... Simple yet very sophisticated. It was like heaven in your mouth. We were so full that we did not order any dessert.

Very hip and vibrant atmosphere. Loved the open kitchen design. Chris was very nice to give us a signed menu plus a photo op with him. It was indeed a pleasurable and memorable experience. Definitely a place worth dining for. One of the best !!! A+++ 

Will come back for another special occasion.
author: Kristina A.

description:
I have to say have this is my favorite place so far in SF. The portions are very generous and the food is super tasty. We started with the little gems and the grilled cheese. 

Little Gems - This is pretty good but it would have been better with more of the deep fried pigs ears. 

Grilled Cheese - MUST GET! This thing is so tasty if you like the sweet and salty taste. Make sure to get the shaved black truffles. It brings a good balance into the appetizer. 

Pin Bone Steak - If you're hungry? Get this. The portions are very generous. We had a party of 5 and if we just got this, then it would have been a perfect sized meal. The server will try to tell you that it only feeds 3. Don't believe him!

Bacon Chop - I'm not a big fan of pork but my friends thoroughly enjoyed this. The meat was nicely cooked. The fava beans and rhubarb was amazing. Make sure to eat that. 

I really enjoyed my time here. The venue is super hipster with lots of reclaimed wood and industrial fixtures. Make sure to get reservations a month in advance.
author: Gary I.

description: Worst place. Please avoid. Starters, the waiter tried to upsell us by over 35 dollars for a little more streak. When we did not accept he was heard making comments about it at the bar. Then the steaks we ordered medium came out rare and well done, anything but medium. On top of that the service was slow and the waiter was inattentive.
author: Shazad A.

description:
Loooove this place! I dream about their pork chop all the time and have to go back at least once a month.

If you are a meat lover and are adventurous, this is the place for you. Forget about healthy quinoa, time to pig out! My favorite is the pork chop, though their meat pie and foie gras are equally delicious. The pork chop feed 2 easily, though I don't mind taking the left over home. 

Super convenient location, great place for a drink as well. I am in love and will never go back to Marlowe again, now this place is in town.
author: Ashley Z.

description:
Maybe I went on an off-night, but I don't know what all the hype is about.

I ordered the Buvette steak. It was tough and gristly. My jaw and teeth would cry out in exasperation at the herculean amounts of effort it would take to chew each piece of steak. The entree also looked ugly as sin - a pile of brown meat and seaweed colored butter with no bright colors or green whatsoever. My eyes vomited at the sight before me.

I was also lucky enough to try some of the other dishes from my dining companions, which brightened the dinner a bit, but left me puzzled. "Eggs, eggs, eggs" was delicious, but it felt sinful and bizarre having a brunch dish for dinner (also not filling). Grilled cheese was fingerlicking good but also seemed like an odd choice for dinner.

I enjoyed my cocktail but the paper straw felt gimmicky to me and proved inconvenient when it started dissolving into my drink. I also did not love the menu, and choosing an entree for the evening was a tough endeavor.
author: Lawrence H.

description:
This place is great. I enjoyed the lamb shoulder, which was so tender that it just fell apart. It can probably be shared between 2/3. The collar of tuna was tasty but very difficult to serve. The pork chop was awesome & easily enough for two people. 
Tip: don't wear your best clothes as they'll stink of smoke from the kitchen.
author: Barry O.

description: Phenomenal food, drinks and atmosphere. They don't skimp on portions or friendliness. I recommend coming here whether you're a resident of SOMA or passing by.
author: Dhroov M.

description:
Found this suggestion on Eater SF for Christmas Eve reservations. Was worth every penny and not a disappointment. Ambiance was great, as was the service and interaction with everyone there. 
We sat at the kitchen bar and enjoyed watching the prep and cooking of the meals. Our menu was pre set and the choices were spot on. The scallops and goose that I had were done extremely well and my counterparts food was just as good, if not better. 
I would certainly go back here when in town. Loved it!!!
author: Kristin M.

description:
I have had dinner here a few times food from scratch great steaks family style We had 5lb steak and some great side. perfect for paleo or low carb 

 the review is for dinner here I had Lunch here once and that was more of 3.5 stars
author: Chris M.

description: Grilled Cheese with Egg + Mussels + Branzino !! Ambiance, Service and Food was phenomenal ... Good Job Cockscomb!
author: Mitzy P.

description: We ran over from our train and we got there and were told they stop serving at 1:30 but their hours say 2pm if we knew we couldn't t be served at 1:45 even to go order we would have tried to plan accordingly
author: Melissa M.

description: They say they're open until 2 but they stop serving lunch at 1:30. In my opinion, if you stop serving then that should be your closing time. We would have planned our trip differently if the information had been more accurate.
author: Allory W.

description: Wonderful experience!!! From the moment we walked in we were treated like royalty. Drinks were made perfect - if you like tequila order Greed. The waiter Joshua was kind, funny and knew his stuff!!! Chef Chris Cosentino was roaming the restaurant all night, smiling and checking in. He even took a pic with us and got in on a discussion of who should pay the bill at our table. Grilled cheese with fried duck egg and honey is to die for!!! Just abut everything was. We will go back for sure!
author: Kari W.

description:
"You are eating fat".  My companion was compelled to tell me in drastic terms what I obviously refused to acknowledge up to that point.

Disclaimer -- if you into this "whole animal" thing, or think that any SOMA joint is worth a visit because it's the chic thing to do, this might be right for you.  If you believe that eating animal organs like liver that is filtering out toxins for years might be problematic, do not come here.  

What she was referring to is pasta made from pig skin, in tomato sauce and olives, which led to some initial denial / indifference on my part, mainly because it really looked and tasted like pasta.  It was pure fat, and a cheap one (pig!) at that.

The signature dish we went there for in the first place, squid and watermelon salad, would have been delicious if they hadn't lit on the spice fire ruining any flavor that squid barely has to begin with.

The steak (beef, for a change) just came with arugula lettuce, but the disappointing thing for a meat place was that it was very chewy = low-cost supply.  Plus, our red wine (by the glass) was watery.

All this points to low-cost ingedients (what's the cost of pig skin and liver?) and cutting corners to maximize margins, which on the other side of the equation means we spent $140 for an experiment with fat, skin, and chewy meat.

One extra point for great service and an excellent table.
author: Peter D.

description:
Tried this place out last night for my birthday dinner.  Overall, it was a great experience.  I had never eaten at Incanto and offal honestly makes me kind of squeamish, so the dishes that we ordered were a little more on the timid side of things.  

For drinks, I had a negroni which was very good and also an Invasion of the Bodysnatchers.  The Invasion had gin and some sort of fernet type drink with blood orange.  Was good but a little musty tasty at first.

For food we ordered:

The Bruschetta which had a bunch of stuff on it.  There was crab, uni butter, some type of fatty lardon type of stuff, some greens and radishes served on top of Tartine bread.  Was really good, but if you didn't get a chunk of radish with every bite, it was a bit rich.

The hot mess which was foie gras, pig trotters, dates, some other stuff (who knows) on top of some bread thing.  Some bites were a bit too rich for me, but overall, I appreciated the creativity that went into the dish and it didn't taste like anything i had had before.

"& chips" is basically a dish that consists of some meat with these delicious potato wedge-ish type things.  The potatoes tasted like they were fried in some sort of animal fat.  beef maybe?  I don't know, but they were NOT vegetarian and they were GOOD!  The sausage was served in a coil, and i forget the name of it, but it was made with pork and was really really tasty.  It reminded me of when i make breakfast for dinner at home, but so much better.

service:  this is where they still have some kinks to work out.  Our drinks took a very long time to come out and it took our server a long time to take our order for food.  Normally I don't mind, but I was really hungry!  I think this will improve over time, so I am not going to really fret about it, since the service was nice and hospitable.  

I enjoyed sitting at the bar near the kitchen.  It was highly entertaining to watch them cook.....it was really intense.  I also happened to be sitting right where the dishes came out, so I got to see everything on the menu.  The pigs head.....wow!  Not for me, but several people in there were really goin' for it!

Do:  come here hungry and come here if you enjoy meat.

Dont:  bring vegetarians here.  Their poor little heads WILL explode.
author: Christian C.

description:
Second date.  I had a couple of friends that had come here beforehand and tried the pig's head and said it was too big, but an experience to have. Therefore, I wanted to try this place with someone who loves food as much as me. 

Obviously we were going to try the grilled cheese (#57 on the 7x7).  I told my date to choose the other items so he decided on the beef heart tartare and then we were going to go big and try the pig's head. It was a lot of food as expected, but it was all delicious. 

Grilled cheese:  grilled cheese with an egg on top. I know it's popular just to put an egg on top of things, but the egg makes it interesting. Not to say the grilled cheese was the best thing I've ever had, but it was a damn good grilled cheese and the egg was perfectly oozy. 
Beef Heart Tartare: Honestly, if no one told me that it was beef heart, I wouldn't have known. The texture was just slightly more chewy than regular beef tartare, and it was interesting.  I will admit I saw it on Top Chef Masters as a part of his final episode he had some beef heart tartare.
Pig Head: Wow this thing was impressive. It comes with two sauces - one that was like an aioli made from the brain apparently and the other was a chimichurri sauce.  The meat was tender and really delicious, but I will admit there was a lot of fat. The skin was nice and crispy as well.   The snout was an interesting feature, and I even tried a bit of the eye. All and all, interesting experience. Definitely worth it. I would definitely suggest having more people before you order this, but it's great!

Overall, we had a great time. I saw Chris Costello at the restaurant and I really wish I took a picture with him, but that would have been a lot to ask. Regardless, it was great to see him and try his food. 

Protip: pig's head definitely.
author: Nina Y.

description: We came here for the pinbone steak and were thoroughly impressed. Great service, energetic ambience. Loved the whole dining experience.
author: Mitch T.

description:
Sat at the chef's table. Chris Cosentino came up right next to us to check on the dishes and chatted with us briefly - have to admit, was a bit starstruck. Very friendly wait staff and chefs. :)

We ordered the beef heart tartare, grilled cheese truffle, Bacon Chop (gigantic -- looked like a 30 oz or something insane, fatty, delicious), and the quail. Hands down favorite was the quail, mushrooms and crispies (yes, I made that word up) and the amazing sauce they put on it (made of chicken broth, butter, &creme fraiche).  I even started dipping the Bacon Chop in that sauce.

Wine recommendations were great as well. Staff is very knowledgeable about wine pairings.

I got the "chocolate" dessert. I forgot what it consisted of aside from the toffee/caramel brittle - which was addicting. We almost asked for more brittle to sprinkle on the chocolate mousse... but finished the dessert too fast. 

Overall: great atmosphere, food, staff, and head chef! :D Looking forward to coming back to try the pig's head :) 4 stars for the food + the last star for the wonderful overall experience.
author: Mary L.

description: One of my top food experiences! It was difficult to know what to choose because I wanted to try everything! We started with grilled cheese. How one can make a grilled cheese that is so amazing I do not understand but it was the most perfect grilled cheese ever. Next a selection of oysters which were beyond fresh and the sauces were a beautiful accompaniment. Next the roasted pepper salad - again how roasted peppers and walnuts taste so amazing from this kitchen I do not understand but they were. And then pastrami roasted chicken and waffle - wow! The chicken was moist and flavourful. The balance of spices with the allspice standing out but not being over powering was so fabulous. Cocktails and wine were perfect as well. If you have not figured out yet - I definitely recommend this restaurant if you want a top food experience with a cool laid back vibe!
author: Bonnie M.

description:
Went last nite with some meat lover friends for some Friday nite SoMa ambience.. We practically ordered everything on the menu

The  bacon chop was just wrong it's like they rendered the meat and served the fat ..and there was nothing to cut it with ... 

But everything else we ordered was so good ..the pin bone steak served rare although I like it medium ..The pigs head though delish was a bit too fatty .. I wish they had served it with fresh citrus on the parsley salad ..instead of the marrow jus ..

The oysters were great and the desserts were superb.. 

The highlight was the bone marrow with toast and greens the duck fat cauliflower was a great complement 

I can't help compare with incanto in noe valley back in 2010 ..am hoping the tuna heart pasta is back on the menu
author: Abby B.

description: Literally one of the best meals I've ever had. The food was incredible. The service was excellent.  The theater of sitting at the Chef's Counter watching Chris Cosentino expedite was the icing on the cake.
author: Jen H.

description: I love this place! I've been twice - and have tried multiple dishes - Amazing ! Claudette is awesome and our waiter Vincent was EXCEPTIONAL!!
author: Mark P.

description:
Top Chef Cosentino is not.

Having dined at Cockscomb pre-opening, I returned with hopes that Chris Cosentino had upped his game.  Not so: Cockscomb is very disappointing.

The ambiance is cool: loft-like with bar area upstairs; trendy and industrial vibe. 

The service is good and the ambiance is great, but the food is nothing special. Grilled cheese "with truffles" ($16) did not evidence even a hint of truffles. While OK, the broccoli rabe was nothing to die for. The roasted pig's head ($65) is more of a spectacle than a dish: all flash, no taste.

Chris, go back to the drawing board and man-up. Without some serious alterations, Cockscomb will be a flash in the pan in the highly contested San Francisco restaurant scene.
author: CJ G.

description:
Great experience at Cockscomb!  The service was impeccable and our food was fantastic.  we ordered a bottle of wine, knowing we would need more than one, and stuck with the same kind all night because we all liked it so much- a recommendation from our server.  
I went with a group of 6 which was ideal since I got to try lots of different things.  There were so many specials and I think we got most of them.  The plates are definitely small, but that was to be expected.  I think it would be a great place for a date.  The layout of the place is also very nice- we were upstairs in a quieter more separate room and it was really nice, but I'd love to try sitting down at the bar where you can watch the chefs and all the action.  Very cool decor and atmosphere, I will be back!
author: Rachel M.

description: No question, this place is my favorite place in SF right now and I'm SO happy that it's in close proximity to AT&T Park so I get to take advantage of it more frequently. (Giants season ticket holder). The food is simply incredible. It redefines whole categories. The iceberg wedge salad is totally unique. Fabulous....I could go just for it! The "ham" burger is astonishing....a huge pork pattie on a home made bun with foie gras along with the tastiest potatoes I think I ever had. The oysters on the half shell, the Branzino, the pork chop....everything I've ever ordered here is perfection. I love the ambiance too and it's sort of funky location down an alley with no real sign out front....just the "food" arrow on 4th pointing down the alley. This is a truly great place and not to be missed.
author: Jim M.

description: Yummy food and cute space.  Came with some friends without RSVP but they worked it out and got us a table.  Service is efficient and nice.  Will return.
author: Lev E.

description:
This restaurant met all of our expectations. IT was a sisters birthday celebration. We enjoyed the spaghettini and the "hot mess" was amazing. Chef Cosentino was attentive and a gem!
Highly recommended
author: Regina F.

description:
Great service! The appetizer portions were a bit small. We got the pin bone steak to share which was mostly very good but had some parts that were too chewy or raw.

Also try the negroni.
author: Daniel V.

description:
Wonderful food and pleasant atmosphere but still hard to swallow a $500 bill for 4, although it was New Year's Eve in sam Fran
Other time I went I loved everything I ate from app to desert
Oysters were good too
author: Shereen L.

description:
Crowing about Cockscomb!
The place: is small and rustic - the kind of slightly weird floor plan that you see in old San Francisco buildings. It feels comfortable and not at all designed. It's off an alley and the whole set up makes you feel like you're going somewhere 'insider.' The chef works in the open and is right there - which adds to the feeling of being someone special going somewhere cool and a little undergroundy.
The service: is the tops. Our server steered us away from a meal choice that wasn't going to be as good as what we had. She risked making her opinion known and we were smart enough to take her advice. She knew her menu like she was born with it. She made excellent recommendations on cocktails and wine too. And it wasn't just her, but the rest of the team who were helpful and super professional. All of these people could work at Quince or wherever they wanted - they are that good. 
The food: Oh good God. You have to like meat. What Cosentino can do to protein and fat will make you think you will never want a piece of bread again (though the bread they serve is delicious too). We had the porchetta and it was the best porchetta I have ever had in my whole life. I'm pretty sure I am eligible for a heart attack today but if it happens, I will die happy with my last meal. And it came with some lightly grilled romain, unbelievable tomatoes, and we got the cauliflower (in duck fat I think) and all were equally heavenly. So, a little sweetness from the tomatoes, somehow a little sweetness from the porchetta (I don't know enough about cooking to know why this is) and that balanced the salt and richness of the rest of the dish perfectly. Seriously. Perfectly. I am so happy I got to eat this. You should probably eat this too.
Cocktails: Everyone has already remarked on this but know it's all true. I'm a gin drinker and this is a gin bar. Our server knew about gin (actually knew stuff) and I got some crazy blue gin that was incredible. Drink cocktails here. The wines are nice too - and you can rely on the server to choose well for you.
This is probably the most decadent and calorie rich food I have had in any restaurant. Walk there. Walk home. Work out all week before you come and eat here. Cockscomb will make all your worries disappear in a meal of over-the-top self indulgence that can put your life into proper gracious perspective! Let Cockscomb make you an even happier person too through outrageous, meaty food, inspired cocktails and the best service.
author: Margaret G.

description: Foie with charred dates and garam masala is amazing plus the wood oven pigs head is really good! Definitely one of my favorite restaurants in SF!
author: paolo c.

description: My experience at Cockscomb was fantastic! I'm sure I won't be able to do this place much justice with my review but I just have to say, if you're ever in the Bay Area, this is definitely a must try! I can't wait to take my family here next time! We tried a bunch of stuff but the highlight of the night for me was the Grilled Cheese that everyone's been raving about, the Hot Mess which is my number 1 favorite and the Wood Oven Roasted Pig's Head. Talk about melt in your mouth meat! The duck fat cauliflower is also really good as well as the gnocchi. I'm definitely coming back here to try their other menu items. Oh! And always save room for dessert! Just because they come last, doesn't mean you should forget about it. I don't mind splurging on amazing food (and service) like this!
author: Pia B.

description:
All I can say is HEAD!

If its its a Pigs Head or the seasonal Tune head. I love to get Head at this restaurant!!!!
Of course there is much more then head here, amazing little bites and creations. As well as Leg of Best!! 

The name of this restaurant says it all, you will find original creations from the master. 

If you have been to the previous restaurant that the Chief had then you will get more of the greatness here!
author: Andrey P.

description: Dinner was great! There were many options that are not on the menu. The pin bone streak is huge at four pounds so we decided to go with one of those off menu items -- a pound of wagyu beef. They didn't decant our wine and the food was a little slow to come out but overall it was a great experience.
author: Alex T.

description:
Big fan of the Chris and have had some great meals at Incanto. Had the unique seat right next to the expediter. Wasn't thrilled at first but that changed quickly after experiencing the sights and smells of being so close to the action. We were able to get descriptions of all the dishes coming out before we ordered and suggestions from the chefs. Plus, with the interaction with the Chef, it was like being personally served by Chris Consentino for a private meal. 

We wound up ordering the mussels and chips and the sweetbreads to start. Mussels were OK. Not sure if I would order them again. Sweetbreads were really good though and tasted nice with the peach slices. 

Entrees were the bacon chop and the Zampini. Bacon chop was delicious. Zampini was undercooked though. This wasn't an issue since the chef next to me immediately ordered another one to be fired and gave us some ham (prosciutto?) and melon to enjoy while I waited for my replacement. When I did receive the Zampini, it was tasty. 

Overall, food was enjoyable and service was excellent. Bonus getting to be in the middle of the action watching the staff taking care of the guests. Will definitely be back.
author: Nelson C.

description:
Party of 4 last night.  Full restaurant at 8:30 when we arrived.   Had a short wait until taken to our table on the 2nd floor dining area, which is invisible from the main room.  
Greeted immediately by our gregarious and gracious server.  Explained specials eloquently.   We ordered 2 of them, pig skin spaghetti and steak tar tar bruschetta, as well has Medium oysters/clams/crab platter for $48.  Pig skin was cut into long thin strands and sauteed in tomato and some greens.  It was ok.   
Bruschetta took a long time to get to our table over 20 min.   It was tasty but there was so much topping it was impossible to cut into pieces that you could pick up with your fingers.  It was a knife and fork dish. 
Oysters were delicious, clams tasted good, but the raw bar chef, either needs a new knife or needs to be trained on how to open clams b/c they all were a mangled mess. 

Entrees:  Roasted Pig Head - $69, Sausage $18 and Steak coulotte $32
Pigs head tasty, but mostly bone and fat, not surprising, but probably not worth that kind of money unless you love pig fat. Sausage was tasty, Steak was delicious. 

Had Chocolate cake for dessert, classic super dense, yummy.

Service was great, except for after we finished our crab/oysters/clams our hands were dirty, sticky mess - and no hot towels came or were offered, so I had to go downstairs and wait in line for restroom for 10 minutes.
author: Jay K.

description: Ate at Cockscomb last night and had an interesting experience for sure! The wait staff could not be any more attentive or helpful. Chris Constantino came to our table numerous times to make sure our experience was top notch. The food was amazing! The deviled egg were, no doubt, the best I've had. The pigs ear puttanesca was awesome, do much depth of flavor in the sauce! Had the special, which was lobster with pork belly. It was the best pork belly I've ever had!! My husband had the branzino and I got a taste, it was delish. I highly recommend Cockscomb. If your looking for a special occasion or want a meal that is an adventure this place will not disappoint!
author: Kellie K.

description: All the wait staff was very nice and professional, the food was another story the pigs head was crisp on outside and rare on inside , the beef heart was room temperature, charcuterie plate was also room temperature, little gems salad was delicious.
author: Paul O.

description:
My lovely wife's been talking about this place for a few months now, so we finally came in tonight for her birthday. Here is why I am giving this joint 5 stars:

1. Service - Joshua our server was very good! He was good with our kids and gave us a lot of insight about the food and history of the establishment. 
2. Ambiance - very clean. Great design. Esthetically pleasing. 
3. FOOD - Everything was cooked to perfection and the taste was as advertised! We started with the Bone Marrow, our 2 little ones shared the Grilled Cheese with Duck Egg on top. My wife, eldest son and I shared the Pin Bone Steak. For dessert we had the chocolate and classic.

I can't stress it enough, EVERYTHING was on point. From my initial call setting up reservations, to closing out the tab. First class all the way. Job well done. We'll be seeing you again soon!
author: Adrian D.

description:
All I have to say is that the food is amazing, the service was great, and the night was perfect!! Thank you guys for such a great dining experience, and a wonderful evening.  This place is def. a hidden gem!!  I would recommend this place to anyone!!!!!!

Thanks Cockscomb, you made a happy Jew!
author: David F.

description: Awesome place with delicious well done dishes. The food is awesome. Wonderful and beautiful interior. Awesome atmosphere and friendly staff. Great place for meeting with your friends. But it is a little bit expensive.
author: Kayla K.

description: Wow, I stopped by for lunch, and asked if they had food to go.. They said no, but they would make an exception for me. The staff was very friendly the place was a nice hipster. I got the "hamburger " and it was awesome. It is ground ham, made into a patty, grilled, and simply wonderful. If you are in the SOMA go to this place
author: Paul G.

description: This place is an amazing not to well known of a gem in Sf. A friend that lives in the area took us here and it opened my eyes to a whole new culinary world. The oysters were amazing. we also got beef heart tar tar. I was hesitant to try it but it was amazing! We wanted to order the pigs head but unfortunately they were out. so if you want that get there early!
author: Jessica M.

description:
To preface this, I am not a big red meat eater so I was more than hesitant to eat here as a majority of their dishes are comprised of meat. I was pleasantly surprised by the food. I was with a group of five people, we ordered a few apps to start. The grilled cheese with truffles and honey was far and away the best thing we had all night, SO good! I ended up ordering the 'ham'burger, a burger made out of pork shoulder, it was definitely a bit different but good! The crispy potatoes it came with were also delicious. 

Overall, I would say if you're a meat lover then this is definitely a place to try. There was one veggie option (a spring risotto) but generally speaking it's pretty meat heavy. The cocktails we had were delicious - great martini! It's on the pricier side for sure, so that's something to be aware of prior to.
author: Lizzy U.

description: SOOO good it's a meat lovers paradise!! The service and food was fantastic and the décor was awesome. They have a full bar and the cocktails are gin focused which I love. I will be back very soon, well not too soon because I'm sure I'll be full for a while.
author: Jon W.

description:
Came for happy hour at 10pm on a Wednesday night. 
The $1 chef's choice oysters were fresh and delicious. We also enjoyed fried pig ears and $5 beers off the happy hour menu. Nice restaurant ran by Chef Chris Cosentino from Food Network. Got to meet him, nice guy.
author: Karen T.

description: Ordered the octopus, bacon chop and meat pie. Only regret was not having a party of 4 to share the meal to share which was crab and a tomahawk steak
author: Y L.

description:
Beautiful meal and lovely service.  Drinks were top-notch: the martini was classic and the Chef's Gin Jams was inspired.  Our server, Phil,  made our night. Phil--and the beef coulette. 

Also, get the little gems with pig's ears!  (Technically pigs' ears, I guess.  Multiple pigs.  The placement of the apostrophe is crucial, people.)
author: Jenn L.

description:
Warning: This review has been rated PG-13 for sexual language.

It's risky going to a restaurant with a celebrity chef. Is the celebrity chef a figurehead who never sets foot in a kitchen and is an absent owner? Or is the chef actively running the kitchen and we truly experience what they are about? No such worries at Cockscomb as chef Chris Cosentino was working hard on both sides of the pass to produce satisfying and comforting food.

It's hard enough to get people to eat raw beef. It's harder to get people to eat raw cow heart. Definitely need to attract daring diners to order the beef heart tartare. But those who take risks get the rewards. As my favorite dish of the night, the tartare mixture nicely balanced the "pow" of the heart with enough acidic "zing". The "duck liver croquet en bouche" starter had incredibly flavorful duck liver piped into a baked puff. I would have loved the dish except it had entirely too much sweet strawberry jam that buried the superb liver.

The entrées were slightly homey. The tetrazzini included an entire roasted Cornish game hen topped with mushrooms, crunchy fried fideos, and cream sauce. Typically, scant and dry, this hen was meaty and tender. It surprisingly didn't loose its crisp skin in the sauce. For my entrée, I ordered a "zampini" without knowing what it was. (I later did a web search. Google directed me to a Brazilian actress and Wikipedia to an Indian village. This means I should have eaten a sexy starlet or an entire Asian village like Godzilla.) What I actually ate was a grilled sausage with plenty of corn on the side. Topped with two gutty fried oysters, the ingredients never felt cohesive and the dish was oily.

We didn't have dessert because I was full from cleaning our plates. I don't like to waste food. Speaking of waste, we saw a couple of orders of "pin steak" which was served on a board that barely fit the table. I don't know how many pounds it was, but it's a roast that would probably serve six people. Unfortunately, I saw two boards go back to the kitchen only half finished. I sure hope the restaurant has a good plan for sizable amounts of uneaten meat otherwise that was a shameful waste, but they should consider serving a smaller portion.

The red wines by the glass were curiously South American, but appropriate given the amount of heavy red meats.

The menu had a "Butcher's Choice" of "Daily Fall Offs". Considering they have beef heart, I was expecting some crazy and fun parts like lamb brain, pig pancreas, boar dong, or anything with the word "knuckle" in it. Basically, something that would rival the banquet in "Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom". Sadly, the leftover cuts were the premium foie gras. Furthermore, if someone from PETA heard that the force feeding of fowl yielded what is considered a fall off, it would likely anger them even more.

There was a 4% pretax surcharge for "San Francisco employer mandate", although I'm not sure why some places charge this while others do not. Parking in this seemingly industrial area was oddly high at $7 per hour due do "event parking rates" when no major event was in sight.

The name of the restaurant is a little personal. How someone combs their privates is not my concern (hence the term "privates"). But since it's San Francisco with hairy hippies, they probably carry a cockscomb unlike most of us from Los Angeles with a pornstar shave.
author: Brian U.

description: Holy $#!% this place was good. Came here for a company dinner and every bit of this place is amazing. From the service, to the restaurant, to the food. I definitely recommend coming here if you would like a fancy dinner, but don't want to be fancy. I wish I wrote this earlier as I don't quite remember all the dishes I tried, but one thing I do remember is how incredible it is.
author: Will C.

description: Stopped by for lunch today and the food was just okay. The ambiance is quite nice and reminds me of a cabin or something with animal heads on the wall. Service was good...just wish the food stood out a bit more. I had the pea risotto which was light for a risotto but tasted more like congee. The duck fat cauliflower was so salty and the cauliflower itself was not crispy at all. I had high hopes and came out disappointed.
author: Jenann P.

description:
I've been here twice, and both times were memorable as being some of the best meals I've had in SF.

The first time I was with a group of 5, 4 guys and a girl. All of us had worked out previously, so saying we were starving hungry is an understatement. I'm sure we ordered enough for 8-10 regular people haha. I can't recall everything we ordered, and the menu does change a bit, but the pig head and pin bone steak were fantastic entrees to cap off the meal. The brain-o-naise or whatever they call the sauce for the steak was pure indulgence, like pouring liquid fat over the tender, perfectly cooked beef. I also learned an interesting thing, which is that a pig's head is comprised of many huge chunks of fat. I consider myself adventurous, so I tried my best to eat said fat, but after a few mouthfuls of what's essentially pig butter, I had to give up. My mouth was completely coated with pig fat, so much so that we had to order extra whiskey to help rinse it out. Mind, I'm not complaining, just letting people know in case they think it's just skin and meat - you get TONS of fat in the pig head.

The second time I went here was for my company's holiday party, for maybe 12-15 people. We spent, no joke, something like $2k hahaha. Getting to expense that was great, I love free miles.

From the beginning cocktails we had while waiting for the table to be set up, to the appetizers and shots and wine, to the huge array of meats and veggies, and to the final massive desserts, Cockscomb hooked it up amazing. I was beyond full, in the best way possible.

So overall, this place rocks, it's not cheap, but if you are feeling spendy and want some amazing meat and seafood, it might be SF's #1 spot. The interior is also very cool and unique, and their drink menu is extensive.
author: Sm L.

description: Lived up to our expectations of a Chris Consentino establishment! We especially loved the roasted  pig's head!! It's not everyday you see something like that on a menu so you have to order it. It was more than enough to share between four people. The space is pretty cool too - industrial, urban, cozy-chic. Loved the tap pulls on the beer! Service was excellent and sitting at the chef's counter was pure joy.
author: Zee T.

description:
The pros: nose to tail, negronis on tap, cool space.
The cons: bacon chop requires navigating a majority of hard fat and bone in order to get to a small oasis of edible meat (and I say this as a lover of pork belly, lardons and other forms of deliciously rendered fat). 

The prices seem to slightly outstrip the returns here.
author: Timothy S.

description: A bit pricey overall but the food was delicious and the atmosphere was intimate. A good spot for a date night, but make a reservation as soon as you decide you want to go!
author: Rebecca G.

description:
The food was quite good but the prices were high. So you know, just like all over SF. 

Except in this case the prices were higher than the food was good. I was astonished at our bill for 2 people for lunch.

If price is no concern then consider this a 4 1/2 star review for the food alone.
author: Peter L.

description: The pigs head is really delicious but it is just so rich. The skin comes out really crispy and flavorful but I could only eat so much.
author: Kenson K.

description: OK so this made my visit to San Francisco all Worth it! If I go back to the bay I will definitely be going back to cockscomb! This place was super packed, and super busy, and we were still able to get awesome service and awesome food. The Chef (Chris consentino), sources, everything locally, and the dishes were all so beautiful and creative. Everything from my cured tuna hearts shaved onto a confit albacore bruschetta to the heritage half pig head that I got was absolutely phenomenal!!!! A place you must visit if you love good food!
author: Sammy C.

description: Had an amazing dinner here! Reservations are highly recommended. Everything we had was beyond delicious and I loved that each dish had great presentation!! The ambiance was really great and I loved the lighting. It felt very lively but also intimate. In my opinion, the best seats are the seats at the bar. Here we were able to watch Chris Cosentino do his thing in the open style kitchen. It felt like we were watching Top Chef LIVE! Chris Cosentino even took the time to ask us how we were doing and also served us a few of our dishes! Such a great experience! My favorite dishes were The Medium (13 oysters, 6 clams, and 1/2 a crab), Duck Liver croque en bouche (choux puff filled with duck liver and topped with strawberry jam), the foie gras (Cockscomb has perfected the searing of foie gras!), risotto, and meat pie. If you are going with a group, I recommend the pin bone steak- it's enough to feed 4+ people! Also, their gin cocktails are amazing!! It is a def must try! I loved everything about Cockscomb and now it is one of my favorite restaurants in the city! Can't wait to come back!
author: Lynn T.

description:
I had a reservation for birthday dinner with my girlfriend and they texted me the day of (too late to get a table elsewhere) to inform me that they took a last minute group reservation and we didn't have a table anymore. They stuffed us in a cramped corner by the kitchen bar with another couple who unhappy couple who they screwed in the same way.

Lame.
author: M H.

description: This place was great!  The food was on point and the service was outstanding.   I never walked in when I lived next door cause I thought it was a bar.  I missed out so don't do the same.
author: Hara K.

description:
I planned a birthday dinner for a party of 7 and we were seated immediately. We shared the dishes family style since we all wanted to try a bit of everything. 

Let's get to the meat:
The Pig's Head was my personal favorite. The pig ear was perfectly crispy. The meat was tender and it is super fatty so if you don't like fat, this one isn't for you.

We also ordered the Pin Bone Steak. It was good, but I liked the Pig's Head more. Between these two main dishes, we were stuffed and also had leftovers to take home. 

For sides:
Summer Squash - good
Tripe and Clams - so yummy!
Little Gems - more pig ear! good but pricey
Heirloom Tomato - always a good choice
Bread and Butter - great!

I thought the service was good. Not above and beyond, but it was decent. 

Ambiance - lots of mood lighting
author: Faye P.

description: The spot and the whole "spin" on the restaurant is good. Food wise, it's nothing mind blowing, plenty of spots in SF offer similar quality dishes for less. Skip the beef heart tartar - tastes like a bland version of regular tartar. Steaks are pricey SF restaurant good, but not good steakhouse good. Went there twice, but with so many other similar options in SF most likely will not go again.
author: Dmitriy M.

description: Great spot for dinner with friends or a date. We were kinda disappointed with our roasted pig head but this could also be bc we've had lots of good pork head dishes... Anyway, cool menu, good vibes, open kitchen layout is cool.
author: Laurice S.

description:
Cockscomb is an out and out celebration of meat. And, if you're a carnivore, it's spectacular. But, seriously don't bring your veggie cousin here. Though we did have a fantastic heirloom tomato salad.

For your first time you should go ahead and get the roast pig's head for two or three people. It's kind of a novelty, but you know you won't be satisfied until you try it. The skin is the thing with it. There's a lot of fat -- a lot of fat -- and some yummy meat, but the skin is unbelievable. Once you've done it you can move on to the next meats on your next visit. The bacon chop for example, or various steaks, or even the "ham" burger. Everything is great.
author: Rick H.

description:
Nothing better then a BBQ chicken&avocado sandwich for a lunch ! 
Niece place , great sandwich !
author: Alex B.

description:
Outstanding food and service. I highly recommend it! BTW, the Impossible Burger as OFF-THE-CHARTS!!!
I also love the "hideaway" location.
author: Joanne P.

description: Fun atmosphere, well trained/experienced/engaging/attentive service, awesome food that's different but not overly done. We sat in the top room at the window, which was nice for having a conversation, would also be nice to sit at a table by the open kitchen to watch the show in action. If getting a drink and apps the seats to have are at the upstairs bar area overlooking the restaurant. There are only a few bar stools at each the lower and upper bar. Nice for a date or small group of friends. Had the sole, which was enough for two people! My friend who had the sole who isn't a fish person even liked it. To get the most of the food experience come with a sense of adventure, but if you aren't an adventurous eater there are "safe" choices (sole, steak, etc.). Would go back for sure!
author: Lily B.

description:
Being that I was born in the year of the rooster, Cockscomb was a perfect venue to host my birthday dinner!  And the fact that I live a block away might have had something to do with the simplicity of getting home, post celebration.
I think we ordered every specialty drink which were all delicious.  My party of 10 ordered:
+ two towers of BIG seafood (A+) 
+ the beef heart tartare (A-)
+ duck liver terrine (A-)
+ bone marrow (A+)
+ country pate (A)
+ pin-bone steak (A)
+ pigs head (A++)
As you can see by my complex grading system, nothing was short of amazing. Everything was terrific and the -/+ only designate what was most popular at the table that night.
author: Alex T.

description:
I went to Cockscomb in March 2015, not long after it was opened. I was visiting SF at the time and my good friend Lorrie, who is a Yelp Elite for 10+ years probably and had over 3000 reviews suggested this place. The restaurant is located in SoMa and as we walked in I immediately loved the place, the ambience, which to me felt like rusty industrial meets modern chill. We sat on the top floor by the windows and before we got started, thoroghly enjoyed watching dishes getting served to the large/long table next to us, one of them being a huge slab of medium rare steak which looked amazing. We each looked through the menu and ended up ordering the following: Beef Heart Tartare, Raw Halibut with Jalapeno Peppers, "Hot Mess" Seared Foie Gras, and the Wood Oven Roasted Pig's Head. Delicious!

I'm just going to dive into ranking and reviewing the dishes: 1. Wood Oven Roasted Pig's Head: this dish was HUGE, and both me and Lorrie loved it. The pig's head was so crispy on the outside, especially the ears, and soooo tender on the inside. Probably the most tender pork I have tasted in a long time. 2. "Hot Mess" Seared Foie gras: you can never go wrong with Foie gras - it was delish as usual. Not sure about the beef patty/cake on the bottom though. 3. Raw Halibut with Jalapeno Peppers: it was sooo tasty and refreshing! There is something about raw fish and olive oil, lemon/lime juice, and peppers. 4. Beef Heart Tartare: it was good but not amazing, and it really was nothing special. 

Overall, it was a great dining experience and delicious food. Although the dishes were a lot for 2 people. Our neighbor-next-table (not the large table) bet that we couldn't finish all that food, but we did. We finished everything.
author: Shasha Y.

description: Chef Chris Cosentino does not disappoint! The food and service here are spectacular - we tried the Blue Fin Tuna which my husband and I will remember and talk about for a very long time to come. Also had the bacon chop which was very juicy and delicious. Our servers and hosts were very nice and we even got to say hi to Chef Chris who was working and greeting guests. If you are a Top Chef fan (like me!), do yourself a favor and come here ASAP!
author: Linda R.

description:
Four words:  MAKE SURE YOU'RE HUNGRY.

Are you kidding me with these portions?  I took my boyfriend here for his birthday so it was a No-Holes-Barred experience.  Cocktails to start, appetizers, a bottle of wine and a ton of offaly good food.  (See what I did there?)

I'm going to get right into it.  After finding the front door (which is actually the side door, but who cares), we walked into a modern rustic space which was bustling and very lively for an early (6pm) Wednesday evening.  (I later found out they have one of the BEST happy hours in the city!)  After checking in, we were graciously escorted to our table on the second level which was quieter and more conducive to putting your face down and "pigging out".  (Meh meh meh ... You'll understand why I think that's funny in a minute ... )

Unfortunately, I can't remember what cocktails we had (It was a good night - what can I say?), but for an appetizer we ordered the Beef Heart Tartar with a raw egg.  I may have been a teeny bit apprehensive about the flavor before I tried it, but once I did, all fear and dignity flew out the window.  I scarfed down about half a cow's heart with some unfertilized chicken ova like nobody ever did before.  A bit gamy in the sense that it had a slightly metallic flavor, not quite as pungent as liver ... along those lines.  But I like liver too.  

Onto the mains.  It hurts a little bit to think about how much we ate and how rich it was but you'll get zero complaints from this gal because tasty, rich and filling was what we were going for.  And it was all very tasty.

We ordered the Chef's plate de jour, which was Foie Gras, Pig Trotters and Pickled Green Strawberries served with crostini.  Yes.  Everything you could wish for and more.  Foie Gras.  That is all.  No wait - that's not all because it was cooked to perfection and had the perfect Melt-In-Your-Mouth consistency.  The pig trotters reminded me of pulled pork but bathing in Foie Gras glory and then complimented by the tartness of the pickled green strawberries.  What?

Now onto the real main dish.  We ordered the Half a Roasted Pig's Head.  It's a shared supper - I would say for more than 2 people ... Possibly, OH about 6 to 8?  Yeah, I know.  What were we thinking?  It was huge.  I was obviously in denial about how big pigs can be.  This was NOT your everyday teacup variety.  But delicious!  It was like a huge platter of pork belly ... with a snout, teeth and a crispy fried ear.  Yum!  I think there was some salad on the platter ... But we didn't dabble in the frivolous items.  We took a LOT home and my wee maltese doggy had pig face for  d a y s.  (Don't judge me - She's 11yo and has earned it).  Btw, she's still VERY happy and has a clean bill of health.  No animals were harmed in the making of this review.

We had dessert too.  Something chocolate that we couldn't finish.  It was his birthday - I had to order cake!  Ugh.  I'm full thinking about it.  We stumbled out of there, said a quick hello and thank you to the Chef Extraordinaire and drove home as fast as we could so we could lay ourselves out to nurse our bulging bellies.

And that's about it.  We will go back for sure.  Probably with at least 4 more people so we can try the shared steak, the bacon chop and definitely everything else on the menu.  Thank you.  That is all.
author: Cindy H.

description: Stumbled upon this place looking for something close to the train station. Was immediately encouraged by the open kitchen and vibe. Food was excellent and service was top notch. A little pricey but the quality and the care taken to prepare the food was worth it. Was able to watch everything first hand. Definitely recommend it and will come back.
author: Gary S.

description: I reserved this spot for my gf's birthday and it was perfect. Originally I made a reservation for 9 via yelp, but we had two unexpected guests show up and the staff quickly brought out more seats to accommodate them. Since I've read about the pin steak and pig's head, those were going to be my go to. However they were out of the pig's head, so the server suggested I get the pork tenderloin special. She even suggested I order two of them to sufficiently feed everyone. Boy am I glad I listened to her, that dish was everyone's favorite! She also helped by communicating my intentions of doing everything family style, but turns out one of the unexpected guests at the other end of the table was a vegetarian and she took his additional order of salad. I loved that our server, Jasmine, didn't try to upswell the more expensive pin steak and was honest about how delicious the pork tenderloin was. Not only was she spot on with the dish suggestions and awareness of the entire party, she was honorable with gratuity. I didn't check of gratuity was included so left additional gratuity on accident, to which she kindly thanked me for but did not take since it was included. I'd definitely recommend this place for both large parties or a hip dinner date. I didn't even go into details about the drinks, but I hate writing reviews. I just thought Jasmine killed it so I'm taking time to write this.
author: Hutch K.

description: Loved the pigs head and pork ham burger. Def try grill cheese as well. Good bar with good atmosphere. Make reservation to make sure you get seated on time. Near soma so plenty of things to do afterward. Good drinks with better food. Will be back
author: Danny N.

description:
Dined here a couple of times and have been underwhelmed both experiences.  

It is rather pricey for the amount of food you get, and in my opinion the dishes have not been tasty.  I've tried the steak tartar (just okay), pigsear salad (nothing special), burger (egg is extra, and I don't like pork meat in a burger), the meatloaf (super super salty, and terrible), the pork chop (1/2 of it is inedible fat) and the steak (this was only decent, and I can seriously make a better steak myself. The carrot is undercooked). Each meal is always at least $50-60/ person, and I've always been disappointed! 

Not a fan, not going back.
author: Jenn L.

description: Great service.  Great food.  Hearty plates and potent drinks!  I heard the salad with crispy pig ears is the bomb, but it wasn't on he menu that nite. However our waiter asked Chef to fry some ears up for us special. We got a whole bowl of just ears and it was the BOMB!!! So good, thank you Chef.  We also ordered: Grilled cheese with duck egg and honey; "Hot Mess" with foie gras, pigs trotters, & figs; hamachi collar (it was humongous, as big as my shoulder); "ham"-burger; whole fish; chopped bacon; spaghettini; and for dessert, peach cobbler and creme brulee.  Savory dishes were piping hot and delicious, and desserts were awesome. The five of us stuffed , couldn't eat anymore went home with leftovers.  Definitely come back to try more creations.
author: Lisa W.

description: Their meaty dishes were excellent. I wish there were a more veggie appearance. However I would likely go back to enjoy more!
author: Chacha M.

description: Amazing meal!  Enjoyed everything, but must orders are the grilled cheese & the bacon chop.  Great ambiance and service (thanks Joshua!).  Our first visit, but we'll be back.
author: K H.

description:
The service, while average, is blunted by the splendid quality of food. I had the steak with black truffle oil and foie gras jus (daily special), and a delicious goose dish. Food is well-cooked and prepared, but suffers from a diversity of flavor. That is, if you're looking for a meaty dish with meaty sauce, this is the place. 

I would not recommend the roasted pig head. While it is novel, there is way too much fat to make for a proper meal, and barely any lean meat. Both of us felt sick after eating it, but it made for a fantastic photo op.
author: Shenglong G.

description:
This was such a great experience. I've been wanting to eat at a place with really great and fresh ingredients, and kept looking for a farm to table type feel. I made reservations to Cockscomb because of the great reviews, availability for a reservation, and also the fact it's owned by Chris Cosentino (rockstar chef). And it definitely did not disappoint. 

What we ordered:
- Shaved vegetables - I wanted something fresh and earthy, and that's exactly what I got. Shaved radishes, daikon, carrots, arugula etc. in a light vinaigrette. So delicious and light.
- Tombo ceviche - I loved the flavor in this dish. I reminded me a lot of a Thai dish with the very strong lime flavor with the Thai red pepper. Very delicious and fresh.
- Roasted milk fed chicken - The bf ordered this, and it was the "best chicken he's ever had". It was so juicy and flavorful. It also came with a side of asparagus, which complimented the chicken well.
- Coulette steak - loved my steak. Coming from Texas, it's hard for me to find good steak. It was very well cooked (medium-rare), and tender I could use my fork to cut it! I also really loved the vegetables it came with (radishes, pearl onions, etc.)
- Duck fat cauliflower - We were being pigs and our waitress had to tell us "this should be enough". But this was a great addition, and we were happy we made it! Very tender and flavorful. 

Overall, a really great meal. I think the other thing that impressed me about this place is that nothing was overly salted. I was almost expecting everything to be super salty, but everything was well seasoned and tasty. I will probably come back to try other dishes!
author: Stephanie K.

description: Finally tried this place, & I'm definitely coming back. We got the grilled cheese with duck egg & honey, foie gras special (with blueberry corn salsa), and the beef heart tartare. Everything was great, through my favorites were the grilled cheese and foie gras (which unfortunately was a special, so they don't always have it). I'm definitely coming back to try more.
author: Cici A.

description: Terrific food, great staff and excellent wine cellar. Highly recommend. The food has complex flavors and great presentation.
author: Tytus C.

description:
Small, lively, upbeat restaurant.  Pretty good drinks and service was great.
  
We had a party of 4 and we ordered a couple of little gems salad which was great and as a main entree we ordered the Pin Bone Steak.  We were sooo looking forward to devouring this delicious looking steak, only to find it super tough and hard to chew.  :/  It was perfectly cooked too (medium-rare) but I guess it's the cut of meat.  Not sure.  Oh well, I'm sure other things on the menu were good though.  I will give it a 3 for now.
author: Delilah B.

description: I liked the way they have done the interior. It's almost a warehouse kinda interior with concrete walls with a blend of very cosmopolitan decor. The setup is charming but bit noisy. The food we selected was well prepared although the variety is bit limited. Parking was easy to find due to the location near AT&T park. Service was excellent!
author: Arun N.

description: Absolutely love coming here !!! My only frustration is that we were asked by the manager that we would need to start ordering and be up and gone by 830 because they had another reservation coming in. I do understand that half of my party was late but we spent over $800 for my birthday dinner and I did not like feeling rushed . I have been in the restaurant business before so I understand the importance of reservations BUT when you spend that kind of money .... there should be no rush
author: Christina P.

description:
Nope. Just not good food. 

Bacon pork chop was disgusting, all fat, under-rendered, pretty much inedible. If this dish is intentional, yuck. If it was an accident, that is a huge error. Either way it was not good.

Pork belly salad was standard.

Steak was a 3/5. 

Pig skin pasta special was really unappetizing. Cool conception but not really focused on being edible or pleasant. Noodles were very thick cuts of rubbery pig skin. They were resting in a watery clam-sauce. Nope.  

Best item we tried was the vegetarian beet salad which is ironic given this is a meat-focused place.

Save your money. Go somewhere else.
author: Mike I.

description:
One of the best meals I've had in a long time!! And, got to meet and chat with Chef Chris Cosentino! Such a cool person! 

A gf and I ordered:

- Oysters on the half shell three different types of oysters with three different sauces. (Very surprised to see olive oil, it was delicious! The tomatillo sauce was good too!)
- Lardo & fig salad (best thing all night! Still dreaming about it!)
- Bacon chop - very big portions! We weren't able to finish all of it! But, in retrospect, I wish I took it home now!
- fire roasted eggplants (delicious) 
- desserts : Meyer lemon pannacotta, chocolate cake, and cheese apple tart?
- we got two fig cocktails too, and it was just alright. 

Will be returning soon!!
author: Cecilia N.

description:
We were having the best meal last night until the host came over to tell us that we had to leave because the next reservation was here. I understand that there are set reservations, but I have never been asked to leave a restaurant. At fine dining establishments (i.e. Gary Danko, Kokkari), I would still have to wait for the other party to finish up their meal or close their tab. Before that incident, I would have given this place 5-stars for the food and waitstaff service...

Here's my take before being asked to leave.
____________________________________________________

We took out our friends for a birthday and had an amazing meal. In addition to some drinks, we ordered the following items:

- Mussels and chips
- Foie Gras
- Gem salad
- Pin bone steak (split between 4)
- Asparagus

All were really good. The steak was high quality and cooked perfectly at medium rare. The Au Jus sauce and bone marrow dipping sauce complimented the meat nicely as well.
author: Christina C.

description: Amazing crab and lobster. Amazing quail and pork rib. Good Drinks. Top Service. If you love meat, this is a must try.
author: Brooke A.

description:
The location is convenient, easy to find; plenty of space; great service; the food is not amazing, but good - interesting selection of various appetizers and meats.

They are able to accommodate big groups, as they have multiple floors.  It wasn't loud like in some other places, and of course it wasn't completely quiet.

Overall, I'm glad that we visited this place.
author: P F.

description:
The place filled up rather quickly around the time we arrived.  We're glad we made reservations.  It's not too big of a place, but it has high ceilings and is very airy.

The Bacon Chop was the star of the evening. Cured/salted just right for eating as a pork chop.  We also had bone marrow which was a decent size as well as a meat pie.

We didn't have room for dessert or more cocktails but on future visits we hope to try more.  

I will also be coming back for the oyster happy hour special.
author: Ed G.

description:
(4.2) Service was attentive and friendly, and the interior is very cool with the wood-burning oven spitting out flames in the corner, alongisde the giant buffalo head up on the wall. The offal-themed (but plenty of other great menu items) restaurant is a great addition to SOMA - and the menu is quite unique and a lot of fun.

The heirloom tomato salad was excellent and I can definitely recommend - incredible freshness and great combination of texture.  The wines by the glass list was a bit light but 5 reds is probably adequate. The malbec was pretty weak though, the Turnbull acceptable, and although the Sanford Central Coast/Santa Rita Pinot Noir was very good - I would like to see it served in the proper pinot noir glass (this is SF after all - and an important personal crusade for me). 

Then, there is the (half?) Pig's Head for two coming in at $69. It was a great novelty and fun to take pictures of, however it was 80% pure, glistening fat - we were able to pluck a few solid pieces of pork face meat out of there that were leaner and quite smiley, but pretty much left most of it. I can't see spending that kind of money on that again - so be forewarned if you order it. It might be a better item as an additional dish for 4+ people for a unique experience - but then again a bit pricey for what you get out of it to actually enjoy.
author: Robert B.

description: My first time here after watching Chris chef/owner on tv.  I expected be be blown away and I was.  Seven of us  shared  2 orders of the following: the GRILLED CHEESE duck egg & honey, BEEF HEART TARTARE grilled bread & greens and PIG SKIN PUTTANESCA mint & pecorino for appetizers.  Then we dove into the BACON CHOP cabbage, red onion, pickled peppers & burnt lime  and the PIN BONE STEAK bone marrow dip.  We ended with 5 desserts and meat for all of us to take home.  Chef Chris was there watching the folks walk and walk out stuffed to the max but with a glorious glow of magnificent indulgence.  I will hold every piece of steak I eat from now on to the meat we ate tonight.  Bravo for a memorable meal.  Chris' dimples were the frosting.
author: Toby T.

description: LOL, everything here is done in excess. You think ordering something innocent like cauliflower would be healthy right? Nah, let's drizzle some duck fat on there. I didn't eat the rest of the week after going here, but was it worth it? To which I would retort with, is the sky blue?
author: John B.

description:
WHAT A JOKE.

Absolute worse dining experience I've had in SF. I love restaurant touring and I was so excited to come to this new "gem" that everyone on yelp was raving about!

The best thing I had all night was the bartenders "big trouble in little china" which she sweetly made for us even though it was off menu.

Not only did we have to wait an hour even though we had 9pm reservations, this table was empty next to us and was only offered to us after an hour of waiting.

All in all, major fail on their operational part. I get it, the restaurant business can be hard, I am in it myself. But what happened tonight was just unacceptable!!

After finally being seated, we stayed for 30 mins before leaving. Just could not wait to get out of there! 

Thank god I have reservations for Tosca Cafe to save the night. 

*** OH and if you plan on getting an Uber from here, forget it. We had to cancel two because no one could find the place while we were standing in the rain and cold.
author: Amber S.

description: Decent food and wine list, however the staff, especially the female bartenders (mainly a long haired brunette who I did not get her name) , are so rude and slow, I'm not going to waste my money here again.  I live in the neighborhood, and there are many better places.  For better service for sure, and possibly better food.    It's sad because i would expect more from chef cosentino, I have visited his other establishments, and have been more than thrilled.  It's sad that poor staff is bringing his name down.
author: Rebecca W.

description:
What an overall terrible disappointing experience. Unfortunately I understand Chris's fame level is to a point where he does not need to give two pennies about our terrible experience, but I will say, as a party of 6, with mixed ethnicities, I was amazed to be treated how we were in this day and age.

We had recommendations for 6 people at 8:45pm, we arrived at 8:30pm and were told to grab a seat at the bar.
