We live in different cities, and this dinner was the first time we had seen each other in several weeks, so the only common denominator was the meal we shared.  What was most disappointing was that the next day, we called the restaurant to inform them of our experience.  No one answered, so we left a detailed voicemail.  To this day no one has ever returned the call -- an inexcusable response to a serious complaint about food poisoning.  Diners beware!
author: Randall L.

description: This spot was delicious and the service excellent! Of course, we had the pig head but they had so many delectable options, it was hard to decide. We landed on the pig head, soft shell crab bruschetta, sweet breads, and mussels with chips. The pig head meat was so tender and the sweet breads were my favorite. It's a must try!
author: Lisa G.

description:
Just as many hits or misses. Great tight atmosphere, great cocktails.

- The mixed green salads tasted like a handful of weeds from the side of the highway. Bitter and yuck.
- The "daily droppings" sounded great.. got "hot mess" with trotters in a patty form with foie gras on top. Really disappointing.. salty patty, no particularly porky taste and a ho-hum foie gras topping
- The grilled oysters were a disappointment. We keep hoping for NO style, on the half shell and chargrilled with cheese and bread crumbs. These were not that.

The pluses were really positive
+ The quail was succulent and amazingly delicious
+ The grilled cheese. GOOD LORD. Simple dining? but so so amazing.
+ The bacon chop was an amazing pork steak, huge where we were sharing bites and everyone loved it.

Overall, for hot/hip this place seemed to be, I was a tad disappointed.
author: Wes D.

description: Extremely overpriced! Good ingredients but everything lacks seasoning, and it's just not all that. First of all, the restaurant is cold--stone, wood, industrial high ceilings, hard surface floors and an open front door. (Also a giant taxidermy, buffalo head overlooking the entire restaurant. Second, I bought lunch for my husband, 3 sons and me @ $165 including tax and tip which is ridiculous for 4 ala carte sandwiches, the coulotte steak lunch (a few slices of steak and a few wilted cabbagy type leaves w/blue cheese), 2 sides of potatoes and 2 sides of cauliflower, one miniature latte, and one dessert. My vegetarian son thought the impossible burger was the best vegetarian burger he's had. I am confident I could make a better one with zero wheat gluten, and rather...actual food (!) like portobello mushroom, grilled onion, porcini mushroom powder, decent seasoning, maybe a little grain, vegetable or nut flour, etc., instead... Anyhow, they have no seasoning there. Seriously. Everything needs salt and pepper, and some other seasoning e.g., fresh garlic, rosemary, tarragon, whatever! There's no salt and pepper on the table or apparently in the restaurant. I asked for pepper for my sliced coulotte steak (properly cooked), and not only no pepper grinder to be found but they had to scramble around the kitchen finally settling on a small soup bowl with 3/4 teaspoon of black pepper powder dumped in. I ordered a tall latte because it was freezing in the restaurant and they brought me a miniature teacup filled 3/4 full (tasty though!). Afterward, I asked if I could have a plain coffee refill. Nope. No coffee whatsoever. Except another miniature latte. For $165, five people could have had a field day at any number of lunch places. Spend your hard earned money elsewhere--for $33 each, at least a couple days worth of luscious homemade burritos in the Mission District...
author: Robin B.

description:
The stars I give are for the cocktails and the service (the first time we came).

Round 1: we ordered oysters, the pigs head, uni bruschetta and the "chocolate" dessert offering. The bruschetta and dessert amazing and so were our cocktails - the gin jam and some lavender thing. 
However- the pigs head was one of the worst dishes I have ever eaten. Almost all fat, barely any meat and what meat there was did not taste good. For $65 definitely skip. Oysters ok. 

Round 2: cocktails great again. The strawberry rhubarb gin jam was the best cocktail I've ever had. The mussels were by far not the best I've had, crudo was very mediocre, and the asparagus was average. The grilled cheese, however, was excellent. The duck egg worked really well with it. 

Would not come again. Sorry guys.
author: Maille K.

description:
Great service from start to finish.  Music was a little loud and acoustics of the room amplified everything else.  But not to the point that it was a big negative.  Decor was pleasant, understated.

The menu selections made it easy to share just about everything but one could order individually just about as easily.  We had:

Little Gems - Good but missed the pig's ears!
Country Pate - Not a stand-out but solid nonetheless
Marrow - Solid but portion was on the small side
Mussels & Chips - I don't care for mussels (gross!) but the chips in aioli sauce was good
Bruschetta - This came with pickled quail meat - I wasn't a big fan but everyone else loved it
Meat Pie - Ok, but I didn't really get to try enough to form a real opinion.
Pin bone steak - It's really 3 or 4 cuts of meat.  The tenderloin was good, the sirloin was hit and miss.  It came with the wood oven asparagus which was very good.
We had three desserts of which the panna cotta was the best.

I'd give it another try if just for the Bacon Chop and Surf n' Turf which included pork belly and rock crab.
author: Michael L.

description:
I really want to like this place - we live so close and it smells so good when we walk by. Like Zuppa used to, the restaurant that preceded it.

But, my boyfriend and I have been here a few times now and it's just...underwhelming. We ordered the duck fat cauliflower to start, which was undercooked. I make allowances for different textural preferences but I just don't think a cooked cauliflower dish should be crunchy in a raw way. The flavors are great, and we've replicated it amazingly in our own kitchen (subbing in bacon fat; bacon is better - long live bacon!), but almost raw cauliflower is a deal breaker for us.

For the main course, I ordered the Zambini sausage plate, and my boyfriend ordered the oyster omelet. My sausage was raw in the middle - is this a thing now? I love a nice, rare steak but seriously, my sausage needs to be fully cooked. It was hard to cut through the casing because it wasn't cooked. And, I could overlook this even, but the sausage also didn't really have a flavor. (Not to get nostalgic but Zuppa had some awesome fennel sausage - so flavorful, so delicious, so cooked! I was a vegan when I tried their sausage and it blew my mind right back into being an omnivore. Why can't you blow my mind, Cockscomb?).

The side of coleslaw of great, though - just the right balance of creamy and tart, with a little spiciness - and I don't even like coleslaw. 

My boyfriend's omelet was fine, he liked the texture but felt like it was missing something. For people on the fence about oysters, this is not for you - there is a lot of oyster in this.
author: Brooke T.

description:
I came here super excited to try everything but was disappointed - it was definitely not worth the price. The ambiance was really nice and cozy (came here on a double date with an old friend) but the food itself felt thrown together and underwhelming. 

We had the: scotch oysters (the outer shell was very... meaty? tasted good but not amazing), oyster omelette (tasted somewhat spicy and probably my favorite of the meal), duck fat squash (definitely had a "kick" to it and wasn't bland at all - liked that one), and the shared surf and turf.

I guess since the Surf and Turf was the "main course" of the meal, a lot of my evaluation was based on it. We were told that there was only one left and after a minute of discussion, we frantically flagged down the waiter and told him we'd take the last one. It came with a giant slab of pork belly and a crab. Kind of an alternative version of your usual steak and lobster.

Except usually the lobster comes with all of its bits. We only got an empty crab shell and a few legs. The pork belly was very fatty - which was good but it was unbalanced in proportions toward the pork belly. And that much pork belly is simply really really hard to eat. We all were a bit disappointed when we turned over the crab shell to find that the best part of the crab wasn't even there. 

Maybe we should have gotten the shared 4 lb steak. That actually looked incredible.
author: Sylvia L.

description:
Service and food were seamless. Jose serving the digestifs was icing on the offal cake! Not a misstep in the place...from the moment we entered until we walked out the door, we felt like guests. 

Been back again since I started this review. Same comment=consistency.

You either crave the menu or you don't. So, find out what all the buzz is about already.
author: Ron G.

description:
this was a great experience, but it's definitely a place for an occasional visit, the meat is awesome and inventive, but it's a LOT of meat. they've added oysters to the menu which is a great way to start off.

we also had bruschetta (it changes daily I think) which was awesome, the bone marrow, and we were curious enough, from the other reviews, to try the pig's head. it was definitely worth a try and a unique experience, but as noted elsewhere, there is a ton of fat to poke through to find the meat. we also had roasted carrots which were very good. and the panna cotta for dessert.

corkage was a very reasonable $25 per bottle (max 2 bottles)

the atmosphere was lively, a bit crowded and noisy but not in a negative way. our waiter was fantastic, friendly and attentive.

I'll come back for sure, but need to clean out my arteries with a few salads first :)
author: Bob U.

description: We got someone who was training so service was slow. Even though we made a reservation, we were seated at the bar, which I found uncomfortable despite there being almost all open tables. The impossible burger was interesting and better than the "ham"burger (made of pork). Although both were a bit overpowered by the toppings. The highlight were the potatoes which were perfectly cooked and seasoned. I was most disappointed by the sticky toffee pudding dessert which was more of a dry cake and took a really long time to be brought out.
author: Christine T.

description:
Been looking forward to eating here ever since it opened, and finally got a chance to try it last night.  We got:
- Uni brushetta (5/5) - uni, uni spread, radishes, and greens on grilled bread.  Really nice balance of flavors and textures and probably our favorite dish of the night.
- Grilled cheese (4/5) - nice mixture of sweet and salty, between the honey and the perfectly gooey egg.  Actually, the cheese was a little lost.  Really good, but didn't quite live up to the hype.
- Bacon chop (3.5/5) - do not order this unless you really like fat (like i do).  It's a pretty big chop, and i made the mistake of starting on the larger, meaty end, where the lean meat was.  The lean portion of the chop just tasted like an average pork chop, unfortunately.  That part is a 3/5 at most.  The good stuff is all of the fatty goodness surrounding the meat.  This part is a 4/5.  Definitely make sure to focus on this part.
- Quail tetrazzini - tried a few bites of my girlfriend's quail, and it tasted amazing, with a rich, creamy sauce.  From the small taste, this seemed to be better than the bacon chop.

The restaurant is slightly on the louder side, but the service was great, and we really enjoyed the whole experience.
author: Simon L.

description:
I really really wanted to like this place because I'm a fan of Chris Cosentino. But, sadly it wasn't meant to be. The steak was over cooked, the bacon porkchop was over cooked and was served room temperature, the broccoli rabe was sour, the carrots were cooked on the outside and raw inside, the bone marrow was still pink inside. 

2 stars goes to management though, they listened to us and apologized for the situation and comped the bone marrow and vegetable. They gave free dessert, but that was mediocre too :( 

The grilled cheese with honey and shaved truffle was good though. 

Oh, and also, what's up with the paper straws? You should get rid of that.
author: Gia C.

description: This place was fantastic!  The moment you walk in the door you can't wait to eat, it smells so good inside.  What you smell is what you get , everything tastes so incredibly fresh and yummy.  I loved the ambience, lighting was perfect.  We really had a great time and can't wait to go back.
author: Heather N.

description: Chris Constantine is amazing.  I followed him to In Canto and sampled the Leg of Beast.  Now at Cock's Comb.  The service is great.  Alicia served me a "Boothy" which hit the spot and took me. "There" in fantastic fashion.  For dinner we had everything and love the flavors.
author: Rice Farmer O.

description:
Best Restaurant EXPERINCE EVER!!! The food is awesome as you might expect. I can't say anything that hasn't already been said about it. The Bone Marrow is don't miss dish as is the Beef Heart Tartare. The Restaurant is as welcoming as the Staff and the warm open Wood Fired Kitchen is a perfect place to spend your evening. If your lucky enough to get a seat across from the grill you get to see and smell every dish. 

   Chef was nice, never actually heard of him before, but he said he was "Famous and stuff". Just kidding, Chef Cosentino was humble, helping his staff provide the best food/service you could ask for. He spoke with us throughout the meal, he was excited about what he's doing at Cockscomb and it was our pleasure to be his Guest. 

  Take two things away from this review,

1) Eat the oyster with Bone Marrow.
2) Mash the Meat Pie crust into the pie.

  The one thing you don't take away from Cockscomb is Chef's ceramic Pie Bird you thieving degenerates!
author: Doug R.

description: Def on my top fave SF restaurants on my book. I've taken so many friends here and have come back too many times. Ambience of this place is very cool. It's a loud place but good enough to talk with people you're with. The Pin Bone Steak is just delish, especially with that bone marrow dip! (I love me some meat!) Have had the bacon chop here twice--the first time was ehhh...the second time around was really good. It was tastier than it was the first time. Not sure why or if they changed something with the recipe. Another taker for this place: late at night on weekdays (M-F 10 to 11), they have happy hour drinks and a late night menu for food, that include $1 raw oysters and a few other selections. One of my faves during happy hour aside from the oysters are the crispy pig ears! Def a must try!
author: Elke S.

description: I brought the whole family.  Everything was delicious and outstanding. The Chef was cool as hell! Took a picture with my kids and chatted us up a bit. We will be back!
author: Phil B.

description:
I've been following this place, online,  since Chris Cosentino announced the grand opening.  I figured my best bet to get in, w/o a reservation, was a Monday evening and I was right.  I slid in to a seat at the bar without a wait.  I started off with the daily special of steam mussels ($8 that night).  They were fresh and a good size and portion.  The sauce was a simple butter and white wine from what I could tell and wasn't distracting from the mussels themselves.  Since foie gras is now legal in SF I had to get an appetizer that contained that.  I was recommended to try the "Hot Mess" (picture uploaded) and my mouth is still drooling over this.  It sounded a bit funky but the taste was amazing.  The Hot Mess is grilled sour dough bread covered with strawberry jam/preserves, topped with grilled foie gras, smothered in melted duck fat (and I think some duck meat, but I'm not sure on that).  Granted mine wasn't as picturesque as some of the others I've seen posted here on yelp but that didn't detract from the flavor.  Was a meal, a desert, or both?  I'm not sure but it was damned good.  I decided not to get another Hot Mess but instead try something different and went for the Quail Tetrazzini.  It looked like the smallest, size wise, entry I could order as I was getting full from the 2 appetizers but wanted the chance to try one more thing before I called it for the night.

I loved the open kitchen concept as well as the farm to table style dishes.  For a new, trendy place in SF the prices weren't outrageous and I think fell in line with the quality of the food.  

This place is about the food - the quality, the freshness, and the vegetable pairings.
author: Ben F.

description:
I really wanted to love cockscomb, given all the amazing reviews and awesome menu.

I arrived for my reservation at 8:45 for the bar on a Saturday night--the hostess was very polite and directed us to the bar to wait for our seats and said it would be about 10-15 minutes. We ended up waiting an entire hour, and they didn't offer us any comp on our drinks or a free app or anything. The hostess was apologetic, and we know it wasn't her fault, but that was extremely frustrating. During this time, they sold out of the pin bone steak, which we were hoping to order. Extra frustrating.

We ended up ordering the 1) eggs eggs eggs, 2) sea urchin bruschetta, 3) bacon chop and 4) pig skin spaghetti.
1) eggs, eggs, eggs would have been great but the minute we cut into the egg, the yolk stared back at us - fully cooked, not runny at all. What a total bummer.
2) They gave us the wrong bruschetta, but at this point we were so hungry that we weren't going to wait for them to get the order right. This was pretty good though.
3) bacon chop was disappointing, pretty bland
4) pig skin spaghetti - we barely finished half - would say skip this completely.

I think this restaurant has potential, and I would have given it 3 stars were it not for the horrible wait and lack of thoughtfulness in the service. Will say the atmosphere is really nice and the seats at the chef's counter are really well done. But next time you find yourself waiting hungrily at the bar, head down the street to Marlowe.
author: Nancy Y.

description:
We've been to Cockcomb twice.  Both times we were walk ins. The first time we sat downstairs in the dining room, on the counter near the cooking station.  Service was attentive, and the food was amazingly delish.  Loved the beef heart tartare, the eggs eggs eggs and the uni and Laredo bruschetta.  A great meal.  5 stars.

The second time we were there (last night), we sat upstairs in the overlooking bar area.  The bartender/server was harried and surly, and her overall demeanor was kind of "what do you want?"  In sharp contrast to the service downstairs.  

An overhead pipe dropped condensation on us throughout the meal.  We pointed it out and received glares from the bartender.  

The eggs eggs eggs was still very good, but we wished the meat pie had just a bit less organ and a bit more muscle.  

I definitely want to return, but will actively avoid sitting in the upstairs bar area next time.  For the price you pay, the service is pretty poor.
author: Lorin Y.

description:
We were excited to try out the new restaurant from Chef Chris.  Arrived about 5 minutes early and was seated promptly.  Water selection was asked by two of the staff and then we waited.  We waited while a two top was seated next to us, waiter came by to tell them the details regarding the menu and get their drink order.  Mind you, this was almost 10 minutes after we were seated and wasn't even approached by anybody.  

I flagged the server down and asked him to go over the menu because there were a couple of items that needed explaining.  Then I felt like our order taking was rushed as well, as shown by the missing duck fat cauliflower that I had ordered.  

After that though, the service did pick up once the food arrived.  The food was great,  from the beef heart tartare to the duck liver terrine.  We shard the meat pie which was really good.    The two top had the bacon steak which looked amazing, but they were complaining about there being too much fat... Um hello.. It's bacon!  

If we had more people in our party, we would have tried either the pigs head or the pin bone steak.  Other things to try would be the tripe or the bone marrow plate or the grilled cheese or baked oysters.  

Food: 4 stars
Service: 3 stars
Ambiance: 5 stars

3.5 stars rounded up to 4.
author: Herb C.

description: It took 90 minutes from arrival for entrees to arrive. The waiter gave the drinks to the wrong people, then redistributed to the correct people despite sips having already been taken. The "Ham" Burger was slathered in strong mustard and way too salty, more like something I'd expect at a ball park. Inedible, for my palate. Waiter couldn't remember who was drinking which type of water, and put someone else's plate in front of me before then needing to correct himself. Fine for a Denny's, not so much for a supposed high-end restaurant.
author: Christopher M.

description:
Have been drooling over my MacBook wanting to try this place for quite some times now and we finally got to try it on Monday. It was awesome that we walked straight in and got seated for 4 right away. We got in at around 6 and didn't leave the restaurant until 9 something, which is why the review is only 4 stars. I was not expecting to be at dinner for 3 hours! 

The service was great because they honored all of our needs with no problem. The 4 of us shared the pig's head, oh boy, was it greasy. Even though it was greasy and was as expected, that head was cooked to perfection and EVERY bite is that perfect bite of fall off the bone/melts in your mouth goodness. Besides the pig's head that I recommend everyone to try it at least once in your life, we ordered the pate, bone marrow and steak. The pate is just whatever, could have skipped that. Bone marrow was good, but definitely shouldn't be ordered with the pig's head because of grease overload in your palate. The steak was cooked to perfection as well, would definitely go back to order that again!
author: Nikole X.

description: Came from ANNAPOLIS Maryland.  We missed incanto last time we were here in 2014.  Thanks for coming back guys!  The beauty is we are headed to Carmel in a few days and we have enough leftovers for dranks and picnic pork belly!
author: Matty J.

description: I've always wanted to eat here and decided to come tonight.  I really wanted to try the pin steak which is very visually appetizing.  However, the portions for it was more for 4 people and I just came with my date.  We order the lamb shoulder and this was also incredibly delicious.  The Chef behind the kitchen did an INCREDIBLE job firing off the dishes.  My boyfriend and I decided to sit at the counter by the kitchen to watch the food being made and from the Chef to all the Sous Chefs in the kitchen, you can see they all worked incredibly well as a team.  The great thing about it is watching how they all worked to put the dishes together.  My favorite was the grilled cheese, duck fat cauliflower, lamb, and the special they had that night for the appetizer which is a tripe dish.  Now this tripe dish was like no other and nothing like what you think tripe would be.  Because it was so appetizing for a cut of meat that most people would not order, my hats go off to the Chef for putting it on the menu.  This is a place that if you are a risk taker and adventurous with eating, you must come and try the dishes on the menu.  Every item we ordered was well seasoned and cook to perfection.  I would return to try the pin steak dish. One of the better culinary experience I have encountered.  On top of the great food, our wait staff was awesome making sure out water glasses were refilled and our waiter, Ian was so knowledgeable about the food and wine.  I will definitely be returning.  The only thing I was bummed out was not being able to see Chris Cosentino there.  With or without him, his team of Chefs ran a tight ship.  I hope he checks his Yelp reviews because if he was reading this, he needs to pay his Chefs more money.  They did a fabulous job as I witnessed sitting at the kitchen counter at my dining experience.
author: Mary P.

description: I was excited to eat here but ended up being disappointed. Staff was very unfriendly and we didn't get a "welcome" feeling while there. There is a big mix up with our reservation and I couldn't understand the host and what he was saying. The food was average (had the bacon/pork and dirty potatoes) and we weren't impressed. I'd like to try the Impossible Burger but they only have it for lunch.
author: Nancy P.

description: The space is rustic, urban and cool. Subtle, understated but still sophisticated. Chris is a master chef and Oliver is one of the best operators in the game. This is a must see spot in SF.
author: Michael F.

description:
I scanned the menu, squinting, and found only 2-3 vegetarian dishes. My stomach sank with disappointment. Sigh.

However, I'm pleased to say that I ended up ordering the Greens and the Grilled Cheese and both ended up being absolutely delicious. While both seem boring on the surface, Cockscomb makes them slightly fancier and delightful. The Grilled Cheese was on two large pieces of fluffy brioche and had a healthy amount of truffle shavings paired with honey. Who knew you could be eating a meal and something dessert-y at the same time??

4 stars because of the lack of vegetarian options. But, hey, if you're coming here you're probably not coming for the vegetables ;)

P.S. The restaurant itself is very cute. The 3 other girls I was with agreed.
author: Aditi J.

description:
Food is always consistent and awesome! The tartare is always on point.  The pig skin carbonate was bomb!  The sauce was so rich that I could lick the sauce off the plate if I can. We shared the lamb amongst us 4 with plenty of left over.   The meat was fall off the bone good.   Fish heart Spagettini was ok, i thought it needed more flavor.  Dessert was the chocolate chip cookie that my boys loved.  It was warm with a little hint of salty & sweet and an ice cream to top it off.

Service was good but I felt she was too attentive that it felt pushy.  That's why I only gave it 4 stars but we'll definitely come back.  

Our bill was $270ish.  5 dishes + 1 dessert + 2 beer + 1 lemonade.
author: Michelle T.

description:
Crunchy pigs ears, tripe, and tasty pig face. Yesss!

Can't wait to return. High five, Chef Cosentino =)
author: J A.

description: Came here to celebrate my friend's birthday. We had fresh oysters, their grilled cheese, cauliflower and another dish that was equally delicious that I can't remember. They were a tad more expensive on their oysters than I expected but they had a good variety which I liked. Not many oyster bars have a variety and it was refreshing. I'd come again for a special occasion.
author: Linda L.

description: the pinbone steak was super delicious, 3 of us shared it with plenty to take home. Love the ambiance and the mushroom side dish was spectacular.
author: Chito C.

description: Chris Cosentino artfully blends great food, cocktails and fun ambience. He tastefully demystifies offal cuisine. We had the tuna collar collar and duck bruschetta ( specials for the night) the first time we visited. We returned with a bigger group and we bravely ordered the pin bone steak. Fully satisfied both times.  Great spot for small or medium sized parties. OTHER MUST TRY  ITEMS: Tombo ceviche, Butcher's choice
author: aj s.

description:
It was our first time to Cockscomb.  When I learned that Cockscomb's menu was by Chris Cosentino, I knew that we needed to eat there.  With a couple of clicks I was able to make reservations online from their website. 

Never knowing what traffic was like getting into the city, my wife and I arrived an hour early for our reservations. The hostess greeted us and surprised us by seating us at the "chef's table" (so cool).  We had front row seats, and got to watch a star chef Chris and his crew put on a great culinary show.  All the dishes looked amazing, but we had to decide.

* Gin & Tonic - a must starter  
* Hot Mess (foie gras) - super yummy
* Bacon Chop - delicious
* Side of Caulifower - great

My favorite was when Chef Chris tells one of the cooks to leave some meat on the bone so that the customers can grab it and go "caveman style" on it.  When you see how massive some of the dishes were, you would understand.  We are definitely fans. We will be back.
author: P L.

description: A few weeks ago I was having the "if you were on death row what would your last meal be?" conversation. I couldn't think of the perfect answer, until now. I have never sounded so pretentious while eating food, but holy shit that was the best steak I have ever eaten. Please live with me and cook every meal until I die. Thank you.
author: Shai F.

description:
In the 6 weeks Cockscomb has been opened I've visited 3 times, with small and large groups.  The experience has been consistency awesome.

The service, ambiance and food are all excellent - some of the best meats in town!  Definitely order the Pinbone steak and the grilled cheese.

As an FYI, for those that want a little quieter ambiance, definitely request the upstairs.
author: Robert P.

description: I loved the atmosphere and the menu is great, my only complaint is that the food was very salty.  I have been twice and both times I would have loved the food had there been less salt.
author: Michele A.

description:
We went here the weekend after their grand opening and it was amazing. We were seated right away on the ground level and had a good view of the rest of the restaurant. Overall, the service was great as was the food. 

We started off with the Duck Liver Terrine. Pate is one of my favorite, and this pate is probably one of the best that I've had in SF so far. I wish they gave more bread with it though. 

We followed that plate with the Bone Marrow Mixed Grill. This plate included bone marrow from a lamb, a pig, and a cow. It was shared between four of us, so we weren't able to get much, but the bits we did get were very satisfying.

We finished our meal with two supper items: the Bacon Chop and the Bavette Steak. 
The Bacon Chop was much too fatty for our taste. The first few bites were very good, but we were not able to finish it due to the amount of fat on it. The Bavette Steak was cooked just right and added to our already full stomachs. 

We were very satisfied with the savory items we've ordered, so we decided to splurge on the dessert menu and ordered all four items. The cheese plate was my personal favorite. The waiters were very amicable and offered us free cocktail pairings with all of the desserts. The additional kindness made the desserts even more delicious.
author: Linda P.

description:
The food here is absolutely delicious. We started with steamed mussels - simple, but elegant. Then I got a main dish of bacon chop, which is pork chop with the bacon part still on it, with brusselkraut, onion and apple on the side - amazing!! It was a huge portion size as well - I brought half of it home to have for lunch the next day. And finally for dessert, we split both the 'chocolate' and the 'classic'. The chocolate is a chocolate cake that resembles a Pimm cookie, with hints of orange and cookie in it. The classic is a crepe cake with marmalade in between. Both are absolutely wonderful. 

Service was really good. The wait staff was really on its game - folding napkins when one goes to the bathroom, filling up your water consistently, and checking in to make sure everything is going smoothly. The ambiance of the restaurant was really nice, but it was VERY loud. I didn't detract a star because the food was SO good, but really - you almost have to yell to hear anything. Pricing isn't terrible (unless you get the pig's head or the oyster super-combo - but those are all shareable).

Free parking can be an issue at night, but there are a few $15 parking lots nearby (a few blocks of a walk). It's also really close to the Caltrain station, for what it's worth. 

Would definitely go again!
author: Alexandra G.

description:
Slid in a last-minute reservation here - this place is great! Our server was chill yet attentive, and very knowledgeable - with her help we picked out some butcher's choice items - like trotter rillete topped with foie gras and pickled greens (omg amazing), and a pigskin spaghetti (vinegary, chewy, and delicious), quail, a massive bacon chop, and some chard to cut through the fattiness. The chard was *very* lemony, so it did it's job but wasn't my absolute favorite. 

This is definitely not an everyday place to hit up for me, but I loved it and have no qualms about coming back. This would be great for a group of adventurous eaters to grab a pig's head or maybe an order of that delicious-looking pin bone steak I saw the table next to us devour.
author: Miriam W.

description: Best dinner I've had in a very long time. We had the pin bone steak (huge!), spaghettini, roasted beets, asparagus, and grilled cheese. The food and the service were incredible, and the gin drinks....wow!
author: Alison B.

description: One word describes my experience: AMAZING! The boo and I went there to celebrate my birthday, so ordered the huge steak to share and omg was it huge! We did a pretty good job though, but that definitely can feed 4-6 people easily.  The banana creme pie was out of this world too!  Definitely coming back for the other dishes!
author: Mei C.

description:
Wow, I am still full. 
Congrats Chris on yet another success. 
If you are vegan or vegetarian, as with all of Chris's restaurants, just consider drinking or eating beforehand, however, if you are prepared to eat like a king, come hungry.
Staff are wonderful as are the dishes and drinks. 
As an east coast southerner, I was most excited about the country ham of course. 
Could eat it with just about anything and for any meal. Yum and thank you!
author: Fins L.

description: Cockscomb is a great place to go with a small group of friends. I was too ambitious and shared the pig's head between two people and we were sadly defeated. Make sure to try the "Hot Mess" for a delicious dose of foie and pig trotter and get the truffle grilled cheese. Oh, and there's a seafood bar with a fresh selection of oysters and such. Go nuts. Coming back to try the pin-bone next time, but trying to round up the troops to conquer the next meal together. Closed Sundays, because Chris Cosentino is human and he needs a day off too, you know.
author: Helen Z.

description: Chris Cosentino can do no wrong. I had a great time with pig parts at Incanto, and I had another solid experience at Cockscomb. Service is difficult to come by at the bars downstairs and upstairs, so I recommend a reservation to get tableside service. You already know what you need to get - bacon chop, eggs, eggs, eggs, uni, bone marrow. Throw in some broccoli rabe or other veggies to round your meal out, and you're in heaven. If you have a large group, get the pig's head. Their bread is toasted lightly and buttered heavily to accompany your eggs and seafood. The bone marrow is succulent and fatty, and the pig parts are as flavorful as ever. Food comes out quickly, even if service might be hit-or-miss. You know you're going to shell out though, so keep the alcohol orders low if you want to experience as much food as possible. Cocktails are well-made, though, so get at least one. Or two. Whatever.
author: Danny C.

description: Interesting restaurant w inventive meat choices. Well-prepared foods w large entree portions. Fairly noisy atmosphere.
author: Jim K.

description:
Everyone is raging about it but it doesn't mean that it's good. We of course had the Pig's Head as the waiter was raging about it.We were expecting more "carnitas" or "fall of the bone and into my mouth" pig. At first we thought we just kept getting large pieces of fat but really it was just pig pudding. The texture was very off but I just think the dish wasn't that good. I'm an adventurous eater and appreciate and like almost anything. After all my adventures in the world, I just thought this wasn't that good. i guess that's why there were no other tables ordering it. 

Drinks were great and so were the appetizers.
author: Enoch L.

description: Great ambiance and loved sitting at the cook line, reasonably priced. Only criticism is that the food was over seasoned with way too much salt.
author: Philip G.

description: Friends said this place was great so we tried it out.   I wasn't really impressed.  There isn't much variety on the menu (lots of slabs of meat) and the food wasn't that great and really, really salty.   Also very, very expensive for what it was - $600 for four people.   Waitress was also dismissive and abrupt.
author: Dawn T.

description: There are a lot of hyped restaurants in SF. Michelin stars and Bon Appetit top spots, but Cockscomb should be at the top of every list. Perfectly executed fantastic food. No missed opportunities or good ideas that never quite materialize. Do yourself a favor and skip the bird spot or someone's place and come here. The service is fantastic and the food is sublime. Just go. You can thank me later.
author: laila p.

description: I love this place! One of the best meals I've ever had. Order the grilled cheese!!
author: Katie A.

description:
The food here is amazing.  It is really pricey, but every bit is so delicious.  Not enough vegan options, though. They can take 2 out of the 4 ingredients out of the beet main dish and it is vegan, but it is $22! They should turn it into a more complete vegan main dish rather than just remove the ingredients or lower the price.  The kale salad is perfect, full of seeds and a really nice dressing, which I believe is different as a vegan option. The portions were good, too.  

I called to order the Impossible Burger to take out and they said the only served it in the restaurant.  I made a reservation and sat down to order it and it wasn't on the menu. The waiter said they only serve it for lunch.  I thought I'd come on a Saturday, then thought there might be a weekend restriction and sure enough, they only serve it M-F.  Really?  He said they have a contract with the creators of it and they are only allowed to sell it then and that only 4 or 6 places (I forgot the exact number) in the world are allowed to sell it right now.  Geez!  So, if you don't know about it yet, it is supposed to be a vegan (or vegetarian with cheese) burger that tastes and looks and feels like a meat burger.  I am a vegan for health reasons.  I miss meat so much. The promise of tasty meat-like products like this is such a great thing.  For my fellow vegans, I also found out the Jardiniere on Grove Street sells it in the evenings. 

For you meat eaters, they have amazing shellfish options and probably the best meat dinners you can get anywhere.  The kitchen is open.  That is cool.  They have a wood smoker oven, so go and wrap yourself in the sights and smells of foodie heaven.  The chef is a star, for sure, but please put more vegan options on the menu?
author: Lisa G.

description:
Nifty atmosphere within walking distance of AT&T park in an odd little neighborhood. I made a reservation here with no real knowledge of it, just some good Yelp! recommendations. Glad I did. Excellent wine list accompanied some great eclectic dishes. I had the Quail Tetrazzini. It was different than any I have had before but oh so tasty. The traditional noddles from a Tetrazzini dish were replaced with fideos, a Spanish noodle that's a little shorter and was cooked aggressively al dente.  Yum. My friend had the daily special and while I don't remember what it was, I do remember a jealous smile and a clean plate.

I would absolutely recommend.
author: Bill B.

description:
I really enjoyed this place.

Highlights:

Pigs head.  If you enjoy meat candy pig skin, and delicious fatty head meat, go for this.  well worth the money but really big.  Split with at least 3 people if not 4 or more.

The Bruschetta was fabulous.

I would skip the pig skin spaghetti.  

The grilled cheese was good. 

The Steak and meat pie where also good as well!

ENJOY!
author: BRIAN T.

description: Went for the head to tail dinner, and left with a rather poor experience.  Food was at best average, and at worst not consumable.  The entree we were served was an inedible piece of fat (0 out 5 people at the table could eat it).  Cocktails were solid, and service was friendly, but not attentive--I mean when 5 barely entrees are picked up without the server or chef checking in, that tells you something about the poor quality control.  For the amount we paid that evening ($140/person), we could have had a significantly better meal and experience elsewhere.  Needless to say, I won't be going back or recommending to anyone!
author: Art B.

description:
I went there with my fiancee and my mom and I have to saw, we were all disappointed, we were not blown away as expected.

Oysters - No complaints there.
Pate - It was good but very bland, not well seasoned, bread that came with it was really good.
Uni Bruschetta - This was my personal highlight, it was absolutely delicious!
Grilled Cheese - This was hyped by a coworker of mine as the best grilled cheese he's ever had so I gave it a try. It was very pedestrian, nothing special and the truffle really didn't add anything. I make a better grilled cheese myself. For $16, I expected something much better.

Pig Skin Pasta - Was served lukewarm, my mom had to ask for it to get it reheated. It was interesting but really wasn't great, flavors weren't very apparent. At the end of the day I would expect a good bowl of pasta but it wasn't great.
Quail Tetrazzini - Quail was really good! But the pasta served with it was like dried strands of spaghetti that felt more like a garnish than an entree. Good flavor.
Bacon Chop - I found it dry and tough, tasted good but again, nothing special.

It was a good meal but we expected a lot more, especially at this price point.
author: Nic B.

description: This was a great experience. It was my wife's birthday dinner and we ended up ordering the Wood Roasted Pig Head as we had not seen this on any other menu. It was excellent and along with the gnocchi, duck fat cauliflower, foi gras starter and desserts, it may for a memorable night. Great service and cozy industrial atmosphere. Can't wait to go back with other members of our foodie family. They were jealous!
author: Cliff L.

description: Food was above average. Atmosphere was fun and trendy. Waitress was pushing the entrees over $100 a plate, but was knowledgable and present. It sorta made me want to be a vegetarian? I left feeling guilty about my omnivore eating habits. Too much meat and pig heads/ears for me.
author: Maggie S.

description: Roasted pig's head with "brainase" ..... this is my kind of place!
author: Megan M.

description:
I came here with friends without any expectations, and man, I was completely blown away by the food and the drinks. Chris Cosentino is a solid top chef and his food is a true testament of his talents.

My friends and I ordered drinks as soon as we were seated.  Sweet November is an unforgettable cocktail so much so that I've been trying to recreate it at home! Now on to the food.  Everything we ordered was so rich (in a good way) and delicious.  It was very MEAT heavy, but that's what this restaurant is known for, right?

Eats:
+ Country Pate:  So yummmmy.  I'd come here everyday just to eat this.  Pistachios in my pate? YES PLEASE!
+ Country Ham: Served with chicharrones.. basically pork on pork but the asian pear was a great contrast to the saltiness of the ham and the chicharrones.
+ "Ham"Burger w/ Egg and Foie Gras:  This dish could very well feed at least 2 people.  When I ordered this, I thought I was going to get a juicy beef patty but boy, was I wrong.  "Ham" = lamb.  It was cooked well, although, I should have left out the foie as it got a little overwhelming after a few bites.
+ Bacon Chop: Disclaimer: not actual bacon, but a HUGE portion of thick cut pork.  It was tender and well seasoned.  My friend was surprised at the size of the meat and ended up portioning it out to 3 others.  Besides the pork, the true highlight was the charred onions.  They had a lot of flavor and paired well with the pork.
+ Cornish Game Hen:  My favorite dish of the night.  It was juicy and the pomegranate sauce was amazing!  Everything about this dish was well balanced.. the taste, the textures, and the color of the ingredients. 

I definitely would come back here again just to try their other menu items, perhaps be a little more daring.
author: Anne D.

description: A must go to for any foodie out there. All the sides and veggies are awesome. I would try to take at least a group of six as you will want to try everything. Skip the oysters and go straight for the meats!
author: Pete H.

description: Food was fantastic - we had the special, which was pork loin and dungeons crab. We sat at the bar facing into the kitchen and watching the chefs work was nearly a show in and off itself - what a talented crew!  Would definitely recommend to others.
author: Amanda C.

description: A little underwhelming to be honest. Service was spotty and the food was just okay.
author: Christy C.

description: Exactly what you'd expect from Chef. It's right up his ally. Various "non traditional" aka my favorite sorts of meat. We came for the roasted pigs head but they stopped serving it unfortunately. They hold a few for customers coming for it still, but those couple run out the first couple hours of service. Is all good and so are the drinks. We lucked out on the special and gotta a pig trotter that melted in your mouth. It was porky butterness that balanced perfectly in the sauce with a crunch of the bread under it all that finished it off.
author: Neil D.

description:
The first time I came to this place was for walk-in. We sat at the bar, had some decent drinks and interesting food, and we were pretty happy. If I had time to write my review a month ago right after the first visit, it would have been a 3.5-4 stars.

A month later, we decided to return with a bigger group for birthday celebration. The planning is such an awful experience. We spoke to a couple people and the GM. None of them were customer friendly. We read some of the Yelp reviews knowing that they tend to run out of food items, so we tried to reserve a pig head, but they refused (not even with a credit card charge for the pre-order). I wish I had spent more time to read through others' Yelp reviews before we made the reservation. Now we are stuck with them cuz of the credit card hold :(
author: E H.

description: Tried this new place on a Friday evening with my wife for dinner.  We made late afternoon reservations for two with the only seats left at the counter.  When we arrived they found us a table and we were very happy about that.  The staff are very friendly and welcoming.  The place seems very hip and was full, great layout with an open kitchen, dining area on the ground, a lounge on the second floor and an additional dining area.  We found the tables were a bit too long for two as we could barely reach each other across the table and the noise level made it difficult to hear each other.  I would recommend getting counter seats or a corner table that you could sit next to each other if you want to have any conversation.  The menu was interesting and had a few things we were eager to try.  We started with the Country Ham which was delicious.  Thinly sliced ham, almost like prosciutto, served on top of crispy chicharones, pears, and a bit of greens.  My wife had the chicken tetrazzini which was delicious, with a side order of the eggplant which she loved.  I tried the bacon chop.  This is one of the biggest pork chops ever seen on a serving plate.  Cooked perfect and very flavorful.  I also thought it had ALOT of fat.  Some may enjoy that, but I prefer leaner cuts and found the fat portions made it difficult to find meat I enjoyed and difficult to cut and separate.  I would not order this again but would try the sausage or "ham" burger instead.  They had several dishes that sounded appealing but were for shared portions which we would try if we came with a larger group. I would give it a 4 star except for the noise level and the fatty chop.  I would still give it another try if I was dining in the neighborhood.
author: Steven B.

description: You are paying for the name and the tech bros cool points; also atrocious food to price ratio. Skip this place, I feel like you are paying for the owners ego and not the hired helps' skill sets.  Too expensive for the quality of food served ... Also terrible wine selection.
author: Joshua H.

description:
3.5 stars

My brother, a fan of chef Constentino and of eating odd things wanted to try this place and since I knew he was going to be free, we made the reservation to give it a try.  

The restaurant is located on 4th street, across the street from the Well Fargo.  Anyway walking in, the restaurant has a warm feeling.  Maybe it's the open kitchen on a cold winter night and the big animal head that hung over head (I think it was a moose) but has a cabin like kind of feeling.  Once we checked in we were seated right away in a communal like table where they used a few jars of buddha hands to divide up the two parties.  Since my brother and I have been eyeing the menu for a bit, we knew what we wanted to order and our parents are pretty easy so we ordered uni butter with crab bruschetta, greens and herbs, little gem salad, beef heart tartare, medium shellfish platter, pin bone steak, sole, quail, and 18 layer crepe (I think it was 18).

The bruschetta was good but it was not worth $19.  I didn't taste too much crab or uni and the bread was too chewy for our liking.  The beef heart tartare was a good dish both in portion and taste.  Again the bread that came with it (since they use the same bread) was a bit too tough and chewy.  One thing I didn't appreciate was when we asked for additional bread, they charged us for it which is a bit absurd (2 slices for $1).  The two salads I thought were actually pretty tasty as it wasn't over dressed and decent in portion.  The medium shellfish platter at $48 was enough for us.  A combination of clams, oysters and crab and the few dipping sauces it came with makes this something I will order again.  

For the entrees, I thought the quail was ridiculously over priced.  Two small pieces of meat for $35 was a rip off.  It was good but not worth $35 good.  We had a quail a few weeks ago at another place, while I don't remember the price (it was close, may be a bit less) there was definitely more meat to it.  The sold was a little bit more filling but could have used more seasoning I thought.  The main attraction, the pin bone steak was actually very generous in size.  There was more than enough for all of us but my brother and I both agreed it needed more flavor.  The beef jus that came with it was average and the bone marrow sauce was pure oil.  While I understand that eating meat on the medium rare side is generally how it's supposed to be, I would have appreciated if the waiter asked if that is okay.  

Overall service was above average as they checked in on us often, made sure we had enough water.  One minor complaint is that if you have a special or something that says market price, let us know the price and don't wait for us to ask.  It's not a big deal but just something i appreciate.

For dessert the crepe had just the right amount of sweetness but it could be too much for one person as we shared it.

Why am I giving it 3.5 stars and rounding it down to three?  Overall I think the restaurant is a bit over priced.  We ended up paying $100 a person and I think at a $100 a person, we can probably do fine dining.  I did like this place better than Incanto (chef's last place) and I wouldn't mind giving it another try.
author: Pierre L.

description: I love Cockscomb. The food is always exceptional as well as superb service. When my friends (5+me) and I went there for my birthday recently we family styled 10+ items and all were beautifully prepared and delish. Where to start... My favorites are the Beef heart tartare, Pigs head, Bentons Country Ham, The Farro Pumpkin and lastly the Medium order of oysters. Needless to say this was not even all the items we ordered but everything as I said is incredible. We left with empty plates and full bellies. One of my friends commented that it may be one of the best meals he's ever had! Cheers to Chef Chris and all the other superb chefs in this kitchen. I love what you all do!
author: Dana B.

description: Great food, beer, and wine and music!!! Genius chef Chris create an amazing place with delicious menu! Wish I Could try everything in the menu. Next time we are in SF, this is the must place to stop!
author: Bomi L.

description:
I hate to slam a restaurant during the holiday season, but the treatment my friend and I received on Christmas Eve was truly shameful. First, you should know that the restaurant had an $85 prix fixe menu for that night. We were seated promptly and ordered. My friend and I both had the persimmon and walnut salad. I had the tartare with foie gras, my friend had the scallops. For our entree, I had the goose comfit while he had a vegetarian risotto. Finally, we each ordered one of the two dessert selections. I also ordered wine and champagne by the glass to accompany the courses.

It seems the restaurant had miscalculated the food orders, because they apparently ran out of a bunch of stuff. The persimmon salad had two little pieces of persimmon and a scant amount of walnuts. They had compensated by adding pomegranates, but it seems they were even running out of the pomegranates. However, the coup de grace was the entre. After making us wait quite a long time, the entrees arrived, but my friend was presented with, literally, a half-portion of risotto, which was moreover half cooked. Now I know the new trend is to serve risotto al dente, but crunchy? And the whole thing had been disguised, badly, by adding a bunch of chopped red cabbage on top. 

Everyone makes mistakes, even at a high-end restaurant, and I would not have been so incensed if the waiter had simply told us that they had run out of X and recommended a substitute. But to serve bad food and expect that we wouldn't notice?? That's just humbug. On any other night, I would have asked to speak to the manager, but I chose to respect the spirit of the season. 

And the food was not all that amazing, either. The tartare was under seasoned. The salad greens were not cut properly. The goose leg was a bit dry. The best part of the dinner was the desserts; they were scrumptious.

Yeah, I won't be going back.
author: Ara K.

description: Food was very good.   Lunch time crowd was pretty sparse on a Monday so I think that helped the service to be outstanding.  Had seafood chowder which was awesome.
author: Mike M.

description:
Lovely atmosphere and I hope this restaurant will find itself.  I had a martini.  The beauty of a martini is in the taste and presentation.  The taste was okay but lacked the clean finish of a fine martini.  The presentation was not to my liking at all.  Small and dingy.  Should have been much better.

Too much reliance on "verbal" menus.  I prefer a printed menu, time to ponder while I have a cocktail; frankly, I'm not into memorization folded into my dining experience.

The food was fine but again nothing to rave about.

Let's hope for better.
author: Moxiedot Z.

description:
Well, to start, I am a huge fan of pork, so Cockscomb's menu to me was heavenly. 
I went there mainly for their "Hot Mess"- foie gras sauteed with pork feet. it was indeed delicious yet SUPER RICH! The Celery Victor was tasty and refreshing. The Meat Pie had great flavor but was a little bit too heavy to our taste. We also enjoyed the drinks, the dessert, along with the amazing smell from the bacon chop next table. From chatting with our friendly bartender I have already picked up my next dishes (bacon chop and roasted pig's head.) However, the reservation will have to wait for a while- at least until all the fat from this meal burns out.
author: S M.

description: Very nice bar with HH special after 10pm on weekday nights!(not sure about weekend). Fresh oyster and nice appetizers. Definitely good place to chill if you live nearby.
author: Sophia H.

description:
Came here over the weekend and it was a wonderful evening. I love the atmosphere of this place. The kitchen is open so you can really see everything that's going on. We had the pleasure of sitting close to the expeditor so all the food was passing right by us and everything smells oh so good! 
We started off with the Hawaii crudo which was served with saltine crackers this gave it a nice texture. Then we had oysters, clams and crab appetizer followed with the special of the day lamb hearts. On to the main course which the four of us split. Pin steak and pigs head. The steak is unbelievable they offer 3 cuts of meat and each taste amazing the pig and also yummy and extremely fatty flavored. We all
Agreed that the pig could of cook for a little longer so it got more crispy because it was a bit tough to cut into this would of also cooked down a little more of the fat but overall still a very memorable dish. Dessert was surprising, we ordered a apple turnover with shredded cheese and it blew my mind and all the best ways. Wonderful evening will be back!
author: F F.

description: Tho the fried chicken sandwich and Italian dip were good, they were not excellent. The cauliflower had no flavor even though on the menu it sounded good. The oeufs were great! The overall experience was only meh because we sat at the kitchen counter and saw how the tall chef treated two other men working there. He was overtly condescending and mean. Did not create a positive experience along with pretty good food.
author: Steven M.

description:
Incanto was one of my favorite restaurants in the city, so was super excited to have this place open here. Overall: very good experience, and once they get everything really dialed in I think this could be great. 

Gin Jam cocktail: Fine, but nothing special, lacking a bit of punch/vibrancy. Nothing wrong with it, but I'd prob stick to beer or wine here (which imo accompany this food better anyway).

Uni butter, lardo, and dungeness crab bruschetta: Disappointing only because they said uni butter and there was absolutely zero uni taste at all. If they hadn't said that, would have been very happy with a tasty bruschetta with a great combo of crab and lardo.

Duck fat cauliflower: very good, exactly as expected.

Roasted pig's head: This was almost as epic looking as the whole beast at Incanto. Giant pig's head with a ton of meat to dig into. Tender, flavorful meat from all parts of the head, lots of delicious crispy fatty skin, and an extra-tasty ear. We tackled this with two of us, but I'd probably recommend this as a better dish for 4-6 people with other mains alongside. Great dish, and apparently they run out pretty early. Only minor issue with this dish is it comes with some endives that get a little oily on that plate and don't end up contrasting enough with this intensely rich dish, but that's a small nitpick about an excellent dish.

The dessert menu was like we got transported to a minimalist tasting menu restaurant - entries were "chocolate, classic, (something else), cheese" with no other info, so it was useless without having them explained. No big deal, just seems silly. Was totally stuffed at this point anyway.

Service was good. Sat at the bar, bartender was very nice and pretty knowledgeable about the menu. Rest of service staff was very good, everything went smoothly.

$80 each with not much drinking. I recommend this place already, and suspect once they fine tune some things this will become a real favorite. Rest of the menu sounds great. Especially looking forward to checking out the hamburger (looked great), pork chop, and meat pie!
author: Deva H.

description:
Some highs and one big low. Was excited to try this place and be a little adventurous. There was some adventure for sure. We had a great shared appetizer with the tuna collar. The lemon and aromatics really complemented the star of the show and it was somewhat "fun" to find where all the tidbits of tuna were hiding. For an entree I had the bacon chop with a side of the fried cauliflower. The cauliflower was the highlight of the meal. The bacon chop - not much. It came on the plate with fresh and cooked apples and what I think was arugula but milder. I expected it to have that traditional roasted pork loin flavor. What I got was a muddled dish where most of the chop was unrendered pork fat. I did expect there to be alot of fat given the name, but thought it would be rendered down giving the remaining meat that special deliciousness you can only get from pork fat. Since we were at the counter of the kitchen we asked a couple of the line chefs about it. They all said it was prepared the way it was intended but would be glad to cook it more.  At this point I was full and really didn't feel like trying to find more meat through all the raw fat. I wouldn't recommend this dish. 

Wine list was average. Alot of French wines which I thought was odd given how close we are to Napa and Sonoma. 

Service was really great and attentive. 

I'd go back but would order better.
author: Glenn S.

description: Wow!  What a wonderful meal.  Awesome way to celebrate my birthday.  Food was behind delicious, the wine the waitress suggested was phenomenal,  and the staff was extremely friendly and very helpful.  We live in the area and are ecstatic to have a restaurant that is exceptional.  Will be back for sure!  Thank you for making my day so special!
author: M C.

description: Fourth visit and fantastic as ever. The only debate was the Hot Mess (foie gras, y'know) vs. Beef Heart Tartare to start. We've had them both before and went with the Hot Mess this time. It is a delicious hot mess but we craved more of the foie gras than the other ingredients. Next time it's the Tartare 'cause there is no better. Tried the Gnocci and the Roasted Chicken for the first time and loved them both. The gnocci is not like your mama makes, more like savory potato pillows than what you've likely had before. Very good. The chicken was wonderful - not something I normally say about a chicken dish. And, the drinks, they were so good we had to repeat. Will be back again for sure.
author: David F.

description: I'm so glad I came here.  I typically fly in to SF for a day trip from LA because, well why not?  This time I wanted to try this place as I am a huge fan of Chris Cosentino.  My sister and I sat down for a late lunch and was greeted warmly by the host who ended up serving us.  I feel horrible I didn't get his name but he was outstanding.  We ordered the bruschetta to start and man! That was best bruschetta I've ever had! It was so delicious.  For the entree I ordered the fried chicken sandwich and that was incredible. Apparently there is maple syrup in the batter so how can I turn that down.  The chicken was moist and I ate every bite.  This is unusual for me to order chicken at a restaurant but I'm glad I took the risk.  My sister ordered the fish and chips and the fish was nice and meaty and the potatoes were great. I had a great first time experience there and would definitely come back for dinner next time!  You'll love the feel of the place, the service is great and the food wonderful.
author: C R.

description: I came from Southern California for a weekend at the ASBF in Golden gate park at the beginning of October and asked my daughter to find the best dinning in SF. She did a great job. I wish we had chefs in our area that understand healthy fat gourmet foods. We had pigs ear and it was incredible. We had the half a hogs head. It was soooo good. This place gets it. Healthy raised animals with healthy fats is so densely nutritious. I wish I lived near here I would be going all the time. So many good things on the menu so many gourmet awesome foods from a classical trained 5 star chef. If you do not like fats you won't get it but if you understand the benefits and like them this is the place.
author: Daniel F.

description:
Wow!  I have been dying to come here since Cockscomb opened and finally booked reservations for a Friday nite.  We showed up 5 minutes before our reservation and were given the option of the "chef's table" (bar seats overlooking kitchen) or a table.  We opted for the chefs table and were not disappointed by the show in the bustling kitchen.  

The atmosphere of the restaurant is lively but not overwhelming.  The only negative of the evening was a rude chef's table patron sitting next to my wife who kept fluffing her hair in my wife's space.  My wife addressed the issue and it ceased, but the staff approached her saying they saw the rude behavior however never took action.

The food:  Amazing.

I had the beef heart tartare and bone marrow.  My wife, the grilled cheese with truffle and ahi crudo.  The beef heart tartare was the best tartare I have had, with a robust flavor and perfect compliment of crunchy grilled bread and amazing fired potatoes that maintained a crisp exterior throughout the meal.  I will definitely be back for this tartare!

The bone marrow was luscious and fatty - just as you would expect and the fried oyster complement just added to the decadence of this plate.  

My wife being a vegetarian is a connoisseur of grilled cheese.  She gave it a 4/5 stars - said she has had better. Honestly, i took one bite and I have not had better.  It was crunchy, gooey, cheesy goodness.  

I cannot comment on the crudo as I did not try it.

I would likely go 4.5 stars, but the rude behavior of our neighbor being recognized by but not addressed by staff as well as fact that all plates came out at same time, not staging the meal appropriately result in the 4 stars.  

We will definitely be back many times!
author: Mark D.

description: Went there for an early Valentine's Day dinner.  We got there 10 minutes late, but were still seated promptly.  The food was tasty and the portion size was huge.  We had oysters as appetizers, the Little Gem salad, and a shareable supper (2 pounds of pork belly and 1 pound of snow crab legs).  We left full and happy!  The service was also quick and friendly.  I will definitely be returning soon!
author: Naroth M.

description: Service was great. Steak was tough though. Duck and potatoes were excellent. Really busy for a Thursday night.
author: Elaine K.

description: Outstanding food, service and ambiance.  One of the best restaurant experiences I have had in San Francisco.   Well done Chris!!!
author: Robert H.

description: I decided to go here with some friends after reading a review in Bon Appetite magazine.  I had the coulotte steak.  It was ONE OF THE BEST MEALS I have ever had or will have.  The heirloom tomatoes were so rich in flavor served simply fresh, the tiny bits of blue cheese was perfect in amount, the sauce on top was not heavy and perfectly flavored and the cut of the meat was outstanding...the most tender meat I have ever eaten (even more notable since I like my meat well done - no pink). The service was A+, the size of the restaurant was perfect...not too big.  Our desserts were so delicious, elegant and not too sweet.  Oh yah the crispy potatoes with pickled peppers along with my meat makes me dream about the place ever since I left, what a perfect pairing.  I can't say enough good things about this place, overall A+++ experience.
author: Dorinda S.

description: Great space and yummy food!  We look forward to Chris's new Resturant in St. Helena.
author: Jacqueline H.

description: This place is incredible! Definitely great if you are a foodie like me. The dishes can be a little adventurous but so entirely worth it. The guys who work here have a perfect rhythm down and are so fun to watch. Only complaint is that when I waiter told us the specials, he said we could add king crab as an add-on. That add on was over double the price of the main dish itself! Wish he told us that because we wouldn't have ordered it :/
author: Megan B.

description: My wife and I have always wanted to try a Chris Consentino restaurant on one of our frequent visits to SF, but the locations didn't work for us until he opened Cockscomb which is relatively easy to get to. We went on a Friday night and, as expected, the room was funky with a full house and a great buzz. Our waiter, James, was very helpful and explained some of the subtleties of the oyster choices. I tried the Zampini and my wife the "ham"burger. My fennel sausage, though attractively presented and cooked well, lacked flavor , and I was unable to detect the fennel. My wife's burger was more ground pork than ham, and she was a bit uneasy about the temperature. At any rate we got to meet Chris who was super gracious host. In all, a delightful experience and a very popular restaurant, but maybe not the most memorable food
author: MC B.

description: I couldn't believe Chris Cosentino was actually here and on the grind.  He's such a hard working man, gotta respect that.  The highlight of the meal was the pig's head and it was to die for.  The skin was super crispy and the meat was so soft and tender and all the fat and collagen leaves your lips with that savory sticky film.  If you're afraid of fat, you probably shouldn't order this.  I lost the bet to eat the eye ball, but in retrospect it was a total win!!   The eye was so tendony and juicy, hot damn I wish there was two.  5 stars just for the pig's head!!
author: Amy C.

description:
Loved their food! Would've given them 5 stars except our waiter didn't ask if we had rooms for dessert. Brought us the bill and said " oh did I forget to offer you guys the dessert menu? I figured you guys had leftovers so you had no rooms for desserts" 

Will definitely give this place a try again! Hopefully we don't get the same waiter!
author: Lillian K.

description: This place is heaven if you are a meat lover.  Chris the owner has created a super fun environment to experience his creations.  It is ideal for a group of friends, but not really ideal for a romantic evening...don't get me wrong, you should bring your partner, but expect to talk over the music.
author: Michael M.

description: This restaurant was really exceptional. My wife and I started with a Crudo, which was infused with Vietnamese flavors similar to larb. My wife had the hamburger which is really a ground pork shoulder which is really good with the mustard and cheese.  I had faro stuffed pumpkin. I'm not a big fan of vegetarian dishes but the presentation of this was exceptional and the Faro was very nicely seasoned. Highly recommend.
author: Jeff M.

description:
OMG! This place is so great. After roaming around the 4th Street looking for a good place to eat at, and after getting rejected by every restaurant in vicinity, we stumbled upon Cockscomb. I am so glad we did! Fortunately one of their reservations never showed up so they seated us immediately. The place was packed! Chris Cosentino was there running the kitchen which was pretty fun to watch. 

My favorites from the current menu: arugula salad, cornish game hen, culotte steak. For drinks: classic gin and tonic, pisco punch, maltese falcon, chef's gin jams. 

Delicious!!! I wanted to lick my plate after each dish.
author: C. T.

description:
This was such a disappointment after my supposedly foodie friend raved about the wonderful filet mignon and lobster main dish. Every dish we ordered was laced with nothing but fat and and grease. The foie gras was overcooked and soaked in a sweet and fruity sauce. The nightly specialty of ribeye steak and dungeons crab was the biggest let down. The steak was tough and chewy with little beef flavor and the crab was cold and half cooked, laced with again grease!! It was so awful that we ended up sending it back to the kitchen!! The spiced chicken and squash waffle was again laced with grease, with the chicken thigh barely cooked and waffles were soggy and soaked in fat!! The only acceptable dishes were the kale and cauliflower for sides!! 
What an absolute shocker. Chris Cosentino, please  go back to the drawing board and revamp the menu by cutting down half the fat and grease!! I definitely would not recommend this place, especially with a main dish for over $120.00. 
A lot better choices for a much healthier and delicious dinner in SOMA by just walking a few doors down!!
Yvonne Lo
author: Yvonne L.

description: super yummy food and friendly staff. i had a big luncheon group and they reserved the upstairs tables for me.
author: Vicky L.

description: It was acceptable, I need to give another try before I finally make a final review about this place.
author: Joe V.

description: Came here for happy hour the other week and was very pleased. $5 on a selection of beers and wine! and great happy hour specials (grilled cheese, crispy potatoes, etc.) I'd love to come back and try their non happy hour food, but definitely come here for happy hour! (5-6 or 10-11) and order the crispy potatoes. SO yum and they come with an aioli sauce that's to die for :D.
author: Christina C.

description: We were so happy they started serving lunch!! This was a fantastic meal and a GREAT place for a large group. They were so attentive and nice. The food was insane and we all left very full and happy. Definitely going back.
author: Kathy W.

description:
Missed out on the meat pie special. They ran out and changed it from oxtail, beef cheeks, and snail to pork trotter and snail. We switched gears and went with the Pork chop which serves two generously. We started with Grandma's tripe, yummy and spicy, the pork chop, and duck fat cauliflower. Chris and Steve and the whole staff gave warm service. High marks for that. Oh, we also had oysters to start. They have seafood on their chalkboard specials and we had two selections of west coast oysters that came with three unique sauces.
We saw many dishes we would love to try. This place will be a success. Great job!
author: Wilson L.

description:
I went to this restaurant with my parents last week and was very excited to try this place out.  I have been to Chris Cosentino's former restaurant, Encanto, a couple times and also was there for the annual "Snout-to-Tail" dinner - such creative dishes with bold flavor that I will probably never forget.  Unfortunately, this experience wasn't anywhere near that of Encanto.  The main issues were dish quality and service time.

To start on a positive, the drinks that they serve here are great.  They have really creative gin and tonics (they add juniper berries and other gin components to the glass, adding a nice aroma and look).  However, the gin and tonic was $15! Way too expensive for a drink.

I ordered the beef heart tartare as a starter and was surprised by how bland it was - I have eaten normal beef tartare with much more flavor.  I followed that up with the "ham" burger - a burger with pork shoulder as the meat, along with caramelized onions and potato wedges.  The meat in the burger reminded me of shumai at a cheap Chinese restaurant - very pink pork with some gristle/toughness to it.  The potato wedges were good, but didn't make up for the dish.  My parents ordered the sweetbreads and squid risotto as appetizers and were not impressed (risotto was "OK").  They also ordered the pig skin spaghetti and the "ham" burger - the pig skin spaghetti had clear noodles that you normally see in Asian dishes and very little to no pig skin.  The sauce also had a strange ketchup taste...

To top this off, we waited about 1.5 hours for our entree!  We noticed that other folks were waiting a while for their food, but not the large tables.  Cosentino came out to expedite the dishes, but it seemed to be only for the larger parties (more $$$).  He also spent a lot of time taking pictures with the diners.  He then moved into the kitchen area to help with the dishes, but we only saw the Pig's Head, large steak dish, and other large party-based dishes coming out.  The waiter apologized to us, but for an hour and a half wait we expected to get a small dish or app on the house - which is typical for higher-tier restaurants in the city.

Possibly will come back - so many other restaurants with equally creative dishes, more flavor, and less wait.
author: Brian C.

description: Great food, very loud on a Friday night. The steak is delicious. The pork belly is good but too much fat, not something you can eat alone. Maltese falcons is delicious drink.
author: Mona L.

description: New York-style ambiance with an SF relaxed attitude. The Pin Bone Steak for 4 was amazing, as were the Little Gems.
author: Mars H.

description:
I took my fiancé in for his birthday dinner on Saturday night.  I have been following Chris and his food for about 7 years now.  

Our experience was wonderful, as it always is, at his restaurants.  From the moment we walked in and were greeted by the hostesses, all through cocktails, dinner service, wine and dessert, everything was perfection.

The Uni (Sea Urchin) bruschetta was amazing.  No other word to describe it.  The duck liver terrine was the best I have ever had. We also thoroughly enjoyed the bone marrow assortment. To. Die. For.  Eggs, eggs, eggs?!  FLAWLESS.

The food and service were both impeccable.  Excellent job Chef.  Can't wait to go back.
author: Lindsay M.

description:
3.5/5.  Dining at Cockscomb was a very enjoyable experience but could have been better.

The food was excellent, but, as other reviews state, a lot of meat.  For our main course the table ordered both the pig's head and the pin bone steak.  The steak was cooked and seasoned perfectly, definitely the best part of the meal.  Highly recommended.  The pig's head was an interesting item and offered some unique flavors, but probably wouldn't be something I would order again.  It seemed like it was more of a novelty item and didn't really provide all that much quality meat for $65.  The appetizers we had were all delicious and top quality -- in particular I enjoyed the beef heart tartare.

A negative part of the evening was the service and pacing of the meal.  There was a large break between the appetizers and the main course.  That, and the kitchen brought out the side dishes we ordered for the table a good 15 minutes before the meat came.  I expected better.
author: Andrew D.

description: Definitely a unique dining experience.  You have to let some of your pre-conceived notions go and try some new things!  We had a dish that was shredded meat and foie gras that was amazing.  The tuna collar was delicious and the pig skin amatriciana was delicious but rich.  I had a fabulous cocktail, "greed".  Did the job after horrible traffic to get into SF. The staff was attentive and friendly.
author: Victoria M.

description:
I gave it a 3 star rating because I had built up a lot of expectations for this meal and it didn't quite meet my expectations.

We ordered the meat special which was a giant T-bone steak with foi gras, foi gras butter, and au jus, a pig's head, a hot mess, the pate, and beef heart tartare. We also had cocktails beforehand and ordered two sides with our meal: mushrooms and foi gras cauliflower.
