The beef heart had a creaminess you wouldn't expect and was very pleasant. Not overly flavorful but very mild. If you didn't know it was beef heart, you'd never be able to tell. The pate was okay. It had more texture than I'd expect but flavor wise, it wasn't bad. The hot mess was delicious. The trotters were perfectly melt in your mouth. There were some bones left which I didn't mind at all. 

The steak was to be cooked medium rare but we all agreed it came out more rare as some of the beef appeared to still be breathing. It wasn't well seasoned but it was still good. I don't feel like the foi gras or the foi gras butter or the au jus added much to the meat other than more richness which it really didn't need. I definitely rate this dish an okay and would not be ordering it again. 

However, the biggest disappointment was the pig's head. It smelled heavenly and it was cooked to perfection. The skin was super crispy and the meat was fall off the bone melt in your mouth. But it was not seasoned!!! At all!! I looked around the table for salt and pepper shaker but did not see any. I normally never add salt to my food at restaurants. Never. But I needed some desperately for this meal. The head came with two "sauces": a white sauce made with brains and a salsa verde made with drippings. I didn't try the white sauce but the salsa verde was a complete fail. It too had no seasoning, just a tanginess and oiliness which was totally not necessary considering the pig's head is pretty much all fat. 

I came into this meal knowing it was super rich and fatty but had it had flavor, I would not have been disappointed. I understand that the inside of the pig's head would have been hard to season but the skin was bland and the accompanying sauces were bland. It was bland fat on fat. 

The mushrooms, on the other hand, were utterly divine! Simply delicious. I could have eaten a tub of that. The cauliflower was also delicious. 

We were also very pleased with the cocktails. Best cocktails I've ever had and we had the special house made ones which usually aren't great but these were really really good, especially the Sweet November. It was sweet with a slight but pleasant bitterness. 

The service was a bit on the slow side but it was a packed house. Our meal took 3 hours to finish. 

Overall, I'm not sure I'd go back. We've had the leg of beast at his other restaurant that closed, Incanto, and we loved it. So we really expected this meal to be on par and it just didn't live up. 

The sides and cocktails are what made this a 3-star experience for me. Otherwise, it would have been hard to give it even 2 stars.
author: Mee V.

description: If you like meat, this is the place for you! We had the angry lobster, pig's head, and the pin bone steak. Small plates were the grilled cheese, little gems salad, cauliflower, something with foie gras, a couple bottles of wine, and 3 desserts. I know I'm missing a couple more sides...anywho the service was attentive and good. The food was impressive and had interesting presentation. I loved how so many different parts of the animal was used, i.e. the aioli for the pig's head was made from its brain. Pretty cool! We got to meet the infamous chef at the end of dinner and got a pic with him but was I little disappointed he didn't stop by earlier since 2 of the girls asked to chat with the chef to the waiter about 3 times. We saw him walking around and chatting with other tables... Overall very good meal but my cholesterol level probably flew off the charts.  Will take the hubby back for him to try it out!
author: Linda C.

description: Great experiences here at Cockcomb! Been here a few times now, and the food was outstanding each time. I highly recommend you wait to hear about the house specials from the waiter. Every time we've come here, we've never ordered straight off the menu. Highly recommend the bruschetta specials and and the Pin Bone sirloin steak for two (easily serves 4). If your feeling adventurous the pigs head with "brainase" is pretty good too!
author: Marco M.

description: This is a fun place and the dishes are pretty creative.  It's definitely a meat-centric menu, but there are some non-meat dishes that others of us who don't care for meat could have, and they are still just as delicious.  Our party talked with the chef a bit too, who seemed very friendly.
author: a f.

description:
Great cocktails, amazing food and an incredibly knowledgable wait staff (recommending pairings for different parts of our meal). The bacon chop was to die for! 

Our seats were incredible - right in front of the open kitchen and next to Chef Chris Cosentino. The kitchen staff was incredibly friendly - answering questions and making recommendations.
author: JR F.

description:
Disgusting. We lived in SF for many years, and this strikes me as a place that is cool because people think it's cool, and that's about it. Summary of our meals:

Bacon Chop: Gigantic, but really because 60% of it was fat. Super bland, very dry. My fiance and his grandma could out-cook this guy in the pork chop territory. 

Steak: Meh. Wasn't bad, but didn't knock my socks off.

Pork Skin Linguine with Clams: The pork skin linguine is made of pork skin, but is mushy, gelatinous, and overall just really fatty. Interesting idea,chef is definitely trying to "do something new" but it was pretty disgusting.

Best items we had were, ironically, fish or vegetarian: tartare was tasty, roasted beet entree was delicious, and grilled cheese with truffle tasted like dessert. 

Overall this place was a bust. For calling themselves meat experts, it was obvious they don't know how to cook, season, or present meat. We could cook a better meal at home. (for about $200 less)
author: Rebecca W.

description: Awesome premise, mediocre execution. Two standouts were the grilled cheese and the cured meat and cantaloupe. We also got the pin bone steak, a medium crudo plate and few others none of which were memorable. Also the place is ridiculously loud, even upstairs.
author: Bryan F.

description: Been here a few times and it was great until I came for happy hour and was told the tiny seating area for happy hour was full and we couldn't attend even though the rest of the restaurant relatively empty (over 30 seats available) and was told to get there earlier with no accommodations made even though I had been there 3 times during the same week and spent over $100 each time. Needless to say they lost my business.
author: Marc W.

description: Food and service here is great. Friend and I came here for happy hour and dinner. We got oysters and pork ears to start - both were delicious. My Malbec was also very good. Friend got the "ham"burger plus foie gras for dinner, while I got the pumpkin farro. She enjoyed her foie gras, and I thought my farro stuffed pumpkin was good and cute. She suggested I try out lunch here with my coworkers, which made me think over the menu and realized this isn't the most vegetarian friendly place.
author: Jess L.

description: If I could award more than five stars I would.  It was THAT GOOD!  Unconventional selections throughout the menu caused me to go out of my comfort zone on a few of them.  So glad I did.  We started with the Tombo Crudo - a first for me.  It was bursting with wonderful flavors of Vietnamese herbs that complimented the tuna. Next came the Beef Heart Tartare.  Perhaps due to rising expectations, it seemed a little lacking in flavor compared to traditional tartare I've had elsewhere.  For our main courses, we had the Bacon Chop and Coulotte Steak along with a side of the "Dirty" Crispy potatoes.  I'm at a loss for superlatives in describing the flavors that we experienced in both dishes.  Both were expertly prepared and complimented with sauces that made me want to slowly savor each bite. I was sad when I took my final bite.  And the potatoes were so unique and tasty with pickled peppers and country ham purée.  These are a must with whatever you decide to have for a main course. Will definitely be back and have already recommended this place to friends and relatives in the SF Bay area.
author: Dave H.

description:
I am in absolute confusion on how to rate this place. I came here for an anniversary dinner with my girlfriend on the trusty reference of our good friend and this place definitely lived up to the hype. In retrospect, I am disappointed in not ordering the foi gras that we were advised to must get, but because we didn't see it on the menu, we didn't know that was an option. So we went on and ordered other stuff, listed below soon. What I am confused about on how to rate this place is not between good or bad, but why I can only rate it at 5 stars and how to describe the night we had here. 

First off, service is perfect. Made a reservation, showed up a few minutes late, and we were instantly seated at a table set aside for us even when the place was super packed and there were people waiting. The server was amazing and friendly and recommended a lot of good food options to us, however, we went away from the recommendations and went ahead to ordering the whole pigs head and 2 side dishes as well as champagne for our celebration. We were expecting something small and nothing crazy. 

The pig head comes out and is the size of our table. We didn't see anyone else order it so we were a little scared and when it came out, well it did was hard to miss. It was half a pigs head (1 side only) and it was in a giant wok like plate. This thing is huge. We proceeded to take pictures and what not but we had no idea how to attack this monstrous head. We tried to butcher it but the skin was so crispy and thick it was a little hard. We had some trouble so the 2 tables to our left and right tried to give us help and instructions but it was hard and we needed our server. Our server saw us struggle and came over to cut the head properly. He pointed to which parts had all the meats and which parts were best to eat. The skin was definitely crispy for those that likes it. The meat was limited under the cheeks and was extra tender and fatty (delicious!!!). One thing that some may try and may not, is the eye of the pig. If you are Asian the story is that fish eyes are good for your eyes and green onions make you smarter, but what about the pig's eye? Well my girlfriend gave that a try and it was an interesting piece to the pigs head indeed. Overall it was too much for us and we failed to finish the whole pigs head. However, we did take it home! :) The champagne was great accompaniment. 

After pictures and attacking this, the service, the price, the quality, the ambiance, we will definitely be looking to going back!  This place is very casual and a bit loud. The kitchen and bars were perpendicular to each other and you can see the chefs cook as well as walk up to the bar to grab a drink to wait for a table if you need it. 

This place is great and I am looking forward to going back to try this giant steak and foi gras that was recommended to us. 

Tips: 
1) Make a reservation
2) The front door is in the ally (hard to find if you walk down the street towards the sign
3) Pigs head (3-4+ people portion)
4) Try the pig's eye if you get the pig's head 
5)Have a few drinks
6) Enjoy!
author: Kevin W.

description: The best steak I have ever had - it had been marinated so well and the depth of flavor !!! Everything we had was perfectly done and some really interesting menu options.
author: Kiks L.

description: Creative menu, helpful staff and overall cool vibe. Flew in from NYC and needed a quick bite and a glass of wine and Chris and staff did not disappoint!
author: Polly A.

description: Great service!!!! I am never going to be a goose liver pate' fan.  Half the plates we ordered were great the other half were just okay :)
author: Tanya L.

description: I really liked the place (food, service, the whole package), but I'm writting this review only to recomend the dessert that I loved! "The classic"!!!
author: Nicholas S.

description:
I became a huge fan of Chris Cosentino after rooting for him on Top Chef Masters so I was really excited to check out his newest venture, Cockscomb. 

3.5 stars for the food. 

The standouts:
-fried potatoes served with & Chips and the "Ham"Burger: the side crispy potatoes that accompanied these dishes were outstanding. Chunky, twice-fried nuggets of potatoes that are impossibly crispy on the outside and creamy inside. These should be made into their own side dish. They were soooo much better than the side dishes we actually ordered. 

Pretty good:
-BACON CHOP apples, brussellskraut & mustard: not a Tomahawk size, but the pretty damn biggest serving of meat that I've had in awhile. I dug into it immediately and barely put a dent in it. But that's probably because I had to cut through 2-3" of fat to get to the meat. If you're not okay with fat and gristle (which you don't have to eat, but which I did sneak bites of), you may be disgusted by the Bacon Chop. Bacon is ideal name for this chop as there are several thick layers of fat interlaced with meat. As I was cutting through the fat & gristle, I had a flashback to that scene from The Great Outdoors where John Candy gnaws and sweats his way through a 96oz steak. This pork chop was not on that level, but definitely reminiscent. The THICK layers of fat do serve a purpose tho. The resulting meat is enveloped in juicy layers of fat, self-basting itself with juices and super tender and juicy to the bite. The chop was probably brined as well to up the juicy-quotient. The apples/brusselskraut seemed more of an afterthought for me and it didn't stand out. I wish this dish came with a starch b/c the meat portion was daunting and needed something to contrast/offset it. I barely ate a third of it and I couldn't even bring myself to finish the leftovers for lunch because of all the fat. 

-COUNTRY PATE pistachios, cornichons, butter: one of the better country pates I've had in awhile. the pate was rustic and meaty and you could really savor and taste distinct pieces of meat in it

-LITTLE GEMS green goddess, radish & cracklins: a nice beginning to the meal. the lighter, sweeter pieces of the romaine variety were a nice contrast to the crisp radish and the crunchy, slightly saltly cracklin pieces 

-"HAM"BURGER grilled onions, gruyere cheese, Dijon & fried potatoes: the server described it as as a ground pork patty, but it tasted and felt more like a salty bits of ham cold cuts that had been ground up and re-fashioned into a patty. The doughy bun, grilled onions and melted cheese made for a tasty sandwich, but it definitely doesn't pack the beef "meatiness" that you crave from a traditional hamburger. 

-"& CHIPS": a fancy version of traditional British bangers and mash, or sausages and mashed potatoes. The pork sausage itself was meaty, but the texture left something to be desired. It was slightly dry and I was craving a bit more fat content. The taste is interesting as well: super herbaceous, bright, and citrusy. 

-MARKET VEGETABLE weather dependent: roasted acorn squash 

Okay, but I would pass: 
-'EGGS, EGGS, EGGS' salmon roe & tarragon aioli: a creamy poached chicken egg, 2 poached quail eggs, and salmon roe atop a creamy, herbacious tarragon aioli. The combination of the luscious broken yolks, delicate egg whites, and aioli made for a light, yet decadent mouthful. The bright pops of saltiness from the salmon roe were an interesting side  note. However, it came with one hard piece of table bread. This would've been better if more thought was put into the accompanying bread, like if it were a buttered, toasted brioche. 

-CRUDO OF THE DAY: while crudo and ceviche are very similar, we felt that this was more of a ceviche preparation because it was served with tortilla chips. Pretty non-descript. 

-BROCCOLI RABE garlic, lemon, chili & breadcrumbs

-DUCK FAT CAULIFLOWER red fresno, garlic, caper & mint

I would like to give Cockscomb another chance and try other items on the menu (especially the shared suppers), but for now 3.5 stars for the food.
author: Monelle A.

description: So glad that I finally got the chance to dine here. The Pin Bone steak was awesome and service was great! I am a big rooster art collecter...I felt like I was right at home!
author: Billy V.

description: Absolutely love the open kitchen at Cockscomb!  We were lucky to get two seats at the bar and got to watch Chef Cosentino expedite and schmooze with patrons.  Service was somewhat impersonal, though efficient.  We started with a 1/2 dozen oysters (yum!) and the squid watermelon starter which I would highly recommend (highly highly).  We shared the albacore and steak mains and absolutely loved the albacore.  Great space, good wine, and would recommend checking it out!
author: Angela R.

description: Was a little underwhelmed. All the dishes we ordered tasted fine but none was particularly memorable, except for the bacon chop that stood out for being undercooked. For the most part, the menu was more interesting in concept than execution.
author: Ivy W.

description: Popped in for a gin drink and first course. Quintessential SF, with a big city vibe and a great craft bar feel. Casey and Alicia were behind the bar and the service was impeccable. I had the Spring 44 Mountain Gin, and a life changing grilled cheese with a quail egg and honey. We walked to the Rocha Art Gallery afterwards for a peek. Loved our time here!
author: Pat B.

description: I've been to Incanto and loved the meal there so when we heard that Chris Cosentino was opening this place we made reservations to try it.  We started with the homemade cured ham, a small selection of oysters and clams, some pate and the special of meat pot pie.  Also, I couldn't pass up the Foie Gras dish.  All dishes were so good.  The ham looked beautiful on the plate and along with the Asian pears, complemented it well.  For dessert I got the chocolate cake which melted in my mouth.  Great service as usual and loved sitting at the bar watching the kitchen in action.  Will come back again to sample more of Chris' work.
author: Gina W.

description:
If you enjoy restaurants where you must shout and the people who are only 3 feet away, this is the place for you. Probably one of the loudest venues I have been to in a long time. 

Additionally, although the food was very well prepared, dont expect anything on the menu to be anything remotely "healthy". This is about hedonistic eating not healthy eating. 

It may be some people's go-to place, but it isnt really my taste. Otherwise the venue is beautiful, the food well prepared and although the waiter had horrible breath, the service was very good.
author: Will G.

description:
no idea how this guy won top chef because everything is UNDER SEASONED.

lamb tartare tasted like any beef tartare dunked in olive oil, and again, no taste. bacon chop cooked nicely but had no flavor save for a hint of jalapeno.

best part of the meal? fantastic cocktails.
author: Sherman L.

description: Overall overpriced. Every bottle of red wine is over $40. We had a $50 mediocre one... 2 appetizers, one starter and one entree and the bill went up to $86 each including gratuity. I was disappointed with the mussels. I knew it was not mussels season but  waiter said they had good ones so i went for it. Over half of the plate was fries and a few little mussels on the side. I don't think i will be back for a while.
author: Susana G.

description:
I came here for the first time yesterday. My friend had been raving about this place for a while, so we made plans to go here a month in advance and made a reservation.

Service was perfect. Very friendly, knowledgable about the menu, and always kept our water filled.

Food:

Asparagus Starter - very acidic, green, fresh, crisp salad. Almost like taking a mouthful of grass.

Butcher's Choice for the day - Morel Mushrooms + Cow Udder in a creamy white sauce. The morel mushrooms were delicious, but the cow udder was basically lightly fried fat. It got sickening really quickly.

Bacon Chop - 80% fat, 20% meat. The fat was good (fat is always tasty), but it got really really sickening.

Meat Pie - Ingredients change daily. Mine had oysters, beef, carrots, and collared greens. Beef was tough and chewy. The pie was very disappointing. I was expecting an actual pie with a thick meat filling, but it was just a piece of crust on top of a bowl of watery soup, with no crust around the filling. The filling was, like mentioned, watery soup filled with oysters and unchewable beef.

At this point, we were disappointed with the meat pie and completely sick of all the fat from the bacon chop, so we decided to order the grilled cheese to get some carbs in.

Grilled Cheese - Brie-filled grilled cheese sandwich perfectly fried, drizzled with honey, and topped with a sunny side up duck egg. In my opinion, it was the best dish of the night.

For desserts, we got the chocolate and the fruit desserts:

Chocolate hazelnut ganache cake topped with clotted cream - absolutely perfect. Moist, delicious, not too sweet.

Strawberry Shortcake with mint leaves and rhubarb - the shortcake wasn't moist. It felt kind of old and dry. The mint was very refreshing though (the whipped cream seemed to be infused with mint as well), and the strawberries were tart and tasty.

Here's the not so fun part. As soon as I finished eating, I had an upset stomach. After I got home, I threw up, and the morning after, I had uncontrollable diarrhea for hours.

So, in summary, this was my experience with Cockscomb:

- Good service.
- Tons of things not listed on the menu, such as Surf & Turf and Hot Mess. Pretty damn annoying. I know the ingredients change every day, but at least put the name of the dish on the menu. I don't want to be repeatedly asking the waiter for the specials ("Hey, can we have the thing you mentioned that has cow udder in it? Oh that's called Butcher's Choice? Okay yea I want that.").
- Everything just has WAYYY TOO MUCH FAT. Like solid cubes and globs of lard.
- The only dishes I truly enjoyed were the grilled cheese and the chocolate cake.
- I got some kind of indigestion or food poisoning afterwards.
- After tip, the bill came out to $75 per person (2 people total).

I might come back to try out the pinbone steak instead sometime, but for now, I don't think I even want to look at meat.
author: Michelle H.

description:
If you really, really, really (!) love pork and the less popular cuts of piggies (also known as offal), this is the place for you.  But make sure that everyone in your dining party has the same taste because there are no "safe" alternatives for someone who would like to opt out.  (No pasta dish, no chicken, not even a typical hamburger.  Instead, they offer quail, fish with sea urchin salsa and a burger made out of ham.)   I like piggies, but the menu was a bit much, even for my adventurous tastes, and I felt like they were pushing the offal a bit too much.  

Our server was very, very slow.  We waited 45 minutes for our meals (while other tables were served around us), and although I hate to say it, he came by to top up our wine glasses so often that between this and the delay, we felt like it was a ploy to get us to finish the bottle, so we'd order another with dinner.  We also had to wait twenty minutes after the dessert menu before he took our order for dessert.   Minus a star for service.

Pricey, but that's to be expected in SF.  Cool space, and I liked the upstairs in particular.
author: M D.

description: Sat at the chefs table which was an experience in its entirety as my girl and I got to see the chefs in action - she had their Escape from Alcatraz (gin and elderflower) and I had their drink that was a mix of an old fashioned and a Manhattan (bulleit with Cynar and grapefruit bitters) I thought the double dash of bitters was too overwhelming. This time around, since it was just the two of us; unfortunately we weren't able to try their shareable dishes,which included the lamb shoulder, pig head and pin bone steak. We had the beef heart tartare to start which was delicious but some of the bread it came with was burned. Good balance with the arugula dressed with olive oil and lemon juice. Next course was the udder and escargot special. Really fatty and really delicious. Finally the "hot mess" with foie gras with pig trotters - might have been the most flavorful dish but the white strawberries may have been added late and were not softened like the traditional red ones. Service was on point. Have not tried dessert yet but definitely will be going back.
author: Gibran P.

description: The dishes were definitely creative and left a lasting impression with some great flavors - especially the lobster and pork belly dish which I believe was a special. Service was decent although our waiter was noticeably impatient that one of our guests arrived late (there were plenty of empty tables so we weren't backing up the line).
author: Matt E.

description: Love it love it love it. I took my wife here for her birthday, and was not disappointed. I am a chef in SF, and have been looking forward to trying chef constantino's new spot for a while. we started with the beef heart tartar and ceviche. Both were presented well and tasted fantastic. From there we got the duck egg and honey grilled cheese and the mussels and nduja. Again, so good. We ended with a daily special called the hot mess. Oh yeah.  Melt in your mouth good pork skin, foi, toast, gravy, etc.. My wife ordered a ricotta and stone fruit turnover, even though our server recommended the banana dessert. She brought us a complentary one anyways... And she was right. Banana desert was on point. So freaking good.  Our server was the best also. I think she said she's normally a bartender, so glad we got her. Not pushy, attentive, on time, good reccomendations, all you need... And chef constantino was there expediting. Fun to watch. Prices seemed very fair to me as well. We will be back with a group to get our hands on the pigs head!!!!
author: erik a.

description: Had dinner on a Saturday night. So it was packed of course but the service and hospitality was incredible. We waited for our table but of course the restaurant can't control how long a group stays at the restaurant. They provided us an entree and appetizers as we waited. order all the specials and everything was great. Would come here again again and again
author: Rhod U.

description: Good food, good vibes, service without personal touch ( too busy).good food, grilled cheese whatever you have heard is correct , shrimps avocado ;creative and fine ,highly recommend ,the foia gra is overrated. Bacon chop big dish I didn't enjoy, ham burger -good, the trout was very good,  we liked the place we may try it again.
author: Yona F.

description:
Right now, in this moment that I am typing on my 'puter: I JUST read Chris Cosentino's Wikipedia page. Prior to this evening; I had NO idea that he was a Celebrity Chef (I knew he was a SF Chef, but really NO clue about the rest), no idea that he grew up in Rhode Island and no idea that he's an entrepreneur with a sausage outpost at San Francisco's Ferry Building. I didn't know about Iron Chef; i simply didn't know about the brainstorm behind the experience I had tonight that I am about to share with all of you. All I knew was this was a place to get great meat, great drinks and Cherrystones. Being from MA, I crave a little bit of home every now and then. Cockscomb is THE PLACE for lobster, clams, oysters, real meat on the grill, potatoes cooked just like Grammy used to...THEY USE REAL BUTTER! The entire thing, everything...its done with love. The ambiance, the music, the little tongue-in-cheek labels on the hand drier in the bathroom...the line of (mostly super smokin' hot men) cooking, burning themselves, sweating their balls off; literally...all in the name of great food for YOU, Me...and everyone that walks through the threshold of this glorious masterpiece.

There are 3 ways that captivate my heart and create loyalty; authenticity, the little details and great food. From the moment I opened the door to this amazing venue everyone on 'Team Cockscomb' was attentive, courteous and professional. My friend and I were seated at the bar, which is perfect for 2 single girls enjoying the open kitchen and everything else that is sensory overload for a good solid hour. I was welcomed by a wonderful man that let me know just as part of my conversation where the bathroom was located and where the 'hooks for your purse' are located. PHENOMENAL. It's not that I don't ever leave my home and people aren't nice to me; it's just awesome to experience great attention to the 'little things' when you aren't expecting it. The Yelp reviews lead me to this place, but don't do any justice when it comes to really, truly experiencing what it's like to dine here. 

Our Server knew my name, he knew it was a Birthday Dinner for me (which was not necessary, I have generous friends). I liked the guy so much I hugged him twice...once at the beginning of our meal and at the end when he told me how great we were. HE was the great one. I mean this guy Gabriel...he gave us a tour of the menu, explained the details, helped us feel at home and everything...was PERFECT. We tried the oysters, the cherry-stones (which were fabulous). The avocado enhancement was killer, I wish I knew exactly what that was because it's creamy and so yummy on the raw shellfish. Never have I had that, and I love it much more than a mignonette. We also asked for the beef heart tartare with roasted/pan fried/buttered potatoes (I want a bucket of them so I can be in a carb coma); whoa! you have to order this. The foie gras...best I've ever had. The bacon chop; it's enough for 4 people. The thing is HUGE and yummy, bacony...again, I'd never had this cut of meat and I hardly eat pork. You must get this. We also tried the chocolate...and yes...the cheese. Chocolate was decadent, rich, chocolatey...I much preferred the cheese. Bleu, honey, walnuts, jam...yum. We left with a doggie bag. I left with a new found love for a slice of my home in San Francisco. The entire evening I felt like I was in the company of an old friend and now it makes complete sense why. Thank you for a wonderful memory.
author: Sherie R.

description:
I loved Incanto, didn't love Porcellino, but I was intrigued by Cockscomb since it's supposed to be more what Chris Cosentino envisioned.  Low and behold, right when we walked in, we saw Chris Cosentino looking super involved in everything, which we took as a good sign.

The menu features a lot of more unusual animal part and offal and has slightly less options for non-meat eaters (I liked the pastas at Incanto a lot).  

We started with a bottle of Barbaresco that was pretty tannic, and it was really unexpected for a Barbaresco, but after some decanting it was ok.  I also had a Bullit, which was rye, cyanar, and bitters, but it was basically an Old Fashioned in the end, and it was still a little sweet for me.

Onto food: We definitely did this family style.  Things are pretty rich, so it's better for sharing..
- Grilled cheese with truffle: the truffle was very subtle, but I loved the honey with it, and in the center, it was quite generous with the melted cheese
- Celery Victor: a non traditional play on the dish with celery root and celery with chicken skins
- Toasted oats: probably my favorite dish - it was like a risotto made with oats, mushrooms, and a soft cooked egg.  It had a nice black pepper kick to it
- Butcher's choice: calves liver - loved the mushrooms with it, but liver just isn't my thing
- Meat pie: pork belly, snails, black mushrooms.  Broth was very flavorful, and the crust on top was good, but the broth could use some more bread (they do have Tartine bread for $1)
- Escarole with boccarones: so we could feel less guilty about all the meat; but this was still pretty rich
- Pig's head (reserved ahead of time): An entire pig head, served with poached pig brain and aoili ("brainaise?") and another herb oil.  This was very impressive in presentation, but you have to love all the gelatinous and fatty stuff.  The pig skin was really good and crisp on the outside, but even with the greens, it was too heavy for me.

Service is pretty spot on considering they just opened.  Prices ended up being pretty reasonable since the food is very filling.  If you like meat and offal, definitely come.  The layout is nice, and it's always good to see the chef there actively involved.  However, if you're not big on animal parts, then it may not be the place for you.
author: Marilyn T.

description: It's hard to overstate how much fun we had at Cockscomb. We sat at the counter which gave us a great view of the kitchen. The chefs were friendly and we enjoyed watching them cook massive pieces of meet on the grill and in the oven. Our favorite dishes were the "fall offs," which was a lovely dish of pork knuckle, foie gras, and strawberries (super rich and amazing), the coulotte steak, and the tartare. The roasted branzino was solid, but we felt it could've used more of the the mint, lemon, and sea urchin as those flavors were lost after the first few bites. We can't wait to return
author: Will C.

description: As with all new SF restaurants, this place is super popular. Known for their pigs head and giant steak, some menu items can be hit or miss. We loved the meat pie and the burger. Pork skin pasta was a miss. Also in case you're wondering, Chef Chris is always  there!
author: Calvin W.

description: This is one of those must-try once in your lifetime type of restaurant. With that said, once in a lifetime is probably good enough for me. The pig head has a good taste, but it was too oily. Rest of the dishes were okay, nothing stood out to me particularly.
author: Becky W.

description: The place is lovely, a little hipster, very cool and welcoming. The decor was fun and whimsical, loved the linens and "cockscomb" plates. Drinks were beautifully presented and tasty. Started with oysters and was not so thrilled with one set of the variety we tried  but the tomatillo sauce made up for the bland oyster taste. Had the Crudo and bruschetta and was in heaven. The bruschetta was made with morels and ramps...divine. While this place is known for meat, we did not indulge in the heartier dishes but had a grilled sausage with fennel that was a bit spicy but really good. Overall, the food was very different than what you will get in other restaurants and that is the reason to come back again. Chef Consentino has created a truly unique and signature experience.
author: Diane J.

description: Excellent, delicious food. Came here for lunch then happy hour the next day. The lunch I got (grilled cheese) was delicious and one of those rare fancy grilled cheeses that actually taste wonderful. The gin & tonic I ordered was very strong and insanely good. Happy hour was good as well--oysters were tasty but shucked somewhat poorly (lots of shell bits in the oyster). Menu rotates throughout the year and I can't wait to go back!
author: Irin S.

description: Holy cow, and I guess holy pig! This place was ah-mazing! Randomly stumbled in here after Marlowe's had a long wait. We started with delicious oysters. Next up - our salads. Really nice size portions, great flavors. I had the butter lettuce with lemon/anchovy dressing - I love anchovies, so it was delicious! We then shared the angry lobster and pork belly - um, I didn't realize they would serve us the entire pig! This was honestly the biggest serving of pork belly I had ever seen! It was incredible - it just melted after you got that nice crunch from the outside. They left the meat under the layer of pork belly fat, oh yummy. I almost forgot the best dish of the night - hot mess? It was foie gras with some duck meat served in this delicious sauce and some pickled rubarb! I could have probably had that all to myself, but we shared. I don't want to share next time!  The service was great - but do be warned, you may leave smelling like that hickory smoke, but I happen to like the smell! I want to go back and try more sides and apps and dessert!!!
author: Rochelle T.

description: Fun environment, super friendly staff, and adventurous  food lol. We not only had things like meat pie and foie gras, we had half of a Pigs Head, literally!!! It was a little scary with a rich and crispy taste. Drinks were pretty yummy also, I really liked the classic gin and tonic with a twist of jam and fresh seasonal fruit.
author: Shannon J.

description: Another amazing experience at one of my favorite SF restaurants.  Particular stand out was the bacon chop, which was incredible.  Can't wait to go back.
author: Rob B.

description: My wife and I had the best of meals and times celebrating her birthday at Cockscomb. The wait staff was totally tops shelf, as well as the brilliant men and woman in the kitchen! The atomisphere was warm and inviting, and the cocktails were smooth and tasty. The Cockscomb is now our go to place for any time we have guests over, celebrations, etc. in conclusion I say 'Go there now. Eat and enjoy!'.
author: Greg R.

description: Chris Cosentino! You are sent from God up above for San Francisco!!! That's all I can say! I'm  just speechless! Food was PERFECT! -the end-
author: Krizzia C.

description: Yum. Love the hustle and bustle sitting in the bar sipping white wine and having oysters
author: Bernino L.

description: All the things we ordered were awesome, especially the whole roasted branzino!
author: K C.

description:
It's all about the food, right? The cocktails are pretty fucking amazing as well. The space is awesome, sitting for a couple of cocktails in the mezzanine lounge overseeing the joy you're about to experience, although you don't know it yet, is delightful and enlightening. Didn't ask the bartenders name up above, but what a great introduction to Cosentino's new joint. What a gem, she is.
 We requested seats facing the kitchen, we got the best seats in the house.
 Great knowledgeable and proud waiter, eager support staff. 
 We had:
 Bruschetta, awesome. Lardo and crab go great together. Great nuances with with uni butter, herbs, and Radish.
 Beef heart tartar. Oh baby. No bread or potato needed. Great peppery herb baby greens to accompany. 
 Bacon chop. I loved it, but in retrospect, there may be one element missing to make it completely orgasmic. I still orgasmed tho. 
 Then we thought a little different dessert of things we omitted. Grilled Cheese. Fucking awesome, except the Oregon white truffles were a bit lost, too delicate. Some black truffles would have given it a little more attitude. Still great.
 Still after this intense meal, we were still in the mood for more. Watching all this food come out, and having the absolute privilege to watch Chef Cosentino guide his staff with such firm respect and encouragement, we wanted his newly legal foie interpretation. Again, amazing. A little too much happening on the plate, but who the fuck am I to complain? 
Overall a great experience. My new favorite spot in the city.
 Unpretentious and to the point. Great food.
author: Fabian F.

description:
Several years ago, we celebrated my husband's birthday at Incanto, so when I learned Cockscomb is Chef Cosentino's new restaurant, I was eager to try it. (I admit that the many Yelp pictures of the pig's head also peaked my interest.)

The beef heart tartar was a nice starter to share. My husband really enjoyed the bacon chop, all ~2 lbs of it! I had the oyster omelette, which was simple and tasty. (I just wasn't in the mood for anything heavier that night.)

We came on a busy Friday night, but the service was welcoming and attentive. My water glass was never empty.

The only down-side was that it was a little too loud. Still, I'd be up for returning with a larger party to try the pig's head!
author: Amanda M. C.

description: I loved cockscomb....and not just because I was super starstruck by Mr. Cosentino....so adorable with those dimples...  Everything was so good.  Pigs Head...so good, actually might go veggie for a while after that...so much wonderful pork.  Bartenders are great.  Drinks are great.  Food is great.
author: stephanie L.

description: I came across this establishment due to Andrew Zimmern of Bizzare Foods, not because of Bizzare foods but because Andrew is doing a new show and made a visit to this restaurant. I became obsessed with trying and decided to wrangle my aunt into accompanying me to visit. I made reservations which is very smart for this place. The location is great, one of those tucked in areas of SOMA surrounded by loft like restaurants and businesses. We started with a pork skin putanesca with capers and olives ! It was marvelous! I'm really picky about the cuts of meat I like. The pork skin was cooked very tender and wash slice was coated with a great tomato, garlic, caper sauce. It was like I was eating the best noodles !! We also ordered the beef heart tartare which I have to admit I was reluctant. I don't care for organ meat, boy did this change my mind. A very mild taste that was so tender. Topped with a mustard sauce. ( I think that was mustard) during our visit Chef Cosentino  was ever present. We finished our meal with the Bacon Chop , this isn't your regular pork chop. It is a hearty pork chop bone in with pork belly attached. The best cooked pork chop ever, the pink ring that surrounded the chop is a telltale sign of a perfect cook. I can't recommend this place enough. if you like Chef Cosetino's vision "Putting a face on what you eat opens your eyes a lot" Definitely on my top 5 list of places to try !
author: Rosa V.

description: Love! Great atmosphere, cocktails and food. Our table of 4 enjoyed the whole fish, eggplant, beets, squash. Started with the medium "fruit de mer". Great service too. Fun seeing the handsome and cool "chef Chris" in the kitchen. Finished off with pot de creme and panna cotta. (Having celiac, dining here was a breeze - all mentioned were GF!!)
author: MaryK G.

description: We went to Cockscomb yesterday for our anniversary. The atmosphere-- fun, loud, and very unique with the open kitchen. We were seated at the bar, right in the thick of all the action. Instead of ordering two big entrees, we ordered four appetizers-- the grilled cheese with truffles, uni and lardo bruschetta, beef heart tartare, and the hot mess (foie gras with strawberries and trotters). The food was AMAZING. The foie gras was by far the best-- just out of this world delicious. I was surprised how much I liked the tartare, never having eating raw meat before. And the uni and lardo bruschetta was delectable, something that I would have never thought I would have liked. Out of the four, i guess my least favorite dish was the grilled cheese because i found it slightly too salty and would have preferred it without the egg, but that is just personal preference because my husband loved it. All in all, it was a fantastic experience. I highly recommend it and we will be back again. We met Chef Chris Cosentino on the way out, and he just seemed like a sweetheart-- someone that is just really happy with the work that they are doing. Obviously, he and his team are amazing at what they do.
author: Julia T.

description:
Dinner at Cockscomb was one of the greatest culinary adventures I've had in years.  

We started with a round of cocktails and apps at the bar. Their signature drinks are all names for films shots in San Francisco, and the menu includes biodynamic wines from Italy that only produce 800 cases a year. 

For apps, we had the "Egg, Egg, Egg" and the Truffle Grilled Cheese. Both were delectable!

Once at our table, chef Chris Cosentino (yeah, the super famous guy!) started sending out a barrage of courses, each one topping the others. He started us with a huge tower of oysters, lobster, crab, mussels, and urchin.  The five of us left no shell untouched. 

Next came the "pork chop," which was a 3 lb. pork rib roast that basically still included the bacon on it. Soooooooo tender. 

Following the chop, Chris sent out the....wait for it.... PIG HEAD. Literally a half a pig head roasted to perfection. Who knew pig cheeks were so tasty and tender. It was like fire roasted butter!

Finally, we were delighted by the "Pinbone Steak" -- another HUGE cut of meat (this time beef -- 96 oz. of it).  

What made every course so special was its slow roasted treatment in the kitchen's wood oven.  It gives everything that comes out of it a rich, smokey flavor, a crisp exterior, and an oh-so-tender core. 

All-in-all, Cockscomb far exceeded my wildest expectations, even given Consentino's reputation. I will most definitely be back -- I just hope I can get a reservation.
author: Edward S.

description: Bad linguine.  Sand and unreduced wine in clam sauce.  Steak was horrible.  Eggs eggs eggs was ok
author: J S.

description: The liver and the beef heart tartar were excellent. Coming back to try the rest of the tasty bits in the menu. The cocktail list is a bit heavy-handed on bitters and stuff like that, will go for a nice bottle of wine instead :)
author: Anton S.

description:
I have been here 2 times in 2 weeks. Yes, I had a serious craving.   

1. Grilled Cheese, with honey, fresh brioche and topped with truffle.  Oh dear, this is just too good to be true.
2.  "Ham" burger, yes, it is made from pork parts.  Pork shoulder and another part, which escapes me.   The crispy fried potatoes that accomany this should be a menu item on it's own.....delicious.   Truly handsdown one of the best burgers in the Bay Area.  Believe me, few, very few places have met expectations.  Not only did this burger do that, it went over and beyond.
3. & chips.  This particular evening, it was a sausage, and oh how fresh and lovely this was.   
4. House draft Cider.   This is my new thing, cider.  Irish, English and lately American.   This one had the perfect balance and went down quite nicely.
5. Dessert.  Hmmm, where to start on this wonderful treat?   We ordered the "Fruit" plate and it came with a cake that was made with olive oil.  I can't say enough about this because it was a 2nd time order and just as terrific as before.

Stop by if you don't have a reservation, sit or stand at the bar.  Ordered the Grilled Cheese and a glass of wine. You will be in for a treat.
author: Mo C.

description:
Way overated... and way over priced. Pig head that tasted truely nasty and fatty for @
About $70. Duck fat cauliflower that was bland. To think I waited 2 months to go to this place...Skip it. You will be disappointed.
author: John S.

description: This place is amazing. We had a steak that was by far the best ever had in sf. Great ambience with a cool upstairs bar. New go to spot in soma.
author: Honest A.

description:
I have eaten here a few times a week since the place opened (because I live around the corner and am lazy/don't Like cooking solo).  In short, the food is fantastic!  Last night I took the BF there for dinner, and wow, both food and service was incredible.  

Standouts for me:
- uni and Lardo bruschetta (OMG- this is what unicorns must taste like- how does something taste that incredible!)
- celery victor- would never have ordered if BF didn't want but such a ridiculously good app!
- "ham" burger...there are no words...just get it if on the menu
- roasted pig head- again, no words...took rest we didn't eat home to make kotteri ramen and broth turning out as good as I had last time in Kyoto
- pork chop is incredible and huge!
- duck fat cauliflower- wow, perfect balance of salt, heat, herbs, and tanginess of capers
- crepe cake- so thoughtfully executed
- whatever that crack laced chocolate dessert is- yes please.

Others I enjoyed:
- grilled cheese- not my thing but was very tasty
- sweetbreads from Butchers Choice- really well cooked with a nice salsa verde
- "and chips" with a pork kale and chile sausage.  There are they more exciting menu choices, but this a solid dish with amazing potatoes

Only criticism- I did not like the Eggs, Eggs, Eggs- to me,  temperature made it fall flat and one-noted.  Would love if eggs were warm to contrast the tarragon and trout roe.

This place is a rockstar in an emerging area of the city for dining- in short, I heart this place:)
author: T G.

description: I had a great time here. Service was great. Food was outstanding. Would love to come back when i return to san francisco. Loved the bruschetta, the pork skin puttanesca, the Hot Mess, and the desserts.
author: Rob L.

description: My friends took me here for my bday this past Saturday. Everything was amazing and cooked to perfection. Stand outs were the Fois Gras loaf, Crab and Pork Belly, Pig's Head and Bacon Chop. Service was top notch. Highly recommended.
author: Virgil H.

description:
First off, I'm really impressed by the fact that Chef Chris Cosentino is not one of those chefs that just walk around and don't actually get involved in the kitchen. He was also nice enough to say bye and thank us from behind the counter when we left. 

DRINKS:
1) Pisco Punch - My fiancee loved it.
2) Vertigo Fizz - I thought it was tasty. Would have been better if it had a little more fizz though.

FOOD:
1) Crudo of the Day - This was very good. We decided to add this onto our menu for the night last minute. No complaints here.
2) Gems salad - I loved this dish. The pig ears added a nice crunch to the salad. My fiancee didn't care for them, but that just means more for me!
3) Grilled cheese - THE BEST GRILLED CHEESE YOU WILL EVER HAVE! Gotta learn to make this at home.
4) Hamburger - My fiancee said it was the best burger he's ever had. Even better than the one he had at Gordon Ramsay's Burgr in Vegas. I had a taste too and it was heavenly. I think if this came on toasted sourdough, it would be my dream sandwich. 
5) Pizzani (?) - It's the sausage dish. This was the least exciting of the night. I felt the sausage was spicy, but bland. Could have used a tad more salt and char. The salad was dressed in a sort of creamy dressing, which became difficult to eat when paired with the sausage. I would have been happy with a green salad dressed with just lemon juice and olive oil. 

Overall, it was great. Would definitely return, especially for that delicious grilled cheese!
author: L M.

description: Had dinner here tonight. Was so freakin amazing had to post a review. Came as a party of 9. Tried most of the menu. Appetizer: cured ham and apples- amaze balls! 5-stars. Great flavor. Oysters/clam- fresh, clean, and shucked well without bits. Crab guys sauce delicious to dip bread into. 3 different sauces. Bruschetta with crab meat, 5-stars! Prom chop, #1 entree no hesitation. Served rare and thick like filet mignon. Big enough for 3-4 ppl. Sol (fish) served with grape garnish a close 2nd. Bavette steak was okay. Several slices. Nothing extraordinary. Served atop a few whole carrots. Meat pie with escargot was prob lease favorite. Crust done well, escargot a bit over cooked and chewy. Cauliflower side was super tasty. Will definitely come back. Congrats Chef Chris!
author: Mark C.

description: We SO wanted to love this place and enjoyed our lunch immensely until my husband came down with food poisoning!  He believes it was the pork belly sandwich (we both ate the seafood chowder and I didn't get sick-loved the chowder by the way) and he even commented that the last few bites of the sandwich just didn't taste right.  We are such huge fans of Chris Cosentino and are so disappointed.
author: Loni P.

description: Great seats at the bar, in front of all the action, very lively vibe and full of open-minded eaters. The menu is great, our 3rd time eating here and keeps getting better. You can't go wrong with any item on the menu, and Chef's offal tastings are consistently the high points on the menu. We had a array of briny oysters and flavorful mignonettes, Benton's ham and melons, the "hot mess" with trotters was amazing and the epitome of pork and liver goodness, and the rosemary panna cotta is still the best dessert in San Francisco, perfect technique and flavor. I wish more people understand what's going on here and how special this place to the city!
author: John A.

description: This is my first review on Yelp and gotta say, this restaurant is awesome--I am a pretty hardcore Vegan and they do Vegan well.  The eggplant entree was very flavorful, my tomato and peach salad was perfect and the cocktails great.  My carnivore friends had a lamb shoulder--nothing I could have but they raved about it.  On top of that, our server (Joshua) made vegan dining in a meat oriented place easy and he was just super attentive and friendly. I will be going back a lot.
author: Tom B.

description:
Delicious. Been here 5x had the pinbone steak everytime.

The medium sized shellfish app, sole, and sides were delicious also. 

Chris cosentino is present in the kitchen. He also comes to the table and eats with you if you know the code word. 

Definitely visit.

The desert menu is weak af though!
author: Benny C.

description: Food was great. A little pricey for my personal taste, but service was great.
author: TJ H.

description:
Happy hour at 10 pm is a brilliant idea.  That is my favorite time to visit. 

The atmosphere is modern chic, the lighting is flattering, the food is edgy and will executed.  The crowd is a blend of neighborhood locals, startup tech types who work nearby, hipsters, and foodies.

This is a great place to bring a date or out of towners (not for picky eaters who are afraid of the unusual).  They'll modify dishes to be vegetarian if you ask.  The menu is for a little more adventurous eater.

They do change up the menu somewhat regularly; the meat pie changes frequently and it's always fantastic.
author: C B.

description: Good food. Not great. Not as original as I had hoped. Service was some of the worst I have experienced in my travels. Made a 1015 reservation, showed up on time and was rushed from the time we sat down. Made to order drinks and dinner within minutes of sitting down and told the kitchen was closing.
author: Adam E.

description:
great room for dining - cozy and spacious,fun, festive, lively

hearty food

friendly staff

:-)
author: Maggie L.

description:
I'm not a big food reviewer. An experience has to really stand out for me to say something on a forum like this. Two of us had birthdays in the same week and decided to do something really different with our accompanying friends on what can only be billed as a taste safari.

This menu is really different. 

I say that as a compliment because it delivered exactly what we were looking for - the novelty of experiencing exotic and unconventional-to-the-American-palette dishes in a pleasant setting. We skipped the more traditional entrees and went straight for the jaw-droppers: the towering melange of a seafood platter, the pigs head, the snail shepherd's pie, etc. I can't tell you whether the food was properly prepared because I have nothing to compare it to, except to say it was a memorable and fascinating experience. We had people from a nearby table request to take pictures of our plates, which only added to the surreality of what we were eating, but perfectly titled for a birthday dinner adventure. You won't otherwise hear me say this about a restaurant, but I really didn't care if the food was delicious - I was more interested in just experiencing it - savoring each bite and trying to evaluate my own visceral impression of "do I like this?" and checking to see what my tablemates thought as well.

For that, this restaurant gets four stars. I don't know that I would order those dishes more than once a year (they are inherently rich foods) so when I return for a non-birthday, I'll have a chance to sample the less eye-catching fare that would normally be the highlight of your better dining establishments but at first can't compete here with the rest of the edible cirque du soleil on this menu. 

I applaud the chef for attempting something bold and unique and entertaining and pulling it off. For that alone, I'm going to suggest you try it at least once this year. Maybe twice just to make sure.
author: Christian V.

description: Awesome food! Excellent service. We were there just for a quick drink and a bite at happy hour. Great happy hour menu for both food and drinks. We had the pig ear and $1 oysters. Both were terrific. Looking forward to going back for a full dinner.
author: Whit G.

description: BFF's birthday dinner and it was awful. The bone marrow dish wasn't done at all and mostly just bone.  The porkchop and steak were flavorless and over cooked.  The broccoli rabe was sour.  The cauliflower didn't taste like it had duck fat.  The carrots over cooked on exterior and hard on the inside.  The desserts were mediocre.  They were nice enough to remove a couple of dishes, brought some shots.  Oh and the paper straws!  Throw them away!!  Overall it wasn't a great experience and we really wanted to like it.  Maybe an off night?  Not coming back.  It was a disappoint.
author: D C.

description: Awesome food, drinks and service crew. Very unfortunate bad time estimation for the table and food. We were told it would be 30 minutes wait for the table and it turned out to be an hour. Once we sat down, it then took about 40 minutes between the ordering and actually getting the food on the table. Lots to improve but the food and atmosphere are great.
author: Penfan S.

description: The food was good, but our plates came out a bit too slowly, and our server wasn't very attentive. She didn't even check on us  once. We didn't expect that there would be a charge for bread, and it would have been nice if our server had told us ahead of time. The food was worth going back for, but the poor service this evening left me disappointed.
author: Wing W.

description: Staff was great and attentive. The remodel looks great. Love the renovated space upstairs. Food was good. We were appalled they charge extra for the bread to go with the pate. I mean seriously we're paying $200.00 dollars for a party of two - deal with an extra Alice of bread.  I don't really care that it comes from Tartine.
author: Andre S.

description: The food that we ordered was really delicious, worth at least 4 stars if not more. The variety of food was very limited to pork based. There were few chicken, beef and veg options. The service was also intermittent and thus based off the limited foods and service, I give this a 3 star
author: Haris I.

description: Tried a broad assortment of their offal offerings, each was disappointing. Definitely sub-par for SF.
author: Joe H.

description: Sorry but this place is ordinary. Nothing special, nothing bad, but everything's ordinary. I'm from Montreal, and I'm still looking for a restaurant with the same quality of food and ambiance in SF .... Didn't find it yet.
author: Marie Andree S.

description:
We had an amazing dinner!  Our waiter was fantastic (a young Denzel Washington look alike) who gave us wonderful recommendations for our entire meal.  We shared the quail which was perfect and so tasty.  The cauliflower side was amazing.  We started with mussels and "chips".  The "chips" were wonderfully seasoned, crunchy small potato pieces.  Fabulous fruit dessert with sponge cake.  Our waiter recommended a cocktail, wine, and an after dinner drink for my husband which was right on spot.  We ended our meal with a great espresso - large, hot, and strong!

Can't wait to go back.  I also loved the decor!  Fantastic new find!
author: Jan B.

description: Glad to see Chris C back at the stoves of his new place because the guy can cook.  He is on the wild side as he likes weird ingredients like beef heart tartar, etc.  But his cooking is spot on.  Service was good and vibe was pleasant as small warm place that features dishes you won't find anywhere else.  Decent wine list and good cocktails.  Be warned that 4th St is under construction so need to get belie to Brennan or you will be late for your Reso!
author: Gregory C.

description: This was a wonderful dining experience! We went for my wife's birthday. Everyone in the staff greeted her and  made sure to wish her a happy birthday. The food was incredible! We had oysters, the grilled cheese with honey and duck egg and the pigskin carbonara. The pigskin carbonara is genius and delicious!! Our friendly waiter Gabe suggested we have the last special available, the pork belly with angry lobster and clams. All I can say is WOW! The peach dessert was also incredible. The open kitchen allows you to see the chefs preparing everything and adds to the vibe. Highly recommend you go try this place out!
author: Jose L.

description: Very happy we came here.  The pig face was delicious and bruschetta with uni butter was divine!
author: Ted K.

description: So bad attitude. I made a reservation here but they couldn't find the reservation and ask me to wait forever. And it was FOREVER! And they were blaming me for this! So ridiculous! Can't stand!
author: Jinyi C.

description: My meal here is easily one of the best I have ever had, from start to finish. Service was spot on and very well informed. My suggestion is a go as table of four as the portions are perfect for four people to share and do as many courses as possible. My girlfriend and I had the crudo, morel, ricotta and ramp salsa verde bruschetta, Kudomo oysters, foie gras, confit and medium ripe strawberries (my favorite), roasted petrale sole with uni and shaved fennel and we finished with panna cotta.  I absolutely love this place and will be back many many times.  My only gripe would be the website needs to be updated so the menu online matches what they are serving because I was really hoping to have the whole roasted branzino.
author: Bren D.

description:
By the end of the meal we wished Cosentino had kept Incanto.

In a nutshell, we felt our entire meal was average.

We ordered ... 

the crudo special of the day (tasty but nothing special),

the  Bruschetta (lardo, dill & sardines; the best dish of the evening), 

the lamb chop (the special Butcher's choice; very, very fatty), 

pig's skin linguini (I love pig skin and the linguini didn't hint of it whatsoever) and,

the Duck Fat Cauliflower (bland).

In sum, it felt like steak house with a twist but not enough of a twist for us to return.  

There are simply too many other awesome restaurants in SF where, for us, are no brainers to return.  

Nonetheless, give it a try because perhaps we just tried the wrong dishes.
author: Bill N.

description: We loved this place!! We sat next to the expediter's station, and the Chef was there too, and we were so impressed with everything, if we lived there, we would be there every night!!! Carnivore Heaven!!!
author: S. S.

description: I went for the special Historical San Francisco menu. It was really consistently good! I'd like to go back for the regular menu. My friend had food off the regular menu and the gnocchi and branzino were both excellent.
author: Daniel C.

description: Wow - I've been back twice now since my 1st visit and I've had the same awesome experience!  The beef tartare, pigs head and the steak are ultimate must gets.  I was really impressed by the steak.  I don't often order it at restaurant and this was perfectly made and served by the Chef!  The pigs heads now that I've had twice is definitely fat over kill but definitely a once in a lifetime type of dish.  It's super fatty, so don't over do it and maybe best accompanied with bread.
author: Meredith K.

description:
The food was good. Good quality and good taste. The service however...not very transparent or delighting.

We (4 of us) were informed about a Lobster and Pork Belly special that only had one order left, so one of our friends quickly ordered it as her entree The waiter never mentioned the price or portion size. The other 3 of us, got the pinbone steak which is meant to feed 4 people. Our waiter though still encouraged us to get an appetizer. We already thought the steak and an order of cauliflower was more than enough for just 3 of us and the friend who got the special was planning on dessert so we politely declined. 

The Lobster and Pork Belly special came out and the portion was huge. It could've easily fed 2-3 people if not 4. Combined with the pinbone steak, we had WAY TOO much food. Granted we didn't ask how big the special was, but knowing the portions why would the waiter still encourage us to order more food, unless only to up the bill/tip. Sufficed to say we were surprised at the portions and then of course dreaded the cost of the bill, with a ton of food leftover. To top it off, we couldn't find our waiter to get the bill for about 15 min, so we had to go get it ourselves. 

Again food was good, but the service leaves something to be desired.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
Perfect from start to finish. We sat next to Chef Cosentino in front of the roaring fire with cans of Oskar Blues Pinner Throwback IPA. Sip Sip Pass... Then onto the meal:
Fresh Oysters and Cherrystone Clams
Country Pate
Bruschetta with Ricotta and Morels
Roasted Bone Marrow 
Fire Roasted Asparagus (some veg to not feel so guilty)
Blue Cheese Wedge 
Basil Panna Cotta     
We will be back again and again. Everything on the menu, and coming out of the kitchen, looked great. If your a vegetarian you not only suck but don't bother coming here.
author: David W.

description: PIG! PIG! PIG!  In styles you can only imagine.  How about half a pig's head (snout included), or a "bacon" pork chop to die for? a really excellent place for the unusual treatment of any number of dishes.  The pickled sardine bruschetta was marvelous.  And don't miss the variety of unusually infused gins.  I'll have to go back several times to fully sample their fare.  Hasten thee here to sample on your own!
author: Howard B.

description: Amazing as always! Oysters, "Ham" burger, and bacon chop - Yum!!!
author: Christopher B.

description: Awesome food!   Had the oysters as well as the fried chicken sandwich.  Loved it!   Can't wait to go back!   Great service too!!
author: Kristen M.

description: We ordered the roasted pig's head which.. was delish but unfortunately we didn't realize it's a really fatty cut, so there was not as much meat as we would have liked. But what wasn't fat was so tender and full of flavor. We also ordered the crudo and seasonal veggie which were both really well seasoned and just very tasty. For dessert we had the cheese which was a smoky blue cheese, I highly recommend it. Overall it was great service and I will go back and try some of the other main dishes. But, if you are ordering the pigs head you might want more than 2 people so you can also order some other mains to fill up on.
author: Carey T.

description:
After reading reviews I came here with a friend with an empty stomach, expecting a feast. Apparently we ordered the wrong things, and instead left hungry and disappointed. We tried a few of the nightly specials, and perhaps that was a mistake, though we would come back and try some of the not so experimental fares.

As we saw the pig head getting rave reviews, we tried the special fish head of the night. It was $60 and supposed to serve two people. It came out on a giant platter, and we thought it looked amazing with all of its garnishes, until we tried to eat it. There was a rather miniscule amount of meat on it, and all together much smaller than a single filet. The waiter didn't once come by and ask how we actually thought it was, and I didn't bother asking for anything else due to the fact that it took so long to get our meal and we wanted to get out of there. All in all we were pretty disappointed, maybe avoid the "specials" if you go.
author: Kevin G.

description: I have been to Cockscomb several times for both food and drinks, and every visit has been solid. The pig's head is definitely the most memorable and interesting. But if that's too adventurous, should get a group of 4 to try the pin bone steak. For light snacks with drinks, the grilled cheese and bruschetta are great choices. The staffs and bartenders are very knowledgeable, makes great recommendation and very friendly. You can't go wrong with anything here.
author: Elaine C.

description:
Overall an enjoyable experience.  The pig's head was a great novelty item, but was 80% fat, too rich for our table, as others have noted. The pin bone steak was very good, charred on the outside, rare inside, just how we like it.

The service was excellent.  The vibe of the place was unique, rustic, hip, fun.  We definitely enjoyed our experience there, just have to experiment more with with the, rather unique, menu.  We're Asian and are used to the various offal parts, so that says a lot about their level of experimentation.

Chris was gracious in having his picture taken with the ladies in our party.  Definitely worth another visit.
author: Tuan N.

description: First of all I don't write a lot of reviews, but in this instance I think it would be in the best interest to a new merchant to have this feedback. First of all the food was awesome, that atmosphere was great and the server was knowledgeable and on point. This could have been a 5 star review. Unfortunately the host decided that it was a good idea to rush us away from our table as soon as the check was paid. Now I don't know about you but in my 44 years I've waited "with" reservations for people who were having a good time on many occasions. Especially when the bill was $490 bucks. I just thought it was tacky and it left a bad taste in my mouth, after what would have been a great evening. Don't shy away from this place, just don't pay the bill until your ready to hit the door.
author: Mallory G.

description: The celery victor and lobster were standouts. Great service.  Will definitely be returning soon!
author: Fred X.

description:
Eating at Cockscomb is like living an episode of No Reservations. Specifically, the one where Anthony Bourdain goes to that place in Montreal that tries to kill him with foie gras. Cockscomb is run by people who really love food, and it shows in the open kitchen layout, the sense of humor in the menu, and all kinds of little touches. They want you to have an experience here.

I hosted an eight-person birthday party here. We ordered about a third of the menu and came out at $92 per person, tips and (many) drinks included. I highly recommend the pin bone steak for four or more, and if you like pork you are going to love the roast pig's head. We took the carcass home and made ramen.
author: E L.

description: Although the food was excellent; I arrived having a reservation at 8:45 and was not seated till 9:25. I was hungry. I get cranky when I'm hungry..... You know ?
author: Sanam A.

description:
Man this place is good!

Came here on a Saturday night (had reservations, but really don't think you need them), and was blown away by how good the food was. Note, this place is in an alleyway, just follow the neon sign and you will be fine.

Plus, Chris was actually here tonight working (which I feel is a rarity for some chefs), and just seeing his interactions with the staff and the customers really tells you how much he cares about the food. Started off with the daily crudo (excellent, well seasoned, and fresh), as well as the pate and the terrine. I admit, probably not the smartest idea to get both of those to share with the lady, but we had to try them both and while they were both top notch, it was almost like it was too much of a good thing. Looking back, with just the two of us there, I wish we had tried something else for variety's sake. Also got the grilled cheese with white truffles and honey (read: REALLY good, but then again white truffles sort of makes EVERYTHING better), and the pig skin spaghetti with puttanesca sauce. It had a bit of a weird texture (after all noodles made of pig skin probably would), but it was really flavorful, and the acidity and brightness of the sauce definitely balanced out the richness of the noodles. Followed that up (I know right, somehow we still had space in our stomachs) with the crepe cake with yuzu marmalade and citrus, which while I thought it was good, just seemed a bit too tangy/acidic. Really wish it had some chocolate sauce to balance it out and it probably would have been perfect. 

All in all, pretty dang close to a perfect meal, Chef Chris also stopped by the table at the end of the meal and it was really nice to shake his hand and thank him for an excellent meal. Definitely give this place a try if you're in the area!
author: David H.

description:
I walked past Cockscomb on my birthday a few weeks ago while en route to another restaurant.  The small restaurant oozes "hipster foodie cool" from half a block away.  I booked a reservation here with the intent of entertaining some out of town guests, and I was not disappointed!

Ambiance:  Very cool and industrial space, but warm lighting and cool decor that is very animal-centric.  I love the open kitchen and the staff was super friendly (everyone looked as though they had been awaiting my arrival all night :-P)

Cocktails/Beverages:  Decent beer and wine selection with a nice cocktail list.  This is pretty standard in all restaurants of this caliber in SF, so no complaints here

Apps:  Started with the oysters, which were served with varying sauces/oils.  I really liked the avocado green tomatillo salsa!  OH. MY. CHEESE.  The honey truffle grilled cheese app was PHENOMENAL.  Somehow still golden and crispy even though it was drizzled in sweet honey...perfectly topped with shaved black truffle.  I think this was the best thing I ate at Cockscomb.

Mains/Sides:  We ordered the pig's head (to share between 4), the Meat Pie, and a side of broccoli rabe and duck fat cauliflower.  The pig's head was cooked to perfection...crisp, light skin with juicy pulled-pork style meat underneath.  The flavor was incredible.  The Meat Pie of the evening was pork belly and clam.  Interestingly enough, the server described this as a stew with a crust on top, but it was more like a soup.  The pie was mostly a rich, delicious broth with some juicy bits of pork and veggies inside.  It tasted like home.  The sides were good, though nothing to write home about.  We basically just ordered them as obligatory fiber additions to our fat kid meal.  

I definitely recommend Cockscomb for those who want to do something a little different and interesting for dinner!
author: Vivien M.

description:
If you're looking to have a very meaty dinner then you've come to the right place. My buddies and I came out here with our expectations being met by the end of the night.  The restaurant is located in SOMA and a convenient pay parking lot can be found right across the street. The place is welcoming and the staff is excellent  with the waiters always attentive .  The interior of the restaurant is very simple and modern with a large bar on the first floor, another mini bar on the second and plenty of tables on both. Bathroom was OK although you would have to wait in line - could be better. Reservations are a must as it gets packed, definitely a good place to go to if you're going out with a group of friends. Not sure how I would feel though on a date night as the place can get a bit loud.

The menu was promising. Starting off with the grilled cheese, beef heart tartare, and foie gras. The grilled cheese and beef tartare was delicious but the foie gras is must if you're a fan. The combination of the three was definitely enough for 4 grown men. 
For my entree I ordered the Bacon Chop and  shared with the guys on the Pig's Head. The Pig's Head was roasted near to perfection coming out hot from the wooden oven, watch you're fingers! The best part was definitely the cheek, melting like butter in your mouth. The skin wasn't too over cooked but just at the right crunchiness, mm-mm! The Bacon Chop, unfortunately, was a bit of  a disappointment as most of it was all fat but nonetheless the flavor was excellent and the dip that came out with it made you want more. I would suggest ordering more bread if its gets too porky or meaty for you. I will note though that my two other buddies came out with better chops as theirs were not as fatty. The dinner ended with some coffee and chocolate which was satisfying. 

Overall, the place was  good but what made the place stand out I think was the service and the portion size. Our sever David did a very good job always meeting my groups needs. The waiting time for our food was conveniently fast. Drinks were always asked for which was great. I would  definitely come again.
author: Alvin T.

description:
Fantastic!

When I read the menu, I was worried that I would hate everything.  But my friends are, and they ordered all the random stuff - and it was AMAZING!

I went with a large group, so we ordered the Pinbone steak and pigs head to be served family style for the group, and suplemented with a bunch of appetizers.  It was a great way to taste all sorts of icky-sounding dishes that all tasted amazing.  

The only thing that wasnt a rave, was the pot pie, which was merely ok.  Not sure why all the raves are here on yelp.  But everything else was phenominal.
author: Jeffrey H.

description:
We came here to eat at the end of December, and I realized I needed to write a review, so long after the fact, as I am still reminded of the meal and have talked about it with so many people. 

Please note that I am not a prolific Yelp review writer, but this meal had me talking about it over other meals and with strangers about the latest most memorable dining experience in San Francisco. And, it made me realize that it was an injustice to Cockscomb and the genius of Chris Consentino not to do so. 

I went to Cockscomb with one other person, and we split two appetizers, the bacon pork chop and a dessert. The bacon pork chop was so amazing, that it made me question why I haven't ordered pork chops for every meal that I've eaten before. It was the best pork chop I've had, and it changed my mind on pork chops going forward. 

The duck fat braised cauliflower was a perfect complement to the main course. And the meal was rounded out by a light salad to start and a light dessert to end. 

I am terribly sorry to have never had a meal at Encanto before it closed, but I count myself so lucky to have caught a meal at Cockscomb now.
author: Quan L.

description: Well-prepared food in a large, beautiful 2-story space where diverse cuts of meat are the star! Drinks were good as well. Our server had a lot to remember but did fine. Dessert was decent but not the star of the meal.
author: Dennis W.

description: Meat lovers paradise, and great cocktails. Crudo was a bit bland, but I think that's because it hand to stand up to all the other strong flavors. The tombo was certainly buttery-fresh. Grilled cauliflower was underdone and boring. Everything else was strong. Quail, beef tartare were original and perfect. We went on a Tuesday. Had a reservation and were seated promptly. At the kitchen counter -- a little hot considering all the firepower back there, but it was fun and the chefs were charming and interactive, unexpected considering how busy they were. A bit pricey, but I think you get what you pay for in terms of quality, craft, portion and originality. Will definitely go back because there is so much on the menu I want to try!!!
author: Rob K.

description:
Pretty tasty food, and good drinks. If you're looking for lighter or vegetarian fare, you probably want a different restaurant.
