The signature roasted pig's head is fatty, crispy, hearty, salty, and delicious--for the first couple servings. It's too heavy beyond that, so don't count on eating it as your sole entree. They'll also say that 3 people can share it, but it's really better for 5-6 people, with each person having a small portion along with other entrees or side dishes.

The cauliflower was mediocre. The celery salad was good.
author: Eric S.

description: Wonderful evening, the food was outstanding. The service was world class. Thanks to the kitchen and staff at Cockscomb for a prefect evening.
author: Ryan B.

description: Love the vision and the enthusiasm that Chris and his team put into every aspect of the restaurant.  From the repurposing of the former dinning room tables, to the tchotchkes, to the plate ware,  it shows how much love and thought went in to creating this space as well as the menu.  The food was spot on, rich and comforting on a December evening.  The entire staff was welcoming, it was evident that they were proud of the food and beverages that was being served.  Excited to have this caliber restaurant housed in such a comfortable space.
author: Brye L.

description: I can't wait to go back and back again. The duck liver terrine was great with the coach compote and a little spiciness. Lamb pie was so tasty and gamey the way I like. Beef heart tartare was another hit!
author: Marie r.

description: Very slow service. The food came out quick but the people working really take their time doing thinks. Overall this place reminds me of a scene from Hostel.
author: Kris K.

description: Food is good, but only 3 stars because they don't know how to run a restaurant and manage tables turn-over. Had appointment at 18:30 and only got seated at 19:20. During this time, you on your own. No updates given or a drink. Services is suuuuuuper sloooooow.
author: Zici L.

description: Nobody can cook meat like this place! Cauliflower cooked in duck fat, capers and red chilli...weird combination but it tasted amazing. I don't dare talk about the foie gras with meat dish in a delicious sauce... Not to mention the uni butter bruschetta with crab, radish, and other wonders.
author: Lians S.

description: Very nice location, great food and great service. Bacon Chop and the Sole are stupid good. Great Drinks too
author: Esteban U.

description: Loved my first experience at Cockscomb! Chris did a great job with his new place, and everything was amazing.
author: Richard B.

description: great food, great service. loved the impossible burger. desserts were killer.
author: jewel r.

description: Fantastic dinner & the best service we've had in San Francisco in a very long time. The blood sausage & grilled cheese were the favorites of the night. Our server Josh was so friendly and made great recommendations. He even got the cockscomb postcard signed by Chris Cosentino for my diehard fan fiancé. We'll be back!
author: Linzi B.

description: Food sooooooo good.  Service absolutely impeccable.  However it was so loud in there if you are there to visit with someone this is not the place.  Chef Constentino did a great job except needs some soft surfaces to absorb at least a little bit of the sound
author: Katie H.

description: This place is a go-to for me whenever I have SF visitors. Can't go wrong with late night happy hour: $1 oysters on weeknights and yummy pork ears! PIN BONE STEAK--must try! Good to share.
author: Elke S.

description: Very nice dinner last night highlighted by the Pin Loin platter for four and the Pork Sugo. Chef Cosentino was ever present, both in the kitchen (exhibition kitchen fronted by a bar with 10 or so seats) and in the dining room which was nice to see.  Table next to us had a great looking roasted goose platter, we'll remember that for next time.
author: Nikki H.

description: Some hits & misses here. The Little Gem salad with Dungeness Crab was light and flavorful with just the right amount of dressing to allow the crab flavor to still come through. Oysters & clams from the raw bar were good & fresh. The Quail Tetrazinni was disappointing - the dish was smothered in mushrooms which made the tiny and unboned birds hard to find and eat. The sauce was bland. With a price of $35 it was very poor value for the money. Prices overall are quite steep for a casual environment. We had also hoped for a better remodel of the cold Zuppa concrete space.
author: Michael B.

description: We had a great time! Husband's last day of work party (for awhile)... everyone is so friendly..that being said, the food is sooo unique innovative and delicious. Had the specials... pate and tuna so tasty. So glad we live down the street! Gonna go for lunch .. perfect cold day restaurant. Thanks for everything and the hospitality!!!!
author: Amanda J.

description: Ambiance is nice, very much like other hipstery joints in vogue right now: cheeky details referencing the name, lots of wood, vintage light bulbs. Drinks were solid but their drinks menu was heavy on the gins which I personally don't like and found disorienting. Paper straws are awesome in general but didn't work when hanging out in a cocktail for a while. I had to navigate giant icecubes to get to my drink after  the straws stopped working. Beer menu is pretty good. We ordered the grilled cheese, salad of the day, the pork skin pasta, and the pig head. Portion sizes seemed average except for the pasta. Listed as an entree it was the tiniest bit of skin pasta I've ever seen. I know the pig skin gives it a mouth feel and weight that makes this the perfect size but it just didn't match up. The pigs head is a great visual dish but the ratio of edibles to solid fat and bone is skewed against the edibles, and my party was the kind that digs to find everything, including what we think was the dark, minerally larynx.   Also loses some points for not offering the brain as is. The brain aioli is a joke. Finally I felt that the head would be better cooked rotisserie style because the current cooking method leaves a bunch of the skin floppy and inedible. Desserts were meh. Service was ok. People will come for the name behind the restaurant but prob many won't return because the food really doesn't hold up.
author: Miriam L.

description: Amazing food, lots of good paleo dishes available. We had the pig brain, steak and pate and they were all delicious. I would avoid the liver salad (it has almost no liver in it) and the bacon chop was also a bit disappointing. Several good wine choices available as well.
author: Andy A.

description: There were four of us last night, and as soon as we walked in I liked the vibe. Small restaurant, but the tables are well placed.  You MUST be a carnivore, since this place is all about meat.  The service was good, but slow.  The food, well...we walked out $600 later (albeit 2 bottles of nice wine), and overall not happy with what was served.  The meat pie sounds yummy, but we didn't care for it.  It had red meat, kale and oysters.  The fish smell overpowered the dish (and they looked/tasted like OLD oysters).  The quail was smothered in rich sauce, which took away from the taste of the bird.  I've had amazing quail in the past, and this was just a soupy mess.  I love grilled cheese, and we did try this as an app for the four of us.  The two bites each was enough...there is honey on the bread, which is just a little sweet for everyone at the table. I'm glad we tried it, but sadly we won't be going back.
author: A H.

description: Great meal. Great service. Loved the bruschetta and coulette steak. Accommodated my fussy gluten free friend with great options on food and alcohol.
author: Lynley P.

description:
I really wanted to like this place. It has a great ambiance and a generally nice vibe at first glance. However, the experience was so lackluster I can't really imagine going back.

Our reservation did not get off to a good start. Due to a serious "texting while walking" problem (and just generally being late), I walked past the "FOOD AND DRINK" sign on 4th St. (indicating the whereabouts of the actual alley-way entrance), costing me a very valuable and important minute. Alas, I had arrived at 8:46pm for an 8:30pm reservation. With little emotion and certainly nothing registering anything close to sympathy, we were informed that there is a 15-minute policy that was to be enforced vigorously, and thus the wait for our table will now be up to 30 minutes. Okay, fine - there is a policy; a policy that makes sense, and my party was certainly not above the rules. However, the draconian application was both off-putting and ironic given that Cockscomb fails to meet (maybe even set?) deadlines in preparing and serving food to the very guests it worries so much about seating within a particular time frame.

Although the food was definitely good, the manner in which it was served left a bad taste. We had placed an order for an entree to share between three people while upstairs in the lounge, but were sat at our table immediately after doing so. Re-thinking our decision, we asked to cancel it to re-assess our overall dining strategy while at the table. We were faced with another policy prohibiting our actions, but this time an exception was graciously made and the order was purportedly canceled. 

Many moons later, our appetizer order is taken. A long time after that, our entree order is taken - at which time, the server verbally re-confirms our appetizer order, strongly suggesting it still has not been put in. During both of these conversations, we re-confirm with him that our upstairs order has in fact been canceled. Our server "hadn't heard anything about it," which was enough to allay our concerns.

By the time we received our appetizers, the couple who had sat next to and also after us had already eaten and left. In a flurry of activity, we receive in a flash all four appetizers at once, including the oysters - which, in my experience, are served a) almost immediately after ordering and b) separate and apart from other appetizers. Accompanying these appetizers is NOT the grilled cheese I ordered (which I assume for space reasons will come later), but the canceled entree in question. "I told them that we ordered that entree and I wanted to make SURE you got it," says the server. I cannot tell if this is vindictive or just evidence of confusion.

Time passes. No grilled cheese.

Entree silverware is placed. No grilled cheese.

Entrees finally arrive. I ask about the grilled cheese.  I am met with a blithe and toally unconcerned: "Oh, it didn't come out?" No, it did not. Obviously. Because I am asking about it. Several minutes later, it appears, borne by the manager who admittedly does apologize and says by way of explanation that they "have several large parties upstairs." I do not know what this explains, as our server is stationed downstairs and the restaurant has by this late hour mostly cleared.

The rest of the meal was generally uneventful, although the server seemed more than done - with us specifically or his shift, I'm not sure, but I swear all comments contained in this review were kept to myself at the time so it would be undeserved if it were aimed at us.

The grilled cheese was still on the bill, which felt like a slight after a meal that took almost 3.5 hours and was served in a very stop-and-go, inconsistent fashion (and given it had been ordered as an appetizer, was forgotten and added only after a reminder during the entree course).

Any one of these things might not in and of itself been enough to make me feel annoyed, but overall I feel I did not enjoy my experience here as much as I should have. In short, it feels like Cockscomb was put together by people who really know restaurants, and then run by people who really don't. Next time, I would rather go a few doors down to Marlowe than come back here.
author: Tom H.

description: Ordered drinks - both of which were on tap and then when the first course was delivered had to reorder them after a 15 minute wait.   The server did not tell us about the specials, we had to ask about the different brochetta and didn't realize that there was a "Chef's daily special that we should have asked about.  The Uni brochette was tasteless, salad over salted the cauliflower and steak were delicious.  The place is so loud there is no point in trying to talk.  Would I go back?  Questionable.
author: Annie B.

description: Did a group dinner here with 3 couples, so 6 of us total.  Did a few random apps and cocktails, all great.  Then had the pig's head and the large steak dish to share.  Both were stunning.  We kept digging at the pig's head and finding new flavors and textures.  I would go back in a flash.
author: Michael H.

description: They handled our party of 10 great. We got to meet Chef Cosentino and the food was out of this world. Prices were even reasonable. The pinbone steak and the bacon chop were favorites at our table and we got the large mixed seafood plate as an appetizer. Bacon chop is a giant porkchop with the pork belly still attached with a ribbon of bacon meat in it- in case you were wondering.
author: Dave C.

description:
made a reservation for a tuesday night. the restaurant is quite big and can actually fit quite a few big parties, especially upstairs. we had 6 people and they could easily fit more. the lighting and the ambiance of the place was great. my friends noted that they definitely improved the look and feel of the italian restaurant that was here before. 

they are known for their gin drinks. and i got the VERTIGO FIZZ, which to me was better than the martini, maltese falcon, or the gin & jams 

as for food, we ordered:
- BEEF HEART TARTARE - just like regular beef tartare but more unique b/c its beef heart. the potato "fries" were perfectly crispy
- special FOIE GRAS with trotter (pig feet) and strawberries - soo good. i would def recommend this if they have it. they should keep it as a permanent item. 
- PIG HEAD - definitely not for the faint of heart. its literally half of the head fried. there is a lot of fat and a lot of meat. im sure its really unhealthy. i definitely felt that we should have ordered more veggies to go with this. but it was good to try. the best part was the pig ear. really crispy and yum. 
- MEAT PIE - this was good but was very soupy, which you can imagine is hard to eat on a plate and share amongst a big group
- DUCK FAT CAULIFLOWER - veggies + fat? i think it cancels each other out in (un)healthiness but still good to have it with the pig head as a veggie plate 
- chocolate dessert - chocolate cake with hazlenut - the cake tasted dry 
- fruit dessert - strawberry shortbread - the shortbread was rubbbery

the highlights of the night were the appetizers - the tartare and the foie gras. the worse was the dessert. but overall a great meal experience.
author: Jen S.

description: some of the dishes were super good (clams, sole), some werent very average/not so good (steak), all dishes are very expensive for the amount of food we got (10 small clams in a ball for $13) $14 for glass of italian wine that was good but not good to justify that pricepoint)
author: Yannick G.

description: Wonderful.  Staff very friendly and accommodating even though we were 40 minutes early.  Food was top notch! Will be back every time im in town
author: Kevin D.

description: Disappointing. Costly and I had high expectations. The gin and tonic was good but $15! I have had better sweetbreads. Just cooked meat with nectarines.  I prefer a crispy outside with a creamy interior. I also had the special pasta which was called spaghetti with pork skin. It tasted like catsup,rice noddles, and garlic.terrible. Where was the pork skin?. My husband and son had the ham burger. Bland and disappointing.
author: Linda C.

description: Food was awesome. Service was awesome! Had the pig's head and pig skin spaghetti. Definitely unique dishes, great service, fun ambiance. Would highly recommend the place. Keep up the good work Chris!
author: Rich J.

description: amazing!!!! hostess sat us in half a second and our sever 'Josh' was a cool funny dude. really cool to sit by the bar cuz you see all the action in the kitchen. we had the pig ear salad and bruschetta  to start. My girlfriend had the quail and I had the bacon chop for our entree. That bacon chop is hardcore! If you're concerned about fat and your dietary restrictions, don't even bother coming here... this place is legit and for real foodies! what really caught our attention was how Chef Cosentino engages all the dishes before they get served. you could see his meticulous preparation of the plate, it seems like he wants every plate to be perfect. He serves the plates and talks to customers. great place for dinner! would come back!
author: Jason P.

description: Delicious food! The bone marrow was amazing, but the one dish that really stood out was the grilled cheese and fried egg. OMG. Will have to go back and try the bacon chop soon!
author: G K.

description: The food overall is decent. I ordered the pin bone steak with my coworkers. The meat was cooked perfectly which I expect for the price. However $50 for an angry crab was ridiculous. The angry crab was rock crab and not dungeness. Rock crab is not only cheaper but an invasive species. If you crab in San Francisco you can only keep rock crab and never dungeness. Even a dirt cheap restaurant cannot get away with selling rock crab. Overpriced and cutting corners.
author: Laura C.

description:
This was my second visit to Cockscomb.  I took a friend for our mutual birthday celebration; she'd never been there before.  We ordered a LOT of food for two girls, and it was all wonderful.  We started with the Green Goddess salad with pig ear cracklins, then to Scotch Oysters, moved on to bone marrow topped with uni bottarga, Bruschetta with ricotta cheese and Morels was next; by this time we were verging on sensory overload, in the very best way possible.  Next was the Hot Mess, oh man.  It was a hot mess of goodness!  Seared foie gras on toast, topped with pulled pork belly, pickled green and red strawberries and a delicious sauce. The bread absorbed all the flavors and so it was a perfect bite every time. That dish was the winner of the evening for me.  We did share the surf & turf but it proved too hard to crack the crab (surf & turf was spicy crab on top of a slab of pork belly, oh my..) so after getting some help from the waiter, we were able to take a stab at it but by then we were honestly getting too full.  We took most of that dish home.  My only criticism of it was that the crab wasn't partially pre-cracked.  I recently had hand surgery and don't really have a good grip right now so it would have helped to have it made a bit easier.  That isn't a criticism of the dish itself, because it was delicious.  Got to get a pic with the Chef, that was pretty cool.  Last time I was here, my partner and I shared the pig head and I would highly recommend that dish too.
Service is excellent.
author: Kitty D.

description: Awesome meat.  Great service.  Best "leg of beast" I've ever had.  Good for groups, and for casual walk-ins of two.  Not too hipster-ish, thank goodness.
author: Bob S.

description: My husband and I were big fans of this chef's last place and were very excited to try this one tonight. The food did not disappoint, it was all excellent. However I have to take off a star because I am feeling really ticked off at the waitress who I felt was dishonest in an attempt to get us to order more food. We had come especially for the pig's head and were planning to get just one appetizer and then that. But then the waitress told us that the pigs head was not that big and that we should get three appetizers with it and also encouraged my husband to go for a medium seafood platter. This was much too much food for two people, and by the time we got to the pig we were too full to enjoy it. We ended up taking most of it home, a very expensive doggy bag. I really don't appreciate this kind of dishonesty on the part of the waitress.
author: Naomi G.

description: Sat at the bar which was a mistake.  I was able to see that there is so much cross contamination with the seafood and vegetables.  The service was awful.
author: Dd M.

description: We always want to focus on the good at a new restaurant. Cockscomb's space is nice, the hostesses are friendly, the china is cool, and we had a good table. The good pretty much ends here. We've done the animal parts thing in SF and in LA, as well as overseas. There is nothing distinctive about the Cockscomb version. If you haven't partaken, then you may be happy & surprised, hence a great review. If you've been there before, you get why Cockscomb is just meh, average, and verging on boring. We went on a holiday, for dinner, it was 2/3 full at best, the entire time we were there. Waiter was overly solicitous in a bad way, and the manager paces around frowning. They were really over-staffed the evening we went, also in a bad way. And the food, it's average fare for animal parts. The thing about this trend is that is has to be surprising & fun & a WOW factor. Cockscomb is not wow. It's not a distinctive menu. And the plating is beyond minimal, to careless. Crudo scooped from a ice cream scoop with a few chips, burger with nothing on the plate except fries, sole with nothing citrus, bare vegetables...maybe the regulars get some nice flourishes? If you are into this cuisine, you can find it elsewhere in SF with less attitude. If you're really into this cuisine, or looking to get into it, do yourself a favor and head to LA, to Animal. Animal has been doing this cuisine for years, it has the best vibe, it's a fun evening with fellow diners sharing which makes for superb spirit, and every plate is fab looking & unbelievably tasty, not too heavy, and engagingly described by the wait staff as well. Cockscomb reviews are either endorsing (which must be from animal parts newbies) or meh, from folks like us.
author: S S.

description: terrible service and the food wasn't all that. SF has so many other places to offer, so save your time and go some place else. And, if you reserve a table, you might end up at the chefs counter, which to me isn't exactly a table.
author: Trusty D.

description: Service was excellent. We were seated on time. We preferred the seafood dishes over the meat dishes. Also loved, loved , loved the grill cheese sandwich. Petrale Sole was the favorite entree on the table. Bacon chop sounds better than it actually is, and btw it s a huge piece of meat. Not exciting. We would probably return for appetizers and cocktails.
author: D S.

description: All I can say is WOW!   This restaurant really is amazing. I'm lucky enough to live across the street and was hoping his place would be delicious out of sheer convenience...boy did they deliver.  Had the sea urchin and lardo bruschetta and the truffle grilled cheese to start. Both were very solid. Shared a Bacon Chop and Sole for entrees.  Why no one else is leaving the belly attached to a pork chop is mystifying, the bacon chop ROCKS!  Decent selection of beers available, and the cocktails were very tasty.  The look and feel of the space was inviting and the service was actually flawless. Not just great for a restaurant that just opened either, but actually outstanding. Not sure where they found our server(think his name was Dave?) but he was very knowledgeable of the menu, anticipated our every need, and seemed genuinely happy to have us there. Hope this place stays a secret for as long as possible, but would've felt guilty if I didn't share it's awesomeness with the rest of the world.
author: John L.

description: What an experience!!  Took the family to Cockscomb for our Christmas Eve celebration.  Have watched Chris Cosentino make delightful meals on TV and now my family and I actually experienced it in person.  We took the CalTrain from the South Bay and arrived early...had drinks at the bar (the bartender did NOT disappoint).  Staff and waiters (we actually were served by the bartender's hubby...how fantastic is that??) were exceptionally helpful, polite, and wonderful...really made our first time here so memorable.  We started with oysters, pickled sardines and bruschetta...DELICIOUS!!  Our main course was the Wood Oven Roasted Pig's Head and Bacon Chop...Oh my...words can not explain how delightful that was!  Ended with a delicious chocolate dessert and coffee/espresso.  Not only was the food scrumptious and the staff friendly, but Chris was so welcoming and even took some time to talk with us and take a quick photo.  BEST Christmas ever!!  We will definitely eat at Cockscomb again...really want to try the Pin Bone Steak next time (will have to come with more people).  Thank you Chris and staff.
author: Mary G.
